fields.headline: After Prague, the deluge
fields.standfirst:
At its last meeting the IMF was worried by protesters. Now recession, not globalisation, is keeping bankers awake at night

Special report: global recession
fields.trailText: At its last meeting the IMF was worried by protesters. Now recession, not globalisation, is keeping bankers awake at night.
fields.body:
Last autumn, when the anti-capitalist protesters were on the streets of Prague, the International Monetary Fund said the global economy was in its finest fettle for a decade. Yesterday, the IMF admitted it had been wrong.

Since last September, it said, prospects for world growth had "weakened significantly", with a marked slowdown in the once booming US, another false dawn in Japan and a moderation of Europe's expansion. The countries best placed to survive are China and India: both have deliberately chosen to liberalise slowly and integrate with the global economy at their own pace. There will be no violent protests at this weekend's meeting of the IMF and the World Bank, but turmoil of one sort has been exchanged for another. As Harold Wilson might have said, eight months is a long time in economics.

Michael Mussa, the IMF's head of economics, said some easing of the breakneck pace of growth in the first part of 2000 had been necessary, but that "it is now clear that growth is slowing more than was anticipated or was desirable". It had been assumed the US would gradually slow to a more sustainable rate, enjoying what economists call a soft landing.

However, soft landings tend to be about as common as sightings of the Himalayan snow leopard, as the IMF itself admitted yesterday. "As experience over the past central decades has shown, soft landings are not easy to achieve."

The IMF identifies two key reasons for what has happened since the middle of last year. First, the US economy has suffered a series of shocks - higher energy prices, a downgrading of corporate earnings prospects accompanied by a sharp fall in equity markets, particularly in the technology sector, and dearer borrowing costs - which have combined to generate a severe slowdown in domestic demand growth and a pronounced weakening in consumer and business confidence.

Second, the perennial problem of Japan, where the temporary boost to the economy in the first half of last year petered out as a result of lowered consumer confidence, an easing of investment and lower exports. Unlike in the US, where the IMF is upbeat about the chances of the downturn being short-lived, it sees a sustained recovery in Japan as still some way off. With interest rates already at zero and a huge budget deficit caused by boosts to public spending over the past decade, "there is limited room for policy manoeuvre", and the economy remains vulnerable to additional shocks.

As a result of these problems in the world's two largest single economies, the IMF's twice-yearly world economic outlook has shaved a full percentage point off its forecast for global growth this year, which is now expected to be 3.2%.

The scale and the speed of the downturn in the US means the IMF has more than halved its growth prediction for the US from 3.2% to 1.5%, and Japan has been downgraded from 1.8% to 0.6%. The third biggest economy - Germany - is also likely to underperform last autumn's expectations, growing at 1.9% rather than the 3.3% forecast.

With inflation low around the globe, the IMF believes policymakers should be adopting strategies to boost growth. "Inflation remains a concern in some faster growing European countries and in a number of developing and transition [from communism] countries, but in general inflationary risks do not materially circumscribe policymakers' freedom of action at this stage."

This can be summed in three short words: go for it. As the IMF sees it, both commodity prices and consumer price inflation have been on a downward trend for the past 20 years. Long-term interest rates - a sign of market expectations of future inflation - have come down too, and that gives central banks and finance ministries an chance to cut short-term rates, thereby boosting growth.

This is the approach being followed by the US Federal Reserve, which has cut two percentage points off borrowing costs since January, and it is evident that the IMF thoroughly approves of what Alan Greenspan has been doing. It believes that early action by the Fed, buttressed by the actions of other central banks, means that there is a reasonable prospect that the slowdown will be short-lived.

Its baseline scenario is that the US starts to recover in the second half of 2001, Europe remains relatively robust and Japan finally turns the corner in 2002. But having been too optimistic in the autumn, the IMF is more cautious about what happens next. "This scenario is certainly plausible, but it is far from assured - experience suggests that when turning points are reached, the shift in momentum is often more pronounced than expected."

This is a polite way of saying that economic forecasting, rather than being an exact science, is actually more of a shot in the dark. In particular, it is impossible to know how US consumers will respond to recent events, and for how much longer foreign investors will retain their faith in the US dollar. US growth prospects would be seriously impaired were consumers to embark on a sustained period of belt-tightening, and the IMF is aware that the imbalances built up over the past five years - high levels of debt, an overvalued stock market, a record current account deficit - could unwind dangerously fast.

"The outlook remains subject to considerable uncertainty and a deeper and more prolonged downturn is clearly possible. Against this background, macroeconomic policies - particularly on the monetary side - will need to be proactive to guard against the possibility of a steeper than expected downturn."

Again, this may need translating. Stripped of the jargon, it means the IMF fears that come September, it may be force to downgrade its forecasts again - and that the best bulwark against that would be further cuts in global interest rates for those who have already taken action, and for the European Central Bank to wake up to the potential seriousness of the problem.

Just in case Wim Duisenberg and his colleagues in Frankfurt failed to get the message, Mr Mussa spelt it out at yesterday's press conference for the world economic outlook's publication. He said the eurozone needed to "be part of the solution, rather than part of the problem", and should have cut rates a month ago.

These are tricky times for the global economy. Differences between the EU and the US over trade mean there is a rapidly diminishing chance of a new round of trade liberalisation talks commencing in Qatar this autumn.

The economic superpowers on either side of the Atlantic seem to be retreating into their own trading blocs. The fact that the ECB is taking such a hard line on interest rates will only make matters worse, since it adds to the feeling in the US that the Europeans are happy to criticise the US for failing to show global leadership over the environment, but are unwilling to take a lead themselves when it comes to underpinning the growth prospects of the global economy.

The IMF is right. There is no reason why the world should suffer a recession - provided the right expansionary policies are followed. The ECB stands alone in its belief that inflation is a bigger threat than recession. In Frankfurt, this is seen as principled independence. In Washington, it is viewed as selfish pig-headedness.

webTitle: Jazz review:  The Mike Stern Band

fields.headline: The Mike Stern Band
fields.standfirst:
Wardrobe, Leeds
***
fields.trailText:
Wardrobe, Leeds
***
fields.body:
A student of the legendary Pat Metheny at the Berklee School of Music, American guitarist Mike Stern went on to collaborate with such giants as Miles Davis and Billy Cobham before embarking on a long solo career with Atlantic Records. He now has a long-standing reputation as a musician of ferocious technical ability, although he has always been keen to stress that soulful emotionalism is a key ingredient in his work. This gig highlighted Stern the technician, placing him at the centre of a phenomenally accomplished quartet, and allowing him the scope for some almost grotesque self-indulgence.

The opening number, Play, set the tone for the rest of the performance, being a heavy-duty stampede through some fairly familiar fusion territory. Bassist Lincoln Goines and drummer Lionel Cordew provided a muscular but brash rhythmical framework, which allowed Stern and saxophonist Bob Franceschini to push themselves to blistering extremes.

Unfortunately, they both showed no desire to hold anything back for later, and immediately set about demonstrating just how many scales and chord progressions they have learned in their lives.

Stern did not stray very far from his signature guitar sound. Clean yet hard, it strove to capture Hendrix's writhing, untamed abandon, but came out sounding more like Steve Vai or Joe Satriani, both masters of using an awful lot of notes for the sake of it. There was little space for fragility, emotion or soul, although one or two of the quieter solos hinted at a much needed lyricism.

Non-converts to the art of instrumental exhibitionism will always prefer a single stinging phrase to a million-note flurry. However, the sheer power of the quartet made up for a lot of the gratuitous fret abuse, and at times the musicians seemed to be trying to achieve in a fusion setting what Motorhead achieved in heavy rock.

More importantly, there was no denying the drooling enjoyment of the audience, who babbled excitedly about their favourite licks and were more than happy to grant these four accomplished show-offs the adoration they so obviously craved.

webTitle: Bold No 10 idea for tax and schools

fields.headline: Bold No 10 idea for tax and schools
fields.standfirst: Think tank says middle class powers a barrier to meritocracy.
fields.trailText: Think tank says middle class powers a barrier to meritocracy.
fields.body:
Tony Blair's personal think tank has told him to increase inheritance and income tax, as well as increase selection in state schools if he is achieve his vision of a genuine meritocratic society in Britain.

The report suggests wealthy parents are buying access to good state schools by being able to afford the higher house prices in the school's local catchment area.

"Significant policy interventions" would be needed to overcome the barriers to social mobility, including the barriers to downward mobility, it says.

It even suggests it might be necessary - on the basis of US studies - to spend as at least 10 times as much on the education of each black child as on each white child to equalise their future wage earnings.

The stark analysis comes from the Performance and Innovation Unit - the Cabinet Office think tank used by Mr Blair to tackle controversial political issues.

The findings, published yesterday, are bound to be attacked by the Conservatives as Labour's hidden agenda. But they are also likely to be seen as a sober warning to Mr Blair either to moderate his rhetoric about achieving a meritocracy, or think through its tough consequences for what the paper describes as "the dull middle class".

The prime minister told the Labour conference in 1999 that he wanted to create a meritocratic rather than egalitarian society.

The report is the product of a seminar involving some of Whitehall's leading thinkers, including key figures from the Downing Street policy unit and Anthony Giddens, the "third way" thinker.

It argues that earnings mobility has stalled in Britain, and suggests that deindustrialisation may have been the single biggest cause. Ethnic minorites, it says, have suffered most.

In the past 20 years income inequalities have widened significantly, Mr Blair's think tank states. "Between 1979 and 1998-99, the real incomes of the bottom decile of the income distribution rose by 6% in real terms whereas the real incomes of those in the top 10% rose by 82%. Mean income rose by 55%".

While "more room at the top" - due to economic growth - has allowed more of the poor to rise up the social ladder, the report finds no evidence that the middle class have been at any greater risk of a fall in social status.

The PIU finds that middle class people buy the best education either through private schools or by moving near to the best state schools.

The report says "the higher levels of education attainment mean that private schools nowadays offer access to good universities through academic qualifications rather than through contacts or old boy networks".

A true meritocratic society must include high rates of social mobility and the absence of any association between class origins and equality of opportunity, the report maintains.

It also shows that when the poor do move out of poverty it is not very far or for very long. Of those in the bottom two deciles in 1991, less than one in four was in top 60% of the income distribution in 1998.

Drawing on government research, the report suggests that there has also been an overall decline in earnings mobility in the two decades between 1977 and 1997, particularly among prime age men. Earnings progression for women seems to have improved.

It also shows that 40% to 50% of employees who start in the lowest quarter of earnings distribution are still there after six years in employment.

The analysis is not likely to be particularly palatable in poitical terms to the Labour leadership, which claimed yesterday that it could largely break the cycle of inequality through implementing its radical ideas for allocating incremental assets through the stages of childhood.

The report says it is a matter for politicians to decide how far they wish to push the mobilty agenda.

If the government wants mobility to be strong and widespread - downward, as well as upward mobility - it will have to chose strong options, including some quite dramatic tax measures.

The report suggests that the strongest option might have disadvantages, including the creation of more "losers, social tension and the possibility that winners could scoop all the rewards".

The findings came on the day the government faced criticism for caving into convention by appointing 15 establishment figures to the House of Lords. They had been billed in advance as " people's peers".

webTitle: UK shoppers out of pocket on top brands

fields.headline: UK shoppers out of pocket on top brands
fields.standfirst:
Guardian Unlimited Money
Guardian Unlimited Shopping
fields.trailText: British shoppers are paying up to 44% more than consumers in other western countries for dozens of branded goods, according to a government report published yesterday.
fields.body:
British shoppers are paying up to 44% more than consumers in other western countries for dozens of branded goods, according to a government report published yesterday.

CDs, DVDs, videos, computer game consoles and cosmetics were more expensive in Britain than in four other countries. The Department of Trade and Industry's inter national price comparison looked at 133 branded items in the UK, Sweden, France, Germany and the US.

Overall, the picture was mixed: British customers got good deals on electrical and sporting equipment. But within Europe, the UK and Sweden were more expensive for most brands surveyed, compared with Germany and France. Prices in the US were significantly cheaper than in Europe for many global brands.

A CD of the No 1 in the charts, costing on average more than £13 in Britain, was £9 in Germany. A DVD of the film The Matrix cost more than £19 in the UK but £15 in Germany. A pair of Dockers K1 khakis was £58 in this country but only £46 in Germany and £32 in the US. Levi jeans cost more than £50 in the UK, compared with less than £40 in the US.

For cosmetics Britain was not always the most expensive, although a basic branded lip stick cost almost £8, compared with less than £6 in three of the other countries.

The trade and industry secretary, Stephen Byers, said companies were abusing European trademark legislation to keep prices artificially high in some countries, and consumers were increasingly saying that was unacceptable.

The trademark directive allows owners to prevent the import of their goods from outside the EU for resale inside it. But once the goods have been sold within Europe, they can be freely bought and sold on, giving rise to the"grey market".

"Action is needed to reform the EU law on the protection of branded goods," said Mr Byers. "I want the Tescos and Asdas of this world to be able to source the best deals from anywhere in the world and pass those savings on to consumers."

The principal policy adviser for Consumers' Association, Phil Evans, said: "The Swedish/ UK price comparison work clearly shows that consumers in Europe suffer at the hands of international brands who price at whatever level that they can get away with."

The report was commissioned by the DTI and the Swedish government, which holds the EU presidency. The findings will be discussed at a meeting of European consumer affairs ministers in Sweden today, with Britain represented by Kim Howells.

Mr Byers said: "We are working with the Swedes to push for removal of trade mark restrictions on the import of branded goods. We hope other member states will support our joint approach... Effectively, the directive forces retailers to import goods from the most expensive suppliers."

He said the French, with their cosmetics interests, might oppose any law change.

Tesco and Asda said such a change would be immediately reflected in lower prices. Tesco has been involved in a legal battle with Levi over selling its items well below the recommended retail price

Tesco's marketing director, Tim Mason, said: "Where Tesco has already sourced goods on the grey market, it has been able to sell them at discounts of between 25% and 50%.

The office of fair trading is investigating the price of CDs in Britain.

fields.headline: Itzhak Perlman/Bruno Canino
fields.standfirst:
Royal Festival Hall, London
***
fields.trailText:
Royal Festival Hall, London
***
fields.body:
Violinist Itzhak Perlman's claim to Jascha Heifetz's mantle as the world's most celebrated virtuoso is arguably stronger than that of any other living violinist.

Perlman's tribute to Heifetz was at its most affectionate in his selection of encores: all Heifetz favourites, from the familiar fireworks of Bazzini's Dance of the Goblins to less well-known lollipops by Hummel, Ries, and Lili Boulanger. For all Perlman's technical wizardry, he refused to indulge in crass showmanship. Instead, there was a classical coolness, whether in the sensuous melody of Boulanger's Cortège, or the out-of-tune joke of the cadenza in Hummel's Rondo.

But the meat of the recital - Handel, Beethoven, and Saint-Saëns sonatas - was less satisfying. Perlman's partnership with pianist Bruno Canino was most problematic in Beethoven's C minor Sonata, Op 30 No 2. Canino could not match Perlman's feeling for phrasing and rubato in the rapt slow movement, while the stormy drama of the outer movements sounded forced and over-projected. There was the air of another era in Perlman's politically incorrect performance of Handel's D major Sonata, from the Op 1 set. But the recital came magnificently to life in Saint-Saëns D minor Sonata.

In the ravishing slow movement, Perlman found a glorious, song-like register, while the finale was a dazzling flash of speed and brilliance. Even if there were only glimpses of his musicianship, Perlman's place in the pantheon of violin virtuosos is assured.

Instead, there was a classical coolness, whether in the sensuous melody of Boulanger's Cortège, or the out-of-tune joke of the cadenza in Hummel's Rondo. But the meat of the recital - Handel, Beethoven, and Saint-Saëns sonatas - was less satisfying. Perlman's partnership with pianist Bruno Canino was most problematic in Beethoven's C minor Sonata, Op 30 No 2. Canino could not match Perlman's feeling for phrasing and rubato in the rapt slow movement, while the stormy drama of the outer movements sounded forced and over-projected. There was the air of another era in Perlman's politically incorrect performance of Handel's D major Sonata, from the Op 1 set. But the recital came magnificently to life in Saint-Saëns D minor Sonata. In the ravishing slow movement, Perlman found a glorious, song-like register, while the finale was a dazzling flash of speed and brilliance. Even if there were only glimpses of his musicianship, Perlman's place in the pantheon of violin virtuosos is assured.

fields.headline: Young shrug off debt worries
fields.standfirst: Guardian Unlimited Money
fields.trailText: Six in 10 people under the age of 26 are now in debt - with the under-20s showing the least concern about their borrowing, a survey has shown.
fields.body:
Six in 10 people under the age of 26 are now in debt - with the under-20s showing the least concern about their borrowing, a survey has shown.

Almost two thirds of 16 to 25-year-olds have some level of debt, with nearly a quarter of those aged between 20 and 24 owing at least £3,000. The Mintel report said: "The 'live for today' attitude runs high among the youth of today."

The form of debt includes outstanding credit card balances, student loans and other forms of credit. Those aged 17 are more likely to owe less than £100, with the level of debt increasing with age.

Almost two thirds of young adults seem uncomfortable with debt, but a higher number of younger 16 to 19-year-olds agree credit for essentials is "not a bad thing".

The report's author, Graham Collett, said: "This eagerness to use credit products among the particularly young consumers is something consumer groups are concerned about but providers are keen to cater for.

"Debt is more acceptable as a nation now than it was 20 or even 10 years ago."

Half of under-26s consider buying a house as being of major importance while only 10% put retirement needs first. Fewer than one in 10 has a pension.

More than a third (36%) view travelling as a priority compared with the 41% who favour providing for a family.

But financial priorities seem to differ for men and women with more than half of men believing buying a house remains their highest priority.

In contrast 53% of women believe providing for the future family would be of financial priority - compared with 30% of men.

The survey of 698 young people also found a quarter do not have a current account. And surprisingly - given the option of direct banking - there is an almost even split between those who believe it is attractive and those who do not.

Given a lump sum of £2,000 to invest, 32% would find it most productive to pay off debts. This was almost equalled by the 31% who would place it in a high street account.

The report said in general the under-26s veered towards a relatively safe investment. Only 16% would invest in higher risk stocks and shares.

webTitle: Protests at birth of baby bonds

fields.headline: Protests at birth of baby bonds
fields.standfirst:
Politics

Guardian Unlimited Money
fields.trailText: The government's ambitious plans to spread wealth throughout society via "baby bond" trust funds generated instant controversy yesterday as radicals protested that the scheme did not go far enough while Conservatives dismissed it as "frankly insulting" to the nation's poor.
fields.body:
The government's ambitious plans to spread wealth throughout society via "baby bond" trust funds generated instant controversy yesterday as radicals protested that the scheme did not go far enough while Conservatives dismissed it as "frankly insulting" to the nation's poor.

Tony Blair lined up three of his cabinet colleagues for a Downing Street press conference to launch what will - if implemented after the coming general election and widespread consultation - be one of Labour's most far-sighted and idealistic proposals.

It seeks to ensure that every child enjoys the benefits of savings and inheritance that middle and upper class families take for granted: by introducing both tax free bonds for newborns, which would be topped up over 18 or 21 years to maturity, and a "savings gateway" account - in which government would match individual savings pound for pound.

Mr Blair presented the scheme as the fourth strand of Labour's post-1997 welfare reforms after improving skills and job opportunities; raising living standards for the worst off; and modernising public services. He called it "more people getting the benefit of assets and savings."

Mr Blair said it was a "financial springboard" to a meritocratic society - where people had a fair chance to exercise their talents.

The chancellor, Gordon Brown, who hopes to announce the full scheme in his 2002 budget, said it opened "saving and wealth ownership to all".

But the education and employment secretary, David Blunket, grabbed the day's snappiest soundbite after expressing his wish to restore the old working class habits of thrift, reliance and mutual support - embodied through friendly societies and the co-op movement.

"We are replacing 'on your bike' with 'on your tandem'," he said - with the government helping individuals from the back seat.

As reported in yesterday's Guardian the scheme would, subject to detailed discussion with interested parties, provide the New Labour equivalent of a "trust fund babe". Every child born after an agreed date, not before April 2003 at the earliest, would get £500 at birth, topped up with an extra £100 at five, 11 and 16.

The children of better-off families would get half that sum, though ministers are said to believe that making it payable universally is the safest way to protect the scheme from being abolished when the Conservatives next win power.

Yesterday the rightwing Adam Smith Institute claimed authorship of the idea, as did the Fabian Society and the IPPR think tanks on the left. But the left fears that the right will seek to gut the scheme or use it to substitute for existing welfare benefits - most obviously for student loans which many 18-year-olds would be seeking just as their funds mature.

The £800 version alone would generate £1,600 in real terms by the age of 18, though a modest family top-up of £5 a month - from parents, uncles or grandparents - plus interest could more than double it. Mr Blair sees it as a down payment on a mortgage, a business or training.

Alistair Darling, the social security secretary, later stressed that - as with pensions and Isa savings rules - the system would be policed to prevent abuse of tax-free benefits, though policy-makers admit it will be hard to enforce once the money becomes payable.

The savings gateway would allow parents who put aside a modest amount - say £25 a month - to have their funds matched by the government up to a time limit of 3-4 years and a capped total.

The idea is that the scheme dovetails with Isas and stakeholder pensions - which ministers are also keen to encourage among the lower-paid as part of a "savings" culture.

Poverty lobbyists welcomed the plan as a bold first step, though some would like the £1bn it will cost - Mr Brown refused to provide a figure - spent on more urgent poverty via the social fund.

Ministers say it is establishing a principle. But the shadow chancellor, Michael Portillo, said it was giving back to poor people a portion of the extra taxes they have paid - and it was "frankly insulting" to expect them to be grateful.

webTitle: Theatre review:  Henry VI/ Richard III

fields.headline: A visionary 13 hours of the Bard
fields.standfirst:
Henry VI/ Richard III
Young Vic, London
*****
fields.trailText:
Henry VI/ Richard III
Young Vic, London
*****
fields.body:
This Shakespearean tetralogy - Henry VI Parts One, Two and Three, and Richard III - runs to nearly 13 hours and offers the most exciting experience in theatrical London. If you come out exhilarated rather than exhausted, it is because director Michael Boyd and his RSC team offer infinitely more than a carnage-and- cutlery chronicle; instead they offer a consistent vision that embraces all four plays.

And what exactly is that vision? Partly that the plays are meditations on time, in which the past permeates the historic present. You see this in the ghostly ubiquity of the dead, culminating in the extraordinary climax when the slaughtered Richard and the suffering Henry VI, apparent polar opposites, confront each other in perverse kinship. But Boyd also matches image to language in a way that makes nonsense of the false division between "text-based" and "visual" theatre. From myriad moments, the one that lingers is when the militant Talbot, having compared his son to Icarus, sees his offspring's lifeless body winched tragically skywards.

Above all, Boyd sees the plays in terms of politics rather than theology - not simply as the working out of a curse on the house of Lancaster, but as a study of power in action. And this inevitably affects Richard III. In isolation, the play becomes an individualistic study of a satanic joker. But when you see Aidan McArdle's Richard of Gloucester developing from Henry VI Part Three, it becomes something entirely different: a continuation of his late father's throne-lust and an extension of the de facto approach to power.

I wouldn't deny that there have been many Richards, from Olivier to Antony Sher, who have been more charismatically evil. What McArdle offers is a puckish, bustling, cerebral Richard who plots his route to the throne like a conscienceless chessmaster methodically eliminating the obstructive pieces. Boyd and McArdle don't exculpate Richard; what they make clear is that he is an outsider ("misshapen Dick") whose deformity has been a lifelong source of mockery and who has grown up in a corrupt ethos of insatiate crown-hunger. One touch brilliantly shows this. Clive Wood's Duke of York earlier illustrates his claim to kingship with the aid of a bag of stones; McArdle's Richard pathetically produces the self-same stones at the very moment he is to lose both power and life.

Echoes and reverberations are the key to Boyd's magnificently unified vision of the tetralogy. The bond between fathers and sons is a constant refrain embodied throughout with despairing tenderness by Keith Bartlett and Sam Troughton. Female militancy is an equally powerful thread, seen in Fiona Bell's astonishing double of Joan la Pucelle and Queen Margaret, and Deirdra Morris's angry Duchess of York. But possibly the strongest theme is the insecure isolation of monarchy - which is what links David Oyelowo's physically weak but morally strong Henry VI to McArdle's obsessive but defeated Richard.

The pervading unity is richly enhanced by Tom Piper's design, Heather Carson's lighting and James Jones's music, which compound the sense that one is watching a collaborative vision of national chaos. It adds up to a breathtaking achievement that, like Wagner's Ring cycle, needs to be taken whole.

 Until May 26. Box office: 020-7928 6363.

webTitle: Ballet review:  Stars of the Bolshoi

fields.headline: Flashy Don Q can't save the Bolshoi's pick'n'mix
fields.standfirst:
Stars of the Bolshoi
Theatre Royal Drury Lane, London
**
fields.trailText:
Stars of the Bolshoi
Theatre Royal Drury Lane, London
**
fields.body:
The Bolshoi have been so much in the news recently, with reports of rancorous feuds, dramatic firings, economic meltdown and government intervention, that the ballet's first UK appearance in two years has aroused much speculation. Would we see an institution in tatters? Or a company triumphantly rejuvenated?

The season's title, Stars of the Bolshoi, certainly fuelled the hype. But, disappointingly, what we saw on Wednesday (Programme One) didn't twinkle, let alone dazzle. We saw a competently trained ensemble who were fighting nerves and boasted few memorable talents. If they didn't have the Bolshoi name attached, I doubt the theatre would have booked them for more than a week.

One shouldn't be too harsh on the dancers, though, given that they're obliged to perform in dispiritingly cut-price format. During the whole four-week season there's not a single full-length work or new production to display their talents in depth, simply a pick'n'mix of classical excerpts and pas de deux.

Programme One opens with act two of Swan Lake, which the performers have to come on and dance cold. During the second half, the ordering of items is so odd that they have to try to whip up a storm with the notoriously flashy Don Q straight after the audience has (hopefully) been stilled by the spectral poetry of Giselle.

Lollipop divertissements may work for special galas or for dancers so brilliant they can ravish the audience whatever they do. But the Bolshoi don't field anyone with that kind of instant, grabby charisma.

Sergei Filin, dancing Siegfried and Albrecht, cuts a credible princely figure with his courtly partnering and cushioned jumps, but he desperately needs the full picture of the ballet to create his effects. He also needs an Odette more eloquent than Anna Antonicheva; she has pretty arms but none of the musical fluency that can make classical steps sing.

In Giselle, Filin partners Svetlana Lunkina, who tries harder to instil some emotion into their pas de deux. But, accompanied as she is by a ragged orchestra and stranded in the middle of a drab, empty stage, she fights a losing battle.

The only genuinely class act of the evening is the excerpt from Bournonville's Flower Festival at Genzano. It's pleasure enough to see this infrequently performed 19th-century gem - but it's a real lifesaver watching Maria Alexandrovna dancing with a personality and intelligent style that transcend the rest of the evening's bland, cynical packaging.

 Until May 3. Box office: 020-7494 5000.

fields.headline: Hats off to the American dream
fields.standfirst: The government wants low earners to save. Rupert Jones and Patrick Collinson examine how it intends to help them.
fields.trailText: The government wants low earners to save. Rupert Jones and Patrick Collinson examine how it intends to help them.
fields.body:
Self-help the American way is the cornerstone of the government's proposals for a Saving Gateway account which is likely to match pound-for-pound any savings made by adults on low incomes.

In what may go down as a turning point in the history of the welfare state, Prime Minister Tony Blair, Chancellor Gordon Brown, Social Security Secretary Alistair Darling and Education Secretary David Blunkett all took the same platform on Thursday this week to hammer home the message that shared responsibility, rather than handing out benefits, is at the core of their vision of the future welfare state.

Mr Darling summed up the government's new attitude: "If you make the effort, then we will help you. It is a fundamentally different attitude to the welfare state," he said. Details of the Saving Gateway are much sketchier than for the Child Trust Fund; an example it gives, peppered with warnings that it does not represent the government's final thinking, is of a £50 per month scheme, matched by £50 per month from the government.

This would build up over three years to be worth just short of £4,000. The target would be the low paid, with or without children. But Mr Darling refused to specify government thinking on how many adults will be eligible, saying that it is all up for consultation.

The proposed Saving Gateway has been closely modelled on a US concept called the Individual Development Account. In the US, Idas have been helping the less-well-off to achieve the American dream since 1997.

These accounts typically encourage people to save for a specific purpose, such as buying a home, starting up a business or funding education, by matching the money they put in with a contribution from public or private funds. Ida schemes already operate in around 250 communities across America, and those taking part range from those just into their teens to pensioners.

The matching rates vary greatly, though the most common contribution is two dollars for every one dollar put in by the individual. However, some schemes are a lot more generous than this - a programme running in Indianapolis, for example, has a match rate of nine-to-one. Twenty-nine US states have passed some form of Ida legislation, some labelled Downpayments on the American Dream.

The Washington-based Corporation for Enterprise Development says the accounts are "emerging as one of the most promising tools to help low-income American families save money, build wealth and achieve economic independence".

However, they have been something of a victim of their own success - in spite of the fact that new schemes are springing up all the time, the demand for Idas far outstrips what is now available. The schemes usually involve people having to agree to undergo several hours of financial education and counselling.

Arkansas has a programme for people to save towards owning a home, starting a small business or paying for education where they receive three dollars of state funds for every dollar they put in, and must agree to take six classes in "economic literacy".

One recent US study of 14 Ida programmes found that the average age of people signing up was 36, while the youngest was 13 and the oldest was 72. The typical account-holder was a single working woman living in an urban area.

At the time the study was carried out, the vast majority of people had not taken their money out. Most (57%) said they intended to buy a home, 18% said they planned to use the money to help start up a business, and 15% said they intended to undertake some form of post-secondary education. On average the people had attended 10 hours of financial education.

fields.headline: Cubanismo
fields.standfirst:
Royal Festival Hall, London
****
fields.trailText:
Royal Festival Hall, London
****
fields.body:
This was an important show for Cubanismo and its leader, trumpeter Jesus Alemany. He and the band may tour the world, but in Britain they have never achieved the status of those rival Cubans launched through the Buena Vista Social Club. Playing on the final night of the La Linea Latin festival, they proved triumphantly that they too can transform the Festival Hall into a dance club with their own intriguing Cuban fusion.

Their last album, Mardi Gras Mambo, was a collaboration between Cubanismo and musicians from New Orleans, recorded in New Orleans. It set out to revive and update the musical links between Havana and the city famous for the birth of jazz and blues. They previewed the project, on their own, at London's Jazz Cafe last year, and now returned not - as originally expected - with those New Orleans musicians, but with the addition of just one vocalist from the Crescent City, Terri Degruy. No matter. She alone transformed the band.

The great strength of the 14-piece Cubanismo is their musical skill, with their strong horn section (led by Alemany), their percussion, keyboards and tres (the Cuban guitar). Introducing Degruy into this all-male ensemble changed all that.

Here was a cheerfully enthusiastic performer, with a vocal style as slinky as her high heels and black dress, who could ease between Cuba and the home-grown R&B, boogie and Mardi Gras chants of New Orleans.

fields.headline: Union pledge on banking hours
fields.trailText: The finance union, Unifi, intends to prevent Barclays branch workers being coerced into working longer hours after confirmation yesterday of the bank's move to extend opening times.
fields.body:
The finance union, Unifi, intends to prevent Barclays branch workers being coerced into working longer hours after confirmation yesterday of the bank's move to extend opening times.

A union spokesman said management had guaranteed that the 20,000 branch staff would be able to choose whether to alter their patterns of work to accommodate the new longer weekday opening and more Saturday openings. The union would keep a close watch for "peer pressure" to alter working hours.

"The whole basis of the change is that it would be voluntary", the spokesman said.

Barclays confirmed that 2,000 jobs - or 4,000 part-time - would be created as a result of the plan to open 1,446 of its 1,719 branches for longer. Over the next two years the bank intends to increase the weekday opening hours of some branches currently closing between 3pm and 5.30pm. Some 50 busy branches will open from 8am to 8pm. A total of 314 branches will be open between 9am and 5pm on Saturday, while a further 77 will open from 10am to 2pm.

To public outcry, the bank closed 171 branches a year ago and over the last few years has announced 7,000 redundancies among its 70,000-strong worldwide workforce.

Malcolm Hewitt, Barclays' UK sales and service director, said the decision to open for longer was an attempt by the bank "to become more like a retailer". He said: "We don't expect our people to work for longer." For instance, an employee could chose to work four longer working days instead of the current five days to make up their 35 hours.

Matt Barrett, Barclays chief executive, said: "The old reality of bankers' hours doesn't cut it any more."

fields.headline: Pension movers anger workers
fields.body: ly parking itself on the wall of Kent-based packaging firm Crest early this week would have noticed that something seemed to be troubling the workers. Staff gathered furtively in corners to discuss some pressing topic and there was dissent in the air. ÒThe attitude here is somewhat mutinous,Ó one angry employee told Jobs & Money this week. ÒThere are lots of very unhappy and worried people here.Ó Some might be surprised to learn that the issue causing so much consternation was the companyÕs pension scheme Ñ a topic not usually known for its capacity to dramatically stir up peopleÕs emotions. This week Crest closed down its generous final salary company pension scheme Ñ where staff are guaranteed a certain level of pension benefits at retirement Ñ and replaced it with a money purchase stakeholder scheme, a type of arrangement which offers no such guarantees and leaves them more vulnerable to the whims of the stock market. ÒI think Ôkick in the nutsÕ is an expression I could use,Ó says the employee. ÒYou look around and there are huddles of people and all they are talking about is pensions.Ó Crest, which makes the packaging for products as diverse as Mr Kipling cakes and Linda McCartney frozen vegetarian meals, isnÕt the only company that is tampering with its pension arrangements. Supermarket giant Tesco and business services group Hays are just two of the big-name employers making changes to their company pension schemes which could result in some of their workers losing out, it was revealed this week. Last Saturday Jobs & Money told how BT has just closed its final salary company pension scheme to new entrants. All new employees will only be able to join a money purchase scheme. We asked readers to contact us if their employer had closed its final salary scheme to new entrants or had made other changes that they were concerned about Ñ and we got a huge response. Extracts from some of the emails we received are on the right. Many pension experts say final salary (aka defined benefit) schemes offer workers a better deal because they guarantee to pay a pension related to your earnings and length of service at or near retirement. With money purchase (aka defined contribution) schemes, the value of the pension you get when you retire is determined by how much is paid in, investment performance and annuity rates. Switching to a money purchase scheme enables an employer to cut its costs and in effect pass the burden of risk over to the employee. Hays, which employs around 13,000 people in the UK, is doing the same thing as BT. It closed its final salary scheme to most new entrants earlier this year and is bringing in a new money purchase scheme. As was the case with the old scheme, eligible employees will receive pension contributions from Hays on top of what they themselves put in. Provided the employee puts in 2% of their pay, HaysÕs contribution will be 2% for the first two years and 3% after that, though you can put in additional contributions which will also attract extra cash from Hays. This doesnÕt seem to compare well with what some of those staff in the final salary scheme get Ñ they contribute 4% of their pay with the employer putting in around 11%, says one Hays employee who contacted Jobs & Money. The company denies the move is designed to save money but says it will make its pension costs more ÒpredictableÓ. Literature being sent out to Hays employees states that money purchase schemes Òare in part a response to changing career patterns ...[and] can work better for people who have several employers during their working livesÓ. This is the typical defence given by companies when they make the switch. What they donÕt of course mention is that industry research has found that employers tend to put less money into money purchase schemes. And consulting actuaries Lane Clark & Peacock warns that the move away from traditional final salary schemes towards money purchase means Òincreased uncertainty and volatility for the employee, who is far less able to bear the risks of stock market fluctuations than large companiesÓ. Tesco, which employs 169,000 people in the UK, recently unveiled a major ÒmodernisationÓ of its pension provision which came into effect this month. A lot of what it is doing is good, but below the surface lurk hazards which employees should be aware of. Tesco has just closed its final salary company pension scheme to new employees and has made a new scheme available which is similar to a final salary arrangement but where the pension you eventually get is based on your average earnings, not your pay just before retirement. The plusses are that, unusually, the new scheme is available to all employees, whether full-time, part-time or temporary. And if youÕre a Tesco employee who works full-time for much of your working life and then goes part-time towards the end, this sort of scheme could actually offer you a better deal than the old final salary one. But the opposite is also true: if youÕre a long-term employee who is promoted later in your career, the fact that your pension isnÕt based on your final salary could make you a loser. Critically, the new scheme is linked to price inflation whereas if youÕre in a final salary scheme each bit of pension you accrue gets bumped up in line with earnings inflation. This is bad news for some Tesco workers joining the new scheme. ÒFor those employees who do have a long and full career, the pension earned in the early years could end up being less than half of what a final pay scheme would have given for those same years,Ó says employee benefits consultancy William M Mercer.

fields.headline: Northern Sinfonia/Harle
fields.standfirst:
City Hall, Newcastle
****
fields.trailText:
City Hall, Newcastle
****
fields.body:
To have an international-calibre chamber orchestra on your doorstep is fortunate; to have a home-grown saxophonist capable of standing in for Branford Marsalis is positively freakish. It could only happen in Newcastle, home of the Northern Sinfonia and saxophonist John Harle, who were both remarkably on hand to save the day when the Orpheus Chamber Orchestra's European tour collapsed due to sponsorship difficulties.

Harle shot to prominence with an infamous Last Night of the Proms appearance in 1995, when he premiered Harrison Birtwistle's fearsome sax concerto Panic. A notable collaborator with Elvis Costello and Paul McCartney, here he featured as soloist in a jazz-inflected 20th-century programme comprising two rare saxophone concertos by Ibert and Dubois.

For the Newcastle-born Harle, this last-minute engagement became a triumphant homecoming. A broad-shouldered Geordie, he looks as if he could be as well-employed ejecting drunks in the city centre as performing concertos in the city hall. But it is those mighty lungs that are responsible for a swooning, seemingly endless legato - and the sustained, half-whispered harmonic that floated out at the close of the Dubois concerto was a miracle of artistry and control.

The programme focused on the artistic fertility of Paris in the first half of the 20th century, when classical music, cubism and jazz all seemed to be sharing tables at the same pavement cafes. The ballet La Création du Monde was the masterpiece of Darius Milhaud, mentor of Dave Brubeck and, though his ballet suite is full of quirky syncopation and strange sonorities, none of it is quite enough to persuade you that it is more than the soundtrack to something missing.

Not so Stravinsky's Pulcinella, which had sets and costumes by Picasso but has always got on well enough without them. Here conductor Thierry Fischer finally had some sinew to engage with in the mock-baroque gestures of Stravinsky's score.

At last, an evening of soufflé music rose to perfection.

fields.headline: IMF angry at euro inaction
fields.standfirst: European Central Bank refuses to cut interest rates in face of rising inflation
fields.trailText: European Central Bank refuses to cut interest rates in face of rising inflation.
fields.body:
The International Monetary Fund last night stepped up the pressure on the European Central Bank to cut interest rates after warning that a failure to boost growth prospects in the single currency zone was adding to the plight of a weakening global economy.

As the ECB announced in Frankfurt that borrowing costs would remain unchanged at 4.75%, the IMF's chief economist, Michael Mussa, said: "The euro area needs to be part of the solution rather than part of the problem of slowing global growth."

Mr Mussa's explicit criticism sets the scene for a tense meeting of finance ministers and central bank governors of the Group of Seven industrial nations on Saturday, when Wim Duisenberg, the ECB's president, will be unrepentant about the bank's policy stance.

Financial analysts said yesterday that the rise in German inflation to its highest for seven years meant there was little chance of a cut in eurozone rates until June, with the ECB concerned that its credibility would be seriously damaged if it cut rates at a time when inflation was rising.

Mr Mussa added that there had been a case for a cut in eurozone rates for the past month, and that the ECB should give more heed to the needs of the world economy than to domestic inflation. "From the global perspective, the case for easing is unambiguous", he said at a press conference in Washington to publish the IMF's half-yearly World Economic Outlook.

The report praised central banks - including the US Federal Reserve and the Bank of England - for taking early action to prevent the slowdown in the global economy from turning into a full-scale recession, but Mr Mussa made it clear that patience with the ECB was wearing thin.

He said Europe's overall growth rate was faster than the growth of domestic demand in the 12-nation monetary union zone, leading to lower growth in the rest of the world. "It should be doing better than that".

The IMF believes that infla tion pressures in Europe are on the wane.

Just before the ECB's "rates unchanged" announcement, Germany reported a surge in April inflation to a seven-year high of 2.8% from 2.5% in March, largely on stubbornly high food and fuel costs.

The figures followed data from Germany and Italy this week showing that food scares relating to mad cow and foot and mouth diseases are driving eurozone inflation further above the ECB's ceiling.

German producer prices, a key indicator of future consumer inflation, hit a 19-year high of 4.9% in March. Two-year bond prices slipped immediately after the ECB announcement, with the yield rising 1.8 basis points to 4.484%. The 10-year bund future held steady, however. "They're [the ECB] not going to be frightened into making any early rate cut," said David Brown, an economist at Bear Stearns in London.

The IMF said supported the two cuts in interest rates this year from the Bank of England, adding that with inflation subdued there was room for further easing if "the growth outlook were to deteriorate further". It shaved its forecast for UK growth this year from 2.8% to 2.6%, noting that the UK was more vulnerable than the eurozone to external events.

fields.headline: Second sight
fields.standfirst:
Traditional search engines only access a small fraction of the web says Victor Keegan
More internet news
fields.trailText: Traditional search engines only access a small fraction of the web.
fields.body:
The internet has quickly become the biggest source of instant knowledge the world has ever known. It sometimes seems, as we type in requests to a search engine, that the whole world of learning and entertainment is at the tips of our fingers. But we haven't seen the half of it yet.

The store of knowledge on the internet is like a rapidly expanding iceberg in which most of the mass remains stubbornly invisible. Some estimates suggest that the "invisible"or "deep" web of impenetrable databases could be up to 500 times larger than the current web search engines are able to penetrate. In terms of exploration, we are still in the pre-Columbus era.

But they are working on it. One of this year's Big Things will be the emergence of a family of new and improved search engines, with minds of their own, aiming to get at the parts of the web today's engines can't reach.

Where is all this data hiding? A lot of it is on our own hard disks. Most of us have forgotten exactly what we have stored there and the rest of the world hasn't got a clue. But all that is changing as the peer-to peer (P2P) revolution (enabling data to be exchanged from hard disk to hard disk without going through a central server) gathers pace. Napster started it with the exchange of music files online - but made the mistake of channelling all requests through a central server (ie a huge computer serving lots of individual ones) thereby attracting the attention of teams of lawyers from the record companies.

But the dozens of other P2P companies inspired by Napster don't need to go through a central node. The P2P revolution turns home and corporate computers - including personal digital assistants (PDAs) into servers themselves. Suddenly, the hard disks of all participants will become a huge addition to the information sources of the web. And it won't just be music on tap. Users can exchange personal files, spreadsheets, poetry, operating systems, audio files - almost anything that can be digitised.

This includes full-length movies as well. Check out DivX a compression technology for film which is tipped to become the video sister of MP3. Jordan Greenhall, chief executive officer of Project Mayo )claims the technology is spreading faster than MP3 did at an equivalent stage in its development. DivX claims to be able to compress a 4GB DVD disc into only 650MB (small enough to fit on a CD-rom).

Another part of the treasure trove of the web ripe for mining is the labyrinth of chat rooms. Predictably, demand from corporations is leading the way. Moreover.com, the news monitoring company from Clerkenwell that is building up a worldwidereputation, is in the forefront. It searches financial chat rooms where comments - true or false - are made that could affect a company's share price. Moreover can search these rooms every 15 minutes and sell the information it gleans about what potential punters has a ready outlet with marketing departments and small companies prepared to to sign up for a deal. Nick Denton, founder of Moreover, says he advises companies not to get too "heavy handed" with people making adverse comments about their activities - but there are obvious privacy issues here. They could become explosive if search engines start to comb private chat rooms or secretly monitor employees searching the web for illicit reasons during working hours. PA's www.ewatch.com monitors news sites commenting on companies as well and also keeps an eye on which writers are covering particular industries.

The most profitable part of the submerged web is hidden in the bowels of corporate databases where up to 85% of information is said to be "unstructured". That makes it ripe for tackling by the new army of intelligent search engines including Britain's Autonomy. Others include www.purpleyogi.com which claims to connect information from multiple sources to a user based on their interests and what they are currently reading on the screen. In the consumer sector, www.mysimon.com searches 2,500 shopping sites to glean product prices for cost-conscious consumers.

A new generation search facility attracting much attention is www.groove.com. Groove is a P2P application that enables groups within an organisation to share files and do different activities at the same time. It has been sold to a number of corporations including GlaxoSmithKline, which took out 10,000 licences. It will enable the company's scientists to coordinate research projects internally and in collaboration with other companies and universities. Groove claims its software, which doesn't go through a central server, is "undiscoverable". Another new age search engine offering access to content that ordinary engines miss is www.brightplanet.com. It believes that traditional search engines only have access to 1% of what exists on the web.

That, in turn, raises the bigger question of all the knowledge that isn't on the web but should be. One obvious example is the British Library which, despite putting unique material on its web site, such as the Gutenberg bible, is only scratching the surface of its potential. Well under 1% of its riches are accessible through the web. If the invisible web represents all the material on the web below the surface that can't easily be seen, then the BL and other storers of knowledge represent everything underneath the iceberg. The land grab on the web is just beginning.

But all that is changing as the peer-to peer (P2P) revolution (enabling data to be exchanged from hard disk to hard disk without going through a central server) gathers pace. Napster started it with the exchange of music files online - but made the mistake of channelling all requests through a central server (ie a huge computer serving lots of individual ones) thereby attracting the attention of teams of lawyers from the record companies. But the dozens of other P2P companies inspired by Napster don't need to go through a central node. The P2P revolution turns home and corporate computers - including personal digital assistants (PDAs) into servers themselves. Suddenly, the hard disks of all participants will become a huge addition to the information sources of the web. And it won't just be music on tap. Users can exchange personal files, spreadsheets, poetry, operating systems, audio files - almost anything that can be digitised. This includes full-length movies as well. Check out DivX a compression technology for film which is tipped to become the video sister of MP3. Jordan Greenhall, chief executive officer of Project Mayo )claims the technology is spreading faster than MP3 did at an equivalent stage in its development. DivX claims to be able to compress a 4GB DVD disc into only 650MB (small enough to fit on a CD-rom). Another part of the treasure trove of the web ripe for mining is the labyrinth of chat rooms. Predictably, demand from corporations is leading the way. Moreover.com, the news monitoring company from Clerkenwell that is building up a worldwidereputation, is in the forefront. It searches financial chat rooms where comments - true or false - are made that could affect a company's share price. Moreover can search these rooms every 15 minutes and sell the information it gleans about what potential punters has a ready outlet with marketing departments and small companies prepared to to sign up for a deal. Nick Denton, founder of Moreover, says he advises companies not to get too "heavy handed" with people making adverse comments about their activities - but there are obvious privacy issues here. They could become explosive if search engines start to comb private chat rooms or secretly monitor employees searching the web for illicit reasons during working hours. PA's www.ewatch.com monitors news sites commenting on companies as well and also keeps an eye on which writers are covering particular industries. The most profitable part of the submerged web is hidden in the bowels of corporate databases where up to 85% of information is said to be "unstructured". That makes it ripe for tackling by the new army of intelligent search engines including Britain's Autonomy. Others include www.purpleyogi.com which claims to connect information from multiple sources to a user based on their interests and what they are currently reading on the screen. In the consumer sector, www.mysimon.com searches 2,500 shopping sites to glean product prices for cost-conscious consumers. A new generation search facility attracting much attention is www.groove.com. Groove is a P2P application that enables groups within an organisation to share files and do different activities at the same time. It has been sold to a number of corporations including GlaxoSmithKline, which took out 10,000 licences. It will enable the company's scientists to coordinate research projects internally and in collaboration with other companies and universities. Groove claims its software, which doesn't go through a central server, is "undiscoverable". Another new age search engine offering access to content that ordinary engines miss is www.brightplanet.com. It believes that traditional search engines only have access to 1% of what exists on the web. That, in turn, raises the bigger question of all the knowledge that isn't on the web but should be. One obvious example is the British Library which, despite putting unique material on its web site, such as the Gutenberg bible, is only scratching the surface of its potential. Well under 1% of its riches are accessible through the web. If the invisible web represents all the material on the web below the surface that can't easily be seen, then the BL and other storers of knowledge represent everything underneath the iceberg. The land grab on the web is just beginning.

fields.headline: Pulis 'drank champagne' after sacking
fields.trailText: The former Gillingham manager Tony Pulis, who is suing the club for wrongful dismissal, drank champagne on the night he was sacked as manager, the high court in London heard yesterday.
fields.body:
The former Gillingham manager Tony Pulis, who is suing the club for wrongful dismissal, drank champagne on the night he was sacked as manager, the high court in London heard yesterday.

Pulis confirmed he drank champagne after learning of his dismissal on June 30, 1999 but denied he had tried to engineer his sacking and rejected claims that he told the Gillingham goalkeeper Vince Bartram that night: "You have no idea how hard I had to work to get him [Gillingham's chairman Paul Scally] to sack me."

Nicholas Mostyn QC, representing Gillingham who are counter-claiming for damages against Pulis over alleged "gross misconduct", put it to Pulis that he had wanted to join another club and sought to get himself dismissed "so you would have the best possible chance of suing Gillingham in the high court".

Gillingham insist Pulis' conduct breached the terms of his contract. Among other things they allege that the 43-year-old, who was also dismissed by Portsmouth in January after being given leave of absence to fight this case, handled stolen documents belonging to the club with a view to exploiting them for gain.

Gillingham claimed that Pulis had broken his contract by holding "clandestine" talks with three clubs: Bristol City, whom he joined within days of leaving Gillingham, Stoke City and Norwich.

Pulis, giving evidence yesterday, said he had spoken to Norwich with Scally's permission and maintained that talking to the clubs, whom he said approached him rather than the other way round, was not an "instantly sackable" offence. It was, he said, common for rival chairmen to approach successful managers. "I don't think the Football Association or Football League would like me saying this but it does happen," Pulis said.

Pulis said that, although he held secret talks with Bristol City and Stoke, he did not want to leave Gillingham but felt "threatened, insecure and very upset" by what he alleged was Scally's failure to pay him money that he was owed.

As part of his claim, Pulis complains that Gillingham did not pay him £195,000 in bonuses due to him following the sale of three players, Ade Akinbiyi, James Corbett and Iffy Onuora.

He is also suing for loss of at least £168,000 in salary, plus bonuses and expenses-paid car and telephone benefits. The case continues.

The Football League's disciplinary panel will reconvene on Tuesday in Leeds to re-assess allegations of financial irregularities at Chesterfield.

The league's board refused to ratify the panel's recommendation to dock the Third Division club nine points, claiming the punishment was too lenient. The panel will again be chaired by Gordon McKeag.

Frédéric Kanouté has hinted he wants to leave West Ham this summer. The striker rejected an approach from Chelsea in mid-season but said yesterday: "Each offer I receive will get all my attention because now I feel ready. My ambitions have changed."

Marcel Desailly has said he is "95%" certain of staying at Chelsea next season, even though he described the club's training ground as "disgusting" and the demands of the Premiership as "terrible".

fields.headline: Breen soothes Irish nerves
fields.standfirst: Kilbane 34, Kinsella 36, Breen 76 |  I Lima 32
fields.trailText: A first-half goal by Andorra briefly threatened one of the upsets of all time before Kevin Kilbane, Mark Kinsella and Gary Breen eased Irish nerves for the expected victory.
fields.body:
The butchers, bakers and candlestickmakers from Andorra came perilously close to wreaking havoc on Ireland's World Cup aspirations and punishing their manager Mick McCarthy for resting key players before next month's meeting with Portugal.

A first-half goal by Andorra briefly threatened one of the upsets of all time. That was quickly cancelled out but it was not until Gary Breen drove in the third after Ian Harte's 76th minute free-kick that the Irish could breathe easily.

It had been hard to envisage a more negative tactical statement from the Andorrans than the one they made in the first meeting, won by Ireland 3-0 in Barcelona last month. Yet, somehow, that is precisely what they made.

A formation that featured a solitary striker, Juli Sanchez, when Andorra had possession rapidly became a 5-5-0 line-up when the visitors were without the ball, which was, predictably, most of the time.

The inevitable frustration would have been greatly diminished had the Irish breached Andorra's defence early on. Instead, the 22nd minute booking of Mark Kinsella for a foul on Juli Sanchez summed up the growing unease.

By then, Ireland had already created seven decent chances, although the Andorran approach in trying to gain their first point in 18 European Championship and World Cup qualifiers would have been spectacularly vindicated had Manuel Jimenez's low 24th minute shot not skidded wide of Shay Given's post.

The Irish soon enjoyed their best chance of the half, Gary Doherty's powerful shot being punched clear unconvincingly by Andorra's 5ft 8in peanut salesman goalkeeper, Alfonso Sanchez.

But instead of building on that attack, the unimaginable happened. Andorra, a nation with one victory in their history from a meaningless friendly with Belarussia, scored first.

In the 32nd minute Harte conceded a free-kick near the right-hand corner flag, but Justo Ruiz's cross should have been easily dealt with by the Irish defence. Instead they allowed Ildefons Lima a free header which he gleefully converted to spark a goal celebration of epic proportions.

The priceless work accomplished previously in Group Two by McCarthy's team was briefly at risk but two Irish goals in the next four minutes soon restored normal service.

After 34 minutes, Matt Holland's cross was knocked down by Doherty for the fast-arriving Kevin Kilbane to drive in from eight yards before Kinsella put his side in front, two minutes later, forcing in a rebound after Doherty headed Mark Kennedy's cross against the underside of the bar.

The cushion should have been larger before the interval as the aerial bombardment of Andorra's crowded penalty area continued, Kilbane heading disappointingly into the arms of Alfonso Sanchez from close range and Doherty's towering header being kept out, one-handed, by the goalkeeper.

Route one was clearly the path Ireland needed to follow to improve their goal difference. In Niall Quinn's enforced absence, Doherty proved an able replacement. He constantly won set-pieces and there were early second-half chances for Kinsella, whose low shot was superbly turned around the post, and David Connolly, who deflected a Breen shot and forced the recovering goalkeeper into another piece of sure handling.

Republic of Ireland (4-4-2) Given; G Kelly, Breen (Staunton, 85min), Dunne, Harte; Kennedy, Kinsella (Finnan, 79), Holland, Kilbane; Doherty, Connolly.

Andorra (4-5-1) Alfonso Sanchez; Escura, I Lima, T Lima, Jonas; Luena, Gonzalez (Soria, 87), Ruiz, Sonejee, Jimenez (Pujol, 80); Juli Sanchez (Fernandez, 90).

Referee : K Jakobson (Iceland).

webTitle: Rural theme lends topicality to Proms

fields.headline: Rural theme lends topicality to Proms
fields.standfirst: Current events give cutting edge to concert series ranging from Vaughan Williams to 'killing of countryside' oratorio
fields.trailText: With bleakly immaculate timing, the BBC yesterday announced the theme of this year's Albert Hall Proms season: the pastoral influence on classical music, a subject chosen over a year before the outbreak of foot and mouth.
fields.byline: Maev Kennedy, arts and heritage correspondent
fields.body:
With bleakly immaculate timing, the BBC yesterday announced the theme of this year's Albert Hall Proms season: the pastoral influence on classical music, a subject chosen over a year before the outbreak of foot and mouth.

"Our main theme does now have a slightly menacing topicality," Nicholas Kenyon, director of the Proms, said. "It isn't a joke at all. We hope that we will provide some really serious background to why the countryside is so important to people, why it has roused such deep emotions."

All 73 nightly concerts, from July to September, will be shown live on the internet for the first time, as well as broadcast on Radio 3, with television broadcasts of the highlights.

The pastoral theme was originally chosen to reflect the enduring influence of an idealised image of the countryside on generations of composers. The concerts will now be heard and seen against a backdrop of months of news images of a countryside darkened by smoke from animal pyres.

One of the highlights of the season is the world premiere of the Knotgrass Elegy, by Sally Beamish, which will be a striking contrast to the lyrical evocation of green meadows and birdsong in the music of Beethoven, Haydn and Vaughan Williams.

Her desolate oratorio was inspired by Graham Harvey's book The Killing of the Country, which chronicles the disastrous impact of pesticides, agri-chemicals and intensive farming. Mr Harvey is the agricultural storyline adviser to the Radio 4 soap The Archers, where Ambridge is in the grip of the crisis.

As well as guaranteed crowd pleasers such as Beethoven's Pastoral symphony, Vivaldi's Four Seasons and an opera gala, the season will include 10 BBC commissions, and 11 world, UK or London premieres, including works by Sir John Tavener and Sir Harrison Birtwistle.

In all, 100 pieces will be new to the Proms, a third of the total repertoire. Artists appearing for the first time range from conductor Elmer Bernstein to jazz pianist Jools Holland.

There is also a strong American theme this year, reflecting the first season of the BBC Symphony Orchestra's new chief conductor, American Leonard Slatkin, who will lead both the first and last nights. His last night joke item is Sousa's Liberty Bell march - better known nowadays as the Monty Python theme tune.

The Proms have been an annual phenomenom since 1895. Virtually every place - including standing room for almost 1,000 people - every night from mid-July to mid- September, is expected to sell out at the Albert Hall, at a time when the audiences for concerts and recordings of classical music are falling.

Last year the television broadcast of the Last Night of the Proms attracted an audience of 5m, and during the season 88.9% of all available tickets for concerts were sold.

The season costs the BBC £5.5m, but it recoups £3m of that at the box office, as well as gaining hundreds of hours of broadcast material. In contrast to the market forces-driven era of John Birt, the BBC is no longer interested in commercial partnership or sponsorship for the entire season, but was happy to pay a premium for the privilege of hosting such a prestigious event.

Yesterday Mr Kenyon said the figures proved reports of the death of classical music were premature.

"I think what is suffering is the ordinary 'meat and two veg' concert, which is not in any way an event, but it is not true there is a falling audience for live music, which is a real event."

Mr Kenyon has abandoned the efforts of some of his pre decessors to persuade last night prommers - sometimes raucous enough to drown out the orchestra - to sit or stand quietly.

"I'm a 'let joy be unconfined' person, so I can't see that there's any point in trying to stop people singing. Anyway, people who have stuck with us through Mahler and Bruckner for 73 concerts should be allowed to let their hair down."
