fields.headline: Uphill struggle
fields.standfirst: After  pulling out all the stops to raise the £2,250 required to participate in a sponsored trek to Chile, Alex Fouché finds that the view from the top of the Paine Massif makes the previous six months' work worthwhile
fields.trailText: After pulling out all the stops to raise the £2,250 required to participate in a sponsored trek to Chile, Alex Fouché finds that the view from the top of the Paine Massif makes the previous six months' work worthwhile
fields.body:
For some people, it started with an alluring poster in the office corridor; for others, it was an advert in their local paper; for a few it was repeating the experience of a lifetime. Whatever the reason, sponsored treks are an increasingly popular way of combining trips to remote places with the chance to make a difference to other people's lives.

Destinations range from Tibet or Costa Rica to Namibia or the Sahara desert, and the causes vary just as widely, from learning disability support to cancer research to help for deaf children.

I chose to trek for Mencap - or rather, the trek chose me. Lurking next to the lift at work was a poster advertising the trek with a mesmerising picture of three granite peaks towering over a turquoise lake, and after one glance I knew subconsciously that I wanted to do it. I struggled with the idea for a while, but ultimately I knew I would give in and raise the £2,250 required to go trekking in Chilean Patagonia, at the very tip of the South American continent.

The concept is a heady mix of exotic location coupled with the opportunity to participate in a challenging event which requires preparation, logistical support and knowledge of the terrain. For the charity involved, sponsored treks are a good way to raise their profiles and tap into new sources of funding via previously unsolicited networks of family, friends, colleagues and local organisations. Treks can raise a substantial amount of money for the charity - on my trek, close to £150,000 was raised by about 100 participants (split into two groups trekking over a month). With half the money raised going towards the cost of the trip, the outlay for the charity is minimal. It's all down to the participants to start fundraising.

Initially, £2,250 seems such a huge amount of money that the task of raising it is insurmountable, and there are moments when you seriously question your sanity. There's definitely a genuine time commitment involved - be it through the organising of activities designed to raise money or just in terms of coming up with ideas on how to get that damn dough.

One simple method used by a fellow trekker was to ask 100 people he knew to give him £20 each - although that obviously involved knowing a lot of generous people. Another participant boasted of raising money through stripping, but when challenged to repeat the performance on the trip, flatly declined.

In the midst of all the excitement and as the money builds up in front of your eyes, it's also easy to lose sight of the training required for such challenges. It's emphasised in the literature you receive, but when you consider that you'll be travelling to a remote location (it took three full days in our case to reach our final destination), that you're likely to be jet-lagged and will not sleep very well in your strange and none too comfortable surroundings, the preparation you put in will prove life-saving.

As part of a group, you probably won't be able to walk at your own pace, which in itself is tiring, and becomes problematic when you are walking an average of 20-25 kms a day (the entire trek was 125 kms - about 100 miles - over five days). Because the group is by definition diverse - having drawn together people of all ages and background - various abilities and attitudes will be represented, from the die-hard trekker to the "I'm not on holiday to exhaust myself"-type rambler.

But the rough, rugged landscapes of the Torres del Paine National Park, reminiscent of the Scottish Highlands in some parts, the Swiss Alps in others, certainly help you to forget your sore knees, aching ankles and blistered feet, and a hot shower or the simplest meal seem like gifts from heaven.

On the final day of the trek we climbed towards what would be the culmination of our trip - the famous towers of the Paine Massif, the ones I had spotted on that poster many months before. It was the most difficult day of our trek - the walk started off up a long, unrelenting slope among rolling hills which took several hours to ascend, followed by a spell of clambering in the woods and then about an hour of scrambling over boulders to reach the top.

In my group, everyone gradually dropped out - victims of sore knees or sheer exhaustion - until only my sister and I were left with the medic. As we carried on up the long incline, the groups ahead of us encouraged us by singing to us over the walkie-talkie. Soon the sun was blazing down and we began to struggle, but when we got to the refugio at the halfway point the sight of the pretty chalet and bounding stream injected renewed energy into our tired limbs.

After a spell in the neighbouring woods, we reached the final stretch of moraine. The trail looked clear enough at the edge of the woods but it soon dwindled into nothing, until we were left clambering over rocks like overweight goats.

When I thought I had come to the end of my tether, a middle-aged Chilean woman sporting a stick stopped to spur me on - or, more accurately, to harangue me. She told me indignantly that if she could make it to the top, someone like me - half her age - surely could, and that I should enjoy this part of the walk while I could, because getting back down again was going to be far more difficult.

With these words of comfort ringing in my ears I forged on, feeling so completely exhausted that I doubted my ability to crawl up the final vertical metres to the summit. But Janice the medic (who had heroically relieved me of my pack) single-handedly dragged us - physically and emotionally - to the top.

Incredibly, when we got there, the three other groups were booming La Marseillaise at the top of their lungs in a surreal greeting, and as a token of their appreciation that two limping froggies had made it in spite of the odds.

And the feeling I experienced when I turned around and laid my eyes on those breathtaking peaks was like no other feeling in the world - an overwhelming mix of exhaustion, elation, amazement, achievement and gratitude. Once in a lifetime indeed.

 Mencap organises a range of adventurous activities which combine a personal challenge with the opportunity to raise funds for people with learning disabilities. To find out more, email events@mencap.org.uk or telephone 0845 9777 779 or go to the Mencap site.

Lurking next to the lift at work was a poster advertising the trek with a mesmerising picture of three granite peaks towering over a turquoise lake, and after one glance I knew subconsciously that I wanted to do it. I struggled with the idea for a while, but ultimately I knew I would give in and raise the £2,250 required to go trekking in Chilean Patagonia, at the very tip of the South American continent. The concept is a heady mix of exotic location coupled with the opportunity to participate in a challenging event which requires preparation, logistical support and knowledge of the terrain. For the charity involved, sponsored treks are a good way to raise their profiles and tap into new sources of funding via previously unsolicited networks of family, friends, colleagues and local organisations. Treks can raise a substantial amount of money for the charity - on my trek, close to £150,000 was raised by about 100 participants (split into two groups trekking over a month). With half the money raised going towards the cost of the trip, the outlay for the charity is minimal. It's all down to the participants to start fundraising. Initially, £2,250 seems such a huge amount of money that the task of raising it is insurmountable, and there are moments when you seriously question your sanity. There's definitely a genuine time commitment involved - be it through the organising of activities designed to raise money or just in terms of coming up with ideas on how to get that damn dough. One simple method used by a fellow trekker was to ask 100 people he knew to give him £20 each - although that obviously involved knowing a lot of generous people. Another participant boasted of raising money through stripping, but when challenged to repeat the performance on the trip, flatly declined. In the midst of all the excitement and as the money builds up in front of your eyes, it's also easy to lose sight of the training required for such challenges. It's emphasised in the literature you receive, but when you consider that you'll be travelling to a remote location (it took three full days in our case to reach our final destination), that you're likely to be jet-lagged and will not sleep very well in your strange and none too comfortable surroundings, the preparation you put in will prove life-saving. As part of a group, you probably won't be able to walk at your own pace, which in itself is tiring, and becomes problematic when you are walking an average of 20-25 kms a day (the entire trek was 125 kms - about 100 miles - over five days). Because the group is by definition diverse - having drawn together people of all ages and background - various abilities and attitudes will be represented, from the die-hard trekker to the "I'm not on holiday to exhaust myself"-type rambler. But the rough, rugged landscapes of the Torres del Paine National Park, reminiscent of the Scottish Highlands in some parts, the Swiss Alps in others, certainly help you to forget your sore knees, aching ankles and blistered feet, and a hot shower or the simplest meal seem like gifts from heaven. On the final day of the trek we climbed towards what would be the culmination of our trip - the famous towers of the Paine Massif, the ones I had spotted on that poster many months before. It was the most difficult day of our trek - the walk started off up a long, unrelenting slope among rolling hills which took several hours to ascend, followed by a spell of clambering in the woods and then about an hour of scrambling over boulders to reach the top. In my group, everyone gradually dropped out - victims of sore knees or sheer exhaustion - until only my sister and I were left with the medic. As we carried on up the long incline, the groups ahead of us encouraged us by singing to us over the walkie-talkie. Soon the sun was blazing down and we began to struggle, but when we got to the refugio at the halfway point the sight of the pretty chalet and bounding stream injected renewed energy into our tired limbs. After a spell in the neighbouring woods, we reached the final stretch of moraine. The trail looked clear enough at the edge of the woods but it soon dwindled into nothing, until we were left clambering over rocks like overweight goats. When I thought I had come to the end of my tether, a middle-aged Chilean woman sporting a stick stopped to spur me on - or, more accurately, to harangue me. She told me indignantly that if she could make it to the top, someone like me - half her age - surely could, and that I should enjoy this part of the walk while I could, because getting back down again was going to be far more difficult. With these words of comfort ringing in my ears I forged on, feeling so completely exhausted that I doubted my ability to crawl up the final vertical metres to the summit. But Janice the medic (who had heroically relieved me of my pack) single-handedly dragged us - physically and emotionally - to the top. Incredibly, when we got there, the three other groups were booming La Marseillaise at the top of their lungs in a surreal greeting, and as a token of their appreciation that two limping froggies had made it in spite of the odds. And the feeling I experienced when I turned around and laid my eyes on those breathtaking peaks was like no other feeling in the world - an overwhelming mix of exhaustion, elation, amazement, achievement and gratitude. Once in a lifetime indeed.  Mencap organises a range of adventurous activities which combine a personal challenge with the opportunity to raise funds for people with learning disabilities. To find out more, email events@mencap.org.uk or telephone 0845 9777 779 or go to the Mencap site.

fields.headline: Web watch
fields.standfirst: More internet news
fields.trailText: Art for all | BT changes
fields.body:
New seekers
Despite so many dot.com's falling out of the sky, it is getting no easier to find your way around the ever-sprawling web. Traditional methods of finding what you want are simply straining to cope. Once-trusted search engines such as AltaVista and Northern Light have long been clogged-up with links to bookshops. Of course there is always Google to rely on, but recently two new sites, both built at home with virtually no budget, have come up with useful additions to the search and hope method.

Diana McK, a librarian based in Hong Kong, has had the bright idea of assembling a library of websites according to the Dewey Decimal System (DDC).

First published in 1876, the DDC is the system used by libraries throughout the world to categorise books. Although the project isn't fin ished, the list at www.geocities.com/deweyhk/ is already quite extensive and growing by the week.

Another good reference site, this time for history, can be found at http://members.aol.com/historyresearch. Information is arranged either by continent or by topic, but the really clever part is that the site only links to other link pages. It is an effective reference tool, and a must for most undergraduates or anyone with an interest in history.

Toaster
Students at Brunel University have invented a net-enabled toaster that displays the weather forecast by browning an icon on your bread. Soon, no proper e-home will be without one. Details can be found at www.brunel.ac.uk/.

Urban links
The ugly confrontations at Monday's Mayday demonstrations have already started dominating the headlines, but it's worth remembering that for many people, Mayday is much more about a serious political movement that is being fostered on the net.

Dozens of groups claim to be laying siege to the forces of capitalism, and there are far too many to list here. However, the underground e-zine Urban 75 has an exhaustive set of links at www.urban75.org/mayday01/links.html

Art for all
The Beeb's recently relaunched arts site has added a little online gallery featuring digital artworks from a number of well-known artists.

What's nice is that the Beeb hasn't gone for the usual suspects but has commissioned a number of artists from other disciplines instead. Works from the likes of Bob and Roberta Smith, Janette Parish and a beautiful screen saver from Michael Craig-Martin are already there.

Expect works from Gilbert and George, Matt Collishaw and Julian Opie in the coming weeks, say the online curators.

The site welcomes contributions from less famous digital artists, too. Send your masterpieces to www.bbc.co.uk/arts/digital

BT changes
More BT number changes come into force on Saturday affecting mobile, pager and premium rate numbers. All mobile and pagers will now begin with the prefix 07, special rate numbers will continue to begin with 08 and have expanded to include internet services, and premium rate numbers will begin with either 090 or 091. See www.numberchange.bt.com for more details.

Census day
The census is issued on Monday, and although you can't fill it out online, there is help with the form, and a decent set of FAQs (answers to Frequently Asked Questions) at www.statistics.gov.uk

Cancer cure
Scientists at Oxford University are working with Intel to search for a cure for cancer using the internet. Inspired by the Seti@home project that links computers to search for extraterrestrial life, the project uses similar technology to network computers in order to process the vast amounts of data.

A network of PCs pool their processing power, which gives the scientists the power of a supercomputer at a fraction of the cost. Seti@home has attracted almost 3m users since its launch in 1999. See www.intel.com/cure

Pay or else
One of the UK's internet industry news services, Netimperative.com, says that unless its users volunteer to switch to a subscription model by next Tuesday, then it's curtains for its mix of daily bulletins and weekly analysis. At the moment membership is free, but Net Imperative want to charge £50 a year.

Six degrees
Students at the department of computer science at Virginia University have updated the modern parlour game, Six degrees of Kevin Bacon. Taking its cue from John Guare's play, Six Degrees of Separation, the object of the game is to link any well-known actor to another using only six steps. Two people are said to be linked if they star in a film together. See www.cs.virginia.edu/oracle/star_links.html

New and noted
 Tomato, a British design collective, has participated in a pan-European art project at www.absolut.com/lights

 A stylish city guide for the capital can be found at www.viewlondon.co.uk

 There is a witty spoof of The Weakest Link at www.supanet.com/missinglink

 The founder member of Faithless goes around the world with digital camera. Check out his progress at www.1giantleap.tv

www.traveldonkey.com

Bag a bargain

www.cheapflights.co.uk

Foreign office advice

www.fco.gov.uk/travel

Go green

www.greentourism.org.uk

Write about it

www.travelintelligence.net

Not forgetting

fields.headline: What does contiguous mean?
fields.standfirst:
Until foot and mouth and the fame of Phoenix the word 'contiguous' was unknown to the vast majority of the population. David McKie takes a look at the word of the moment

Special report: foot and mouth
fields.trailText: Until foot and mouth and the fame of Phoenix the word 'contiguous' was unknown to the vast majority of the population. David McKie takes a look at the word of the moment.
fields.body:
Until just the other day, contiguity was not a concept that most people in Britain spent much time on at all. If they entered this territory, they used simple terms like near or close. If lawyers, they were just as likely to use a term like adjoin or abut - a word you rarely hear nowadays pronounced by people who do not have documents with them.

Yet suddenly the word "contiguous" is on everyone's lips. This is mostly down to Phoenix, the cuddly soft-eyed calf, which this week melted the hearts of a nation and by all appearances the heart of the prime minister's press secretary too.

Contiguous culling was the doctrine that so nearly put Phoenix to death. Therefore, contiguity matters.

But what does it mean? That is rarely explained. The newscasters and reporters who let it slip off their tongues in bulletins, the pundits who so gaily toss it about, never stop to define it.

Producers who allow its use on Sky News do not flash up a subtitle usefully telling their audience what the word "contiguous" means. Maybe only those, a dwindling breed, who once went through a classical education, would grasp its meaning immediately. Yet to them the meaning is very simple. It comes from the Latin and means: to touch with.

Collins English dictionary says:
 touching along the side or boundary; in contact
 physically adjacent, neighbouring
 preceding or following in time

Longman's says:
 in actual contact, touching along a boundary, or at a point
 (of two angles) adjacent
 next or near in time or sequence

Chambers has:
 touching, adjoining
 near

By another route, the latin "con-" and "tangere" (to touch) give us the word contingent.

Sometimes when a word enters popular language it lodges there; sometimes it enjoys its moment of fame and then quietly fades away.

Since the man one has now come to think of as Robin Cooka Masala made his controversial remarks on race, fierce delight has been taken in dragging tikka masala into contexts where you would not normally hear it. That will not last.

However, other speech habits stick. Using, for example, "I went" instead of "I said", which grates on the ears of anyone over 40, is now an ineradicable practice.

Whether the mass employment of "contiguous" sticks will depend on how many everyday contexts it can now be employed in. Will people cease, for instance, to refer to "my neighbours" and say instead "the family that we're contiguous with"? Probably not.

Will cricket pundits describe lbw appeals as "pretty contiguous" instead of "pretty adjacent"? Perhaps.

Will civil servants defend some evasive answer on the grounds that what they are saying is "contiguous with the truth?" Very likely.

Nevertheless, it is not a word to be generally recommended. For, as George Orwell taught, a short, simple word is invariably to be preferred to a cumbersome, pompous one. The word "contiguous" is no more inherently cumbersome and pompous than the word "continuous", which long ago came into every day use.

But if children come back from school next week describing the friends with whom their desks are contiguous, rather than just next door to, please don't encourage them.

fields.headline: Let me be your fantasy
fields.standfirst: Good for crowds but still problematic as star of the show, virtual actors may already be at a screen near you.  S A Mathieson  reports
fields.trailText: Good for crowds but still problematic as star of the show, virtual actors may already be at a screen near you. S A Mathieson reports
fields.body:
The Screen Actors' Guild, the US union to which most film stars belong, is poised to go on strike in June. But one summer release may be pioneering the way to make future thespian walkouts an irrelevance.

Final Fantasy, due to reach UK screens in August, uses state-of-the-art virtual actors - sometimes known as vactors, or synthespians. The film, a science-fiction thriller set in 2065, has been entirely computer-generated by animation specialist Square. Flesh and blood actors contribute just basic movement data, and voicing.

But anyone hoping to be convinced by the female lead, Aki Ross, is likely to be disappointed. A preview last week in London showed that "she" may look more human than most characters of software born, but there's still something wrong. Her skin and eyes look lifeless, and when she runs, her movements are somehow too smooth.

Some of these problems also affect Eve Solal, a computer-generated character produced by Parisian animator Attitude Studio. In stills - such as "her" recent cover shoot for women's magazine Madame Figaro - Solal looks disconcertingly real. But in a short video interview, available on her website, she doesn't quite convince.

This is because, when computer animators try to simulate human life, they are trying to trick one of our brain's most reliable processes. "There is a disproportionate amount of mental capacity used for dealing with faces," says Dr Donald Laming, lecturer in experimental psychology at Cambridge University. "If the face isn't quite right, it's not going to work."

The brains behind Solal and Ross know they aren't quite there - yet. "Her face is a bit plastic, and her eyes move a little bit too much," says Rémy Brun, motion capture director at Attitude, of Solal.

Jun Aida, producer of Final Fantasy and president of Hawaiian-based studio Square, agrees. "Our goal was not to create photo-real characters. I don't think technically it's possible with animation. In still photos, we can." He sees his film as creating a new category of high-quality animation, rather than as a challenge to live-action movies.

Virtual actors are not even a cheap alternative to the real thing. Aida says the 60,000 hairs on Ross's head took a fifth of Square's graphic rendering capacity to produce. "She ended up costing us millions of dollars," he says. "We should have given her shorter hair." The resulting hairdo, although one of the more realistic things about Ross, does tend to make her look as if she's just stepped out of the salon even when cheating death - but perhaps that's a screen siren's prerogative.

Despite the difficulty in creating faces, realistic body movements are at least as tricky. In Final Fantasy, producers used a technique called motion capture. This involves real people performing the required actions, such as running or walking, while wearing sensors spread around their bodies. Cameras track the sensors, then map them on to the virtual actor.

But using this process to create convincing movement is fiendishly difficult, according to Chris Ford, senior product manager for Alias Wavefront's Maya, the software used by many firms to handle three-dimensional models. "Motion capture is true to life, but it is sampled data," says Ford. "It's a bit like digital versus analogue [sound]." Motion-captured movements often look odd as a result of poor sampling.

With Solal, Attitude has got closer than most to convincing human movement, by basing almost all her actions on those of an actress of a similar build; Final Fantasy's animators, by contrast, have used actors only to model action sequences. "We chose the actress as we would for theatre or cinema," says Brun. "Often, people use their friends, but acting is 50% of the movement." Brun uses 12 cameras running Vicon, a system from UK firm Oxford Metrics, and his eight years of experience in the field, which he describes as "very high-tech puppetry".

Some animators are experimenting with virtual animals. Although in some respects more difficult - fur or hair is notoriously hard to get right - our eyes are less attuned to any imperfections, and also, the results will often be impossible to obtain in real life. Viewers of the latest surreal Guinness television ad may have noticed the appearance of a group of squirrels, who talk and quaff glasses of the black stuff. They are computer-generated.

Sally Goldberg is head of creature animation for Computer Film Company, one of several Soho firms working in this area. She is also virtual mother of the Guinness squirrels. "We built them from scratch," she says. This is unusual, as three-dimensional characters are often designed from a template, such as with the firm's work on Eyes Wide Shut (see box).

Goldberg filmed squirrels from an animal rescue centre, and then translated their movements into the three-dimensional models used in the ad. "When he sat there and held a nut, he looked just like he was drinking beer," she says, of the squirrel she based the main character on.

It is already possible to fill the screen with computer-generated humans and convince the eye - if you're using thousands of virtual actors, rather than one close up. Mill Film, a few hundred yards south of Computer Film Company, last month won an Oscar for its work on Gladiator, which included a 50,000-strong virtual Roman crowd - an obvious moneysaver for the production company.

It is partly financial concerns that hold back use of virtual actors as leads. "If money's no object, it's possible now," claims Dave Throssell, a head of computer animation at Mill. "But I'd ask, 'are you sure?' You want a real person, then there's thousands of them outside this window." He adds that computer generating an actor for a whole film would be expensive even compared to a star demanding $20m.

And then there's the Lara Croft effect. Virtual characters to date have been not so much Final Fantasy as Unrealistic Male Fantasy. The somewhat top-heavy star of the Tomb Raider games has recently been joined by two similarly shaped virtual pop stars, TMmy and T-Babe, created by Glaswegian animators. "Most people who sit in front of computers tend to be male, and that's what they think about 24 hours a day," Throssell points out.

Attitude's Brun says Eve Solal was deliberately designed to break this stereotype. "She's 1.62 metres [5ft4in], which is quite short, so she's not a top model. She's good-looking in a way, but she's not Pamela Anderson, or Lara Croft," Brun says.

The French studio is, however, trying to perfect elements such as Solal's skin, in its quest to make the character more convincing. But it may be a long task. "In the history of painting, it took several hundred years for artists to learn how to paint in three dimensions, and to draw the human figure and face," says Cambridge's Dr Laming, adding that science doesn't yet fully understand how we read each others' body language. "It's as if computer animators are in the position of those early artists."

The film, a science-fiction thriller set in 2065, has been entirely computer-generated by animation specialist Square. Flesh and blood actors contribute just basic movement data, and voicing. But anyone hoping to be convinced by the female lead, Aki Ross, is likely to be disappointed. A preview last week in London showed that "she" may look more human than most characters of software born, but there's still something wrong. Her skin and eyes look lifeless, and when she runs, her movements are somehow too smooth. Some of these problems also affect Eve Solal, a computer-generated character produced by Parisian animator Attitude Studio. In stills - such as "her" recent cover shoot for women's magazine Madame Figaro - Solal looks disconcertingly real. fields.headline: Feedback
fields.standfirst: From Hettie
fields.trailText: When I visited Peru I was on an organised tour with an excellent Australian-based firm called Geckos (we booked through Exodus in London): this turned out to be a really good way to see a lot if you're short on time.
fields.body:
When I visited Peru I was on an organised tour with an excellent Australian-based firm called Geckos (we booked through Exodus in London): this turned out to be a really good way to see a lot if you're short on time.

The Hotel Regency in Lima was very good, and the El Conquistador in Arequipa was lovely and not far from the main square. As for the Inca Trail, I honestly think anyone can do it. Our tour leader had taken a 90-year-old up it, and I wasn't planning on doing it initially as I have been diabetic for two years and was a bit nervous. However, the diabetes was no problem and I wouldn't have missed it for anything. We tended to start very early in the morning and would be at our campsite no later than two in the afternoon, so there was plenty of time to recover.

The end of day one and the beginning of day two are quite tough, but as long as you go slowly you'll be fine - it's your knees on day three that you have to worry about! We had brilliant porters who carried everything and set up camp, so there was very little you had to do except walk. I honestly think it was one of the best things I've ever done, and you'll love it. I can't remember the names of the other hostals offhand that we stayed in but we had a lovely one in Cusco (an amazing place that is a must see) and a fantastic jungle lodge... if you want me to try and find the details, let me know.

All the best,

Hettie

webTitle: 'Sector must speak with unified voice to impact policy'

fields.headline: 'Sector must speak with unified voice to impact policy'
fields.trailText: Too many volunteering organisations are in competition with each other, which is weakening the sector's influence on government policy, according to the chief executive of a high profile national campaign.
fields.body:
Too many volunteering organisations are in competition with each other, which is weakening the sector's influence on government policy, according to the chief executive of a high profile national campaign.

John Rafferty, of the TimeBank volunteering initiative, said organisations such as the National Association of Volunteer Bureaux, the National Centre for Volunteering and others are often competing for grants from the same funders and there was a lack of collaboration on lobbying.

Mr Rafferty said: "There is no clear, unequivocal voice for volunteering [at government level] and the winners are the bureaucrats."

The sector now has a prime minister, chancellor, cabinet office minister and home office minister all apparently committed to promoting volunteering, he said, but without a single voice to express the views of volunteering agencies, the sector had not influenced policy sufficiently.

Also speaking at the Charityfair 2001 seminar, Directory of Social Change director Mike Eastwood said he was concerned that when the prime minister gave examples of volunteering the government wanted to encourage, he focused on several activities not necessarily related to the voluntary sector, such as the territorial army and adults helping children to read.

If extra funds for volunteering were not to end up in health or education budgets the voluntary sector would have to improve its lobbying skills, said Mr Eastwood.

Mr Rafferty added: "With many volunteering organisations bidding for the same funds it is hard to build a consensus, let alone joint working, but that's exactly what we need." The way ahead was not mergers, he added, but some form of volunteering alliance that could set the agenda for government initiatives and become the natural group for ministers to consult when considering changes.

He said he was concerned about the lack of leadership in the sector at a crucial time, on the brink of a general election: "Now is the time to look at why we're here and how we can move forward."

Volunteering also suffered from a lack of coherent and visible marketing, argued Mr Rafferty, suggesting that a single brand and logo, such as TimeBank, could make it easier to communicate with the public.

"TimeBank has only been going a year but there's already high public recognition of the brand," he said, adding that the volunteering sector could benefit from a single brand and logo, similar to that for legal aid.

TimeBank, he said, was "the marketing department for volunteering" and could exploit its high profile to play a wider publicity role for volunteering generally.

Mr Rafferty highlighted research carried out by TimeBank into placing volunteers, he said it suggested a dramatic difference between potential volunteers who were simply sent information about volunteering by TimeBank and those that the organisation managed to put in touch with local volunteer coordinators.

TimeBank took samples from its 15,000 registered volunteers and found that 15% of those that had been sent information had actually volunteered but that number soared to 39% of those that had been put in touch with a volunteer coordinator in a local charity.

"That suggests there is a big need for more resources to be channelled to existing volunteering practitioners," he said.

Mr Rafferty referred to Gordon Brown's £300m boost to volunteering announced in January, which included £20m for a "new experience corps" to promote volunteering among older people and £60m on modernisation of volunteering.

There had been concerns from some in the sector about how the new experience corps would operate, he said, adding that it was still unclear what the £60m modernisation fund would actually be spent on.

These uncertainties only underlined how important it was for the volunteering sector to able to speak with one voice to government, he said, so that initiatives flowed from consultation with those in volunteering rather than being imposed on them by ministers and civil servants.

webTitle: Hendry gets six-match ban for San Marino elbow

fields.headline: Hendry gets six-match ban for San Marino elbow
fields.trailText: Colin Hendry's international career is almost certainly over after he was found guilty of elbowing Nicola Albani during Scotland's match against San Marino last month - and banned for six matches.
fields.body:
Colin Hendry's international career is almost certainly over after he was found guilty of elbowing Nicola Albani during Scotland's match against San Marino last month - and banned for six matches.

Hendry, who has played 51 times for Scotland, has also been fined 10,000 Swiss francs over the incident which saw the 19-year-old Albani receive treatment in hospital.

The Scottish FA is considering whether to appeal against the ban. They are also seeking clarification over whether the ban includes friendlies as well as World Cup matches.

If it applies only to competitive fixtures the ban would rule Hendry out of Scotland's final three World Cup qualifying matches and then, if they qualified for Korea/Japan 2002, the first three fixtures of the World Cup. Hendry would be 36 by then.

SFA chief executive David Taylor said: "I am disappointed at the severity of the punishment, given the particular circumstances of the incident and the player's previous good disciplinary record.

"Fifa has not yet communicated the basis for reaching this decision, and once we receive this clarification we will then be in a position to decide whether or not to lodge a formal appeal."

fields.headline: Calf becomes a symbol
fields.standfirst: Special report: foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: Phoenix, probably the best-known calf in the country, is now being hailed as a symbol of hope for the farming industry after she avoided being culled yet again.
fields.body:
Phoenix, probably the best-known calf in the country, is now being hailed as a symbol of hope for the farming industry after she avoided being culled yet again.

Yesterday Devon farmer Philip Board said: "Everything has been slaughtered. This calf survived, why not give it a chance?"

His wife, Michaela, said Maff officials had gone away to obtain a court injunction so they could kill the calf. Mrs Board said Phoenix had no signs of foot and mouth disease.

fields.headline: 'People's peers' commission defends new Lords
fields.trailText: Britain's first ever peers to be appointed through public application were announced today, but the so-called "people's peers" come exclusively from the worlds of diplomacy, education and business.
fields.body:
Britain's first ever peers to be appointed through public application were announced today, but the so-called "people's peers" come exclusively from the worlds of diplomacy, education and business.

The final 15, selected by panel from a total of 3,141 applications sent in by would-be Lords and Ladies last year, include seven knights and three professors.

The much trumpeted scheme to allow British citizens to sit on the red leather seats of the House of Lords was launched last year in a bid to make the upper chamber more "representative."

But today the chairman of the Lords appointment committee, Lord Stevenson, was forced to defend the "highfaluting" nature of the 15 chosen, claiming that the criteria for selection was that "the human being will be comfortable operating in the House of Lords."

The nature of the appointments immediately ran into a barrage of criticism from MPs, democracy campaigners and union leaders.

The general secretary of the GMB, John Edmonds, which represents hairdressers, said: "If Lord Stevenson ever has his hair cut by one of our members, I would warn him to keep a close eye on his ear lobes.

"This response proves that while the membership list may have been reduced, the club remains as exclusive as ever. Surely the Lords must now be quaffing their champagne in the last chance saloon."

Gordon Prentice, MP for Pendle and a Commons modernisation select committee member, called for "a directly elected House of Lords of no more than 100 members". Mr Prentice tabled a Commons early day motion, also signed by Paul Flynn, MP for Newport West, which regretted that the failed applicants were not given reasons for their rejection, even though some had asked for explanations.

The MPs were "astonished" that "non-party political people's peers" would be free to take a party whip in the Lords. The motion concludes: "In a modern democracy the election of legislators is preferable to appointment."

The Demos thinktank author and veteran constitutional reform campaigner, Anthony Barnett, said the appointment of 15 "people's peers" was an attempt to avoid real reform of the House of Lords.

He added: "This is a pseudo-democracy, not a real thing. It's a cosmetic exercise. The fact that they are being chosen from above and are being made peers for life mean that however good the candidates this is no more than a masquerade of democracy."

Pam Giddy, the director of Charter 88, a group which campaigns for a modern democracy, said: "These people will be altering and passing laws but the people have no way of getting rid of them. This is simply patronage by another name."

All the peers announced today nominated themselves, after finding two referees to back up their claim, and have been agreed to by the prime minister, Tony Blair. Their applications will now go forward to the Queen for approval.

They will sit in the Lords as crossbench independents. One of the criteria for applying for the posts was that the person was not a member of any political party. Candidates also had to be British citizens, and over 21 years old.

The commission wrote to more than 10,000 organisations, including charities and quangos, requesting names of worthy candidates be put forward. Lord Stevenson claimed the notion of dubbing the appointments "people's peers" was not the commission's idea, and added: "You haven't got your hairdresser in this list, but if you go back to our criteria [for choosing a new peer] one of them is that the human being will be comfortable operating in the House of Lords."

"Before we were to nominate someone from that kind of background, with an outstanding achievement in his or her chosen way of life, we would have to be very, very confident that they would feel comfortable standing up in debates and talking and cutting it.

"I don't rule out the possibility that someone of that kind will be appointed, but it would be a great responsibility on our part appointing them, we would have to do it very carefully. "There were a number of people who applied with less obvious highfaluting achievements, some of whom we are taking forward. An ordinary person is in the eye of the beholder."

The Conservative ex-foreign secretary, Lord Hurd, a member of the Appointments Commission, added: "I don't know what 'people's peers' means. It's not a phrase we have ever used."

The 15 new life peers are:
 Sir Paul Condon, former commissioner of the Metropolitan police
 Sir Herman Ouseley, former executive chairman and chief executive of the Commission for Racial Equality
 Victor Adebowale, chief executive of Centrepoint
 Richard Best, director of the Joseph Rowntree Foundation
 Amir Bhatia, businessman
 Sir John Browne, group chief executive of BP Amoco
 Professor Michael Chan, a paediatrician
 Professor Ilora Finlay, a world expert in palliative medicine and vice-dean of the School of Medicine, University of Wales College of Medicine
 Professor Susan Greenfield, director of the Royal Institute of Great Britain
 Sir David Hannay, a former diplomat
 Valerie Howarth, chief executive of Childline
 Lady (Elspeth) Howe of Aberavon, a former chairman of the Broadcasting Standards Commission
 Sir Robert May, president of the Royal Society
 Sir Claus Moser, a former professor of statistics at the London School of Economics and former head of the government statistical service
 Sir Stewart Sutherland, a leading figure of the field of education.

The perks of the job are:

 Life membership to the 'most exclusive club in the country'
 A working week often running from Tuesday to Thursday
 £84 accommodation allowance a night, £37 a day for meals and taxis and £ 36 towards a secretary and postage
 Free first class rail or air travel
 A generous allowance of 52.5p a mile
 Use of five luxurious bars and restaurants, including the Peers' dining room, the bishop's bar, the Attlee room, the home room and the Barry room
 Free gym membership
 Use of the Westminster shooting range.

All the peers announced today nominated themselves, after finding two referees to back up their claim, and have been agreed to by the prime minister, Tony Blair. Their applications will now go forward to the Queen for approval. They will sit in the Lords as crossbench independents. One of the criteria for applying for the posts was that the person was not a member of any political party. Candidates also had to be British citizens, and over 21 years old. The commission wrote to more than 10,000 organisations, including charities and quangos, requesting names of worthy candidates be put forward. Lord Stevenson claimed the notion of dubbing the appointments "people's peers" was not the commission's idea, and added: "You haven't got your hairdresser in this list, but if you go back to our criteria [for choosing a new peer] one of them is that the human being will be comfortable operating in the House of Lords." "Before we were to nominate someone from that kind of background, with an outstanding achievement in his or her chosen way of life, we would have to be very, very confident that they would feel comfortable standing up in debates and talking and cutting it. "I don't rule out the possibility that someone of that kind will be appointed, but it would be a great responsibility on our part appointing them, we would have to do it very carefully. "There were a number of people who applied with less obvious highfaluting achievements, some of whom we are taking forward. An ordinary person is in the eye of the beholder." The Conservative ex-foreign secretary, Lord Hurd, a member of the Appointments Commission, added: "I don't know what 'people's peers' means. It's not a phrase we have ever used." The 15 new life peers are:  Sir Paul Condon, former commissioner of the Metropolitan police  Sir Herman Ouseley, former executive chairman and chief executive of the Commission for Racial Equality  Victor Adebowale, chief executive of Centrepoint  Richard Best, director of the Joseph Rowntree Foundation  Amir Bhatia, businessman  Sir John Browne, group chief executive of BP Amoco  Professor Michael Chan, a paediatrician  Professor Ilora Finlay, a world expert in palliative medicine and vice-dean of the School of Medicine, University of Wales College of Medicine  Professor Susan Greenfield, director of the Royal Institute of Great Britain  Sir David Hannay, a former diplomat  Valerie Howarth, chief executive of Childline  Lady (Elspeth) Howe of Aberavon, a former chairman of the Broadcasting Standards Commission  Sir Robert May, president of the Royal Society  Sir Claus Moser, a former professor of statistics at the London School of Economics and former head of the government statistical service  Sir Stewart Sutherland, a leading figure of the field of education. The perks of the job are:  Life membership to the 'most exclusive club in the country'  A working week often running from Tuesday to Thursday  £84 accommodation allowance a night, £37 a day for meals and taxis and £ 36 towards a secretary and postage  Free first class rail or air travel  A generous allowance of 52.5p a mile  Use of five luxurious bars and restaurants, including the Peers' dining room, the bishop's bar, the Attlee room, the home room and the Barry room  Free gym membership  Use of the Westminster shooting range. fields.headline: Education's Lords
fields.trailText: Britain's first ever peers to be appointed through public application were announced today. Here is our guide to the 'people's peers' from the education sector.
fields.body:
Sir Robert May
Professor of Zoology, Oxford University and Imperial College
The former chief scientific adviser to the government, Sir Robert, 65, is now the president of the Royal Society. According to Oxford's zoological department, he is currently engaged in the study of the causes, consequences and magnitude of biological diversity and mathematical models of the population dynamics of the immune system.

Sir Claus Moser
Formerly Professor of Statistics, London School of Economics
Sir Claus, 78, is a chancellor of Keele and the Open University of Israel and formerly a Warden at Wadham College, Oxford. Adult literacy is one of his major interests - since 1997, he has chaired the Basic Skills Agency - as well as opera and theatre.

Professor Susan Greenfield
Chair in Pharmacology, University of Oxford
Professor Greenfield, 50, could probably claim to be Britain's best known female scientist: last summer, she presented a BBC2 series and published The Private Life of the Brain, which is currently lurking just outside the top 200 bestsellers on Amazon.co.uk. She is the first female director of the Royal Institution of Great Britain. Her research interests include identifying brain changes among sufferers from Alzheimers and Parkinsons diseases and other biochemical activity in the brain.

Sir Stewart Sutherland
Vice-chancellor, Edinburgh University
Before Chris Woodhead's reign as chief inspector of Ofsted, Sir Stewart, 60, was in charge of the schools inspectorate - indeed, he founded it in 1992. Before that, he lectured in the philosophy of religion and history at Bangor, Stirling and King's College, London, and later became vice-chancellor of the University of London. For the past seven years, however, he has been Britain's second-best-paid vice-chancellor, on a salary of £149,000. Staff and students at Edinburgh can rest easy, however. Sir Stewart will not be giving up the day job, despite its "formidable workload". He is currently in the US representing his university. His interests include Tassie Medallions, theatre, jazz and "rough gardening".

Professor Ilora Finlay
Vice-dean of the School of Medicine, University of Wales College of Medicine
Welsh Woman of the Year, Professor Finlay specialises in palliative care, particularly for cancer patients.

fields.headline: T Rex - our feathered friend
fields.trailText: A spread-eagled outline in a 130m-year-old rock from China has raised one of biology's great questions: did the Tyrannosaurus Rex baby have feathers?
fields.body:
A spread-eagled outline in a 130m-year-old rock from China has raised one of biology's great questions: did the Tyrannosaurus Rex baby have feathers?

The fossil discovery shows a bird-shaped dinosaur with sickle claws, and a coat of fluffy down and feathery quills.

It may look like a bird, but according to Mark Norell of the American Museum of Natural History and Ji Qiang of the Chinese Academy of Geological Sciences, it is an earthbound predator. They report in Nature today that it was a dromeosaur, a small, swift-footed, two-legged predator.

"This fossil radically modifies our vision of these extinct animals," said Dr Norell. "It shows us that advanced theropod dinosaurs may have looked more like weird birds than giant lizards."

Researchers long ago proposed that birds could be the descendants of dinosaurs. Theropod dinosaurs and birds share more than 100 anatomical features. But the guess had been that feathers emerged after flight.

In 1995 geologists combing fossil beds in Liaoning in north-eastern China began to find hints of a dinosaur with feathers. The debate faltered when one fossil turned out to be a fake. But the dromeosaur has feathers from head to toe.

"Modern birds are warm blooded and their feathers play an integral part in keeping them warm, so a reasonable idea is that non-avian dinosaurs developed primitive feathers at the same time that they developed warm-bloodedness," Dr Norell said. "It's conceivable that small dinosaurs like this one and even the young of large species like Tyrannosaurus Rex may have needed featherlike body coverings to maintain body temperature."

webTitle: Archaeological dig unearths Roman army treasures

fields.headline: Archaeological dig unearths Roman army treasures
fields.trailText: A workshop which may have produced armoury for cavalry escorts of the Roman emperor Hadrian has been unearthed by archaeologists in the most significant find for 50 years from Britain's Roman period.
fields.body:
A workshop which may have produced armoury for cavalry escorts of the Roman emperor Hadrian has been unearthed by archaeologists in the most significant find for 50 years from Britain's Roman period.

Weapons, siege equipment and some of the best-preserved armour ever discovered from the days of the legions are among hundreds of finds which will go on public display next year. Waterlogged ground on the site of the dig - by the main east-west street in Roman Carlisle - contained preserved leather bindings and complex iron scales joined by bronze wire which are thought to have protected cavalrymen's shoulders.

"We believe this is a unique discovery from anywhere in the Roman world," said Thom Richardson, keeper of Oriental and European armour at the Royal Armouries. "It has the potential to solve the puzzle of how such armour worked," he said.

The scale of the finds, which also include extremely rare sets of armour for arms and legs, was revealed when clods of rock-like, congealed mud and metal were taken for x-ray checks at the armouries in Leeds.

To the delight of the dig team, scans revealed the ghostly shape of the armour sections, plus brighter twists of wire, hidden inside. "Basically, they look like lumps of gunk at the moment, but we should have something really spectacular to show the world when conservation is finished," said Mr Richardson. Specialists will chip delicately away at the metal's mud casing, salvaging leather components as the work is carried out.

The finds, discovered during a rescue dig on the site of Carlisle's new Millennium Gallery by the former Roman fort of Luguvallium, are thought to be rejects and scrap which accumulated under the armourers' workbenches.

Mr Richardson said: "It looks as though we've got years of the sort of stuff engineers and craftsmen put to one side or throw away - bits of this and that which all help to build our picture of how the Roman army was equipped."

Mike McCarthy, head of Carlisle Archaeology (a commercial offshoot of Bradford university, which carried out the dig) said: "It's been a wonderful discovery, one of the most important yet from Roman Britain. The hundreds of different items are going to give us a fascinating insight."

The discovery is the biggest since large scale excavations in Corbridge in Northumberland, where material unearthed in 1964 changed historians' views of the Roman defensive system.

webTitle: Pensioner and academic vie for top ranking

fields.headline: Pensioner and academic vie for top ranking
fields.trailText: An Ulster pensioner and a Malaysian-born academic are competing for the crown of Britain's wealthiest biotech entrepreneur, with fortunes of more than a quarter of a billion pounds each.
fields.body:
An Ulster pensioner and a Malaysian-born academic are competing for the crown of Britain's wealthiest biotech entrepreneur, with fortunes of more than a quarter of a billion pounds each.

At present, Galen Holdings' founder Allen McClay, 69, holds the title. His stake in the Northern Irish health care company, which has developed a new way of delivering hormone replacement therapy, is worth £331m. Taking account of share sales over the past two years, his wealth amounts to more than £360m.

Dr McClay remains president of Galen and was recently spotted cycling around the US countryside with his girlfriend, near the New Jersey head office of recently acquired Warner Chilcott. He contends that money is of no interest to him: "The Lord gives nuts to those who have no teeth."

Second in the wealth stakes is Kim Tan, the founder of KS Biomedix, which is developing antibodies to fight arthritis. A former academic at Surrey University, Dr Tan is the son of a rice and sugar trader in Malaysia.

He has additional interests in early-stage firms GeneMedix and TranXenoGen, but recent weakness in the stock market has pushed his fortune just below the £300m mark. Like many of his peers, Dr Tan stresses his frugal lifestyle - in a recent interview, he said his car was an eight-year-old Volkswagen Golf.

Another director of Galen Holdings, John King, can boast wealth of £200m. Next, Terry Sadler, the founder of skin care specialist Bioglan Pharma, has chalked up paper wealth of £179m. His profitable company sells drugs for eczema, acne and psoriasis, although biotech purists point out that few of its products are developed in-house.

Sir Christopher Evans, the founder of Chiroscience and Celsis, is worth £150m according to the latest estimate by the Sunday Times' Rich List. The son of a Welsh steel worker, Sir Christopher lives in an estate backing onto the Sugar Loaf Mountain in Abergavenny. He has a bacteria named after him, is close to Tony Blair and his incubator fund, Merlin Bioscience, is preparing to raise a further £250m by the end of the year.

Among the also-rans, Shire Pharmaceuticals' chairman James Cavanaugh is valued at more than £135m. Jacques Gonella, the Swiss backer of drug delivery firm SkyePharma, has shares worth £90m, while chairman Ian Gowrie-Smith is worth some £40m.

Former Trebor sweets director Paul Drayson, who now runs Powderject Pharmaceuticals, has amassed a paper wealth of £87m by building the company's needle-free injection technology.

webTitle: Oxford don takes swipe at Brown

fields.headline: Oxford don takes swipe at Brown
fields.standfirst: Guardian Unlimited Education
fields.trailText: The government should stop "sneering" at Britain's elite universities and concentrate instead on tackling the broader social problems which have created an educational divide, the Oxford don at the centre of the Laura Spence affair said yesterday.
fields.body:
The government should stop "sneering" at Britain's elite universities and concentrate instead on tackling the broader social problems which have created an educational divide, the Oxford don at the centre of the Laura Spence affair said yesterday.

Its drive to increase the proportion of working class children applying to Oxford and Cambridge would be boosted only when the cycle of low expectation and poor achievement was broken, said Anthony Smith, president of the university's Magdalen College.

Addressing the heads of independent schools at a conference in Brighton, Mr Smith said educational deficiency began even before children set foot in the classroom. He urged ministers to "improve the cities where children live, ensure that their fathers have jobs, restore the quality of television, cut the supply of drugs and reduce the level of violence. All that would be a start."

The decision last year by Mag- dalen College not to award a place to Laura Spence, a talented pupil from a Tyneside comprehensive school, sparked a debate about university elitism, and was even dismissed as "a scandal" by the chancellor, Gordon Brown. Mr Smith criticised his intervention as "truly biased and ill-informed".

Mr Smith said it was disappointing that ministers had taken the trouble to go to the US to "sneer at Oxford". The Ivy League universities, such as Harvard - where Miss Spence is studying - and Yale, were now the British universities' main competitors. He also revealed that Magdalen reserved three places every year for students from educationally disadvantaged backgrounds with exceptional "innate ability". The offers would be subject to them getting lower grades than the usual Oxford requirement.

A spokesman for the Department for Education said: "A young person's chances of entering a leading university should depend wholly on ability, not social background."

webTitle: Chester College angry at Hollyoaks image

fields.headline: Students angered by militant image in TV series
fields.standfirst: Guardian Unlimited Education
fields.trailText: If storylines in the Channel 4 series Hollyoaks are to be believed, students at Chester College should be building barricades. But far from revolting, the students have complained that they have been portrayed by the soap opera as militant protesters.
fields.body:
If storylines in the Channel 4 series Hollyoaks are to be believed, students at Chester College should be building barricades. But far from revolting, the students have complained that they have been portrayed by the soap opera as militant protesters.

A storyline in which a college magazine editor organised a sit-in was the last straw for the Chester students, who say they are fed up with being compared to the students in the fictional show.

"Students at other universities think we are a bunch of radicals and militants because that's how the students are portrayed in Hollyoaks," said student union president Gordon Reay. "They assume that the college in the programme is Chester College, because Hollyoaks is set in the city.

"This is not the 1960s or 1970s - we get on very well with our institution, and the programme's portrayal of students is outdated."

He said that even when students had become involved in a national protest against tuition fees it had been a well organised and professional demonstration.

"The way they portray the college is consistently inaccurate. As a student union we don't go round shouting at people."

The union has in the past written to Mersey Television, makers of Hollyoaks, objecting to a storyline it considered to be politically incorrect.

Far from organising student protests, the union was more likely to be helping students with academic problems or financial difficulties, as well as helping the college gain university status, Mr Reay said.

"We are going to write to the programme makers again because I am sure the public views students as militant people who sleep in late and dodge taxes.

He added: "Programmes like these reinforce that view."

Robin Gill, vice-president of the union, said the sit-in storyline had made him cringe.

Hollyoaks producer Michael Rolfe - who was arrested outside Leeds town hall during a student demo in the 1960s - apologised for not answering the students' original letter of complaint about the allegedly politically incorrect storyline.

He promised an open dialogue with them in future.

"Hollyoaks is not a documentary, it is a drama," he said. "People must take on board that it is a fantasy and a fiction. But I am aware that the picture on demonstrations has changed. I accept that students are more businesslike and prepared to discuss matters than they used to be."

He said care was taken on Hollyoaks about political correctness, and that the programme depicted the editor of a student magazine, not a student connected to the student union.

Hollyoaks was devised by Phil Redmond, chairman of Mersey Television. The programme makers describe it as a teenage drama, aimed at viewers aged between 16 and 22.

Background

The council is a tax-payer funded organisation founded in 1913 to tackle tuberculosis. It took its current title in 1920 by royal charter and now funds research into all areas of medical and related science. It runs three main institutes and about 50 smaller units, as well as funding independent research.

webTitle: Humour key to management guru success

fields.headline: Humour key to management guru success
fields.trailText: A sense of humour is key to the success of management gurus, say researchers Dr Tim Clark and Dr David Greatbatch, of King's College, London.
fields.body:
A sense of humour is key to the success of management gurus, say researchers Dr Tim Clark and Dr David Greatbatch, of King's College, London.

"Initially," said Dr Greatbatch, "we weren't really looking at humour. When we set up the 'Talk in Training' project, we wanted to look at management gurus and their public performances, but throughout the study it became increasingly apparent that humour was a central issue."

Top performers on the management circuit, such as Tom Peters, Rosabeth Moss Kanter and Gary Hamil, employed humour to keep their managerial audiences on their side, he explained. "After analysing a large number of videos of such performances, and interviewing some of the top names on the management circuit, it became clear that because the gurus are there to convince managers to take on new and often radical managing practices there is a great risk of the speaker alienating their own audience. Listeners may well feel threatened or criticised by the speakers, and to combat this, they make people laugh.

"Laughter works because it allows the audience to affiliate with the speaker, to generate a rapport, without automatically suggesting they are taking the underlying point on board. They feel less pinned down."

Dr Greatbatch and Dr Clark applied to the Economic and Social Reserch Council (ESRC) for funding for their research in 1998 because they felt that the work of management gurus affected not only management practice, but, through a drip-down effect, also the working lives of a large section of the population. "Very little work had been done on what we perceived to be a very important area," said Dr Greatbatch. "I'm sure that that was one of the reasons our proposal was successful."

The duo also feel that their £33,000 application, which covered expenses and replacement teaching costs, was accepted because they had already secured access to resources and contacts.

Dr Greatbactch said: "Prior to the application we secured access to about £30,000 worth of video footage which we wanted to carefully go through and analyse. When making an application I think it is vital to demonstrate that what you're proposing is do-able. It also helped us that our methodological approach - looking at videos of real interaction in a management context - was innovative."

The project is now officially complete, and the researchers now intend to further their investigations into the relationship between public speeches and laughter by turning their attention to politicians. "We can't assume it'll be the same story there," said Dr Greatbatch. "Politicians may well use humour for an entirely different purpose."

fields.headline: The future of language studies
fields.trailText: The study of modern languages risks becoming either a rarefied study of obscurity or purely industry driven, according to detractors from either side of a debate about the future of languages in UK universities.
fields.body:
The study of modern languages risks becoming either a rarefied study of obscurity or purely industry driven, according to detractors from either side of a debate about the future of languages in UK universities.

Practitioners say the teaching of modern language courses for undergraduates has long been distanced from the leading research.

"The problem is that people who become involved with research have very specialised areas of interest, but most people involved in teaching want to see them more involved with pedagogical research," said Elspeth Jones, secretary of the University Council of Modern Languages, vice chair of the standing conference of heads of modern languages in universities and director of the centre for language study at Leeds Metropolitan University.

But Michael Worton, vice-provost of University College London and Fielden professor of French language and literature, argues the real danger is that, as a result of fears over decreasing applications for undergraduate courses, language departments may be forced to give up their specialist studies of cultural, political and social linguistics.

"We should not become a glorified Berlitz. We have a real contribution to make to people's quality of life through research. It cannot just be about an undergraduate's employability," Professor Worton said.

Both sides of the debate might have some ground to concede: moving towards a greater skills emphasis in undergraduate teaching may not only be about employability, but about helping students in whatever they go on to do. And lecturers that are failing to keep up with advances in pedagogical research may find that, in the long run, they have made more work for themselves.

At least that's the unifying perspective of Mike Kelly, professor of French at Southampton University and director of the learning and teaching support network for language, linguistics and area studies.

He explained, "A lot of people are teaching in the same way they were taught. We're trying to address that. But also, at the moment most students are being taught only about, say, France and French. It's increasingly important that the skills they learn in relating to France are transferable, if they end up working in Japan. We need to develop programmes that take that into mind."

fields.headline: Lost innocence
fields.standfirst: Keith Devlin salutes the mathematician Kurt Gosdel, who would have been 95 on Saturday
fields.trailText: Keith Devlin salutes the mathematician Kurt Gosdel, who would have been 95 on Saturday
fields.body:
T his coming Saturday marks the birthday of the mathematician Kurt Gödel. Born in what was then Austria, on April 28 1906, Gödel died in Princeton, New Jersey on January 14 1978, having developed a paranoia that he was being poisoned and, as a result, starving himself to death (an altogether odd end for one of the greatest logicians the world has ever known).

Two years ago, when Time magazine conducted a poll to determine the 20 most influential thinkers of the 20th century, Gödel was one of just two mathematicians in the score. He came in ninth, ahead of astronomer Edwin Hubble, physicist Enrico Fermi, philosopher and economist John Maynard Keynes, transistor inventor William Shockley, biochemists James Watson and Francis Crick who discovered the double helix pattern of DNA, polio vaccine developer Jonas Salk, and world wide web creator Tim Berners-Lee. (Albert Einstein ended up as Time's person of the century.)

Gödel is best known for his discovery, in 1931, of the famous Gödel Incompleteness Theorem. In everyday terms, this says that no matter how hard you try, you will never be able to reduce all of mathematics to the application of fixed rules. Regardless of how many rules and procedures you write down, there will always be some true facts that you can't prove.

Some scientists, most notably the Oxford mathematician and physicist Sir Roger Penrose, have used Gödel's Incompleteness Theorem to argue that the human brain does not operate like a computer, and in particular that artificial intelligence is not achievable. According to Penrose's interpretation of Gödel's theorem, mathematics has an element that is completely creative.

The above summary of the Incompleteness Theorem is a bit, dare I say, incomplete. Here's what Gödel really did.

Because mathematics deals with abstractions, you cannot establish mathematical facts by making observations in the world or by performing experiments the way other scientists do. You have to use proofs - logically sound arguments. Those arguments have to start somewhere. So, you start off by writing down some initial set of basic assumptions, known as axioms.

The axioms are supposed to be so simple that their truth is beyond question. Things like, two straight lines are either parallel or else meet in exactly one point, or when you add two numbers it does not matter which one goes first. (The first of these two examples turned out to be less "obviously true" than first appeared, but that's another story.)

Once you've written down the axioms, to decide whether some given statement is true or false, you try to prove it from the axioms.

This way of doing mathematics was introduced by the ancient Greeks 2,500 years ago, and worked well throughout history. It was always assumed that the only thing that could prevent you from being able to decide the truth or falsity of any mathematical question that came up was if you'd overlooked one or more basic assumptions to put into your list of axioms. And that was easy to fix: just add in the missing axiom(s).

Gödel shattered this belief, and changed forever our understanding of mathematics. His Incompleteness Theorem says that you can never find enough axioms. No matter how carefully you try to make sure you have written down all the basic assumptions, there will always be some questions that you can't answer. Mathematical knowledge is destined to remain forever incomplete.

In fact, the situation is even worse. Gödel went on to show that one of the questions you cannot answer is whether your chosen set of axioms is consistent or not. You can never be sure that, in writing down your axioms, you haven't made a mistake and introduced some subtle conflict.

Until Gödel's result, everyone assumed that, unlike all the other sciences, mathe matics offered absolute certainty, and one path to perfect, sure knowledge. To some extent, that's still true. Pythagoras's theorem about right-triangles is as true today as it was when it was first proved 3,000 years ago, and it will remain true forever. Once a mathematician has proved something, it's truth is permanent. (Unlike the situation in any other science, where theories are constantly being modified or overturned.) However, what Gödel discovered was that this kind of certainty does not extend to all questions of mathematics. Some remain beyond proof. If you think such a statement is true, you simply have to take it as an act of faith.

In that sense, Gödel's discovery can be regarded as the end of the age of innocence in the field of mathematics.

 Professor Keith Devlin's latest book, The Maths Gene: Why Everyone Has It But Most People Don't Use It, is a Phoenix paperback, £7.99
