fields.headline: Tracey finds her voice
fields.standfirst: Jonathan Jones is bewitched by a gentler, more passionate Tracey Emin
fields.trailText: Jonathan Jones is bewitched by a gentler, more passionate Tracey Emin.
fields.body:
Since getting drunk on late night television, Tracey Emin has achieved the kind of fame that makes critics feel a little sidelined. What does it matter what I say about her new solo show at White Cube2, given this level of celebrity? All the things that are irritating about the rent-a-quote, self-dramatising person I watched having a bizarrely hateful conflict with John Humphreys on Have I Got News For You at the weekend were in my mind as I followed the ridiculously huge press crowd into the gallery, to be instantly charmed by a show as gentle as it is extravagant, as disciplined as it is passionate.

Birds caw around a lifesize rotting wooden helter-skelter and by the dunes there's a mad little garden with a birdhouse on stilts that you climb up a ladder to peer into. Nearby, a mother and daughter are discussing why the mother doesn't think her child should have a child. You can taste the salty air, hear the rattles and shrieks of the ghost train. Emin has already excavated her Margate past as ruthlessly as a gull sucking out a crab's insides. You would have thought that after all the revelations and confessions she'd be a bit lost for words by now. The memories would have dried up, the stories withered on the vine. Perhaps they have, because her new work is more visual and less explicit than any before. Instead of stopping you like the Ancient Mariner and telling you about the lousy week she spent in her rancid bed, she takes you on a more winding path.

The central fact of this show is the helter-skelter whose spiralling slide towers over everything. It's creaky, gothic, mysterious. As she elaborates in a blanket work that describes her life as "Hellter fucking skelter", Emin portrays herself as lost in the funfair, both in her life as a celeb and in her relationships. "You see it's a spirial (sic) which goes down." Scary, fragmented insults, sewn in radically distinct shapes and colours, accuse people of envy, plead "But I love you". But they don't exhaust the image of the helter-skelter; you don't feel it has all been said. It is not confession. It's art.

There is nothing unmediated about Emin's art. Like any successful contemporary artist, she has assistants, fabricators. She wasn't up all hours with a hammer, nailing that slide together. She was too busy appearing on Have I Got News For You. Pure self-expression is, in any case, an impossibility in art. As Ernst Gombrich pointed out in a famous essay on the fallacy of expressionism, all art draws on pre-existing visual schemata; artists do not see the world like Miranda in The Tempest but through previous art. Even Turner began by pastiching Claude.

The trouble with Emin, made manifest in her Turner Prize showing, is that she can seem naive about the pitfalls of expressionism to a degree that brings her to the brink of being a really bad artist. Recently she published a self-indulgent article in the Times about her relationship with Munch's The Scream. She seemed to claim a kind of divine communion with it without considering that the painting might be an aesthetic masterpiece, a work of art that communicates through line and colour. She talks about My Bed as if it was the first time anyone had ever thought of doing it, but there is a long history of artists exhibiting their beds: Robert Rauschenberg, Robert Gober and Felix Gonzales-Torres have made poetical bed art. So it's not a pure statement at all, but a mannerist one.

Here, however, Emin emerges as an artist, not just a callow diarist. There's a generous imagination at work here that doesn't instantly translate itself into words. Even the words don't instantly translate themselves into words. Her marriage of rhetoric and dyslexia can be playful as well as furious. "May Day, Be Day, D Day," she's scrawled under a sketch of a woman on the bog. Next to a naked woman whose scribbly body sits alone on the white page, she writes, "It's just an idea of space".

There's a delicacy in a series of little drawings of birds, rough and rapid. Emin juxtaposes her sketched sparrows with the words she imagines them speaking. "Shall we go to bed?" asks one. "I've done that better than I thought I would," another congratulates itself, fat on a nice worm. Emin has broken out of the neo- minimalist, ironic conventions of contemporary art to find a voice that is not afraid of emotion or poetry. If it sometimes grates, here it sings.

Nearby is Concorde smothered in newspaper, stuck on a pole; the plane that once symbolised perfect flight has become an image of failure, crashing in flames. It's not surprising that as the most famous "young" artist in Britain, even more famous than Damien Hirst because she's good on telly, Emin should be full of thoughts of her own destiny - according to the crude narratives of modern fame - which is to crash and burn. But she avoids that narrative cliche by complicating her art. The oddest, most delightful thing in this show is a fantasy dwelling that could have come straight out of Dickens, inhabited by some Mr Cheeribottom eccentric. It's a little wooden contraption on stilts standing over a flower bed, and you climb up a rickety wooden ladder to look in through a tiny peephole. Inside, on video but so close it feels real, a jolly fat man - I think her father - comes towards you bearing a big red flower, which he pushes into your face.

At this point those art historical ghosts return. Emin's peepshow recalls the most celebrated peepshow in art, Marcel Duchamp's Etant Donnés, the work he spent his last years making. Duchamp's installation invites you to press your eye to a hole in a wooden door, through which you see a naked woman, her legs splayed. Duchamp plays a cruel trick on us. Emin's peepshow appears to be a riposte. Instead of something nasty, she gives us something nice.

The return to childhood is more troubling when you sit on a child-sized wooden chair to listen to her mother telling her why she's not cut out for motherhood. Her art is characterised by its texture, the rough-hewn quality of expressionism with a ritualistic use of materials and motifs; blankets, wood, drawings. This is reminiscent of Joseph Beuys, who declared that "the silence of Marcel Duchamp is overrated." Emin is like Beuys in other ways. They both talk nonsense and draw beautifully - the structures and shapes in this show feel like drawings translated into three dimensions. And like Beuys, you can dismiss her as a woolly-minded fraud or hail her as a poet. It depends what side of bed you get out of in the morning. Perhaps the polluted Shoreditch air was depriving my brain of oxygen, but I inclined to the poet side.

 Tracey Emin: You Forgot To Kiss My Soul opens at White Cube2, London N1 (020-7930 5373) tomorrow and runs till May 26.

Her marriage of rhetoric and dyslexia can be playful as well as furious. "May Day, Be Day, D Day," she's scrawled under a sketch of a woman on the bog. Next to a naked woman whose scribbly body sits alone on the white page, she writes, "It's just an idea of space". There's a delicacy in a series of little drawings of birds, rough and rapid. Emin juxtaposes her sketched sparrows with the words she imagines them speaking. "Shall we go to bed?" asks one. "I've done that better than I thought I would," another congratulates itself, fat on a nice worm. Emin has broken out of the neo- minimalist, ironic conventions of contemporary art to find a voice that is not afraid of emotion or poetry. If it sometimes grates, here it sings. Nearby is Concorde smothered in newspaper, stuck on a pole; the plane that once symbolised perfect flight has become an image of failure, crashing in flames. It's not surprising that as the most famous "young" artist in Britain, even more famous than Damien Hirst because she's good on telly, Emin should be full of thoughts of her own destiny - according to the crude narratives of modern fame - which is to crash and burn. But she avoids that narrative cliche by complicating her art. The oddest, most delightful thing in this show is a fantasy dwelling that could have come straight out of Dickens, inhabited by some Mr Cheeribottom eccentric. It's a little wooden contraption on stilts standing over a flower bed, and you climb up a rickety wooden ladder to look in through a tiny peephole. Inside, on video but so close it feels real, a jolly fat man - I think her father - comes towards you bearing a big red flower, which he pushes into your face. At this point those art historical ghosts return. Emin's peepshow recalls the most celebrated peepshow in art, Marcel Duchamp's Etant Donnés, the work he spent his last years making. Duchamp's installation invites you to press your eye to a hole in a wooden door, through which you see a naked woman, her legs splayed. Duchamp plays a cruel trick on us. Emin's peepshow appears to be a riposte. Instead of something nasty, she gives us something nice. The return to childhood is more troubling when you sit on a child-sized wooden chair to listen to her mother telling her why she's not cut out for motherhood. Her art is characterised by its texture, the rough-hewn quality of expressionism with a ritualistic use of materials and motifs; blankets, wood, drawings. This is reminiscent of Joseph Beuys, who declared that "the silence of Marcel Duchamp is overrated." Emin is like Beuys in other ways. They both talk nonsense and draw beautifully - the structures and shapes in this show feel like drawings translated into three dimensions. And like Beuys, you can dismiss her as a woolly-minded fraud or hail her as a poet. It depends what side of bed you get out of in the morning. Perhaps the polluted Shoreditch air was depriving my brain of oxygen, but I inclined to the poet side.  Tracey Emin: You Forgot To Kiss My Soul opens at White Cube2, London N1 (020-7930 5373) tomorrow and runs till May 26.

fields.headline: Blooming marvellous
fields.standfirst: Climate change means flowers are opening sooner.  Sanjida O'Connell  looks at the impact
fields.trailText: Climate change means flowers are opening sooner.  Sanjida O'Connell  looks at the impact
fields.body:
For the past 35 years a woman in Norwich has been recording the flowering times of the butter-yellow aconites which grow in her garden. Instead of blooming in January, they are now flowering a whole month early, in December. She is not the only one to notice these changes.

"It is easier to detect in plants," says Tim Sparks, from the Centre for Ecology and Hydrology, Monkswood, Cambridge, "there's been a three week to one month advance in spring plants over the last 50 years." His research, as well as data gathered by other scientists, shows that there is a definite trend towards earlier flowering in plants and reproduction in animals. Now a new mathematical model can help explain how and why climate is having a major impact on our ecology.

In Origin of Species, Darwin wrote, "Climate plays an important part in determining the average numbers of a species, and periodical seasons of extreme cold and drought, I believe to be the most effective of all checks." However, few models of climate change have actively sought to understand how weather can affect sex and death in plants and animals. The model, created by assistant professor of biology, Eric Post, from Penn State University, is the first of its kind, incorporating biology to help quantify ecological responses to climate change.

"We hear with increasing frequency reports about birds nesting earlier and flowers blooming sooner," says Dr Post. "Those reports get a lot of attention because they provide convincing evidence that species are responding to climate change. But if we really want to understand what is happening, and make predictions about what will happen with future climate changes, we need to get at the mechanisms and relationships behind the changes." Dr Post used data collected by a botanist for 50 years in Norway on three species of flowering plant: two kinds of anemone and colt's foot. Dr Post included the North Atlantic Oscillation (NAO) to account for climatic variability. The NAO is an alteration in atmospheric pressures over Iceland and the Azores. It's responsible for a third of the variation in rainfall in the Northern Hemisphere, and over half the variation in temperature.

What Dr Post and his colleagues discovered was that flowering was directly related to the NAO. After a warm winter, the flowers he studied bloomed earlier. The climate did not impact directly on the plants themselves, but on "resources". Resources in the case of plants would be nutrients in the soil, but Dr Post deliberately chose this rather nebulous term so that the model could apply to other species too.

The effect was strongest on early blooming plants and those found in southern latitudes. The density of other flowering plants also had an affect. As Dr Post says, the timing of reproduction influences the numbers, growth and viability of offspring. One possible interpretation of the results is that the density of other plants triggers earlier blooming in order to minimise competition for food or pollinators.

His theoretical predictions accord with data gathered by Tim Sparks and his colleagues. They have looked at 24 species of flowering plants, such as hazel and wood anemones, between 1891 and 1948. All of them show earlier flowering in response to a milder temperature. A quarter of a decade of data on laying dates for British birds, from great tits to sky larks, shows that eggs are being laid earlier. The warmer winters are prompting aphids and moths to emerge sooner, frogs to spawn and bees to be more active earlier in the year.

Dr Post has looked at how the NAO can specifically influence animals. He found that red deer and reindeer breed earlier when the winters are warmer, but that the deer produce smaller calves which grow into smaller, less fertile adults. Climatic fluctuations can even influence what kind of creatures live where and with whom. In a wood near Dlouhá Loucka in the Czech republic lives a group of pied and collared flycatchers which have been studied for the past 13 years. The two species compete with one another to the detriment of the pied flycatcher. The collared birds frequently evict the pied species from nest sites, and the latter are forced into poorer territories. Their breeding is delayed and in some cases they are unable to breed at all. Dr Post was able to show that the fate of the pied flycatchers is influenced by the NAO; in warmer winters the collared flycatchers produce more offspring and are able to suppress the breeding rates of the pied flycatchers.

Could these warmer winters be a direct result of global warming? Sparks says: "It is hard to believe that man hasn't had an effect on the climate - though not all Americans think so." The real problem for species is variation, according to Dr Post. In general there is a trend for increasingly warmer temperatures, but temperature deviates on a year-by-year basis. Sounding as if he's talking about an Escher painting, he says: "The change in climate is like a staircase going up, but in profile, you can see it goes up and down."

Animals have to respond to these changes, those that are unable to die out. Warmer winters could be beneficial, says Sparks. Quite apart from our own desire for a little more heat, butterfly populations could survive longer and increase their range; currently we only have about 60 species, whereas France enjoys 200. However, there is a downside. Not all species can adjust and may be indirectly and adversely affected, such as the pied flycatchers. "We could have pests we'd rather not have," says Sparks, "insects that carry plant diseases, moths which feed on bark." Flowers that bloom early may succumb to a late frost or snow, and those that leaf too soon could be devastated by drought later in the year. Darwin, as usual, was correct; but not even he could have foreseen how human activity could be the most effective of all checks. To help record changes taking place in plants and animals, go to:

 www.woodland-trust.org.uk/phenology

fields.headline: Richard Schultes
fields.standfirst: A leading authority on the hallucinogenic plants of Amazonia, he acknowledged his debt to the rainforest natives who shared their knowledge
fields.trailText: A leading authority on the hallucinogenic plants of Amazonia, he acknowledged his debt to the rainforest natives who shared their knowledge.
fields.body:
The work of Richard Schultes, who has died aged 86, was in the tradition of some of the great botanical explorers of Amazonia. One of the founders of modern ethno-botany and ethno-pharmacology, he researched the many uses of plants by native cultures, such as the Amazonian Indians, and documented the medicinal application of more than 2,000 of them.

Schultes considered it part of his research to try out preparations, such as coca powder, with the tribesmen with whom he lived. He became the leading authority on hallucinogenic plants such as peyote and ayahuasca, which are used by Indian tribal cultures for ritual purposes.

In the 1950s and 1960s, he influenced the likes of Aldous Huxley, William Burroughs and Timothy Leary, and the drug culture to which they helped to give birth. But, more importantly, he gathered some 24,000 Amazonian plant specimens, of which 120 now carry his name, though Schultes always acknowledged the prior botanical knowledge of his Amazonian tutors.

In the introduction to his Where The Gods Reside (1988), he wrote: "A number of years ago, I heard a high ranking South American diplomat describe the Amazon as a 'desert of trees that had to be cleared for the benefit of mankind'. Yet, investigations by Colombian and foreign botanists have recognised an unbelievably rich flora, and the detailed knowledge of it possessed by its native inhabitants. Advancing acculturation and civilisation everywhere spell the doom of extinction of this knowledge faster even than the extinction of species themselves as a result of forest devastation."

Realising this grave threat, Schultes became a pioneering campaigner on protecting the forests from inappropriate, short-term development. He was one of the first researchers to point out that the conversion of forests to cattle ranches was a folly, because the soils would become infertile in a matter of years. He never tired of telling visitors about his deep concern about Amazonia and its tribal cultures.

As a child, Schultes, the son of a Boston plumbing engineer, collected, and dried, plant specimens. Bedridden in early childhood, he became fascinated by Amazonia through reading the 19th-century British naturalist Richard Spruce's Notes Of A Botanist On The Amazon And The Andes. He was educated at East Boston High School and then won a scholarship to Harvard. As an undergraduate, he researched and wrote on the hallucinogen peyote, ritualistically used by Oklahoma's Kiowa Indians. Having received his doctorate - on plants used by the Indians of Oaxaca state in southern Mexico - in 1941, Schultes decided to study the medicinal, narcotic and poisonous plants used by natives of the north-western Amazon, mainly in Colombia.

He spent 14 years almost uninterrupted in this area, journeying its rivers in an aluminium canoe. Schultes initially went to the region to investigate the source of curare, a composite hunting poison made by many differ ent tribes from various plant ingredients. Curare's special characteristic is that it kills the animal hit by a hunter's dart or arrow by paralysing its muscles, but does not kill the person eating its meat.

These properties were found to make it valuable as a muscle relaxant in hospital surgery. He helped to identify more than 70 plant species that were used to produce different versions of the drug. Since the 1930s, curare has been widely used in medicine. At first it was supplied to American and European hospitals by tribal people themselves, but when it was synthesised in laboratories, the trading relationship with the forest people ended.

During the war years, Schultes's work was directed towards the investigation of rubber trees of the genus Hevea, native to the north-western Amazon forests. The main purpose then was to encourage indigenous groups to harvest latex from wild stands of these trees for the war effort after the Japanese occupation of Malaya. After the war, he changed the focus of this work to the collection of living plant material for cultivation in the plantations of tropical countries of Asia and Africa.

After going back to Harvard in 1954 to teach botany, he continued to return every year with some of his students. Schultes spent most of his time in the Amazon in the villages of tribal people. His approach acknowledged that people who have lived in a complex natural environ ment for a long time will have acquired a profound knowledge of the botanical riches that it contains and will also have developed complex language systems to match that knowledge.

Schultes believed that tribal people should be approached with the respect due to all people. He treated the often fearsome-looking individuals he met with disarming cour tesy and never carried a firearm. "I do not believe in hostile Indians," he said. "All that is required to bring out their gentlemanliness is reciprocal gentlemanliness."

After his retirement from Harvard in 1985 - where he was director of the botanical museum - Schultes, professor emeritus, was honoured with botany's "Nobel prize", the Gold Medal of London's Linnean Society, in 1992. He edited Economic Botany journal (1962-80), published hundreds of scientific articles, and wrote 10 books, including Plants Of The Gods (1979), with Albert Hofmann, the Swiss chemist who synthesised LSD.

Schultes was a man of athletic stature, but with the bespectacled face and high forehead of a man of letters. He was fearless, despite many minor and major accidents in his treks and canoejourneys across Amazonia.

When filming with him for the Channel 4 documentary Jungle Pharmacy in 1988, I asked him about his adventures there. He answered: "I have never really had adventures in the Amazon. In civilisation there are many dangerous situations. We can get run over by a truck or bus any day. There are too many books by people who go to the Amazon for two or three weeks and escape horrible death on every other page of the book they have to write."

Sadly, despite his warnings, Schultes had to witness the continuing destruction of forests in many parts of Amazonia till the very end of his life. But his work contributed to the Colombian government's decision to set aside some 45m acres of land for use only by the sparse Indian population. Of this, 2m acres have been designated Sector Schultes, in honour of his work in the area. The naming of many plants after him and the protection of such a large area of rainforest will be a permanent testimony to Schultes's pioneering conservation work.

In 1959, he married opera singer Dorothy McNeil, who survives him, as do their two sons and a daughter.

fields.headline: Robert Gray
fields.standfirst: He unravelled the links between class and language
fields.trailText: He unravelled the links between class and language.
fields.body:
Professor Robert ("Robbie") Gray, who has died of cancer aged 55, made a remarkable contribution to the discipline of social history, effectively redrawing the map of the mental and class landscapes of the mid-19th century.

Robbie was born in Glasgow into an academic family, took a first at Cambridge and completed his doctorate at Edinburgh. The ground-breaking work in his thesis was converted into his first book, The Labour Aristocracy in Victorian Edinburgh (1976), which, along with his subsequent writings on the labour aristocracy, demonstrated once and for all that there was no automatic link between the class identity of individuals and the discursive frameworks which they deployed.

His work was marked by a willingness to take risks in order to disinter the consciousness of social groups, and by a desire to attribute to previous generations a consciousness as complex as our own. In 1981, he wrote The Aristocracy of Labour in 19th Century Britain 1850-1914. His last book, published in 1996, The Factory Question and Industrial England 1830-1860, used a wide range of primary mate rial, but was most remarkable for the subtle and nuanced way in which Gray also used literary texts of the period.

Latterly, with the support of a grant from the British Academy, Robbie undertook a major project on autobiography in the mid-Victorian period. Working with Donna Loftus, now at the Open University, he had begun to think through the implications of the ways in which class differences could be signalled in the style and metaphors of written and reported text.

Robbie joined the Communist party in 1970 and never left it, but his adherence to socialist politics was never doctrinaire. The same year, he joined what is now the University of Portsmouth, was appointed reader in 1986 and professor in 1997. He played a full role in the life of the university, always insisting on the vital link between teaching and research. He was a pioneering influence when Portsmouth established its history degrees, which placed a high premium on the relationship between the social and the cultural.

Robbie was fiercely loyal to his students, and they in turn learned to cope with the way in which he sometimes used his silences as a teaching tool in seminars. His occasionally waspish sense of humour always derided pomposity and self-regard.

In 1976, he joined the editorial board of Social History and wrote influential articles for that journal, for Marxism Today, Urban History and many others.

He will be sadly missed by colleagues, students and friends, but most of all by his family. Robbie had an extremely happy marriage to Joan Gray, who had, he noted in the acknowledgments to his 1996 book, "made everything possible".

Tragically, he died when his major project with Loftus on autobiographies was about to come to fruition. The effect and significance of his work has been widely acknowledged. His style of intellectual commitment and seriousness is sorely needed in a period where "spin" sometimes counts more than substance.

He was very attached to Joan's daughters, Marian and Rosie, and is survived by them and Joan.

fields.headline: Smoking pill link to 35 deaths
fields.standfirst:
Inquest told of pill's adverse effects

Special report: smoking
fields.trailText: GlaxoSmithKline, the world's second largest drug company, conceded yesterday that the anti-smoking drug Zyban was suspected of causing adverse reactions in 35 people who have died in the UK since it was introduced last June.
fields.body:
GlaxoSmithKline, the world's second largest drug company, conceded yesterday that the anti-smoking drug Zyban was suspected of causing adverse reactions in 35 people who have died in the UK since it was introduced last June.

The acknowledgement came at the inquest of Kerry Weston, 21, a British Airways air hostess who was found dead in a hotel room in Nairobi, Kenya, in January, two weeks after she began taking the drug to help her quit her 15-a-day habit.

Giving evidence on behalf of the pharmaceutical giant, Dr Howard Marsh, senior medical adviser on Zyban to Glaxo, said that while there had been 35 deaths following adverse reactions to Zyban, there was no conclusive proof that any were directly linked to the drug.

"Although there has been this number of reports of fatal events, it has to be said these are suspected adverse reactions," he told the inquest at Hertford coroner's court. "We are very keen to look at each and every one of these cases very, very carefully to see if there is a contribution from Zyban to any of these deaths. But the contribution of Zyban to any of them remains unproven."

Zyban, which is taken in pill form, has been prescribed to 360,000 patients in the UK. Of that number, 5,352 have reported adverse reactions. Zyban is a "black triangle" drug, meaning it is new to the market and has therefore to be monitored closely.

The Committee on the Safety of Medicines (CSM), which monitors the introduction of new drugs and has scrutinised Zyban use, said these figures where consistent with its expectations.

"Zyban is used in a population of patients who are put at risk because of smoking and, therefore, reports of deaths of patients receiving Zyban are to be expected," said Professor Alasdair Breckenridge, CSM chairman.

"Where information is available, the majority of patients who died had underlying conditions that provide an alternative explanation. The CSM considers that the reports received are in line with the known safety profile of Zyban, which is fully reflected in the product information for health professionals and patients."

The inquest into Ms Weston's death heard that in addition to Zyban she had taken non-prescription anti-malarial tablets and a sleeping compound on the day she died. Dr Marsh told the court that in future Glaxo would be warning that Zyban should not be taken in conjunction with anti-malarial drugs.

He said people with a history of seizures, epilepsy, manic depression or liver disease were already warned not to take the drug.

Ms Weston was prescribed the drug by the BA cabin crew GP, Dr Mark Andrew.

"She described great difficulty with the problem of smoking," Dr Andrews told the inquest.

"She requested help with this ... and what she called the pill for smoking."

Aware that the drug was under scrutiny, Dr Andrews prescribed a fortnight's supply and told Ms Weston to return when she had taken the pills.

Her mother, Eileen Weston, told the court that shortly after her daughter began taking Zyban she passed out at Gatwick airport after returning from Baltimore.

"She remembered feeling unwell and then all she remembered was waking up on the bathroom floor as if she had gone to sleep," Mrs Weston said. "Her words were that she thought she had fallen asleep in the bathroom but her head was very sore when she stood up."

Shortly afterwards, Ms Weston flew to Nairobi. Colleagues on the plane said she seemed well, but became concerned when she failed to turn up for a drink in the cabin crew's hotel.

Steward Philip Stuart said hotel staff had to force open the door to her room. He said: "We could see Kerry inside lying on the floor with her head close to the door. "We put our hand in and felt her neck. She was still warm and clammy."

When the group entered the room they discovered Kerry had vomited and that her nose and legs were turning blue.

Zyban or bupropin hydrochloride, developed as an anti-depressant, was found to ease the desire for nicotine, even in heavy smokers. It works by supressing the neurotransmitters dopamine and noradrenaline - the brain's "pleasure centres" - which are stimulated by nicotine. Glaxo sank millions into marketing it. More than 1m Americans claim to have stopped smoking after taking the drug.

fields.headline: Dealer 'snatched Bacon paintings away'
fields.standfirst: Court hearing on claim that could run to £100m highlights artist's unique relationship with 'minder'
fields.trailText: An art dealer acted as the painter Francis Bacon's "keeper or minder", removing his paintings to her gallery "as soon as the paint was dry", a high court judge was told yesterday.
fields.body:
An art dealer acted as the painter Francis Bacon's "keeper or minder", removing his paintings to her gallery "as soon as the paint was dry", a high court judge was told yesterday.

This was said to be one of the principal roles of Valerie Beston, who organised the artist's life for more than 30 years.

The allegations were made by Geoffrey Vos QC, who called Bacon Britain's greatest 20th century artist. He was acting for Bacon's estate in a claim which could run as high as £100m. The estate is suing Marlborough Fine Art (London) and the Liechtenstein-based Marlborough International Fine Art Establishment for breach of duty and undue influence over Bacon.

Mr Vos was speaking at a preliminary procedural hearing of a complex case which is expected to bring the dead painter's often desperate life back into the limelight when it is fully argued in January.

Mr Vos told Mr Justice Patten: "The relationship which is at the root of this litigation, which one suspects will never be found again, is a relationship between Britain's greatest 20th century artist and his dealer. This is a unique case. There is nothing normal or run of the mill about it."

The Marlborough gallery exclusively represented Bacon from 1958 - shortly before he became celebrated and was sometimes getting only a few hundred pounds for a canvas - until he died in 1992 as the world's highest-priced living artist.

Marlborough are contesting the claims of the estate, of which Brian Clarke was appointed executor in 1998. It is urging the judge to strike out the case this week.

The estate accuses the gallery of retaining up to 70% of the sale value of Bacon's paintings. It says a fair share of the proceeds would have been about a third. It alleges Marlborough has not yet demonstrated that it has paid for all the paintings it received. The estate is demanding a full accounting of the gallery's role to show that a fair balance was struck between its interests and those of Bacon. It also alleges that Marlborough have failed to account for the proceeds of a sale of 47 series of Bacon lithographs.

Mr Vos told the court Ms Beston could be described "as the defendants would have it, as Bacon's assistant", or "as one might say, his keeper or minder".

"But what is beyond doubt is that Valerie Beston, a director of Marlborough UK at all times material to the case, organised much if not all of Francis Bacon's professional and personal life.

"One of her principal roles on behalf of Marlborough UK was the removal of the paintings that he completed to its own gallery as soon as the paint was dry".

Outside court, the estate said in a statement: "It is right that the truth about the UK's pre-eminent artist and the treatment of his work be established and not buried."

Bacon left his £10m fortune to his longstanding friend John Edwards, 51, an illiterate east Londoner who now lives in Thailand.

The case continues.

fields.headline: Phoenix highlights hypocrisy
fields.standfirst: The mass lunacy in evidence throughout the foot and mouth crisis has reached its zenith with the reaction to a cuddly calf called Phoenix, writes Madeleine Bunting
fields.trailText: The mass lunacy in evidence throughout the foot and mouth crisis has reached its zenith with the reaction to a cuddly calf called Phoenix, writes Madeleine Bunting.
fields.body:
The foot and mouth crisis has been characterised throughout by a kind of mass lunacy that has beggared belief, but today it reaches its apotheosis. Having consigned millions of animals to a completely unnecessary death, the nation falls head over heels in love with a cuddly Charolais calf called Phoenix.

Its fluffy white curls and cute eyes are staring out from most of the newspapers today; it was considered an important enough issue to get a top slot in the BBC news; unbelievably, the decision over whether it was to live or die went all the way up to Downing Street. Has there ever been a prime ministerial statement devoted to the life of a calf before?

There was barely a murmur of protest when Phoenix's mother, dozens of cousins and thousands of contemporaries were killed, but suddenly a torrent of frustrated sentimentality is poured into the plight of this calf.

So, on the very same day as we hear of the extraordinary brouhaha over Phoenix's survival for five days after a cull, we hear of hundreds of pet dogs being abandoned and off loaded by owners fed up with walking them under the foot and mouth restrictions. Never have the English seemed quite so batty in their attitudes to animals: slavishly mercenary and yet still capable of intermittent deep sentimentality.

In fact, the two attitudes are different sides of the same coin: brutality is often masked by a warped tenderness. Now that the virus seems to be finally ebbing, the public is ready to relax their passive quiescence in the horror of this mass cull, and are anxious to reassure themselves that they are not quite so horrible after all.

See, we may be in the process of massacring close to 4m animals but we still care for our lovely cuddly four-legged friends. The only sense to emerge from this pantomime (in which even Downing Street was prepared to play along) is that the rules on culling on contiguous farms is to be relaxed.

Finally, this grim chapter in recent British history is drawing to a close; in a few more weeks, there will be no more nightly footage of mountains of rotting corpses.

What will not fade is how this episode has exposed the brutality of our attitudes towards other living creatures and a sense of breathtaking hypocrisy.

webTitle: New register planned for unemployed MPs

fields.headline: New register planned for unemployed MPs
fields.trailText: New Labour's class of 1997 MPs holding on to wafer-thin majorities in can sleep easier in their beds tonight - Westminster politicians are considering setting up a "Register of ex-MPs" to offer support to members left on the dole after the next election.
fields.body:
New Labour's class of 1997 MPs holding on to wafer-thin majorities in can sleep easier in their beds tonight - Westminster politicians are considering setting up a "Register of ex-MPs" to offer support to members left on the dole after the next election.

The idea, which has cross-party support, is designed to give bewildered former politicians a hand in the outside world after the shock of being booted out by the voters.

More than 600 MPs have left the Commons since 1987 and some have sunk into oblivion since their departure.

The Labour MP Joe Ashton, standing down at the election, is so worried by the phenomenon of disappearing MPs, that he has suggested a register of former politicians so they can be tracked down more readily.

He told the Commons today: "Nobody knows what has happened to them with their jobs or their problems or what advice they might need."

He added that it was difficult for individuals to trace MPs due to restrictions imposed by the Data Protection Act. Mr Ashton said the organisation would be a voluntary one and would not be paid for by the taxpayer.

Margaret Beckett, leader of the house, said: "There is cross-party support for the fact that we should have some discussions along these lines to see whether there can be some voluntary organisation.

"There is actually no record of what has happened to former MPs or indeed to their spouses and it is extremely difficult to make contact. There are many with whom no one is in touch, some of whom are in considerable difficulties."

fields.headline: Kavanagh QC draws 8m
fields.trailText: TV overnights: ITV's two-hour one-off episode of legal drama Kavanagh QC drew nearly 8m viewers, writes Ashley Davies.
fields.body:
Nearly 8m viewers tuned into ITV for a one-off episode of Kavanagh QC last night.

The two-hour John Thaw legal drama began at 8.30pm and pulled in 7.9m viewers, 53% of the audience.

Over on Channel 5, 1.3m watched France beating Portugal at football. The match ran from 7.30pm and earned the broadcaster only a 6% audience share.

Channel 4's Teachers pulled in a steady 2m viewers, an 11% share of the audience, in its 10pm slot.

Apart from the early evening regional news, BBC1's strongest performance of the night was Crimewatch UK. Airing at 9pm, it attracted 5.9m , a 26% share.

webTitle: MPs tackle Fifa over World Cup rights

fields.headline: MPs tackle Fifa over World Cup rights
fields.trailText:
5pm: Fifa's role in handling World Cup TV rights will come under attack tonight in Westminster, writes Ashley Davies.

24.04.2001: World Cup price 'outrageous' says BSkyB
20.04.2001: World Cup chaos as Fifa marketing chief sacked
fields.body:
Fifa's role in handling World Cup television rights will come under renewed attack tonight in Westminster.

Labour backbenchers John Grogan and Ivor Caplin are putting forward an adjournment debate to highlight fears that football fans will have to pay to watch the next two tournaments.

The MPs will repeat calls for the event to remain listed as one of broadcasting's 'crown jewels' and available only on free-to-air television.

The German broadcaster, Kirch, owns the rights and wants UK broadcasters to pay £170m to show the 2002 and 2006 tournaments.

Mr Grogan and Mr Caplin are chairman and treasurer respectively of the Commons all party football group.

webTitle: Ensuring disabled children are seen and heard

fields.headline: Ensuring disabled children are seen and heard
fields.standfirst: Social workers and other professionals do not have the skills or confidence to communicate sufficiently with disabled children though they are twice a likely to suffer all forms of abuse as their able-bodied peers. A training pack aims to change that, writes Chris Cloke
fields.trailText: Social workers and other professionals do not have the skills or confidence to communicate sufficiently with disabled children though they are twice a likely to suffer all forms of abuse as their able-bodied peers. Chris Cloke reports.
fields.body:
Jennifer, who has cerebral palsy, and her able-bodied sister, Paula, were sexually abused by a close relative for several years during their childhood. The abuse only came to light five years after the abuse began when 13-year-old Paula told her mother what had happened.

Jennifer remembers the social worker who came to see them. She says he talked to her parents and to Paula, but she was never asked by anyone if anything had happened to her.

Although the government's Working Together guidance - which sets out how agencies and professionals should collaborate to promote children's welfare and protection - includes disabled children, such situations are still too common. Disabled children and young people are rarely consulted or involved in decisions that affect them, and their wishes are often ignored or misinterpreted because social workers and other professionals do not have the skills or the confidence to communicate with them.

Up to one in 10 children in the UK are classified as disabled. But they often remain physically, geographically and socially isolated, which makes them particularly vulnerable. Studies have shown that disabled children are twice as likely to suffer all forms of abuse as their able-bodied peers.

According to the NSPCC, a third of all children never tell anyone about their abuse. For disabled children, it is both hard for them to tell and less likely others will listen. Denying disabled children and young people a means of communication means many are suffering in silence.

Rosemary Gordon, a training and consultancy manager at the NSPCC said: "How can we protect these children if we do not know what is happening in their lives? Disabled children are losing out because we, the adults, lack the training we need to communicate better with them to help and keep them safe."

To help combat this, the NSPCC and the Joseph Rowntree Foundation have funded Triangle, an organisation working with disabled children and their families, to create a training pack called Two-Way Street. Twelve disabled children have been involved in deciding on its content.

The training pack pulls no punches in explaining to professionals the barriers that can lead to disabled children not being consulted. The Two-Way Street video and handbook should help make professionals more aware of the wide range of ways children show their feelings, from their use of sounds and gestures to facial expressions and signs. The pack aims to increase professional competence and confidence when dealing with disabled children and to highlight common mistakes and misconceptions.

Ms Gordon thinks the main barrier that social workers, health practitioners and other professionals experience when trying to communicate with disabled children is the feeling that they won't be understood. "They worry that trying to communicate is a fruitless task and that a child without speech will not be able to respond to them. But disabled children clearly can, and do, communicate."

Challenging presumptions about disabled children and their ability to communicate is vitally important. In a recent survey, half the professionals questioned reported that training in communicating with disabled children is limited or non-existent.

Triangle's co-director Marcus Page said: "All too often we hear professionals asking: 'Can she talk?' What they really should be asking is: 'How does she communicate?'

"Adults need to adapt their usual methods of interaction. Disabled children are very tolerant of our mistakes if they sense that we keep an open mind and want to listen to them."

To deny so many children communication is shocking. But Mr Page believes things are beginning to change and he feels that most professionals want to be able to communicate better with disabled children.

It is the simple actions that can help make all the difference to whether a child feels valued, he says. "Asking a child whether they prefer apple to orange juice, for example, is the first step towards showing respect and taking their views and feelings seriously.

"One young man I know had been in residential care for almost 18 years before anyone thought to ask him this question."

The Two-Way Street video and handbook costs £55 plus p&p from the NSPCC national training centre, 3 Gilmore Close, Beaumont Leys, Leicester LE4 1EZ, tel: 0116 234 7223.

 Chris Cloke is director of child protection awareness at the NSPCC.

The abuse only came to light five years after the abuse began when 13-year-old Paula told her mother what had happened. Jennifer remembers the social worker who came to see them. webTitle: Charity chiefs and medics dominate 'people's peers' list

fields.headline: Charity chiefs and medics dominate 'people's peers' list
fields.trailText: Members of the "Great and Good" with links to the voluntary sector, local government and medicine dominate the 15-strong list of self-nominated "people's peers" announced today.
fields.body:
Members of the "Great and Good" with links to the voluntary sector, local government and medicine dominate the 15-strong list of self-nominated "people's peers" announced today.

They include the former chief executive of the commission for racial equality Herman Ouseley; the chief executive of homelessness charity Centrepoint, Victor Adebowale; and Richard Best, director of the Joseph Rowntree Foundation.

Valerie Howarth, chief executive of Childline, and Professor Sir Stewart Sutherland, the chairman of the controversial royal commission on long-term care of the elderly are also made life peers.

Despite government spin that the list would be drawn from a wider section of the population than the existing Lords, there were no signs of hairdressers, bus drivers or members of "ordinary" professions on the list.

Instead the 15, drawn from a total of 3,141 nominations, are all well-known figures in their fields of expertise and include seven with knighthoods and three professors.

From the world of medicine are paediatrician Michael Chan, and Professor Ilora Finlay a world expert in palliative medicine and vice-dean of the school of medicine at the University of Wales. Sir Claus Moser, former head of the government statistical service, and Lady Elspeth Howe, who has sat on a number of public sector working parties and committees, are also on the list.

The 15 will be expected to play an active part in the proceedings of the Lords that can involve long hours, voting and examining government legislation in line-by-line detail. The government threw out more than 600 hereditary peers in November 1999, leaving a temporary rump of 92 with inherited titles, plus life peers, bishops and judges.

The 15 individuals, whose names will now be recommended to the Queen, put their own names forward to the Lords appointments commission.

But the commission also wrote to 10,000 organisations including charities and quangos, asking them to put forward names of people they felt deserved a seat in the Lords, the upper legislative chamber of parliament.

Lord Stevenson, the chairman of the commission, said they would bring "considerable experience and authority to the House".

The other new peers are: Sir Paul Condon, former commissioner of the Metropolitan police; businessman Amir Bhatia; Sir John Browne, group chief executive of BP Amoco; Professor Susan Greenfield, director of the Royal Institute of Great Britain; Sir David Hannay, a former diplomat; and Sir Robert May, president of the Royal Society.

webTitle: Relatives say attack was not racist

fields.headline: Relatives say attack was not racist
fields.standfirst: Special report: race issues in the UK
fields.trailText: The family of a white pensioner beaten up by Asian youths has denied speculation that the incident was a race issue.
fields.body:
The family of a white pensioner beaten up by Asian youths has denied speculation that the incident was a race issue.

Walt Chamberlain, 75, was kicked in the face after being punched to the ground by three youths in Oldham, Greater Manchester.

It was alleged the Asian gang told the D-day veteran he was not allowed in the area because he was white. The attack, which happened on Saturday, followed reports that parts of Oldham had become no-go areas.

But Mr Chamberlain's son Steven said: "It was a violent assault on an elderly man. As a family we don't think it was a race issue at all - it's an assault."

Describing the attack, the pensioner's daughter Anita said: "There were two youths behind him and one in front. He said he felt uncomfortable. As he walked down, the third youth approached him and said, 'Where do you live?'

"Walt said at that point he just wanted to get home and told the youths, 'I live a long way from here'.

"Walt was holding a bag, which contained his flask. He seems to think they tried to get the bag off him, spun him round and after that he doesn't remember.

Obviously something has really hit him hard.

"The next thing he remembers is feeling blood on his face, getting his tissues and wiping his nose.

"He said, 'All I wanted to do was get home.' If the neighbours hadn't spotted him there was no way he would've phoned an ambulance or the police.

"It was terrible. Even the ambulance men were appalled by his injuries. He just had no idea of how bad he looked at the time.

"He complained of numbness on the side of his mouth and nose. But Walt just said, 'I might have a bit of a shiner in the morning.'

"There are two fractures in his nose. His cheekbone is badly fractured and it's affected his chin so they've had to take his teeth out and re-do his dentures.

"We don't know whether he'll have to have a plate in his face or a frame to rebuild it. My dad just thought he had a broken nose - he's never had an operation in his life."

Anita also disputed the idea that her father was a hero and appealed for anyone with information about the attack to come forward.

She said: "My dad is a victim, not a hero, and somebody needs to be brought to justice over it.

"Somebody please have a conscience. The people who have done this have to be found."

Ex-bus conductor Mr Chamberlain's family made the remarks to journalist Martin Bashir on ITV's Tonight With Trevor McDonald, which will be broadcast tonight. Steven also paid tribute to his father on the ITV show. He said: "He is a very independent single-minded man. He enjoys his sport and getting on with life.

"His main concern was whether Alex Ferguson has paid too much money for Van Nistlerooy. It sums him up, he'll get on with his life."

fields.headline: 'Athlete's ex-lover faked race attack to pay debts'
fields.standfirst:
Defendants sent abusive mail to other stars to cover tracks, court told


Special report: race issues in the UK
fields.trailText: It was partly about greed - and an attempt to hoodwink Ashia Hansen. In fact, it all failed. He didn't get the girl, he didn't get the money and it all ended in tears.
fields.body:
The white former boyfriend of black athlete Ashia Hansen set up a brutal "racist" attack on himself in the hope of rekindling their dying relationship and making money to pay off his debts, a court in Birmingham heard yesterday

Christopher Cotter was slashed across the forehead and knifed three times in the back in the attack near Hansen's house in Birmingham on March 21 last year.

He claimed that he had been attacked by neo-Nazi thugs objecting to his relationship with the Olympic triple jumper.

But Tim Raggatt QC, acting for the prosecution, told the jury at Birmingham crown court that the 29-year-old financial adviser had arranged for two friends to assault him so that they could sell his story to a newspaper for thousands.

He alleged that the trio then sent abusive mail to Hansen and other leading black athletes - including the Olympic gold medallist Denise Lewis, the sprinter Dwain Chambers and hurdler Tony Jarrett - to make the attack seem more convincing. "They sent a batch of deeply offensive letters to Miss Hansen and - perhaps to give it more credence in the eyes of the world at large - to other household names," he said.

Mr Cotter, Surgit Clair and Craig Wynn are jointly accused of conspiracy to pervert the course of justice and conspiracy to obtain property by deception because of their plans to sell the story. They deny the charges.

"It is a case that is essentially about deceit - about elaborate and carefully thought-out lies," Mr Raggatt said. "It was a confidence trick by these three defendants that was partly about greed, possibly attention seeking behaviour and certainly for Mr Cotter, an attempt to hoodwink Ashia Hansen and persuade her that a relationship she thought was over wasn't and should be resumed.

"In fact, it all failed. He didn't get the girl, he didn't get the money and it all ended in tears."

He added: "Mr Clair and Mr Wynn were clearly not part of getting the girl, but they were very much part of getting the profit."

Mr Raggatt told the court that Mr Cotter, who earned around £20,000 a year in his job at the Prudential, owed creditors including Hansen up to £25,000 and had a substantial mortgage.

"I have no doubt someone will say to you that it is a pretty extraordinary thing that someone will allow himself to be injured with a knife," he said. "If this was a plot, it was a very sophisticated one, designed to deceive people who are by nature sceptics: senior police officers and hard-bitten journalists. It needed to be convincing."

Over-exuberance

He added that the back injuries had been superficial, that the attackers might have caused more damage than they intended to through "over-exuberance" and that, according to Hansen, her former boyfriend had an unusually high tolerance of pain.

Mr Cotter, who had arranged to have dinner with Hansen on the night of the attack, arrived on her doorstep bleeding heavily and claiming he had been assaulted in a cul-de-sac close to her home, where he had parked. He usually parked directly in front of her house, where there was space that evening.

Extensive house to house inquiries by police failed to trace any witnesses to the incident, although the attack Mr Cotter described to police would have been "protracted, noisy and violent".

The prosecution also detailed the flurry of phone calls between the defendants on the day of the attack. Mr Cotter had called Mr Clair four times within half an hour that evening and received a call from Mr Wynn minutes before the assault.

Witnesses spotted a blue N-registered Ford Mondeo estate - the same kind of car as Mr Wynn drove - close to the scene.

The court heard that Mr Clair, a sales manager for the Asian Business Directory, and Mr Wynn, a heating engineer, were not only close friends of Mr Cotter but had also acted as sources for the Daily Express in the past. Mr Clair allegedly tipped off a journalist at the Express about the supposed racist attack just an hour after it happened, when even Hansen was unaware of the apparent motive.

The paper agreed to buy the story and went as far as drawing a cheque for £6,000 made payable to Mr Cotter, although they never handed it over.

Mr Cotter, a former long jumper, met Hansen in 1994. He moved to Birmingham with her two years later so that she could train with the Birchfield Harriers club.

The couple split up and bought separate homes in 1997 and, although they continued to see each other, the relationship had entered "a particularly torrid period" by last March, the prosecution claimed.

Mr Cotter's diaries, which are to be used as evidence, were said to demonstrate his "strong emotion" about the situation.

Mr Raggatt described Hansen, who is due to give evidence today, as "a lady of complete integrity". The triple jumper failed to pick up any medals at the Sydney Olympics last year after suffering injury, despite being tipped for a gold.

"There was a pretty naked attempt to exploit her both personally and emotionally," Mr Raggatt said, adding that the public as a whole had also been affected by the plot.

"It was a use, or rather a misuse, of questions involving racially motivated violence, prejudice and that sort of highly emotive topic," he said. "If you make light of matters of that kind and use them for selfish ends, you do considerable harm to the mixed community in which we all live."

The case continues.

webTitle: Gary Younge: who's in the race debate?

fields.headline: What was all that about?
fields.standfirst:
The prolonged debate is a problem for whites. Black people aren't really bothering to listen

Special report: race issues in the UK
fields.trailText: The prolonged debate is a problem for whites. Black people aren't really bothering to listen.
fields.body:
So we have come full circle. Not so long ago to get a national discussion, let alone a row, going on racism, black and Asian people would have to at best lobby hard and at worst riot. While they would discuss how best to tackle the dead weight of bigotry that affected every aspect of their daily lives, white politicians - for the longest time there were no black or Asian ones - would discuss the issues that really mattered. During debates about immigration or crime, black people would often be talked about but rarely talked to. And occasionally, waiting in the wings during a scene of deplorable discriminatory excess, the subject of racism would get a walk on part only then to be summarily dismissed.

The events of the last few weeks could not have been more different. For this latest spate of breast beating has taken place almost entirely without reference to the black communities. Splashed across tabloids and broadsheets alike, clogging up airwaves and dominating our television screens, politicians and pundits have delved into the subject with all the subtlety and zeal of teenagers discovering sex.

It is a sign of the parallel universe in which these discussions have taken place that they have in no way been informed or particularly enlightened by the riots in Bradford, the white pensioner who was beaten senseless by Asians in Oldham or the latest asylum figures. While the politicians trade insults and up antes over racism the talk in the barber shops, mosques and workplaces is of anything but. Look in the black and Asian press and you will see it relegated to the inside pages. We are in the midst of a "race row" that is apparently of little interest to those who are most likely to suffer racism.

While there is cause to be depressed by a great deal that has been said during this time, the process by which it has come into the public domain indicates a peculiar kind of progress. This is a legacy of Macpherson. The Stephen Lawrence report stemmed from an incident prompted by a group of white racist louts, bungled by an overwhelmingly white police force, which triggered an investigation presided over by a white lord. This very process transformed the race paradigm. Before it was a debate about how to contain the problems that black people cause by their very presence. Now white people are talking to other white people about the problems engendered by their racism.

What was once understood as a marginal issue that affected black people is now a mainstream issue that is defining the nation. As such race in Britain is becoming a touchstone for modernity. Just as supporting privatisation was once regarded as a signifier of economic maturity and defending the National Health Service denoted compassion in the most conservative of times, so race is developing into a marker of what one makes of Britain's place in the 21st century. The fact that, even as we top the league in our hostility to asylum seekers, Hague's remarks have sent him plunging in the polls among his own supporters is instructive. There are plenty of racist attitudes about; but they are not deemed worthy of a political leader.

It is through the prism of race that we are beginning to ask questions to which all of Britain has long sought answers. What does it mean to be British? Are you confident about what Britain might be or do you mourn the passing of what it was? Do you think that everyone should be treated equally, or do you believe that some should have privileges and others disadvantages inherited from birth? In that sense race is becoming the road map by which we navigate our way through a whole host of national issues, such as class and equality of opportunity.

Whether it deepens our understanding of Britain depends very much on the level of discussion that takes place. It is here that the problems start.

While both main parties have accused the other of using the race card neither is actually playing with a full deck. The Tories are desperate and Labour are cocky. Neither mindset is particularly conducive to a mature debate about a sensitive issue.

To criticise the commission for racial equality for asking Tories to sign its pledge is a bizarre move. A link has been established between racially charged campaigning and racial attacks. "The most serious trend we have seen is a rise in reports of incidents when the issue of asylum seekers and refugees is brought into the public domain by reputable politicians making inflammatory statements," one Scotland Yard source told the Observer. In that climate asking Tories to agree not to resort to "racially hostile language" makes perfect sense. It is only because some Tories refused that the row took off in the first place. The CRE were asking them to put their hands up for motherhood and apple pie; they ended up being accused of McCarthyism because of rightwing political beef.

But the very fact that William Hague has chosen to challenge Labour on this issue is significant. With the political centre otherwise crowded or hostile to his party, here is one area where he senses that there is both significant difference and significant weakness for Labour.

He has a point. Labour has scored some remarkable successes on race. By launching the inquiry into Stephen Lawrence's death and passing anti-discrimination legislation, it helped reshape the discourse on race. But it implemented punitive legislation on asylum seekers and disparaging remarks about Gypsies. In the words of James Baldwin: "what it gave, at length and grudgingly with one hand, it took back with the other." They are proud of their fiscal prudence, however unpopular with their core supporters. But their commitment to anti-racism, as much as it exists, is their best kept secret. They cannot claim the moral high ground because they have chosen to vacate it.

fields.bodyText: So we have come full circle. Not so long ago to get a national discussion, let alone a row, going on racism, black and Asian people would have to at best lobby hard and at worst riot. While they would discuss how best to tackle the dead weight of bigotry that affected every aspect of their daily lives, white politicians - for the longest time there were no black or Asian ones - would discuss the issues that really mattered. During debates about immigration or crime, black people would often be talked about but rarely talked to. And occasionally, waiting in the wings during a scene of deplorable discriminatory excess, the subject of racism would get a walk on part only then to be summarily dismissed. The events of the last few weeks could not have been more different. For this latest spate of breast beating has taken place almost entirely without reference to the black communities. Splashed across tabloids and broadsheets alike, clogging up airwaves and dominating our television screens, politicians and pundits have delved into the subject with all the subtlety and zeal of teenagers discovering sex. It is a sign of the parallel universe in which these discussions have taken place that they have in no way been informed or particularly enlightened by the riots in Bradford, the white pensioner who was beaten senseless by Asians in Oldham or the latest asylum figures. While the politicians trade insults and up antes over racism the talk in the barber shops, mosques and workplaces is of anything but. Look in the black and Asian press and you will see it relegated to the inside pages. We are in the midst of a "race row" that is apparently of little interest to those who are most likely to suffer racism. While there is cause to be depressed by a great deal that has been said during this time, the process by which it has come into the public domain indicates a peculiar kind of progress. This is a legacy of Macpherson. The Stephen Lawrence report stemmed from an incident prompted by a group of white racist louts, bungled by an overwhelmingly white police force, which triggered an investigation presided over by a white lord. This very process transformed the race paradigm. Before it was a debate about how to contain the problems that black people cause by their very presence. Now white people are talking to other white people about the problems engendered by their racism. What was once understood as a marginal issue that affected black people is now a mainstream issue that is defining the nation. As such race in Britain is becoming a touchstone for modernity. Just as supporting privatisation was once regarded as a signifier of economic maturity and defending the National Health Service denoted compassion in the most conservative of times, so race is developing into a marker of what one makes of Britain's place in the 21st century. The fact that, even as we top the league in our hostility to asylum seekers, Hague's remarks have sent him plunging in the polls among his own supporters is instructive. There are plenty of racist attitudes about; but they are not deemed worthy of a political leader. It is through the prism of race that we are beginning to ask questions to which all of Britain has long sought answers. What does it mean to be British? Are you confident about what Britain might be or do you mourn the passing of what it was? Do you think that everyone should be treated equally, or do you believe that some should have privileges and others disadvantages inherited from birth? In that sense race is becoming the road map by which we navigate our way through a whole host of national issues, such as class and equality of opportunity. Whether it deepens our understanding of Britain depends very much on the level of discussion that takes place. It is here that the problems start. While both main parties have accused the other of using the race card neither is actually playing with a full deck. The Tories are desperate and Labour are cocky. Neither mindset is particularly conducive to a mature debate about a sensitive issue. To criticise the commission for racial equality for asking Tories to sign its pledge is a bizarre move. A link has been established between racially charged campaigning and racial attacks. "The most serious trend we have seen is a rise in reports of incidents when the issue of asylum seekers and refugees is brought into the public domain by reputable politicians making inflammatory statements," one Scotland Yard source told the Observer. In that climate asking Tories to agree not to resort to "racially hostile language" makes perfect sense. It is only because some Tories refused that the row took off in the first place. The CRE were asking them to put their hands up for motherhood and apple pie; they ended up being accused of McCarthyism because of rightwing political beef. But the very fact that William Hague has chosen to challenge Labour on this issue is significant. With the political centre otherwise crowded or hostile to his party, here is one area where he senses that there is both significant difference and significant weakness for Labour. He has a point. Labour has scored some remarkable successes on race. By launching the inquiry into Stephen Lawrence's death and passing anti-discrimination legislation, it helped reshape the discourse on race. But it implemented punitive legislation on asylum seekers and disparaging remarks about Gypsies. In the words of James Baldwin: "what it gave, at length and grudgingly with one hand, it took back with the other." They are proud of their fiscal prudence, however unpopular with their core supporters. But their commitment to anti-racism, as much as it exists, is their best kept secret. They cannot claim the moral high ground because they have chosen to vacate it. gary.younge@theguardian.com

fields.headline: Brown announces reduced cull
fields.standfirst:
 'Major relaxation' of slaughter policy
 Phoenix the calf allowed to live
 Disease 'is on the wane'

Special report: foot and mouth
fields.trailText:
 'Major relaxation' of slaughter policy
 Phoenix the calf allowed to live
 Disease 'is on the wane'
fields.body:
The agriculture minister, Nick Brown, today announced a major relaxation of the government's slaughter policy following the media outcry about the fate of Phoenix the calf.

Phoenix, who was discovered alive under a heap of 15 culled animals, will most likely be allowed to live under the new policy, which will see local vets decide her fate.

The revised government policy will give local vets greater discretion in whether to cull cattle in so-called "firebreak" areas - farms neighbouring those where there had been a foot and mouth outbreak. Pigs and sheep, which pose a greater disease threat, will still be subject to the culls.

Mr Brown also released fresh evidence that foot and mouth disease is on the wane.

In a speech to the Commons, Mr Brown told MPs that for the last seven-day period, the total number of new cases fell below 100 for the first time in eight weeks.

But the prime minister, Tony Blair, faced angry protests today when he visited Cumbria, the county worst affected by foot and mouth.

Farmers from the Cumbria Crisis Alliance gathered with placards to demand help from the government.

Elizabeth Skelton, who owns an open farm in Morland just outside Penrith, said she had lost 14 sheep and 21 pigmy goats because she was classed as a contiguous case.

"Today they are telling people on contiguous farms they do not have to slaughter but it has come too late for me," she said.

Earlier the chancellor, Gordon Brown, had welcomed the reprieve for Phoenix. "I'm indeed very happy about that, and I'm happy that we are making progress so that Nick Brown can make this announcement this afternoon."

He said that the government had been considering changing the policy in "what has been the problem in relation to Phoenix, that is of contiguous farms - farms next door to farms where there is a diseased animal - you don't have to do the culling there in future."

However, the Conservatives last night called on the government for an urgent explanation of the scientific basis for revising the policy.

webTitle: Another day of misery for Brazil

fields.headline: Another day of misery for Brazil
fields.trailText: Brazil's miserable run in the World Cup qualifiers continued last night when they were held to a 1-1 draw at home by lowly Peru - a result that leaves them clinging on to the fourth qualifying place in the South American group.
fields.body:
Brazil's miserable run in the World Cup qualifiers continued last night when they were held to a 1-1 draw at home by lowly Peru - a result that leaves them clinging on to the fourth qualifying place in the South American group.

"Help" read the headline in one Brazilian newspaper on Thursday, and with good reason. Brazil now lie below Argentina, Paraguay and Ecuador - and are in serious danger of missing out of next year's World Cup Finals.

Only the top four qualify while the fifth-placed team must take on the winners of the Oceania region, most likely to be Australia. "It's not an easy moment but we are still part of the group which will qualify," insisted Romario after the match. "Nothing is easy anymore. There's no longer that great respect for us that there was before."

Brazil will have to earn some respect, and soon. They are just two points ahead of fifth-placed Columbia and three in front of Uruguay, who they face in Montevideo in their next game. And with trips to Argentina and the suffocating altitude of Bolivia - 3,600 metres above sea level - also on the horizon, the whole of Brazil is waking up this morning realising their record of being the only country to have played every World Cup Finals is in serious danger.

Coach Emerson Leao, already wobbling after only five games in charge, offered few excuses for another display which belied Brazil's reputation as both world beaters and entertainers.

"A draw at home, under any circumstance, is a dreadful result," he said. "We're not in decline, it's just that at the moment we're not doing well."

After suffering a shock defeat against Ecuador last month, Leao made sweeping changes, dropping captain Rivaldo and including nine home-based players - three of them uncapped - after accusations that the overseas players had not been pulling their weight.

But the move backfired and Leao had to endure the dreaded chant of "idiot, idiot" from the 50,000 crowd as his team again struggled.

"I've never heard the crowd call the coach intelligent. It's part of my job," Leao retorted.

Commentators were unmoved and claimed that Brazil's recent results were the fruits of a deep-rooted crisis, which has resulted in Congressional commissions of inquiry being set up to investigate mismanagement and corruption in the sport.

"We got what we deserved, thanks to the vampires who have sucked the last drops of sweat and blood from our football and left only the tears," said the sports daily Lance.

Critics also blamed Leao for replacing creative midfielder Ricardinho with defensive Mineiro after Brazil had gone in front in the 66th minute.

"It was pathetic, melancholic and repugnant to see the coach of the Brazilian team, halfway through the second half, take off a creative player and bring on a destroyer to try and secure a 1-0 win over Peru, which itself is a mediocre result," claimed O Globo.

"The coach was punished for his mediocrity in the act. Peru equalised right afterwards."

The first jeers from the 50,000 crowd at the Morumbi stadium began to be heard after 25 minutes. By half-time, the crowd were chanting "Ole" as Peru passed the ball around. And when Peru equalised with 11 minutes to go, they hurled Brazil flags onto the pitch in protest.

The home side struggled early on against the well-organised Peru defence, and it took 31 minutes to produce their first shot when a Marcelinho Carioca free kick was tipped over by the Peruvian keeper, Miguel Miranda.

The home side improved after the break after bringing on Juninho Paulista in midfield. Ricardinho and Ewerthon both had good efforts before Romario struck in the 66th minute, beating the offside trap and rounding Miranda to score his eighth goal of the competition after Vampeta had chipped the ball over the defence.

The relief was evident but short-lived. Eleven minutes from time, Pajuelo rose above a static defence to head in the equaliser. And before a disbelieving crowd, Peru finished the game on top, threatening to snatch a late winner which would have handed Brazil a first-ever home defeat in a World Cup qualifier.
