fields.headline: Loyal, Spoil and Toil
fields.trailText: PAT: THAT IS THAT
fields.body:
PAT: THAT IS THAT

The Fiver never ever wants to go to Italy again. Or maybe we do. After all, that Zinedine Zidane has said some lovely things about us. But wait just one ruddy second: we really love England, and our boss. Even though we slag them off occasionally. Confusing signals alert! Confusing signals alert! Oh dear. The Fiver seems to have contracted Vieira-itis, as we just can't seem to make our minds up.

"Although some major clubs in Italy are interested in me, I won't return. Absolutely not!" was what veering Viera said last October, only for him to then do a 180-degree U-turn earlier this year. "I can't say I would never move to a side including Zidane and [David] Trezeguet. My return in Italy is possible", he said. But today, Pat finally got off his large fence and reached a decision: he's staying at Arsenal until the end of his contract in 2004. "I want to make it clear to every Arsenal fan that I have no intention of going to Italy or anywhere else," he announced. "I became a better player after coming to England under Arsene Wenger so why should I even consider leaving Arsenal?"

But before the Fiver could interject with a sentence featuring the words "lucre", "filthy" and "lots of it, baby", Vieira was off again. "It is very clear to the club that I want to stay at Arsenal", he said. "I have a contract until 2004 but who knows what will happen after that?" In the meantime, Pat has predicted a rosy future for the club. "We have a fantastic group of players here," he enthused. "We were very unlucky in Europe but if we finish second and win the FA Cup, it will still have been a good season for us." Which of course, bears no relation to last week's remarks by a certain P Vieira that: "Even if we manage to reach these two objectives, I would qualify our season as average." Is there a doctor in the house?

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

TAYLOR STITCHED

According to Ronan Keating, "life is a rollercoaster". The Fiver is not quite sure what he means by that, having never bothered to listen to the song. But we imagine the observation was only made after careful consideration of the nature of said fairground feature. And we also assume that Peter Taylor, the Foxiest of them all, may find the lyrics somewhat poignant.

At the beginning of the season Pete, and the pair of tracksuit bottoms he borrowed from John Gregory, were all the rage. Indeed, the rage spilled over into outrage when talented Taylor wasn't picked for the England job ahead of Svennis the thicko. But if Leicester lose to Newcastle on Saturday, it will be a club-record 8th league defeat on the trot for the Foxes and, according to former Fox Steve Walsh, Taylor's got a bit of a crisis on his hands.

"In eight months, he [Peter Taylor] has systematically dismantled the side," says Walsh. The in-no-way-bitter Tamworth Town player, who had been tipped to take the top job at Filbert Street before Taylor won the day, claims that disillusionment is rife at the club (that's Leicester, not Tamworth) and that relegation could be on the cards next term. "There's definite unrest in the dressing room," Walsh said. "I think it's going to be an eventful summer with some players who can now see the problems. It's possible others could leave."

The great news for Foxy fans is that the names tipped to leave the club include Trevor Benjamin, Ade Akinbiyi, Callum Davidson, and Lee Marshall. Only joking, it's actually the injured Muzzy Izzet and Matt Elliott (and any other good players). But Taylor is sticking to his guns, and claiming injuries are to blame. "Any side would miss players of the calibre of Izzet and [knee victim Gerry] Taggart, but we will have to battle through without them as best as we can." Which, on recent evidence, is not good enough.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"If people want to call me the saviour of Manchester United, that's not a problem for me." And what if people want to call you a slick-haired big-nosed spookazoid, eh? Nose van Nistelgreg addresses the nation.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

PEP TALK

Welcome to the Pep Guardiola transfer rumour round-up, your one-stop port of call for all your Pep Guardiola transfer rumour needs. We categorically promise NEVER to misinform you about the Barcelona midfielder everybody raves about even though they've only seen him play twice, nor the identity of the club he will join at the end of the season.

Pep is set for Tottenham Hotspur - and that's a fact! The 30-year-old will become the main piece in the stylish jigsaw currently being put together by Glenn Hoddle's glory fingers, a fact hammered home in the Mirror's informative "Glenn takes Guard!" article this morning. "He puts paper to pen on a £50,000-a-week deal starting July 1," it screamed in tones similar to that of an eagle giving birth.

But wait, what's this! It's not Spurs, but Newcastle that Pep's definitely joining! "Bobby Robson will break the bank in a bid to sign Guardiola," claim the Sun, who reckon Robson is "confident" of succeeding with his £60,000-a-week bid. "I'm totally confident of landing Guardiola," Robson is quoted as saying, er, nowhere.

Hmm no, we've changed our minds again, we're totally sure he's going to Spurs. And if not, maybe Chelsea or Arsenal.

But then again, he's not going to London at all! According to the London Evening Standard: "Arsenal, Chelsea and Fulham have all turned down the chance to take the Spanish international on a free transfer and Spurs are turning their attention to other targets." It seems Spurs aren't prepared to meet Pep's wage demands, a stance that rules out a move for He Was He Is He Soon May Be Again Emmanuel Petit as well. Glad we've sorted that out for you.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

THE RUMOUR MILL

Tottenham manager Glenn Hoddle was in Belgrade for Russia's World Cup qualifier against Yugoslavia to assess the form of forward Egor Titov.

Real Madrid are the latest club to be linked with Mark Viduka.

Barcelona are lining up a bid for Internazionale midfielder Javier Zanetti, after his agent revealed that a move to Real Madrid was unlikely because of his high wage demands.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

NEWS IN BRIEF

Celestine Babayaro has been cleared of violent conduct on the recommendation of the FA's video advisory panel. Babayaro was accused of stamping on Fredrik Ljungberg's ankle during the FA Cup fifth round tie between Chelsea and Arsenal. However, the case against him was found to be "not proven" after the FA accepted his defence that the incident had been accidental.

The man who ran on to the pitch and tried to swap shirts with Alex Nyarko during Everton's match against Arsenal last Saturday has been banned from every football ground in Britain for three years. Stephen Price, 41, an Everton supporter for three decades, was also fined £170 and ordered to pay £30 costs after admitting a charge of unlawfully entering a playing area.

Claudio Caniggia's future at Dundee hangs in the balance after he failed to turn up at training for the second successive day. Dundee player-manager Ivano Bonetti admitted: "I am not very happy about this whole thing. We can't have a situation where Claudio is not coming to training."

Leicester defender Gerry Taggart has been ruled out for the rest of the season with a knee injury.

Paul Scholes is set to sign a new long-term contract with Manchester United in the summer, which will double his current salary of around £25,000 a week.

A 25-year-old German man has died from head wounds he sustained as he tried to escape from rioting fans at a friendly match. The man, whose identity was not revealed, fell from a height of six to seven metres after climbing a fence following the game on Tuesday between amateur side Darmstadt 98 and first division Eintracht Frankfurt.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO

Channel 4: Football Stories (9pm) The story of Brian Clough.

Channel 5: Jonathan Pearce's Football Night (12.10am) The story of a fat loud-mouthed bloke who blagged a gig on the telly.

International Football (12.40am) The story of how Dunfermline Athletic took over the entire Scotland team.

Dutch Football (2.10am) The story of Sander Westerveld, who frowned so hard his eyebrows fell off.

Argentine Football (3.45am) The story of a little man with big hair and roomy nostrils.

Sky Sports 1: Futbol Mundial (6.30pm) The story of something you pretended to be interested in when it was on but have since forgotten everything about.

Non-League Football Show (7pm, 12midnight) The story of a team who have to play 387 games in 3 days.

You're On Sky Sports! (10pm, 3am) The story of a big oaf.

Australian Soccer League (11pm) The story of a snag, a ute and a thousand tinnies.

Sky Sports 3: World Cup Football (6.30pm) The story of the same old tat you watched last night.

Spanish Football League (8pm) The story of success.

Football Gold (10pm) The story of some sideburns, skills, a cheeky wink, the terraces, a riot, a burnt-out shell of a train, being knifed, eee, those were the days.

British Eurosport: World Cup Football (8.15pm, 10.15pm) The story of the lonely little satellite station everyone with access to cable or satellite receives but nobody ever watches.

Is there a doctor in the house? * * * * * * * * * * * * * TAYLOR STITCHED According to Ronan Keating, "life is a rollercoaster". The Fiver is not quite sure what he means by that, having never bothered to listen to the song. But we imagine the observation was only made after careful consideration of the nature of said fairground feature. And we also assume that Peter Taylor, the Foxiest of them all, may find the lyrics somewhat poignant. At the beginning of the season Pete, and the pair of tracksuit bottoms he borrowed from John Gregory, were all the rage. Indeed, the rage spilled over into outrage when talented Taylor wasn't picked for the England job ahead of Svennis the thicko. But if Leicester lose to Newcastle on Saturday, it will be a club-record 8th league defeat on the trot for the Foxes and, according to former Fox Steve Walsh, Taylor's got a bit of a crisis on his hands. "In eight months, he [Peter Taylor] has systematically dismantled the side," says Walsh. The in-no-way-bitter Tamworth Town player, who had been tipped to take the top job at Filbert Street before Taylor won the day, claims that disillusionment is rife at the club (that's Leicester, not Tamworth) and that relegation could be on the cards next term. "There's definite unrest in the dressing room," Walsh said. "I think it's going to be an eventful summer with some players who can now see the problems. It's possible others could leave." The great news for Foxy fans is that the names tipped to leave the club include Trevor Benjamin, Ade Akinbiyi, Callum Davidson, and Lee Marshall. Only joking, it's actually the injured Muzzy Izzet and Matt Elliott (and any other good players). But Taylor is sticking to his guns, and claiming injuries are to blame. "Any side would miss players of the calibre of Izzet and [knee victim Gerry] Taggart, but we will have to battle through without them as best as we can." Which, on recent evidence, is not good enough. * * * * * * * * * * * * * QUOTE OF THE DAY "If people want to call me the saviour of Manchester United, that's not a problem for me." And what if people want to call you a slick-haired big-nosed spookazoid, eh? Nose van Nistelgreg addresses the nation. * * * * * * * * * * * * * PEP TALK Welcome to the Pep Guardiola transfer rumour round-up, your one-stop port of call for all your Pep Guardiola transfer rumour needs. We categorically promise NEVER to misinform you about the Barcelona midfielder everybody raves about even though they've only seen him play twice, nor the identity of the club he will join at the end of the season. Pep is set for Tottenham Hotspur - and that's a fact! The 30-year-old will become the main piece in the stylish jigsaw currently being put together by Glenn Hoddle's glory fingers, a fact hammered home in the Mirror's informative "Glenn takes Guard!" article this morning. "He puts paper to pen on a £50,000-a-week deal starting July 1," it screamed in tones similar to that of an eagle giving birth. But wait, what's this! It's not Spurs, but Newcastle that Pep's definitely joining! "Bobby Robson will break the bank in a bid to sign Guardiola," claim the Sun, who reckon Robson is "confident" of succeeding with his £60,000-a-week bid. "I'm totally confident of landing Guardiola," Robson is quoted as saying, er, nowhere. Hmm no, we've changed our minds again, we're totally sure he's going to Spurs. And if not, maybe Chelsea or Arsenal. But then again, he's not going to London at all! According to the London Evening Standard: "Arsenal, Chelsea and Fulham have all turned down the chance to take the Spanish international on a free transfer and Spurs are turning their attention to other targets." It seems Spurs aren't prepared to meet Pep's wage demands, a stance that rules out a move for He Was He Is He Soon May Be Again Emmanuel Petit as well. Glad we've sorted that out for you. * * * * * * * * * * * * * THE RUMOUR MILL Tottenham manager Glenn Hoddle was in Belgrade for Russia's World Cup qualifier against Yugoslavia to assess the form of forward Egor Titov. Real Madrid are the latest club to be linked with Mark Viduka. Barcelona are lining up a bid for Internazionale midfielder Javier Zanetti, after his agent revealed that a move to Real Madrid was unlikely because of his high wage demands. * * * * * * * * * * * * * NEWS IN BRIEF Celestine Babayaro has been cleared of violent conduct on the recommendation of the FA's video advisory panel. Babayaro was accused of stamping on Fredrik Ljungberg's ankle during the FA Cup fifth round tie between Chelsea and Arsenal. However, the case against him was found to be "not proven" after the FA accepted his defence that the incident had been accidental. The man who ran on to the pitch and tried to swap shirts with Alex Nyarko during Everton's match against Arsenal last Saturday has been banned from every football ground in Britain for three years. Stephen Price, 41, an Everton supporter for three decades, was also fined £170 and ordered to pay £30 costs after admitting a charge of unlawfully entering a playing area. Claudio Caniggia's future at Dundee hangs in the balance after he failed to turn up at training for the second successive day. Dundee player-manager Ivano Bonetti admitted: "I am not very happy about this whole thing. We can't have a situation where Claudio is not coming to training." Leicester defender Gerry Taggart has been ruled out for the rest of the season with a knee injury. Paul Scholes is set to sign a new long-term contract with Manchester United in the summer, which will double his current salary of around £25,000 a week. A 25-year-old German man has died from head wounds he sustained as he tried to escape from rioting fans at a friendly match. The man, whose identity was not revealed, fell from a height of six to seven metres after climbing a fence following the game on Tuesday between amateur side Darmstadt 98 and first division Eintracht Frankfurt. * * * * * * * * * * * * * TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO Channel 4: Football Stories (9pm) The story of Brian Clough. Channel 5: Jonathan Pearce's Football Night (12.10am) The story of a fat loud-mouthed bloke who blagged a gig on the telly. International Football (12.40am) The story of how Dunfermline Athletic took over the entire Scotland team. Dutch Football (2.10am) The story of Sander Westerveld, who frowned so hard his eyebrows fell off. Argentine Football (3.45am) The story of a little man with big hair and roomy nostrils. Sky Sports 1: Futbol Mundial (6.30pm) The story of something you pretended to be interested in when it was on but have since forgotten everything about. Non-League Football Show (7pm, 12midnight) The story of a team who have to play 387 games in 3 days. You're On Sky Sports! (10pm, 3am) The story of a big oaf. Australian Soccer League (11pm) The story of a snag, a ute and a thousand tinnies. Sky Sports 3: World Cup Football (6.30pm) The story of the same old tat you watched last night. Spanish Football League (8pm) The story of success. Football Gold (10pm) The story of some sideburns, skills, a cheeky wink, the terraces, a riot, a burnt-out shell of a train, being knifed, eee, those were the days. British Eurosport: World Cup Football (8.15pm, 10.15pm) The story of the lonely little satellite station everyone with access to cable or satellite receives but nobody ever watches.

fields.headline: Tory MP reopens race row
fields.trailText: A Tory MP who sparked a race row with outspoken remarks about immigrants today repeated his warning that multiculturalism  threatened Britain's future.
fields.body:
A Tory MP who sparked a race row with outspoken remarks about immigrants today repeated his warning that multiculturalism threatened Britain's future.

John Townend caused widespread fury by blaming immigrants for rising crime and "seriously undermining" the UK's Anglo-Saxon society.

The row deepened when the Commission for racial equality revealed that the Yorkshire East MP had declined to sign a pledge not to exploit the race issue.

Mr Townend today fired off another broadside. "I believe the concept of a multi-cultural, multi-ethnic, multi-lingual society is a mistake and will inevitably cause great problems," he wrote in a letter of refusal to the CRE chief Gurbux Singh.

"You have only to look around the world to see the growing problems of other such societies."

Mr Townend took ministers to task over the suggestion, made by Robin Cook, that there was no such thing as the British race. "Mr Cook and many of his colleagues challenge the very concept of our nation," he wrote.

"Presumably he considers us a mongrel race. I can tell him my Yorkshire constituents are insulted by such comments."

The government should come clean about the drain asylum seekers placed on the economy, he said. "My constituents, like most people in this country, are opposed to a new wave of illegal immigration under the guise of asylum seekers," he wrote.

"Once more, it is the role of the Conservative party to speak for England."

fields.headline: Emap shuts down Escape Routes
fields.trailText: 4.45pm: Emap's travel lifestyle magazine is to close with the loss of four jobs, reports Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
Escape Routes, the travel lifestyle magazine launched by Emap 18 months ago, is to close with the loss of four jobs, the publisher has announced.

A statement from Emap Elan's chief executive, Barry McIlheney, said Emap had found it "impossible to sustain the magazine as a long-term publishing proposition".

The publisher was unable to either confirm or deny reports it was in negotiations with travel agents interested in purchasing the magazine.

The statement said: "The Emap Elan Network is committed to finding permanent employment for the four members of staff on the magazine elsewhere across the network and would like to thank everyone on Escape Routes for their hard work and commitment over the last 18 months."

Escape Routes was launched as the middle-market rival to Conde Nast's successful Conde Nast Traveller by the former OK! editor and News of the World reporter, Sharon Ring.

Ms Ring, who doubled OK!'s circulation against Hello!, said at launch that she wanted the magazine to appeal to "well-off housewives".

But insiders say the magazine failed to establish a niche in the market.

It was never audited by the ABC, suggesting that copy sales were too low for an official audit figure, and insiders say it struggled to attract the high-end advertising of Conde Nast Traveller.

Meanwhile, Ms Ring has become increasingly involved with the day-to-day running of Heat! magazine, Emap Elan's phenomenally successful celebrity title, whose circulation increased by almost 140% at the last ABCs.

Sarah Miller, editor of Conde Nast Traveller, paid tribute to journalists on the magazine, saying: "It's very sad. A lot of people put in a lot of work into it."

webTitle: Fury over loophole that could see homeless refused housing

fields.headline: Fury over loophole that could see homeless refused housing
fields.trailText: Scottish opposition parties have been accused of using homelessness as a political football by providing a loophole for social landlords that will allow them to avoid housing homeless people.
fields.body:
Scottish opposition parties have been accused of using homelessness as a political football by providing a loophole for social landlords that will allow them to avoid housing homeless people.

Shadow justice minister Fiona Hyslop of the Scottish National Party has successfully amended the housing bill to give more discretion to housing associations about who they house.

Under the change, which was supported in committee by Conservative and Liberal Democrat members, councils will have to consider housing association's allocation policies when exercising their duty to house homeless people.

Shelter Scotland has reacted with fury. It says the amendment will allow housing associations to exclude homeless families if, for example, they have a policy to bar people that have rent arrears or if they have a tough line on anti-social behaviour.

Liz Nicholson, director of Shelter Scotland said: "This change is a body blow to homeless people and seriously undermines the homelessness provisions in the Scottish executive's flagship housing bill."

She added: "To force through this amendment is nothing more than using the most vulnerable people as pawns in a political game."

The SNP is suspected of trying to wreck the bill because it is against plans in the legislation to transfer council homes to housing associations. But Ms Hyslop said Shelter had over reacted and housing associations would not be allowed to exclude homeless people.

She said the amendment would prevent "local authorities dictating allocation policies to housing associations". Ms Hyslop also said it would help housing associations keep homes free that had been earmarked for special groups such as older people or black and minority communities.

The Scottish Federation of Housing Associations said it was opposed to the move.

Parliamentary officer David Bookbinder said: "This is not something that we have asked for or support. It gives the impression that housing associations are trying to get out of their responsibilities."

He claimed there were other provisions that would prevent the inappropriate allocations of housing.

Jackie Baillie, minister for social justice, pledged to attempt to reverse the amendment. She said: "We cannot leave this loophole open to the few landlords unwilling to accept their responsibilities towards those most in need of a home."

fields.headline: Children to share £1bn Labour giveaway
fields.standfirst: Special report: Labour party
fields.trailText: Labour will today unveil its "big idea" for the second term when it publishes a £1bn plan to set up trust funds for every child.
fields.body:
Labour will today unveil its "big idea" for the second term when it publishes a £1bn plan to set up trust funds for every child, which could grow to between £5,000 and £7,000 by the time the individual reaches 18 years old.

The initial state dowry will be worth between £300 and £500 depending on the family income. It will be topped up by sums of £50-£100 three times as the child grows up.

The move is billed as a drive to fight child poverty and provide incentives to save. The shift will also signal that the government is no longer simply concerned with addressing income inequality, but also the distribution of assets.

David Blunkett, the education and employment secretary, in an interview with the Guardian yesterday, said: "Kids who grow up in a household where no one is working or has any savings end up with very dangerous role models. It has knock-on effect for their own performance in schools and in work, so we are trying to break that cycle. It is about self-help."

At the launch of the scheme today, the Chancellor Gordon Brown will say: "To ensure that every child has the best possible start in life, we plan not only to improve the weekly incomes on which a child is reared but to make it possible for them to own and value wealth."

The aim, he will add, is "to open up assets to all" and remove a further 1m children from poverty by 2004.

"A nation at work should also be a nation with wealth and, having created the opportunity for work and for incomes, now we must ensure that people have the security of a base of wealth behind them."

The initial cash dowry - placed in individual child trust funds - will be topped up by government as the child starts school at five, changes to secondary school at 11, and then for a third time at 16.

Each government top-up will be worth between £50 and £100 depending on the income of the parents. No tax will be imposed on the savings and no benefit entitlements withdrawn. Parents, grandparents and family will be encouraged to contribute to the tax-free trust fund.

Ministers also plan to set up a new "savings gateway" for low earning adults in which the government will match the cashed saved by each individual pound for pound up to a maximum of £1,800 saved.

The money will have to be invested for a minimum of three years and then can either be cashed, placed in a child trust fund, a pension fund or reinvested in an Isa.

The consultation paper to be issued at today's press conference is not expected to limit how the income from the child trust fund is eventually spent. Ministers would like the cash to be spent solely on individual development - for example, training, buying a home, setting up a business and helping to fund further education.

In practice ministers fear it would be impossible to police such limits effectively. How ever, they still believe the proposals will encourage self-reliance, forward planning and a habit of saving.

Supporters of the proposals - bound to be dismissed by the Tories as a gimmick - claim it fills a gaping hole in Labour thinking since it addresses the root causes of poverty, rather than the consequences.

The child trust funds would not just be set up for those children born after the measure comes into law, but also for those reaching the ages at which subsequent contributions are triggered. Currently 750,000 babies are born a year.

The two-pronged proposals drawon two years of analysis inside the Treasury, the Department for Education and Employment and the leftwing think-tank, the IPPR.

Using the National Child Development Study, Mr Blunkett's department found a clear link between family asset holding and the child's subsequent life chances.

Polling carried out for the IPPR found some distrust of the idea of capital endowment and matched savings. Some saw it "as too good to be true and that somewhere along the line individuals would pay, probably through future restrictions of government provision".

But government research shows that seven out of ten lone parents have no savings while half of all families on low or middle incomes with three children have no savings. The proportion of people without any financial assets has also doubled between 1979 and 1997 from 5% to 10 %.

In Mr Blunkett's view this in part reflects the collapse of traditional working class savings vehicles such as mutual societies, christmas clubs or post office savings accounts.

In his interview Mr Blunkett also admitted the government had to do more to bring the hardcore unemployed into work and said that among the challenges ahead were narrowing the employment gap in run-down areas and preventing any further rise in the number of people claiming incapacity benefit.

What you could get

Child trust funds

At birth: £300-500 (depending on family income)

At age 5: £50-100

At age 11: £50-100

At age 16: £50-100

Maximum total: £800*

*Could be worth £5,000-£7,000 by age 18

Savings gateway for low earning adults

Government will match pound for pound up to £1,800 saved. Money must be invested for three years, then placed in child trust fund, pension fund or an individual savings account.

Talk about it
Are government sponsored trust funds a good idea?

fields.headline: Bland and the baroness
fields.trailText:
4.30pm: Former BBC vice-chairman Baroness Young has spoken publicly for the first time about working with Sir Christopher Bland. By Jason Deans.
26.04.2001: Who will replace Bland?
26.04.2001: Don't rush succession, say Tories
26.04.2001: comment by Emily Bell
26.04.2001: Sir Christopher quits to join BT
fields.body:
Baroness Young, the former vice-chairman of the BBC, has spoken publicly for the first time about working with Sir Christopher Bland.

And despite speculation about regular clashes at meetings of the board of governors, she spoke warmly about the outgoing chairman.

"Not many BBC chairmen can have watched so much BBC telly or listened to so much radio," she said.

"He was also a regular BBC Online user."

Baroness Young of Old Scone worked alongside Sir Christopher for two years before leaving the corporation last autumn.

She added that one of Sir Christopher's biggest contributions to the BBC had been securing last year's licence fee settlement.

"He successfully steered the licence fee negotiations with the government and got a pretty good settlement, which meant the BBC could plan for the future," she said.

Baroness Young, who was reported to have been opposed to Greg Dyke's appointment as director-general in 1999 - a charge she has vehemently denied - said Sir Christopher also deserved credit for "spanning that period between John Birt announcing he was leaving and Greg Dyke arriving".

"He masterminded the appointment of Greg, which was a thoroughly excellent piece of work.

"Strangely enough for someone who had been in the commercial sector all his days before coming to the BBC, Christopher had a strong and passionate commitment to public service broadcasting.

"He very much carried out that role of being the guardian of public service broadcasting standards."

"Strangely enough for someone who had been in the commercial sector all his days before coming to the BBC, Christopher had a strong and passionate commitment to public service broadcasting. "He very much carried out that role of being the guardian of public service broadcasting standards." fields.headline: Bedside stories
fields.standfirst: The junior doctor grows ever more irritated with his patients, but then along comes a parsnip to cheer him
fields.trailText: The junior doctor grows ever more irritated with his patients, but then along comes a parsnip to cheer him.
fields.body:
Being your doctor is worse than being your mum. Unconditional love, that's what you expect. You think that your mortality is so bloody important that it's weird if we want to go home. "Doctor, exactly why hasn't my mother had a normal bowel movement since this morning?" "I'm not going home until I get the result of my scan." Oh yes you are.

Fortunately, the unreasonable bad behaviour of the unappeasable few has allowed me to develop a professional emotional distance. I have been watching, and it has happened to all of us. We are cleaved from the reality of your pain. Those moments when the nurses bleeped to tell us that Mr P's family were here again, demanding to see a doctor (about why being fat and eating shit gives you bowel cancer, perhaps) and making ludicrous grunting noises about going to the press and the General Medical Council: we shan't be staying late for them any more. Thank you, and bad luck.

Fortunately, people are still sticking interesting things up their bottoms to keep us all in good spirits. I am called from my bleary sleep at three in the morning and curse my way across the barren snow-cursed wasteland that separates my room from the hospital, to find as I wake on arrival that I am wearing theatre bottoms, a white coat, an orange scarf, a woolly hat and a medical school t-shirt with the phrase "diseases are afraid of me" scribbled across the front.

Nights on call are so weird you sometimes wonder if they ever really happened at all. "Did I really wake up at three in the morning when my bleep went off, and spend 20 minutes heroically (and single-handedly) managing a torrential gastrointestinal bleed before retiring once more to my bed?" I sometimes wonder. "Or did I merely answer the phone, mumble some reassuring sleep-fudge to the nurse, go back to sleep, and dream the entire episode? If so, did the patient die? And will I consequently be arrested?"

Anyway, it's not every day that you get called to see a patient with a parsnip lodged in their anus. Root vegetables in general are pretty popular, apparently, but don't let me get away with being sage about it: this was my first vegetable-in-arse call. I was delighted, but my professionalism was breathtaking.

Now, for the purposes of this anecdote, there are certain things you have to know about surgeons. For historical reasons their hobbies are sport, sexism and homophobia, and although there are almost certainly some female surgeons somewhere I've never seen one. An example of surgeons in action: if I am not able to hold a retractor for long enough in theatre, this is because I am either a "poofter" or a "big fat girl".

Outraged? I suppose they don't mean any harm. They're just overqualified manual labourers with aspirations to working-class chic, which they get a little bit wrong. They think it's big and clever. So what if they're doctors. I'm too tired to think about it.

Anyway, this patient has a parsnip up his arse - I cannot even be bothered with the explanation - and we have to get it out. God knows why he can't shit it out. But there you go, I'm just a house officer, I'm as much in the dark as you are on most stuff. Needless to say, I call for senior assistance. First the senior house officer tries his hand, but every time he thinks he's caught it, the tapered end slips further in. Then we think about instruments, but the registrar is worried about perforating the bowel. There is only one option: we sit on it.

In theatre next morning we find our patient once more on his side, this time lightly anaesthetised. Apparently, there is a scene out there for using ketamine as an aid to fisting, the anaesthetist tells me. I pretend not to know what either of those things are because I'm too tired to cope with a weird conversation. Everyone gets down to business.

The SHO successfully grasps the misplaced vegetable through the grossly dilated orifice and begins to edge back. The tension in the room is almost unbearable. All eyes are upon him, and as he eases the offending vegetable gently out, success seems imminent. As the sprouts clear the anal verge, suddenly the patient's flaccid penis begins to twitch, and then emits a steady stream of sticky grey fluid. No one can realistically deny it is semen.

Everyone turns to the SHO, and the SHO turns to the registrar looking concerned. The registrar holds his index finger aloft and raises an eyebrow: clearly this is the most urgent question of his entire homophobic sparring career. He is genuinely inquisitive. "Charles, darling. does that make you gay?"

fields.headline: Marathon man
fields.trailText: I'm looking at my running shoes. They lie, rather meekly now, in the corner of my bedroom.They betray few clues of the horrors they have witnessed.
fields.body:
I'm looking at my running shoes. They lie, rather meekly now, in the corner of my bedroom. A piece of paper has fallen into the left one. They betray few clues of the horrors they have witnessed. They are just simple symbols of traumatic times past. Once upon a time merely catching sight of those shoes would send me into a guilty sweat - knowing they should be attached to me, knowing that I should be training.

But that was then. And now it's more than four days since the London marathon ended and there is no longer a reason to run. Which leaves me feeling a bit empty.

Sure, there has been no shortage of food - I've eaten like a buffalo since Sunday. It's just that I feel sort of emotionally vacuous. I thought the exhilaration of the achievement would have lasted longer than your average cigarette. I was expecting a higher high, a happier happy. But then maybe I am still exhilarated and I've just got used to the feeling.

Whatever. I know it's always best to step back and wait a few days until you pass judgment on important events. Not advisable in air traffic control, but if you have just experienced the nearest thing to multiple surgery without anaesthetic it's important to remain calm, make no rash movements, no rash statements.

So I can, with the benefit of time, assess my endeavours: I survived and I got round and that's what counts. As the pain has subsided, so too my memories of the day have become clearer. The crowds and buildings, colour and friends, the noise, the music, the streets sticky with fallen sugary drinks. The first miles full of happiness and hope, the legs working perfectly, feeling fine. Then the last miles, the quite indescribable pain, the fear that my body could shut down and leave me still. And finally the end, the relief and the promises of never again.

Now it's back to life. I'll have to watch my body. It's been a while since I let it loose in restaurants and pubs. I'll have to learn how to go out in the evenings without shaking my legs and stretching.

And I'll have to decide what to do with those shoes with which I have bonded. Maybe I'll bury them with ceremony, place them in a cabinet, put them in my attic. Or maybe I'll wear them again. Like an old hired gun going back to his favourite weapon. Indeed, maybe I'll keep them there in the corner of my room, put them on again, go for a jog, run another run with my friends.

 Munk finished the London marathon in 4 hours, 37 minutes. This is his final column.

fields.headline: Diary of a hypochondriac
fields.standfirst: Matthew Norman suffers troubled nights - it seems the lump in his throat might really be a tumour after all
fields.trailText: Matthew Norman suffers troubled nights - it seems the lump in his throat might really be a tumour after all.
fields.body:
Friday

Just as with a newly broken heart or a bereavement, the only decent moment of the day is the first millisecond of wakefulness before the horrid reality floods into the conscious mind. I wake, open my eyes, swallow searchingly, and there it is ... the blockage I noticed five weeks ago, assuming it was psychosomatic (it became noticeable while I was re-reading John Diamond's account of his throat cancer on the day after his death). However, I am now convinced it is a growth.

Saturday

When Rebecca finds me sliding my Adam's apple from side to side, she seems concerned. "If you really are worried," she says, "shouldn't you see the doctor?" But I did see a doctor, a new chap at the Grove called Thomson, who said everything was fine, as far as he could see. The thing is, what's going on where he can't see?

Sunday

Rebecca returns from walking the dog to find me ending a call to my mother. "What does she think?" she asks as I put the phone down. "She thinks it's psychosomatic." "Well, there you are." "There I am? Where am I? My mother isn't a doctor." "Yes," says my wife, "but she thinks she is." "Well, what do you think it is?" "I don't think I'm a doctor, so I've no idea." The ensuing silence is not merely pregnant but nine months gone with triplets. "So what exactly should I say?" Rebecca mutters, eventually. "You're meant to say, and we've been through it a million times, 'I don't know, but I'm sure it's nothing to worry about.' " "OK," says Rebecca, "I don't know, but I'm sure it's nothing to worry about." "How on earth can you be sure?" I say, as she storms towards the stairs. "You're not a doctor."

Monday

As dusk falls over Shepherd's Bush I retrieve my wife's address book from its current hiding place (a Wellington Boot drying out in the boiler room). But when I turn to the J section, I find that the last two numbers of Sarah Jarvis's home number have been Tipp-Exed out. It could be any one of a 100 possibilities, from 00 to 99, and I am just apologising for dialling a wrong number for the 42nd time when Rebecca appears to confiscate the book.

Tuesday

I awake limp and morose after a monstrously troubled night. In the dream, Dr Jarvis refers me to a Harley Street ENT specialist, who turns out be the youthful-looking public health minister Yvette Cooper. Midway through the prissy lecture about smoking, she notices that her Hear'Say CD is visible on the desk and slides it beneath under the pile of Jackies and Just 17s. Then she takes the endoscope and slides it down my throat. "I'm very sorry," she murmurs after removing it, "but you're right, there is something there. Remind me, when did you notice a problem?" At this, the tumour leaps out of my throat. "About five weeks ago," says the tumour, pointing at me. "It started as a boil on my arse."

Wednesday

Wearily, Dr Jarvis asks me for the symptoms (I have cracked the home number on only the 73rd attempt), and 40 seconds into my resumé she interrupts. "Globus," she says. "It's something called globus hystericus, a psychosomatic condition brought on by ... hang on, I'll get the book." A minute later she returns. "Blah, blah, blah ... found in people with a strong fear of cancer," she paraphrases, "blah, blah ... brought on by a friend or neighbour contracting throat cancer." "Oh, you won't like this," she continues, before asking me to attend the Grove at 8.30am tomorrow, "it says the only way to set your mind at rest is an endoscopy."

Thursday

In Room 19, Dr Jarvis says my throat looks fine but refers again to the endoscopy. "I won't need that, doctor. It's gone." She smiles. "I see, so my diagnosis convinced you." "Yes. Well, no. Rebecca's friend Gerry was over last night, and when I mentioned my problem she said she'd had absolutely the identical thing. Astonishing. And the second she told me that, the lump went. Not of course," I add, noticing a thinning of the doctor's lips, "that your diagnosis didn't help." But it's too little too late, and pausing only to print out an eardrop prescription (a touch of otitis externa), Dr Jarvis rises smartly and guides me through her door.

webTitle: John Aglionby on the Nepalese conjoined twins

fields.headline: When one becomes two
fields.standfirst: It took 84 hours to separate Ganga and Jamuna, who were born joined at the head. As the fight to save them continues,  John Aglionby meets the surgical team in Singapore
fields.trailText: It took 84 hours to separate Ganga and Jamuna, who were born joined at the head. As the fight to save them continues, John Aglionby meets the surgical team in Singapore.
fields.body:
"ouston, we have separation," plastic surgeon Vincent Yeow announced, as he made the final snip at 1.42am, 16 days ago. And with that Ganga and Jamuna Shrestha, who were born sharing a skull, officially became two.

The joke eased the tension in the packed operating theatre in Singapore general hospital - and what tension there had been. That final snip came after more than 84 hours of unprecedented, non-stop surgery, and 11 months to the day of barely imaginable hardship for two Nepalese babies from a remote mountain village who had never been able to roll over, sit up or even see each other.

Any thoughts of breaking out the champagne never even occurred, however, says Dr Ho Lai Yun, the man in charge of their post-operative care: separating the babies was only the beginning. "It's like climbing Mount Everest," he says. "You have reached the peak and that's an achievement in itself but you still have to get home."

It all began last August when Dr Keith Goh, a consultant neurosurgeon at the hospital, was told about Ganga and Jamuna by a former tutor, Dr Upendra Devakota, who was then practising in his home country of Nepal. "He did not know what to do with the babies," Goh says, "but knew that we had previously treated complex cases, so we got talking about it."

After much arm-twisting and cajoling of hospital administrators and colleagues, Goh decided to bring over the twins, along with their mother Sandhya Shrestha, father KC Bushan, and her father Arjun Dev Shrestha for the operation.

"The large Nepali community here was a big factor," he says. "The family were simple people and if you had placed them in a huge, western city in those circumstances, I think they would not have been able to survive."

Sandhya had already endured an awful ordeal. Not only had the kindergarten teacher had a crude caesarean in a rural hospital, but it had been three months before she found out that her twins were conjoined. "She was very ill to begin with," says a hospital source. "And then when she recovered she was at home but the girls were still at the hospital and the family, including her husband, kept deceiving her about the true state of the girls." Eventually they ran out of excuses and took Sandhya to see her daughters. "She burst into tears when she saw them." By that stage Jamuna was much larger than Ganga because the latter has a cleft palate and was having trouble feeding.

When they arrived in Singapore, the family settled in with the Gurkha community while the honoury consul, MN Swami, started raising funds for the medical expenses. "The initial goal was about 100,000 Singapore dollars (£38,000)," he says. "But the response was so overwhelming we eventually stopped at S$650,000." Four thousand Singaporeans gave money.

Meanwhile, Goh and his team were getting to know the girls. "Jamuna is more introvert and behaves like a lady while Ganga is more like a man or a tomboy. She calls people to play with her while the other is more fussy with her food," says Dr Chumpon Chan, the leading vascular neurosurgeon on the team.

"They were obviously aware of each other," Dr Goh says. "We sometimes saw them reaching out towards each other and feeling the other's head. When one was crying the other would be asleep and when the other made noise the one that was asleep would wake up and get angry. They would try and turn over and find that they couldn't, and get so frustrated."

The doctors faced several major problems. The first was that the girls shared a common skull cavity with nothing between the two brains. Then the team discovered the girls shared veins - blood entered their brains via separate arteries but drained by a common vein. But the biggest challenge was finding a way to create enough skin to cover the two brains once they had been separated.

"We knew Jamuna could get complete skin cover," Goh says. "Did that mean we should ensure 100% survival for her and let Ganga take her chances? Or should we treat them as equal and risk losing both?"

After countless discussions, the family made the decision - they wanted both to have an equal chance. Creating extra scalp cover was done by implanting balloon-type expanders into the girls' heads and injecting saline into the sacks. Meanwhile the medical team prepared with the help of nylon composite models and a cutting-edge 3D computer system called a Dextrascope, that superimposed images of the skull, the brains and the blood vessels on top of each other.

Everything appeared to be going well until two days before the planned operation date in January, when Dr Lee Seng Teik, the leading plastic surgeon, discovered Ganga's skin expander had stretched the scalp too far and caused an infection. "There was no way we could go ahead," Teik says. "So we took everything out, allowed the infection to settle and then went in a second time and inserted a second expander."

Finally they were ready. As Goh stood above the anaethsetised twins at about 4pm on Friday April 6, to make the first incision, he realised he was terrified. "We were trying to dismantle something that God had put together. I'm not sure about the ethics of that, but there was soul-searching and mental anguish the weekend before."

Separating them was far from easy. Not only were the two brains lying half on top of each other, but Teik needed the cutting to be done in a certain way to preserve as much skin cover as possible. Initially everything went very smoothly - the surgeons found a clear plane of separation between the brains. "Each brain was protected by a membrane," Goh says. "It was like a wall between two rooms." But the wall ended about a quarter of the way into the brain. The separation then became "like walking along a garden path covered in leaves and branches and having to decide which to keep and which to move to which side," Goh says. "Except that we were moving a millimetre at a time." They helped make decisions by sending electric pulses to different parts of the mass of brain in front of them to see which limb of which girl responded.

Chan, who did most of the vascular work, says he had no idea of time passing. "When you're doing the operation, you're just focusing on what's in front of you," he says. "You hear noises but you don't know what's being said or how long you're taking."

Seventy-two hours into the operation, after turning the twins over a couple of times - a process which took several hours each time - crisis struck. Blood was flowing from Jamuna to Ganga but not back again. Ganga appeared to be in the most critical condition so the doctors drew blood from Jamuna and physically pumped it into Ganga. They also tilted the operating table to let gravity help. After a couple of hours calm was restored and the girls' vital signs returned to normal.

Once separation was completed, Jamuna was covered first because she had the smaller brain and the better natural coverage. Ganga was more problematic because there was eventually a patch of brain the size of a 50p coin that could not be covered. Teik resolved this by using a piece of Integra, an artificial fibrous tissue.

The babies' recovery since then has been far from trouble-free. Ganga initially appeared to be in greater peril - she had a more serious infection and persistent fever. But then, last Saturday, during a regular examination, Dr Teik discovered that a 12cm-square section of the pericranium flap on Jamuna's head had not survived. "The skin graft was lost and we were virtually back to square one," he says. "We had to go in again or we would have lost her." "Going in" entailed a 19-hour operation on Sunday during which muscle was taken from her back along with more skin from her thigh for a fresh graft. It appears this second graft is healing as it should, he says, touching wood.

"They've come a long way but they're not out of danger yet," he says. "The next six to eight weeks are going to be critical." With luck the girls will be heading home in about six months.

By then the neurosurgeons should be able to have an idea of how much motor damage the girls have suffered. Goh says the signs so far are promising - neither girl is paralysed. "We believe we're over the worst, but we have no idea where the end will be or when we will get there."

And with that Ganga and Jamuna Shrestha, who were born sharing a skull, officially became two. The joke eased the tension in the packed operating theatre in Singapore general hospital - and what tension there had been. That final snip came after more than 84 hours of unprecedented, non-stop surgery, and 11 months to the day of barely imaginable hardship for two Nepalese babies from a remote mountain village who had never been able to roll over, sit up or even see each other. Any thoughts of breaking out the champagne never even occurred, however, says Dr Ho Lai Yun, the man in charge of their post-operative care: separating the babies was only the beginning. "It's like climbing Mount Everest," he says. "You have reached the peak and that's an achievement in itself but you still have to get home." It all began last August when Dr Keith Goh, a consultant neurosurgeon at the hospital, was told about Ganga and Jamuna by a former tutor, Dr Upendra Devakota, who was then practising in his home country of Nepal. "He did not know what to do with the babies," Goh says, "but knew that we had previously treated complex cases, so we got talking about it." After much arm-twisting and cajoling of hospital administrators and colleagues, Goh decided to bring over the twins, along with their mother Sandhya Shrestha, father KC Bushan, and her father Arjun Dev Shrestha for the operation. "The large Nepali community here was a big factor," he says. "The family were simple people and if you had placed them in a huge, western city in those circumstances, I think they would not have been able to survive." Sandhya had already endured an awful ordeal. Not only had the kindergarten teacher had a crude caesarean in a rural hospital, but it had been three months before she found out that her twins were conjoined. "She was very ill to begin with," says a hospital source. "And then when she recovered she was at home but the girls were still at the hospital and the family, including her husband, kept deceiving her about the true state of the girls." Eventually they ran out of excuses and took Sandhya to see her daughters. "She burst into tears when she saw them." By that stage Jamuna was much larger than Ganga because the latter has a cleft palate and was having trouble feeding. When they arrived in Singapore, the family settled in with the Gurkha community while the honoury consul, MN Swami, started raising funds for the medical expenses. "The initial goal was about 100,000 Singapore dollars (£38,000)," he says. "But the response was so overwhelming we eventually stopped at S$650,000." Four thousand Singaporeans gave money. Meanwhile, Goh and his team were getting to know the girls. "Jamuna is more introvert and behaves like a lady while Ganga is more like a man or a tomboy. She calls people to play with her while the other is more fussy with her food," says Dr Chumpon Chan, the leading vascular neurosurgeon on the team. "They were obviously aware of each other," Dr Goh says. "We sometimes saw them reaching out towards each other and feeling the other's head. When one was crying the other would be asleep and when the other made noise the one that was asleep would wake up and get angry. They would try and turn over and find that they couldn't, and get so frustrated." The doctors faced several major problems. The first was that the girls shared a common skull cavity with nothing between the two brains. Then the team discovered the girls shared veins - blood entered their brains via separate arteries but drained by a common vein. But the biggest challenge was finding a way to create enough skin to cover the two brains once they had been separated. "We knew Jamuna could get complete skin cover," Goh says. "Did that mean we should ensure 100% survival for her and let Ganga take her chances? Or should we treat them as equal and risk losing both?" After countless discussions, the family made the decision - they wanted both to have an equal chance. Creating extra scalp cover was done by implanting balloon-type expanders into the girls' heads and injecting saline into the sacks. Meanwhile the medical team prepared with the help of nylon composite models and a cutting-edge 3D computer system called a Dextrascope, that superimposed images of the skull, the brains and the blood vessels on top of each other. Everything appeared to be going well until two days before the planned operation date in January, when Dr Lee Seng Teik, the leading plastic surgeon, discovered Ganga's skin expander had stretched the scalp too far and caused an infection. "There was no way we could go ahead," Teik says. "So we took everything out, allowed the infection to settle and then went in a second time and inserted a second expander." Finally they were ready. As Goh stood above the anaethsetised twins at about 4pm on Friday April 6, to make the first incision, he realised he was terrified. "We were trying to dismantle something that God had put together. I'm not sure about the ethics of that, but there was soul-searching and mental anguish the weekend before." Separating them was far from easy. Not only were the two brains lying half on top of each other, but Teik needed the cutting to be done in a certain way to preserve as much skin cover as possible. Initially everything went very smoothly - the surgeons found a clear plane of separation between the brains. "Each brain was protected by a membrane," Goh says. "It was like a wall between two rooms." But the wall ended about a quarter of the way into the brain. The separation then became "like walking along a garden path covered in leaves and branches and having to decide which to keep and which to move to which side," Goh says. "Except that we were moving a millimetre at a time." They helped make decisions by sending electric pulses to different parts of the mass of brain in front of them to see which limb of which girl responded. Chan, who did most of the vascular work, says he had no idea of time passing. "When you're doing the operation, you're just focusing on what's in front of you," he says. "You hear noises but you don't know what's being said or how long you're taking." Seventy-two hours into the operation, after turning the twins over a couple of times - a process which took several hours each time - crisis struck. Blood was flowing from Jamuna to Ganga but not back again. Ganga appeared to be in the most critical condition so the doctors drew blood from Jamuna and physically pumped it into Ganga. They also tilted the operating table to let gravity help. After a couple of hours calm was restored and the girls' vital signs returned to normal. Once separation was completed, Jamuna was covered first because she had the smaller brain and the better natural coverage. Ganga was more problematic because there was eventually a patch of brain the size of a 50p coin that could not be covered. Teik resolved this by using a piece of Integra, an artificial fibrous tissue. The babies' recovery since then has been far from trouble-free. Ganga initially appeared to be in greater peril - she had a more serious infection and persistent fever. But then, last Saturday, during a regular examination, Dr Teik discovered that a 12cm-square section of the pericranium flap on Jamuna's head had not survived. "The skin graft was lost and we were virtually back to square one," he says. "We had to go in again or we would have lost her." "Going in" entailed a 19-hour operation on Sunday during which muscle was taken from her back along with more skin from her thigh for a fresh graft. It appears this second graft is healing as it should, he says, touching wood. "They've come a long way but they're not out of danger yet," he says. "The next six to eight weeks are going to be critical." With luck the girls will be heading home in about six months. By then the neurosurgeons should be able to have an idea of how much motor damage the girls have suffered. Goh says the signs so far are promising - neither girl is paralysed. "We believe we're over the worst, but we have no idea where the end will be or when we will get there."

fields.headline: Hague blasts chancellor's record
fields.trailText: The economy, and the prospects of a US recession hitting UK businesses, again took centre stage today, as the chancellor, Gordon Brown, and the Conservative leader, William Hague, exchanged insults ahead of the general election.
fields.body:
The economy, and the prospects of a US recession hitting UK businesses, again took centre stage today, as the chancellor, Gordon Brown, and the Conservative leader, William Hague, exchanged insults ahead of the general election.

Mr Brown hit back at the Tories after William Hague launched an all-out attack on his claim to be a "prudent" chancellor.

The Conservative leader used a high profile speech this morning to warn the Government's policies had left the country in "bad shape" to cope with an economic slowdown.

However Mr Brown dismissed the suggestion that he had been imprudent as "ridiculous", and said Tory tax and spending plans would wreck Britain's hard-won economic stability.

"Because we have got fiscal discipline, because we have got monetary policy under control, we are well-placed to deal with difficulties," said Mr Brown.

And he warned that the policies being offered by Mr Hague and the shadow chancellor, Michael Portillo, were simply a repeat of the failed Conservative policies of the 1980s which led to recession in the early 1990s.

Mr Brown said: "That policy was essentially to cut public investment, which they are proposing now. They would then have tax cuts which they cannot support or afford over the long term. They would pay for that by borrowing.

"That is a recipe for a return to the boom and bust that we had in the past."

In a speech this lunchtime to the Centre for Policy Studies, Mr Hague argued that Labour's failure to cut taxes and reform the welfare system, while imposing increasing burdens on business, had left the economy exposed.

He said: "If Labour did take Britain into the euro, the country's one weapon to get out of trouble - its ability to set its own interest rates - would be taken away.

"We're in bad shape to hold our own in an economic downturn. Rather than plotting a course for stability, Gordon Brown is following an imprudent path in an uncertain world.

"Relentlessly raising taxes is the opposite of prudent preparation for economic difficulties. If it is misguided, on the verge of a potential sharp downturn, to be raising taxes on struggling businesses, it is all the more so when the rest of the world is going in the opposite direction."

Conservative aides indicated that Mr Hague's speech was the "opening shot" in what would be a sustained assault on Labour's record on the economy in the run-up to the next general election.

Despite Labour strategists viewing the economy as their one of their strongest policy areas, the Tories believe the threat of a worsening economic outlook could now make them vulnerable.

fields.headline: Who will replace Bland?
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk's list of runners and riders for the soon-to-be vacated post of BBC chairman
fields.trailText: 1.30pm update: MediaGuardian.co.uk has compiled a list of possible contenders for the soon-to-be vacated chairmanship of the BBC.
fields.body:
Gavyn Davies
50, Goldman Sachs chief economist, deputy chairman of the BBC
Well placed for the job. A friend of Greg Dyke and Gordon Brown. Has a working knowledge of the BBC - until recently made regular appearances on the news as a commentator on the economy and he also chaired the independent review panel on BBC funding. He is a New Labour insider and a highly respected economist who distinguished himself with his controversial recommendation of a digital supplement to the licence fee in 1999. But he would be seen as a Tony crony. With Greg Dyke, a former Labour party member as director general, would be a dangerous appointment, leaving the BBC open to accusations that it was an arm of the Labour party. Chances: fair

Lord Cranbourne
56, leftwing Tory
Former Tory leader of the Lords, sacked by William Hague after doing a deal with Tony Blair to keep some life peers and to the left of most Tories. Would appease critics who claim the BBC is a Labour poodle. Chances: very good

Baroness Jay of Paddington
61, leader of the House of Lords
Currently Labour leader of the House of Lords, where she is nicknamed "posh spice", but is stepping down at the general election. Jay is Labour aristocracy - she's the daughter of former prime minister Jim Callaghan. If she got the BBC job she would become the boss of ex-husband Peter, the BBC's economics and business editor. Will be forever remembered for having an affair with Watergate reporter Carl Bernstein when Peter was Britain's US ambassador in the 1970s.
Chances: good.

Lord Alli
36, member of Labour kitchen cabinet
Labour peer and wealthy TV executive. Founded Big Breakfast company Planet 24 with partner Charlie Parsons then sold out to Carlton TV where he briefly held an executive position. Openly gay, he is passionate about campaigning for equal rights for homosexuals and ethnic minorities. Has insider knowledge of both politics and media and has a mischievious streak - he once got into trouble for using the House of Lords address to advertise for staff for a new gay internet website. Chairmanship of the BBC would be a landmark, making him the first Asian to get to such heights, but would be seen as a Tony crony.
Chances: poor

Michael Heseltine
68, Tory wet
Former member of Margaret Thatcher's cabinet whose career came to an abrupt halt over the Westland helicopters affair and later his unsuccessful leadership challenge. His career was resuscitated under John Major when he became chairman of the board of trade, but heart problems forced an abrupt end to his Westminster career. Inside knowledge of both politics and the media - through his 30-year tenure of publishing company Haymarket - makes him a good candidate, as do his Tory leanings. Could be an inspired compromise candidate.
Chances: very good

Gerald Kaufman
70, Labour backbencher
The original culture vulture, the chairman of the Commons select committee on media knows the industry better than most. The MP for Gorton, Manchester since 1983 worked as a journalist on leftwing papers before becoming a Labour spin doctor. He provides better opposition on media issues than the Tories.
Chances: rank outsider

Alastair Campbell
43, PM's spin doctor
Prime minister's press secretary Campbell has been on the left throughout his career, which began in journalism. The former Daily Mirror political editor became Tony Blair's press man in 1994 and has been trying to control the media ever since. He certainly will have spare time on his hands after the general election - he recently announced he would be stepping down to take a more hands-off role at No 10.
Chances: no hope

Peter Mandelson
47, former Secretary of State for Northern Ireland
Another in-the-wilderness MP who has lots of spare time on his hands. The MP for Hartlepool and architect of New Labour has sharp media manipulation skills and would be ideal to take the BBC through the "modernisation" process that Greg Dyke has ordered. His pomposity matches that of Sir Christopher's, adding to his chances. And he knows a thing or two about the BBC. Newsnight recently admitted it was biased against him during the Hinduja affair and he famously pressured the BBC into banning references to his homosexuality. But his friendship with Blair, and his propensity to lose jobs makes him too accident prone. Too high risk.
Chances: will fall at first hurdle

Lord John Wakeham
68, Chairman of the Press Complaints Commission
The smooth Press Complaints Commission chairman is as well known for pragmatism and diplomatic skills now as he was for being a powerful "fixer" while serving as a Tory MP under both Thatcher and Major. He survived a number of reshuffles and, as chief whip, is said to have run his whips like the chief of police.
Chances: medium to good

Lord Bragg
62, polymath
Melvyn Bragg's credentials are excellent - a lifetime in broadcasting, a lifetime promoting Labour and close bonds with Tony Blair. He has published several novels, including the controversial A Time to Dance, but he is best known as presenter of the South Bank Show. He has made a career of championing upmarket, intelligent television, although he has been accused of dumbing down the arts with documentaries on subjects such as Joan Collins. A downside is he is seen as a Tony crony. Friends, however, say he is "one to watch". They claim the PM would be happy to put up with the jibes about the Blair Broadcasting Corporation. "The Tories have always put their men in, so why won't he?"
Chances: good to very good

Liz Forgan
56, TV writer and broadcaster
The former head of BBC network radio and director of programmes at Channel 4, Ms Forgan certainly has the pedigree for the job. She has her own production company, Arrowhead Productions. She quit the BBC after clashing with Lord Birt's head prefect Tony Hall - then head of news and current affairs - over the future of radio journalism at the corporation. She could be the first woman to chair the BBC although she may not have the influence in Labour circles to cement the promotion.
Chances: fair

fields.headline: The original cyberpunk
fields.standfirst: The reclusive science fiction writer, William Gibson, who influenced a generation, is now the star of a revealing movie,  says Sean Dodson
fields.trailText:
The reclusive science fiction writer, William Gibson, who influenced a generation, is now the star of a revealing movie,
says Sean Dodson
fields.body:
William Gibson is the most influential science fiction writer of his generation. In 1984 he published his groundbreaking debut novel, Neuromancer, to critical and public acclaim, and almost single-handedly defined cyberspace.

He is a virtual recluse now rarely giving interviews. Yet five years ago he approached the British director Mark Neale to make a documentary about his life and work. The result is No Maps for These Territories, a 90-minute film being previewed in London on Monday.

Produced on a meagre budget of $250,000, the film features original music from Bono and The Edge from U2. Part road movie, part autobiography, the film offers an intimate portrait of the writer of seven best-selling science fiction novels.

No Maps is told mostly in monologue, mostly by Gibson sitting in the back of a car wired with micro-cameras, a fax machine and the internet. The film is interspersed with other interviews, most notably with fellow "cyberpunk" author Bruce Sterling and both Bono and The Edge read from Gibson's books.

Neale says the film couldn't have been made so cheaply five years ago. "I was able to operate the whole set-up myself," he explains. "We shot over 50 hours of interview with him [Gibson]; very, very cheaply. Both in terms of what it cost and the practicalities of shooting it with micro-cameras, the film is very much a digital production."

Initially Neale acted as Gibson's driver in LA, picking him up after publishers meetings and interviewing him as the pair drove back to Gibson's home in Vancouver. Later, the pair drove further afield, visiting New York, Detroit and Austin, Texas. Neale doesn't appear in the documentary. Instead, the viewer gets the impression that a computer in the car interviews Gibson.

Mark Neale is an LA-based former music director who has made videos for U2, Paul Weller and the Counting Crows. Neale met Gibson while working on the Channel 4 series, Buzz, in the early 90s. The pair first collaborated at the Seville Expo in 1992.

"He'll talk until the cows come home about literature," explains Neale. "But the stuff he hasn't gone on the record about in the past, things like the loss of his parents, his dodging of the draft and taking drugs took a long time to get out of him. I had to go back and ask him those things several times. But drug culture was such a big part of his life.

"He decided to go on the record in a way that he has very deliberately avoided for a long time. Bits and pieces of his story have come out in interviews over the years, but the full story hasn't been told in its entirety. I suppose he has always been a bit of a recluse."

Gibson is writing the script for Neuromancer with another British director Chris Cunningham. The film was due to start filming this summer, but both now feel they need to reinvent it as it has been picked bare by so many other science fiction films.

Interestingly enough, for a writer who has had such a massive influence on the science fiction films of the last decade, only one of his short stories has been adapted for the cinema. "A lot of people think that The Matrix or Neal Stephenson originated this stuff," says Neale. "I think that the film is a timely reminder that he started a whole style of science fiction."The film has no distributor, but Neale is hoping for a limited theatrical release later this summer. But he sees the real target for No Maps as being the DVD market. Neale hopes to have it in the shops by the autumn. This will enable some of the masses of raw footage gathered during the filming to be shown, but Neale hopes that, ultimately, all 50 hours will end up on the net.

"Five years ago the internet was something that most people still hadn't experienced. And today my mother who lives in a little village in Devon is aware of the dizzying pace of technological change, the film does address that things are really unstable."

Beyond that there is talk of a sequel, next time shot in Tokyo and London. Gibson saw a sneak preview of the film at a festival in Vancouver last year. He said he was proud of it and told Neale he was proud of it and proud of him.

• No Maps for These Territories is being screened as part of the onedotzero festival at the ICA in London.

Bits and pieces of his story have come out in interviews over the years, but the full story hasn't been told in its entirety. I suppose he has always been a bit of a recluse." Gibson is writing the script for Neuromancer with another British director Chris Cunningham. The film was due to start filming this summer, but both now feel they need to reinvent it as it has been picked bare by so many other science fiction films. Interestingly enough, for a writer who has had such a massive influence on the science fiction films of the last decade, only one of his short stories has been adapted for the cinema. "A lot of people think that The Matrix or Neal Stephenson originated this stuff," says Neale. "I think that the film is a timely reminder that he started a whole style of science fiction."The film has no distributor, but Neale is hoping for a limited theatrical release later this summer. But he sees the real target for No Maps as being the DVD market. Neale hopes to have it in the shops by the autumn. This will enable some of the masses of raw footage gathered during the filming to be shown, but Neale hopes that, ultimately, all 50 hours will end up on the net. "Five years ago the internet was something that most people still hadn't experienced. And today my mother who lives in a little village in Devon is aware of the dizzying pace of technological change, the film does address that things are really unstable." Beyond that there is talk of a sequel, next time shot in Tokyo and London. Gibson saw a sneak preview of the film at a festival in Vancouver last year. He said he was proud of it and told Neale he was proud of it and proud of him. • No Maps for These Territories is being screened as part of the onedotzero festival at the ICA in London.

webTitle: Shayler case begins in high court

fields.headline: Shayler case begins in high court
fields.standfirst: Special report: The Shayler case
fields.trailText: New human rights legislation has not granted spies and former intelligence agents the ability to disclose state secrets, the prosecutor in the David Shayler case said today.
fields.body:
New human rights legislation has not granted spies and former intelligence agents the ability to disclose state secrets, the prosecutor in the David Shayler case said today.

Lawyers began preliminary arguments today about the three charges faced by the ex-MI5 agent under the Official Secrets Act. The 35-year-old former spy is accused of leaking details of the security services' activities to a Sunday newspaper four years ago.

Arriving at the high court in London with girlfriend and ex-MI5 agent Annie Machon and members of his family, Mr Shayler said: "We are going to put the British state on trial. I have nothing to fear - but they have everything to fear."

Mr Shayler is expected to claim his prosecution under the Official Secrets Act is incompatible with the Human Rights Act, which protects free speech.

Today prosecutor Nigel Sweeney QC told the hearing before Mr Justice Moses: "By any sensible approach as to what the factual background ought to be, section 1 (of the OSA) is plainly compatible with Article 10 of the ECHR."

Mr Shayler will only face charges relating to an article in the Mail on Sunday in 1997 and none concerning a whole range of allegations he has made since then about the activities of MI5 and MI6.

There is a strong likelihood the case will get no further than the legal argument stage, Mr Shayler insisted this morning.

"It's obvious that this trial will be put back as a result of this preliminary hearing, possibly to appeal at the House of Lords," he said. "If it takes place it will take place after the General Election.

"We plan to subpoena [home secretary] Jack Straw and [foreign secretary] Robin Cook and it is quite obvious they don't want to answer questions in open court right before an election."

Mr Shayler claimed in the Mail on Sunday that agents in the 1970s tapped the telephone of the former Northern Ireland secretary, Peter Mandelson, and kept a file on Jack Straw.

The ex-agent claimed that he made these disclosures and his later revelations to expose incompetence and malpractice in the security services.

Two of the charges relate to unauthorised disclosure of security service information and the third relates to revealing details of telephone taps. Each carries a maximum sentence of two years.

Both the prosecution and the defence could take Mr Justice Moses' decision on the human rights issue to judicial review, delaying the case for months.

fields.headline: Walsh: Taylor has 'destroyed' Leicester
fields.trailText: Former Leicester captain Steve Walsh has accused Peter Taylor of "systematically destryoing" the successful team he inherited at Filbert Street from Martin O'Neill.
fields.body:
Former Leicester captain Steve Walsh has accused Peter Taylor of "systematically destryoing" the successful team he inherited at Filbert Street from Martin O'Neill.

Walsh has also suggested that there is "unrest" amongst the players, after a disastrous run of results which has seen the club knocked out of the FA Cup against Second Division Wycombe and lose seven Premiership games in a row. If Leicester are beaten by Newcastle on Saturday, it will be their eighth consecutive league defeat, a club record.

Walsh, who remains a favourite amongst the Filbert Street crowd, is now plying his trade with non-league Tamworth.

"In eight months, he has systematically destroyed [O'Neill's team]. Look who were the first to leave - Tony Cottee, myself and Stan Collymore.

"Even though we've lost Emile Heskey to Liverpool and Neil Lennon to Celtic, we got big money back. But we've spent a lot on players who are yet to convince the fans of their Premiership quality."

Walsh went on suggest that players such as Muzzy Izzet, Matt Elliott and Robbie Savage could be on their way in the summer, leaving Leicester fans with only a relegation struggle to entertain them next season.

"There's definite unrest in the dressing room," said Walsh. "I think it's going to be an eventful summer with some players who can now see the problems. It's possible others could leave."

Taylor, for his part, insists that the club's problems are down to a lengthy injury list which also claimed defender Gerry Taggart today. The Northern Ireland international will miss the rest of the season with a knee problem.

"Any side would miss players of this calibre", said Taylor, "but we will have to battle through without them as best as we can and we are desperate to end this losing sequence."
