fields.headline: Chechnya fuels Russian-Turkish tension
fields.standfirst: A series of incidents have heightened the cold war rivalry between Moscow and Ankara, reports Ian Traynor
fields.trailText: A series of incidents have heightened the cold war rivalry between Moscow and Ankara, reports Ian Traynor.
fields.body:
The age-old rivalry between Russia and Turkey over influence in the strategic near-east regions of the Caucasus, the Black sea, and the Caspian basin is feeding increasingly into the bloody Chechnya conflict, deepening mistrust on both sides of the Bosphorus.

The Turkish foreign minister, Ismail Cem, arrived in Russia today for a four-day visit during which his hosts are certain to give him an earful about perceived Turkish support for pro-Chechen ''terrorists'' and ''extremists'' following this week's hostage drama at a posh Istanbul hotel.

When 13 pro-Chechen gunmen took over the Swissotel and held 120 guests and staff hostage for 12 hours, it was the second major act of anti-Russian violence in Istanbul in two months.

Last month Chechen gunmen hijacked a Russian aircraft from Istanbul to Saudi Arabia. Three people were killed when Saudi special forces eventually stormed the plane in Medina and freed the hostages.

Mohammed Tokcan, a Turk of ethnic Chechen origin who was the ringleader of this week's hostage-taking, was also involved in the 1996 hijacking of a Russian passenger ferry from the Turkish port of Trabzon to the Russian Black sea resort of Sochi.

Of the nine men involved in the ship hijack, four, including Tokcan, quickly escaped from jail after being sentenced. After being re-arrested, Tokcan was then amnestied last December.

To Russian eyes, such events smack not just of leniency towards convicted hijackers or turning a blind eye to their operations, but of outright complicity with ''terrorists'' in the interests of the Turkish state.

In the clash between big Russian nationalism and Chechen separatism, the Turks are broadly sympathetic to their co-religionist Muslim Chechens, whose language is also Turkic.

Chechen refugees are welcome in Turkey, where there are estimated to be some 5m people of Chechen origin.

That diaspora, Moscow protests, has long been a breeding ground for Chechen guerrillas. The separatists, it is claimed, also undergo training and obtain or purchase weapons in Turkey.

Ankara and Moscow have been sparring for centuries for control of the mineral-rich Caspian and Black sea regions. The Kremlin contends that the end of the Soviet Union and the weakening of Russia have boosted Turkish ambitions in the region and that Ankara is now engaged in a frantic cloak-and-dagger campaign to destabilise southern Russia.

Russia and Turkey are on opposing sides of the contest to control the gas and oil deposits of the Caspian. As Nato's key south-eastern flank and window into the Middle East, Turkey is also viewed suspiciously in Moscow as a lynchpin of an expanding western alliance bent on encircling Russia.

The Kremlin lines up behind Greece and the Greek side of partitioned Cyprus in the Aegean contest and the Kremlin sees Turkey as a troublesome proxy for America following a policy aimed at keeping Russia down.

''The interests of Turkish intelligence are quite clear,'' Vladimir Lutsenko, an ex-KGB officer, told a Moscow newspaper this week. ''They are expanding their influence in the Caucasus and working with the Americans who are extremely keen on weakening Russia. Turkish intelligence is more dependent on the CIA than on its own national leadership.''

According to official leaks to the Moscow press, the Turkish intelligence service, the MIT, has become highly active in southern Russia since the end of the cold war.

If the bazaars of Istanbul exert a magnetic pull on hundreds of Russian traders migrating daily across the Bosphorus, the building sites of Moscow and southern Russia are fertile territory for Turkish workers and construction firms.

The two-way traffic provides ample scope for espionage. The Moscow investigative reporter, Alexander Khinshteyn, disclosed this week that six Turkish agents were quietly arrested last year alone, most of them in the Stavropol region of southern Russia.

Russian officials claim that the alleged Turkish agents operate largely without the knowledge of the civilian government in Ankara, but under the auspices of the Turkish military and secret service, with a remit to promote ''pan-Turkism'' among the millions of Turkic-speaking peoples of southern Russia.

''The MIT and the CIA are not only partners, but close allies,'' a former KGB resident in Ankara told Mr Khinshteyn. ''They have always been closely linked and their interests in the Caucasus are identical.''

webTitle: Airlines connect with in-flight net demand

fields.headline: Airlines connect with in-flight net demand
fields.trailText: British Airways and Virgin are preparing to sign up to a deal which will allow passengers connect to the internet during flights. By Keith Harper.
fields.byline: Keith Harper in Long Beach, California
fields.body:
Leading airlines including British Airways and Virgin are preparing to sign up to a deal which will allow airline passengers to connect to the internet during their journeys.

The proposed deal will also allow passengers to take their laptops on board and log on to local radio and TV stations, or link directly to their offices.

Among the leading companies, BA, Virgin, Lufthansa and Singapore Airlines are known to be interested in the system and are likely to make a decision in the next few months.

The idea is expected to be launched in the US later this year on routes between major cities, followed by the north Atlantic routes - including those to New York and London - later next year. This will require a satellite link for the north Atlantic, which is being developed at present. A survey among 60 leading companies has found that 80% of the travelling public considers having access to email important while flying, and that 71% would switch airlines to get connected.

Edward Laase, technical adviser to the project in which Boeing is involved, said the airlines would only have to pay the initial cost of connection, but admitted that problems had to be overcome if the busi ness developers tried to sell the idea to corporate customers, bypassing airlines. He agreed the airlines could object if firms were informed that they could keep a track on staff by allowing them to travel only with airlines where the system was installed. This would put other airlines at a disadvantage, eventually forcing them to introduce the service.

Mr Laase rejected suggestions that the safety of passengers would be put at risk by the introduction of the system. He said the plan required a licence from the civil aviation and telecommunications authorities - and that this would not be granted unless the plan had been cleared by regulators.

He said many business passengers already brought their laptops aboard, and on an average long-haul flight had them switched on for a third of the time.

fields.headline: £27bn talks ignite bid fever
fields.standfirst:
• Halifax and Bank of Scotland stun City • Job cuts feared in banking shake-up

Guardian Unlimited Money
fields.trailText: An unprecedented shake-up of retail banking is on the cards after the unexpected announcement yesterday of £27bn merger talks between Halifax and Bank of Scotland.
fields.body:
An unprecedented shake-up of retail banking is on the cards after the unexpected announcement yesterday of £27bn merger talks between Halifax and Bank of Scotland.

News of their negotiations stunned the City and prompted speculation about the long-term future of Abbey National, already being courted by Lloyds TSB, and Alliance & Leicester, which has been linked with National Australia Bank.

The surprise negotiations - announced yesterday after reports of the talks leaked - appeared to represent a u-turn by Halifax following its boasts of remaining independent. The disclosure raised concerns about job cuts in the combined 57,000 workforce.

There is added uncertainty about whether the head office will be located in Halifax or Edinburgh although early indications are that the England-based bank is ready to make substantial concessions to Scottish national sentiment.

BoS has suffered two humiliating defeats in as many years in its attempts to merge and has been seen as an obvious takeover target - perhaps for NAB, which already owns Scotland's Clydesdale.

If details can be agreed between Halifax, which initiated the talks, and BoS, the combined bank would create a "fifth force" on the high street and save £300m a year.

The combined bank would rival the big four - Lloyds TSB, Barclays, HSBC and NatWest/Royal Bank of Scotland - but a senior industry source last night stressed that the talks were not complete. He described them as "live, serious and continuing".

News of the talks increased the pressure on BoS and Halifax to reach an agreement quickly. Shares in both banks jumped as much as 8%, in part on expectation that their merger talks might be spoiled by intervention from other financial players such as NAB, Barclays and HSBC.

Halifax's shares ended 30p higher at 768p, still below the 774p at which they made their debut on the stock market four year ago, while BoS gained 61p to 803p. Abbey National, with which BoS tried to seal a deal last year only to see Lloyds TSB wade in, also gained.

Some City analysts predicted that the Halifax/BoS talks would increase the chances that Lloyds TSB's stalled £18bn bid for Abbey would be cleared by the competition commission when it reports to the Department of Trade and Industry in June.

One senior City source expressed surprise that BoS had entered into merger talks with Halifax while the outcome of that competition commission inquiry, regarded as crucial to the future framework of the banking industry, was unknown. The outcome might even clear the way for a resumption of talks between Abbey and BoS.

In a terse statement, Halifax and BoS said they were in talks "regarding a potential merger of equals", even though Halifax is worth some £17bn and BoS £10bn.

They said the deal would be structured at a "nil premium" and involve a straight swap of shares, which raised concerns that investors would balk at the terms because they would want to receive some cash for their shares.

Mark Thomas, analyst at investment bank Fox-Pitt, Kelton, put the chances of a deal being clinched at greater than 50-50 with potential problem areas being top jobs and location of the head office.

Industry sources believe that, under the terms being discussed, leading operations would be retained in Halifax and Edinburgh. Control would be split between Halifax's youthful chief executive, James Crosby, and Peter Burt, the 56-year-old chief executive of BoS. BoS's annual results are due next week.

Some City analysts predicted that the Halifax/BoS talks would increase the chances that Lloyds TSB's stalled £18bn bid for Abbey would be cleared by the competition commission when it reports to the Department of Trade and Industry in June. One senior City source expressed surprise that BoS had entered into merger talks with Halifax while the outcome of that competition commission inquiry, regarded as crucial to the future framework of the banking industry, was unknown. The outcome might even clear the way for a resumption of talks between Abbey and BoS. In a terse statement, Halifax and BoS said they were in talks "regarding a potential merger of equals", even though Halifax is worth some £17bn and BoS £10bn. They said the deal would be structured at a "nil premium" and involve a straight swap of shares, which raised concerns that investors would balk at the terms because they would want to receive some cash for their shares. Mark Thomas, analyst at investment bank Fox-Pitt, Kelton, put the chances of a deal being clinched at greater than 50-50 with potential problem areas being top jobs and location of the head office. Industry sources believe that, under the terms being discussed, leading operations would be retained in Halifax and Edinburgh. Control would be split between Halifax's youthful chief executive, James Crosby, and Peter Burt, the 56-year-old chief executive of BoS. BoS's annual results are due next week.

fields.headline: Watches on the web
fields.trailText: 1pm: AOL Time Warner is teaming up with Swatch to develop watches with internet access, writes Julia Day.
fields.body:
It's the stuff of which Star Trek devotees' dreams are made.

AOL Time Warner is teaming up with the Swatch Group to develop watches with internet access.

The multi-year joint venture will see the Swiss watchmaker develop, promote and market a range of watch and wrist-worn devices featuring content from AOL Time Warner.

Swatch owns 18 watch brands including Omega, Longines, Rado, Tissot, Calvin Klein and Swatch.

AOL Time Warner will create promotional initiatives for Swatch's brands across online, print and television platforms, including Time Inc and the America Online interactive properties.

The internet and media giant will also promote Swatch's brands across its assets, such as its AOL flagship web service and Time publications.

Wearers will be able to store their favorite website addresses and AOL screen names on the watches and access AOL content spanning media, entertainment, technology and sports.

The deal is part of AOL Time Warner's efforts to strike marketing deals to expand access to its services beyond the personal computer.

"This agreement demonstrates AOL Time Warner's ability to provide a truly unique value to our partners through a range of offline and online brands" said Bob Pittman, the co-chief operating officer of AOL Time Warner.

Nick Hayek, the co-chairman of Swatch, said: "This agreement perfectly matches the global leadership strategies of the Swatch Group with its strong development and its worldwide, solidly founded activities."

webTitle: In attendance at the court of Kennedy

fields.headline: In attendance at the court of Kennedy
fields.standfirst: Jackie Kennedy: clothes horse or cultural icon? The New York glitterati get the chance to decide at a high-profile new exhibition, writes Michael Ellison
fields.trailText: Jackie Kennedy: clothes horse or cultural icon? The New York glitterati get the chance to decide at a high-profile new exhibition, writes Michael Ellison.
fields.body:
The Kennedy name ensures that anything to which it is attached is An Event: but it is rare when this is not followed by accounts of assassination, plane crashes, dysfunctional marriages, the Mafia, abuse of Marilyn Monroe, inordinate drinking, a woman floating face down in the water or even an obscure nephew who goes on trial soon, accused of a murder from 25 years ago.

So it might be taken as something of a relief when an apparently innocuous exhibition of Jackie Kennedy's finest outfits opens next Monday in the grand setting of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, New York.

Naturally, Jacqueline Kennedy: The White House Years has been seen already by the privileged - the press - and the very privileged - the personalities who paid $3,500 [£2,400] a head to be at the Costume Institute "party of the year" (but of course!) that kicked off the show.

Naomi Campbell, cheeky devil that she is, wore a T-shirt with the words "like a virgin" picked out in sequins, and a breach of etiquette was successfully avoided when Laura Bush left after the cocktails and before Hillary Clinton was last to arrive for dinner. This meant that the current first lady was not in the same room as the previous first lady in honour of the first lady of 40 years ago. Phew.

And the encomiums spiralled off into superlatives. "There's no contemporary match today," says Hamish Bowles, the British dandy who is European editor-at-large for Vogue and guest curator of the exhibition. "In the recent past, maybe only Princess Diana understood the symbolism of clothing and cultural arts and history. Jacqueline Kennedy is one of history's great style icons."

Her daughter, Caroline, says: "I think it was my mother's passion for history that guided her time in the White House. She will always help to grace the history she helped to make. We must learn from the past to understand what is important and pass those values on."

Letitia Baldrige, once social secretary to the icon who died seven years ago, acknowledges the possibility of a little niggle while simultaneously trying to head it off. "She was much more than clothes. She was history, art and culture and she knew how to entertain."

The 88-year-old designer Oleg Cassini does have a problem with the show, specifically its catalogue. "The atmosphere at the Kennedy White House was so enthusiastic, so fantastic and now it comes to this, the diminishing of what I did 40 years later," he says.

Cassini does not care to have his work described as "after Karl Lagerfeld". Or, for that matter, after Givenchy. Or after Christian Dior, or after anyone but Cassini.

You will note that the designer's views do not touch on the aforementioned qualities associated with history, art or culture. He's talking about clothes. When the Guggenheim devoted an exhibition a few months ago to Armani's greatest hits, it was accused of descending into crass commercialism of the kind not seen since, oh, its show on the art of the motorcycle.

Brooklyn Museum of Art has done the honours for hip-hop, when it is not provoking the easily angered mayor Rudy Giuliani with a representation of Jesus Christ as a naked woman. The Museum of Modern Art gave room to gizmo-laden musings on the workplace of the future. Boston did its bit with a tribute to the aesthetics of the guitar.

The Met likes to position itself well above such unseemly embraces, even if it once feature an exhibition of rock stars' stage kit. "Our purpose is not to pull the crowds," says Philippe de Montebello, its director. "Museums will lose. They do not do Disney that well."

Kennedy's Camelot court is, apparently, a different matter.

fields.headline: On Saddam's trail at last
fields.standfirst: Scotland Yard's investigation of the Iraqi president may prove ineffectual, writes Simon Tisdall, but at least it is a step in the right direction
fields.trailText: Scotland Yard's investigation of the Iraqi president may prove ineffectual, writes Simon Tisdall, but at least it is a step in the right direction.
fields.body:
The decision by Britain's attorney-general, Lord Williams of Mostyn, to ask Scotland Yard to investigate war crimes allegations against Saddam Hussein could be described as another milestone in the long march towards global justice.

Despite his numerous crimes, perpetrated against his own people, Iraq's Kurdish and Shia minorities, and the citizens of Kuwait in 1990-91, Saddam has never been formally indicted under the terms of various international conventions to which Iraq is a party or by any UN tribunal.

This contrasts sharply with the creation of a special war crimes tribunal in the Hague covering the former Yugoslavia. It has issued dozens of indictments against suspected war criminals and many have been tried and jailed. In particular, this tribunal is seeking to try Yugoslavia's former dictator Slobodan Milosevic who was overthrown last year.

A similar tribunal was set up to deal with the aftermath of the 1994 genocide in Rwanda. But with Saddam still in power in Baghdad, with much Arab opinion sympathetic to his defiant stance over UN sanctions and weapons inspections and with the West divided over how best to handle him, no court has yet sought to bring him to book.

The British legal action was prompted by lobbying by a US-funded, British-based group called Indict. It presented evidence alleging complicity by Saddam and his close associate and deputy prime minister, Tariq Aziz, in the taking hostage and mistreatment of 4,500 Britons in Kuwait and Iraq at the start of the Gulf war.

Indict asked the attorney-general to act under the provisions of the British parliament's Taking of Hostages Act of 1982. If Scotland Yard concludes that there is a case to answer, arrest warrants could be issued against both Saddam and Aziz. In theory, one or both men could then be detained should they travel outside Iraq (as Aziz frequently does).

This action has recalled the case of the former Chilean dictator Augusto Pinochet, who was held during a private visit to London after receipt of a Spanish court's arrest warrant in connection with crimes committed during his time in power.

Pinochet claimed diplomatic immunity, and immunity arising from his status as a former head of state - claims fiercely disputed by Spanish prosecutors. He was eventually allowed to return to Chile for reasons of ill health, however, and not because his theoretical extradition was deemed illegal.

But unfortunately for those who would dearly like to see Saddam brought to book, the latest British legal moves are unlikely to get very far. In other words, they may prove to be less of a milestone and more a small, faltering step in the right direction.

The reasons are several. Scotland Yard, famous though it is, has no power to investigate events inside Iraq - and will receive no cooperation from the Baghdad regime. More than a decade has passed since the hostage-taking occurred.

Secondly, the attorney-general has already indicated that in both men's cases, his opinion is that prosecutions mounted in Britain would have had little chance of success. The formula used is that the evidence is likely to be "insufficient to provide a realistic prospect of conviction".

A third factor is the likelihood that both Saddam and Aziz would claim immunity from prosecution, should court actions ever be attempted - Saddam because he is a head of state, Aziz because he has diplomatic status.

The final consideration is the unavoidable fact that neither Saddam nor Aziz are likely to accept the jurisdiction of a British court, let alone present themselves for trial. And even if warrants were issued, countries that Aziz often visits (such as France) might well refuse to act on them.

All the same, the exercise launched by Indict is by no means pointless. It has highlighted the anomalous situation relating to Saddam, when compared with other alleged war criminals, like Milosevic.

It has forced the British government to take some action, however perfunctory, instead of doing nothing at all.

And it has underscored the urgent need for the early convening of the UN's international criminal court, the permanent body that is intended to replace ad hoc tribunals like that in the Hague.

Britain and many other countries are in the process of ratifying the Rome treaty that set up the ICC. When it finally comes into being, it is the ICC that will be the natural, impartial forum for hearing cases such as those pursued by Indict.

Significantly for people such as Saddam, the ICC will not recognise the right to immunity from prosecution of serving or former heads of state.

That the ICC is not already in being is due in some measure to opposition to it from the US government. Washington worries about future ICC prosecutions of members of the US armed forces on service overseas, and its opposition has encouraged other countries that also fear giving extraterritorial jurisdiction to the UN.

The irony of this situation will not be lost on Saddam and Aziz, nor should it be ignored by the Bush administration. For it is the Iraqi dictator's staunchest foes who now increasingly appear to be the biggest obstacles in the way of eventually bringing him to justice.

Scotland Yard will no doubt do its best. But the surest legal, non-military way of ending Saddam's tyranny is his indictment, arrest and trial before a court comprising all the nations of the world.

webTitle: Tax check plan to narrow pay gap

fields.headline: Tax check plan to narrow pay gap
fields.standfirst: >Special report: Tax and spending
fields.trailText: The government is planning to scrutinise tax details to help it target employers discriminating against women over pay.
fields.body:
The government is planning to scrutinise tax details to help it target employers discriminating against women over pay.

As part of a drive to tackle the continuing pay gap, the employment minister, Tessa Jowell, is proposing trawling employers' Paye returns, which reveal pay levels and are already categorised by gender.

The move, devised by the new "equal pay czar" Denise Kingsmill, would provide ministers with new information on pay inequalities, including the occupations with the worst record on pay discrimination and blackspot regions. It would also circumvent the need to obtain pay breakdowns directly from employers, which businesses have claimedwould swamp them with bureaucracy.

The government said last month it would not bow to pressure to force employers to conduct gender pay reviews, but would encourage companies to do so voluntarily.

Unions and the Equal Opportunities Commission are continuing to press ministers to legislate on the issue, arguing that the worst offending businesses will otherwise continue to escape reform.

Britain languishes at the bottom of the EU equal pay league. Thirty years after the passing of the Equal Pay Act, women working full-time earn on average 82% of male full-time hourly earnings - up from 69% in 1971. Part-time female workers get an even worse deal, receiving only 61% of male full-time hourly wages, compared with a European average of 73%.

At the first meeting this week of the group of so-called fair pay champions - business and union representatives appointed to press for pay equality - Ms Kingsmill highlighted the vast bank of pay information already held by the inland revenue thanks to employers' annual returns detailing the tax deducted directly from employee wage packets under Paye. Ms Jowell said: "This is one idea we are examining. It is clear there are an abundance of ideas we can build on to drive a culture change which both widen the range of women's work opportunities and confront discrimination and the pay gap."

The government's aim was to make sure a working environment free of pay discrimination was as normal for employers as health and safety legislation, she added.

The TUC yesterday gave the Paye proposal a cool welcome. A spokesperson said: "In the absence of legislation to make employers conduct pay audits, we would welcome the use of statistics which could highlight employers most guilty of gender pay crimes."

webTitle: Delay succession until election, say Tories

fields.headline: Delay succession until election, say Tories
fields.trailText:
12.30pm: The Tories have called for the appointment of a new BBC chairman to be delayed until after the election, reports Jason Deans.
26.04.2001: Bland 'must step down'
26.04.2001: comment by Emily Bell
26.04.2001: Sir Christopher quits to join BT
26.04.2001: BT shares fall on news
26.04.2001 analysis: Can Bland save BT?

Special report: the BBC
Talk about it
fields.body:
The Tories have called for the appointment of a new BBC chairman to be delayed until after the expected general election in June.

Peter Ainsworth, the Conservative's media spokesman, said the chairmanship of the BBC was such an important post that the search for Sir Christopher Bland's replacement should not be rushed.

"It's in everybody's best interests to have an orderly search for a successor, but in any case the appointment should not be made until after the election," he said.

"It's not a process to be rushed."

Mr Ainsworth said he did not see any problem with Sir Christopher continuing as BBC chairman after he takes over as chairman of BT on May 1, until a replacement is appointed.

"The timing isn't ideal, but right before a general election you can't have the BBC without a chairman," he added.

David Docherty, the managing director of broadband at Telewest who worked under Sir Christopher as BBC deputy director of television until last year, said the move was good news for BT.

"He's a tough, clever, focused guy and that's exactly what BT needs at the moment," Mr Docherty added.

Sir Christopher's departure would "make a difference" to the BBC's relationship with the Labour government.

"Whoever comes in will be more of a natural friend of this government, with more of natural understanding of what they're about," Mr Docherty predicted.

Sir Christopher had a prickly relationship with the culture secretary, Chris Smith.

Last autumn, after hearing of Mr Smith's opposition to the plan to move the BBC1 Nine O'Clock News to 10pm, Sir Christopher rather pompously dismissed the culture secretary's concerns by saying he was "entitled to his view just like any other licence-fee payer".

And there were accusations that Sir Christopher bullied the board into voting for his old friend, Greg Dyke, in the battle for the director-generalship.

Barry Cox, the deputy chairman of Channel 4 and a former colleague of Sir Christopher's at LWT, said there was nothing wrong with a bit of antagonism.

"I would argue that the relationship Bland has had with Labour, and the Tories before that, was the proper one," said Mr Cox.

"It demonstrated the necessary independence of the BBC. You might not always agree with him, but he did the job that an independent chairman should do."

fields.headline: Spanish book prize turns into a drama
fields.trailText: The Barcelona appeal court began investigating Spain's hottest literary dispute yesterday: whether the Spanish Nobel laureate Camilo Jose Cela is a cheat and plagiarist.
fields.body:
The Barcelona appeal court began investigating Spain's hottest literary dispute yesterday: whether the Spanish Nobel laureate Camilo Jose Cela is a cheat and plagiarist.

Cela, author of The Family of Pascual Duarte and winner of the 1989 literature prize, vigorously denies the accusation that he based another prize-winning novel on the work of a ghost writer.

The ghost writer, in turn, is alleged by a school teacher to have plagiarised her unpublished manuscript.

Carmen Formoso's lawyers claim that Cela, 85, dashed off his novel - The Cross of Saint Andrew - in a few weeks in 1994 after being promised that if he could deliver it in time his next book would win the £250,000 Premio Planeta lit erary prize. The biggest publishing company in the Spanish-speaking world, Planeta offers its prize as an advance to the winning author, aiming to more than recoup the money with huge sales from prize publicity.

Ms Formoso entered her manuscript - Carmen, Carmela, Carmina - for the prize. There are hundreds of entrants annually, although big names usually win.

She was astounded by similarities between her novel and Cela's. She alleges a criminal and literary conspiracy in which Planeta gave her manuscript to a ghost writer.

Her case has been rejected twice by lower courts but the appeal judges found "innumerable coincidences" and said the suspicion that Cela was promised the prize was "not completely unfounded".

fields.headline: Cannes plumps for new talent
fields.trailText: New talent is to be pushed to the fore in Director's Fortnight at Cannes next month, with the selectors opting for an eclectic mix of films, with few well-established names and 11 debut films.
fields.body:
A host of new talent is to be showcased in Director's Fortnight at Cannes next month. The selectors have chosen an eclectic mix of films, with few well-established names and 11 debut films.

Chief selector Marie-Pierre Macia told Daily Variety: "We want to get back to the original purpose of Director's Fortnight. Our mission is to be a headhunter for talent and to take risks that the main festival can't."

There are no UK films amongst the diverse selection, though Asia features strongly with three films (from China, Taiwan and Hong Kong). Among the four US films in the line-up are two debuts by actora directing their wives. Debra Winger stars in husband Arliss Howard's Big Bad Love and Ethan Hawke directs Chelsea Walls with a strong cast including wife Uma Thurman.

"We saw a lot of American films and I turned down films by well-known directors," Macia said. "When it came to choosing between theirs and first films of equal quality, I wanted to take the first-time features."

The biggest name directors in the line-up are Amos Kollek, who featured at Cannes last year with Fast Food, Fast Women and Sandrine Veysset, who previously directed Will It Snow At Christmas? and this time opens the event with Martha... Martha.

webTitle: Freddy Got Fingered, the worst movie ever?

fields.headline: The worst movie ever?
fields.standfirst: The critics have a new film they love to hate. What if they're wrong, asks  Scott Hughes
fields.trailText: The critics have a new film they love to hate. What if they're wrong, asks Scott Hughes.
fields.body:
The fallow months between Oscar nomination time and the start of the summer season at the US box office always tend to throw up a few stinkers, but Freddy Got Fingered, a new comedy starring, directed and co-written by MTV wag Tom Green seems to have created an awful stench.

On its American opening last weekend, the critics were pulling no punches. "If ever a movie testified to the utter creative bankruptcy of the Hollywood film industry," lamented the Washington Post, "it is the abomination known as Freddy Got Fingered." Roger Ebert in the Chicago Sun-Times gave it no stars out of four and described it as a vomitorium, while CNN film critic Paul Clinton went so far as to call it "quite simply the worst movie ever released by a major studio in Hollywood history".

The worst ever? Perhaps, but the critics have been there before with put-downs that are often more memorable than the movies. Freddy's critical mauling comes only weeks after knives were sharpened over another two films: Demian Lichtenstein's 3,000 Miles to Graceland, the tale of a group of ex-cons robbing a Las Vegas casino during an Elvis convention, and Monkeybone, Henry Selick's dark comedy-fantasy. Assessing Graceland, the Washington Post railed, "What you get is a mean- spirited, completely worthless film that can never give back the two hours it seizes from you." The Toronto Globe and Mail pronounced it, "Remarkably bad, burdened with a tone of self- congratulatory stupidity and the rancid smell of middle-aged star vanity." (The film stars Kevin Costner and Kurt Russell.) Meanwhile, of Monkeybone, Good Morning America film pundit Joel Siegel quipped: "This is the worst movie I've seen in a year that didn't star John Travolta or Sylvester Stallone." (He incidentally referred to Monkeybone and Graceland together as "the double feature from hell".)

Most newspapers agreed with him. "Utterly mirthless," spat the Toronto Star. "This failed attempt at comic fantasy could be used by future film historians - assuming they could endure viewing it - as a useful case study of how badly a single movie can squander talent and experience." (The film stars Brendan Fraser, Whoopi Goldberg and Bridget Fonda.)

Last year, it was the turn of John Travolta's embarrassing sci-fi adventure Battlefield Earth. "We are now spared the sleepless nights of wondering which gobbler will dominate the next [Golden Raspberry] Awards for worst turkey of the year," announced the Toronto Star as it opened, and at the ceremony last month it duly swept the board. The Washington Post was merciless, claiming that "a million monkeys with a million crayons would be hard-pressed in a million years to create anything as cretinous as Battlefield Earth".

Around the same time, British journalists had a turkey of their own to roast in the shape of Honest, the feature film debut of three-quarters of the All Saints, which the Times judged "a laughable fiasco", adding that "the only accolade should go to the fourth All Saint, Shaznay Lewis, for taking no part in the whole sorry affair".

Little wonder, then, that many actors and directors claim not to read the notices. But for the rest of us, waspish comments make far more entertaining reading than effusive compliments, especially in a business noted for its vanity and sycophancy. Film criticism is generally not eminently quotable, so the verdicts that have been remembered down the years tend to be dismissive one-liners. In the 1940s, American writer, James Agee, delighted cineastes with his succinct response to You Were Meant For Me (1948) - "That's what you think", and his ap praisal of Tycoon (1947) - "Several tons of dynamite are set off in this picture - none of it under the right people."

Carry On Emmanuelle moved Philip French to despair: "This relentless sequence of badly-written, badly-timed dirty jokes is surely one of the most morally and aesthetically offensive pictures to emerge from a British studio". Around the same time, the distinction of being "Simply the worst film ever made" went to Irwin Allen's killer-bee farrago, The Swarm, or so said the Sunday Times. In 1991, Christopher Tookey, then at the Sunday Telegraph, called the Michael Cimino remake of Desperate Hours, "One of those films which should never have been released, even on parole - a danger to itself."

One of the most uncharitable judgments ever passed came not from a critic, but from director Alan Parker, who described Peter Greenaway's The Draughtsman's Contract (1983), as "A load of posturing poo poo". Master of the movie put-down, though, is undoubtedly the now- retired American critic Pauline Kael, who never flinched from saying what she thought, even if it meant flying in the face of received critical opinion. In 1990, she dismissed the Oscar-winning Dances With Wolves as "a New Age Social Studies lesson", and back in the 1960s, offered the alternative view that The Sound Of Music would "probably be the single most repressive influence on artistic freedom in movies for the next few years".

Indeed, let's not forget that reviewers themselves have not always had an easy time of it, most notably perhaps at the hands of Kenneth Tynan, who once defined a critic as "a man who knows the way but can't drive a car". And whether they have any real power in the film industry is highly debatable, a fact of which they themselves are only too aware.

On the release of Star Wars: Episode I - The Phantom Menace, two years ago, the Toronto Star wondered: "When [a film is] this big, when it becomes the pop cult equivalent of the Death Star, do standards of movie criticism even apply? Is that not like trying to analyse the tornado when what you should really do is head for cover?"

Perhaps the last word should be left to American director Rouben Mamoulian, who asserted, "The most important critic is Time." Maybe Tom Green's magnum opus is destined for reassessment as a classic.

webTitle: Widdecombe is the new face of Manchester clubland

fields.headline: Widdecombe is the new face of Manchester clubland
fields.trailText: The shadow home secretary, Ann Widdecombe, is the face of a new rock  and roll club night in Manchester.
fields.body:
The shadow home secretary, Ann Widdecombe, is the face of a new rock and roll club night in Manchester.

South nightclub is distributing promotional flyers featuring the MP in a woolly hat with a slogan underneath which is a pun on Badly Drawn Boy, the Mancunian crooner and winner of last year's Mercury Prize for music.

The owner of South, Paul Cons, said: "We didn't have to think long to find the obvious candidate. My boyfriend is an asylum seeker so I'm not very keen on her."

The club, which is just off King Street, in the city centre, initially considered lampooning George Bush with a Badly Drawn Bush flyer, until it came up with the strapline "Look out here it widdecombes".

Club manager, Daniel Morrison, said: "She just suits the hat brilliantly."

webTitle: 'Funding increase is the only way to tackle ageism in the NHS'

fields.headline: 'Funding increase is the only way to tackle ageism in the NHS'
fields.standfirst: The national service framework for older people is an important step forward in setting out the kind of service we should expect from health and social care when we get old, writes Rabbi Julia Neuberger,   but a huge shift in attitudes towards the elderly is still needed - along with a funding injection
fields.trailText: Julia Neuberger: We need a fundamental rethink of the value our society places on the care of older people.
fields.body:
When the government announced its national service framework for older people last month, it said it would "make age discrimination a thing of the past" in the NHS. Media reports of the framework said it would ensure that prejudice and discrimination against older people were no longer a problem in the NHS, setting out standards and investing in services to prevent pensioners missing out.

Yet there remain serious concerns about the incidence of ageist practice within the health system and the degree to which discrimination either could or should be banished.

In a report produced by the King's Fund last year, we found persuasive evidence of widespread discrimination against older people in both health and social care. This was not so much the direct refusal to fund particular operations or procedures on the basis of a person's age - though this does happen sometimes - but the general neglect of services for older people and a culture that assumes people are inevitably infirm and dependent when they get old.

Over-75 health checks, for example, appear to be carried out grudgingly and at a very basic level by some GPs, for whom this service is often seen as an unnecessary burden on their time.

Most worryingly of all, services which work predominantly with older people are often unattractive places for professionals to work. Services for older people struggle to recruit and retain the most able medical, nursing and other professional staff because the work carries a low status and the services themselves are often poorly funded and in dilapidated surroundings.

In addition, the continued failure of successive governments to develop a system for funding long-term care that puts it on an equal footing with acute health care has left us with services that promote dependence rather than freedom, restrictions instead of choices, and endless delays and inconveniences where there should be choice and responsiveness.

In many cases, poor care results from nothing more than a simple failure to ask people about the kind of support they want, or from the inability of providers to offer any real choices to users about the services available to them.

Moreover, access to many of those services depends on people taking means-tests and, in some cases, incentives for local authorities to move people out of their own homes into residential care.

These forms of discrimination do not easily lend themselves to change. They do not explicitly exclude older people from services, they merely provide them in a manner that discriminates through a lack of attention to the individual's needs and wishes.

For those people who have to oversee and implement the new NSF, simply ensuring that boxes are ticked and new services are provided will just not be enough to make a real difference to the health of older people.

Simply banning age-related restrictions to health care will do little to tackle the more pervasive and subtle forms of discrimination that exist within the system. Achieving that will take time, and an attitude toward health and care workers that seeks not simply to monitor performance but to develop skills and understanding. To make this happen, resources will need to be channelled into investment in skilled and dedicated staff and effective leaders.

What bothers most users of long-term care services is not that they are barred from receiving health care but that care is delivered in a "can't do" fashion, which makes them feel like an inconvenience and a burden. They find that patronising attitudes, delays in service delivery, a lack of choice and a succession of people coming into their homes without introduction are distressing and demeaning.

Tackling those requires a fundamental rethink of the value the whole of our society places on the care of older people.

In a survey published by the King's Fund this week, we found that the government's policy of retaining means tests for personal care while making nursing care free of charge is deeply unpopular with the public. They believe that both of these elements of long-term care should be funded by the taxpayer rather than charged to individuals, even if this does mean that people on middle and high incomes will benefit as much as those on low incomes.

This is a significant change from surveys in previous years, and may suggest that public attitudes about the care of older people are beginning to shift. Responding to that change may mean thinking again about how long-term care services are funded, provided and regulated.

The national service framework for older people is an important step forward in setting out the kind of service we should expect from health and social care when we get old.

But achieving that goal will depend on an injection of resources, not just to provide new services but to develop people's skills and to tackle the cultural barriers that legitimate ageism among professionals and other care workers. And it may mean that yet another, this time more radical, re-examination of the way we fund long-term care may still be needed.

 Rabbi Julia Neuberger is chief executive of health charity King's Fund

fields.headline: Huge opposition to care charges
fields.trailText: Almost two-thirds of the public believe that people with long-term illnesses should not have to pay for nursing and personal care services, according to a leading health charity.
fields.body:
Almost two-thirds of the public believe that people with long-term illnesses should not have to pay for nursing and personal care services, according to a leading health charity.

A survey from the King's Fund reveals that most people back the recommendation of the royal commission on long term care that neither nursing nor personal care should be means-tested, whether provided in a hospital, nursing home or at home. The news is a sharp reminder to the government, in the run-up to a general election, of the lack of support for its policy of means-testing for personal care costs.

"Our survey shows that both the government and the opposition are out of step with the majority of people over what is seen to be fair in long-term care funding," said King's Fund chief executive Rabbi Julia Neuberger.

"Ministers' arguments that universally free personal care would only benefit the well-off do not persuade most members of the public. Redistribution can be achieved much more fairly through taxation than through means-tests, which older people often find demeaning and stressful."

Opinion pollsters NOP surveyed 1,000 people over the age of 25, living in England, in February. More than half those surveyed, no matter what their earnings, believe that the state should fund personal care such as help with bathing, eating, dressing and using the toilet.

Perhaps surprisingly, more than half surveyed also think that the government should fund accommodation (or "hotel") costs in nursing homes - which both the government and the royal commission rejected. The royal commission, chaired by Sir Stewart Sutherland, was set up by the government in 1997 to look at the funding of long-term care.

The survey shows that people of all age groups hold broadly the same view. This represents a shift in public opinion from previous years, when fewer people were in favour of making long-term care free of charge.

"One person in four will need long-term care when they get old. When they do, under current proposals, only very narrowly defined nursing care will be provided without a means test," said Rabbi Neuberger.

"Asking people to provide for such a random event in their lives as Alzheimer's disease or a bad fall is no more ethical or rational than asking them to pay for cancer treatment. It is very likely that such an approach will fail within a few years."

"Regardless of which party forms the next government, the issue of long-term care funding - and the false distinction between nursing and personal care - will not go away."

The government countered that it was spending more on intermediate care to prevent older people going into residential homes. Money was better spent on improved health and social services, rather than providing free care, said health minister John Hutton.

"Overall, we are matching the additional expenditure on services for older people recommended by the royal commission but we have chosen to devote the lion's share to improving the range of services available to older people so that they can recover more quickly and avoid unnecessary admission into care homes. These services will be free at the point of use," he said.

"We are making nursing care free in nursing homes from this October, making the funding of long-term care fairer and more equitable and giving responsibility to the NHS where it should be. But we can't spend the same money twice."

Charities for older people said the survey showed the public wanted the government to go further in funding care.

Help the Aged's head of public affairs Mervyn Kohler said: "The King's Fund poll adds to the current momentum to develop a fairer policy between what care the state provides and what people need personally to pay for. Help the Aged and partner organisations are campaigning strongly to make personal care free."

He pointed out that in Scotland personal care is to be free of charge from 2002.

A spokeswoman for Age Concern said that, by rejecting the royal commission's key recommendation to fund personal care at an estimated cost of £1.1bn, the government would force thousands of older people "in desperate need of care to go through the undignified and often complicated process of means-testing or otherwise having to give up their savings to pay for it".

She added: "With just weeks to go before a general election, politicians have got to start listening to the public's voice. They must go further than producing a false divide between nursing and personal care, and instead offer a fairer, clearer system of funding."

 The results of the survey are contained in A Fair Deal for Older People? by Chris Deeming, published today by the King's Fund.
fields.bodyText: Almost two-thirds of the public believe that people with long-term illnesses should not have to pay for nursing and personal care services, according to a leading health charity. A survey from the King's Fund reveals that most people back the recommendation of the royal commission on long term care that neither nursing nor personal care should be means-tested, whether provided in a hospital, nursing home or at home. The news is a sharp reminder to the government, in the run-up to a general election, of the lack of support for its policy of means-testing for personal care costs. "Our survey shows that both the government and the opposition are out of step with the majority of people over what is seen to be fair in long-term care funding," said King's Fund chief executive Rabbi Julia Neuberger. "Ministers' arguments that universally free personal care would only benefit the well-off do not persuade most members of the public. Redistribution can be achieved much more fairly through taxation than through means-tests, which older people often find demeaning and stressful." Opinion pollsters NOP surveyed 1,000 people over the age of 25, living in England, in February. More than half those surveyed, no matter what their earnings, believe that the state should fund personal care such as help with bathing, eating, dressing and using the toilet. Perhaps surprisingly, more than half surveyed also think that the government should fund accommodation (or "hotel") costs in nursing homes - which both the government and the royal commission rejected. The royal commission, chaired by Sir Stewart Sutherland, was set up by the government in 1997 to look at the funding of long-term care. The survey shows that people of all age groups hold broadly the same view. This represents a shift in public opinion from previous years, when fewer people were in favour of making long-term care free of charge. "One person in four will need long-term care when they get old. When they do, under current proposals, only very narrowly defined nursing care will be provided without a means test," said Rabbi Neuberger. "Asking people to provide for such a random event in their lives as Alzheimer's disease or a bad fall is no more ethical or rational than asking them to pay for cancer treatment. It is very likely that such an approach will fail within a few years." "Regardless of which party forms the next government, the issue of long-term care funding - and the false distinction between nursing and personal care - will not go away." The government countered that it was spending more on intermediate care to prevent older people going into residential homes. Money was better spent on improved health and social services, rather than providing free care, said health minister John Hutton. "Overall, we are matching the additional expenditure on services for older people recommended by the royal commission but we have chosen to devote the lion's share to improving the range of services available to older people so that they can recover more quickly and avoid unnecessary admission into care homes. These services will be free at the point of use," he said. "We are making nursing care free in nursing homes from this October, making the funding of long-term care fairer and more equitable and giving responsibility to the NHS where it should be. But we can't spend the same money twice." Charities for older people said the survey showed the public wanted the government to go further in funding care. Help the Aged's head of public affairs Mervyn Kohler said: "The King's Fund poll adds to the current momentum to develop a fairer policy between what care the state provides and what people need personally to pay for. Help the Aged and partner organisations are campaigning strongly to make personal care free." He pointed out that in Scotland personal care is to be free of charge from 2002. A spokeswoman for Age Concern said that, by rejecting the royal commission's key recommendation to fund personal care at an estimated cost of £1.1bn, the government would force thousands of older people "in desperate need of care to go through the undignified and often complicated process of means-testing or otherwise having to give up their savings to pay for it". She added: "With just weeks to go before a general election, politicians have got to start listening to the public's voice. They must go further than producing a false divide between nursing and personal care, and instead offer a fairer, clearer system of funding."  The results of the survey are contained in A Fair Deal for Older People? by Chris Deeming, published today by the King's Fund.

webTitle: Phoenix is a 'ray of light' for farming industry

fields.headline: Phoenix is a 'ray of light' for farming industry
fields.standfirst: Special report: foot and mouth
fields.trailText: The family hand rearing Phoenix the calf were celebrating today after Downing Street stepped in to save her from the slaughterman's gun.
fields.body:
The family hand rearing Phoenix the calf were celebrating today after Downing Street stepped in to save her from the slaughterman's gun.

Phoenix was adopted by the media as a heartbreaking symbol of the foot and mouth crisis after she was discovered alive under a pile of 15 culled animals.

Her case has helped prompt ministers into moving towards a downscaling of the "firebreak" slaughter of healthy animals at farms near to infected sites and a statement on this is expected in the Commons today.

This morning, the week-old calf was fed her breakfast of a bottle of milk by farmer Philip Board and his wife Michaela.

"It is absolutely fantastic - a ray of light for the farming industry," said Mr Board, 42, who runs Clarence Farm in Membury, Devon. Had the rule change come earlier the livestock may have survived, he said.

"I think they deserve a bit of cheering up - it has been so miserable and bad. It is about time we had something good."

Had the rule change come earlier the livestock may have survived, he said.

"When the disease comes out you think it has got to be stopped. I can understand the situation Maff (the Ministry of Agriculture, Fisheries and Food) is in.

"But Maff should stop and talk to the farmers instead of just diving in saying they have got to shoot everything, there should be a bit of communication."

Phoenix survived a cull on a Devon farm but was due to be killed by Maff officials under foot and mouth regulations.

The calf, born on April 13, had survived for five days next to its dead mother, among a herd of 15 cattle culled because of the disease, before she was discovered on Monday.

The cattle, and a flock of 30 sheep - all healthy - were slaughtered on the 35-acre farm last Thursday as part of a cull around another farm in the area, where foot and mouth was confirmed a couple of weeks ago.

Mrs Board, 35, said: "It is brilliant, fantastic. We were not sure were going to get anywhere, but we thought she deserved a chance and we would go for it."

"We have heard nothing official from Maff or anyone, but we have heard it on the news and we are very, very hopeful this is correct. We cannot believe it really.

"We just fed Phoenix with a bottle and she is going to have another now because she is very, very hungry. She is going to go on to the bucket because she is going so well.

"She will have a long stable future. She is going to stay here on the farm and we are going to breed her eventually. But she is mainly going to keep my horse Teddy company."

Mr Board's brother, 59-year-old Fred Board, who owns the land and animals, said: "I think it is a marvellous thing they have done."

The local NFU spokesman, Ian Johnson, said at the farm this morning: "Phoenix is a well-named symbol of hope and rebirth, and it takes a catalyst like that sometimes to bring about the obvious - common sense, which is what we have asked for all along."

webTitle: Vieira to stay at Arsenal until 2004

fields.headline: Vieira to stay at Arsenal until 2004
fields.trailText: Patrick Vieira has dismissed reports which suggest he is angling for a move to Juventus - and says will he be staying at Arsenal until at least the end of his contract in 2004.
fields.body:
Patrick Vieira has dismissed reports which suggest he is angling for a move to Juventus - and says will he be staying at Arsenal until at least the end of his contract in 2004.

"I want to make it clear to every Arsenal fan that I have no intention of going to Italy or anywhere else. I became a better player after coming to England under Arsene Wenger so why should I even consider leaving Arsenal?" he told Football365.

"The people at this club know what is going to happen," he added. "It is very clear to them that I want to stay at Arsenal.

And Vieira claimed that the comments he made last week chastising Arsenal for selling Emmanuel Petit and Marc Overmars merely underlined his commitment to the club.

"From time to time, players will have a moan but I don't talk without cause. I think it's important for the club to realise that I only want the best for them, that I am committed to them.

"If anyone thinks that because I say things it means I want to leave, then they are wrong.

"I have a contract until 2004 but who knows what will happen after that? I could be here for years to come. I know that more success is round the corner for Arsenal."

Vieira insisted none of the Highbury board or management team censured him for his outspoken comments in Valencia after Arsenal's Champions League elimination.

"Nobody has said anything to me about what I said after the Valencia game," he said. "I didn't say it to upset anyone and I didn't say it out of frustration. I still don't think I've made a mistake. I think it's very important for the best teams to keep the best players.

"I've never said I wanted to leave Arsenal, that I'm not happy here. Since I came here everything has been great for me. I won the World Cup, Euro 2000, the title. It's been a dream move for me and I want it to continue because so many good things have happened.

"All I said was that it was a mistake to let Petit and Overmars go. What I meant was that, in Europe, you have to keep your best players.

"We have a fantastic group of players here," he continued. "We've had some new players come in and it takes time for them to settle. We were very unlucky in Europe but if we finish second and win the FA Cup, it will still have been a good season for us.

"What is really important is to keep this team together. We have to ensure we keep our best players and make sure nobody is tempted to leave the club."

fields.headline: What's new
fields.trailText: Panasonic | MP3 in Jungle
fields.body:
Panasonic
Panasonic has announced a UK launch date and a price for its DVD-RAM video recorder. The DMR-E20 will reach the stores later this year and retail for around £1,300. The model is the company's second DVD-RAM recorder. Its debut unit - the DMR-E10 - is already on sale in Japan and the US.

The recorder stores MPEG2 standard video on 4.7Gigabyte DVD-RAM discs, which Panasonic translates as around two hours of high quality images or six hours of low standard footage. Panasonic also intends to market double-sided DVD-RAM discs which can store up to 9.4Gigabytes of video.

There are two key differences between the DMR-E20 and its predecessor. The first is that the new model can record on to write-once DVD-R format discs as well as re-writable DVD-RAM ones. Unlike DVD-RAM discs, DVD-R discs can be played back in most current DVD video players. However, Panasonic insists that from 2002 all its new DVD players will be DVD-RAM compatible.

Panasonic is keeping its options open as to which form will replace the VHS VCR. Just launched in Japan is a hard disk video recorder, the NV-HDR1000, that can record up to 25 hours of analogue TV footage on its 30Gigabyte hard drive.

MP3 in Jungle
Artec is set to shake up the MP3 market with a tiny player that offers more storage than most of its larger rivals. The £200 Jungle I is roughly the same size as a credit card, yet the makers have squeezed in 96Megabytes of embedded flash memory. Most similar units have only 32 or 64MB. The player is strictly MP3 only, although it can store around an hour and a half of CD-ish quality tunes. It is only available via the net, from www.mp3players.co.uk

ONnet
ONdigital, which introduced the internet-through-your-TV system, ONnet, to subscribers last year is offering the system to anyone with a set. Available via www.lastminute.com, the system comprises a decoder box and a wireless keyboard, below left. It offers five email accounts, which can send both voice and images as attachments. Courtesy of the system's picture-in-picture facility, users can read a web page while watching a TV programme.

Would-be sofa surfers sign up for a 12-month period, paying £4 a month for the first three months. The downside is that it rises to £8 a month for the next nine. Users have to pay for the cost of the phone calls.

fields.headline: Labour's 172 advertising campaigns
fields.standfirst: Top 20 government advertising campaigns
fields.trailText:
8.30am The government ran 172 campaigns last month on subjects ranging from car crime to teenage pregnancy, writes Claire Cozens.
<A HREF=""Top 20 government advertising campaigns
25.04.2001: Kennedy enters row over government adspend
25.04.2001: Blair accused over advertising spend
Table: 10 highest-spending UK advertisers
fields.body:
The government ran a staggering 172 advertising campaigns last month on subjects ranging from car crime to teenage pregnancy.

Monthly spending on government advertising soared in March to more than £30m - two-and-a-half times last year's level and almost a quarter of the total spent by the UK's top 20 advertisers combined.

According to figures from media monitor AC Nielsen MMS, the most expensive government campaigns last month involved benefit fraud (£3.4m), entitlements to annual leave (£2.5m), anti-smoking initiatives (£2.2m), the UK Online website (£2.1m) and lone parents (£1.2m).

The figures prompted accusations the government was using taxpayers' money to fund campaigns trumpeting its achievements.

During yesterday's prime minister's question time, William Hague slammed the benefit fraud campaign, calling it an expensive flop.

"The government's own evaluation concluded that... the result of the campaign was respondents perceived benefit fraud as easier to commit than they had thought previously," he said.

He criticised the government for wasting money it could have spent on promoting Britain as a tourist destination to help the industry recover from the impact of foot and mouth disease.

fields.headline: Broadcast
fields.standfirst: Publication date: April 27
fields.trailText: April 27: Key Channel 4 programme suppliers have accused the broadcaster of losing its way.
fields.body:
Key Channel 4 programme suppliers have accused the broadcaster of losing its way, attacking its obsessions with youth and ratings and slating its bland, 'soft-furnishings' schedule.

The government is failing the electorate by insisting that the BBC remain outside the control of a new single communications regulator, Ofcom, according to ITV director of channels David Liddiment.

ITV's main shareholders Carlton and Granada this week unveiled the most radical overhaul of ITV in its 46-year history.

The BBC has revamped its drama department and appointed executive producer Laura Mackie as head of serials.

GWR chief executive Ralph Bernard this week called for greater self-regulation in the radio industry as he launched the group's first listeners' scrutiny panel.

fields.headline: Sir Christopher 'must step down'
fields.trailText:
9.15am: Sir Christopher Bland is facing calls to stand down as chairman of the BBC because of a potential conflict of interest, writes Lisa O'Carroll.
Talk about it
26.04.2001: Sir Christopher quits to join BT
Comment by Emily Bell
Special report: the BBC
fields.body:
Sir Christopher Bland was today facing pressure to stand down immediately as chairman of the BBC because of a potential conflict of interest.

The calls follow this morning's announcement that he is to replace Sir Iain Vallance as chairman of BT.

Liberal Democrats said Sir Christopher could not simultaneously head up the BBC's board of governors and be BT chairman.

He will earn a double salary topping £400,000 for both jobs.

"Sir Christopher Bland can't possibly do two jobs at once. He cannot give the BBC his full attention if he believes the job is that part-time," said the party's culture spokesman, Norman Baker.

"It confirms the view that the BBC's board of governors is past its sell-by-date.

"There is a clear conflict of interest. The merging of telecommunications with traditional broadcasting will make the BBC and BT potential competitors.

"Sir Christopher must resign his position as chair of the board of governors," he added.

Sir Christopher is currently paid £72,000 a year at the BBC and at BT he stands to earn another £350,000 a year.

Peter Mandelson, the Hartlepool MP and a former Labour party communications director, said of Sir Christopher's switch: "I don't think there is any conflict of interest at all in this appointment.

"BBC journalists have clear editorial guidelines to work within, regardless of who the governors are.

"Much more important is maintaining a political balance at the top of the BBC during a general election period.

"Sir Christopher Bland has been an excellent chairman and is not exactly a Labour figure, while the vice-chairman, Gavyn Davies, has a clear Labour background.

"That is a balance that will continue to serve the BBC well, before a replacement for the chairman is found."

BT's share price rose 2% in early trading this morning, up 10p to 590p. However, the price is far below last year's high of £14.23.

Greg Dyke, the director-general of the BBC, said: "Christopher has been a strong champion and servant of the public interest and the BBC's independence in his stewardship over the last five years."

Peter Mandelson, the Hartlepool MP and a former Labour party communications director, said of Sir Christopher's switch: "I don't think there is any conflict of interest at all in this appointment. "BBC journalists have clear editorial guidelines to work within, regardless of who the governors are. "Much more important is maintaining a political balance at the top of the BBC during a general election period. "Sir Christopher Bland has been an excellent chairman and is not exactly a Labour figure, while the vice-chairman, Gavyn Davies, has a clear Labour background. "That is a balance that will continue to serve the BBC well, before a replacement for the chairman is found." BT's share price rose 2% in early trading this morning, up 10p to 590p. However, the price is far below last year's high of £14.23. Greg Dyke, the director-general of the BBC, said: "Christopher has been a strong champion and servant of the public interest and the BBC's independence in his stewardship over the last five years." webTitle: BT share price falls on news

fields.headline: BT share price falls on news
fields.trailText: 11am: The City's immediate reaction to Sir Christophe Bland's appointment to BT was negative, writes Ashley Davies.
fields.body:
The City's immediate reaction to Sir Christopher's appointment to BT was negative.

BT shares fell by 7% in value almost immediately. Analysts said BT should have appointed a more dynamic trouble-shooter instead of "the charming gentleman" Sir Christopher, according to some analysts.

"Good though Bland is, he isn't a hard-hitting individual who will sweep through BT and get rid of the cobwebs as hoped. You could even say it's jobs for the boys," said one leading analyst.

Another telecoms specialist said: "BT could have done with someone far more thrusting and young and preferably with more international experience.

"All Bland brings to the table is experience of dealing with the government and regulators, which was just about the only thing Vallance was any good at anyway."

Sir Christopher has already publicly backed the BT chief executive, Sir Peter Bonfield, who is also under pressure to leave the company. Other analysts were more optimistic.

John Tysoe, head of telecoms research at WestLB Panmure, said: "Vallance has been unduly conservative in his approach until last year when all of a sudden BT went on a spending spree and bought the wrong things at the wrong price."

Mr Tysoe suggested that Sir Christopher was a less interventionist chairman who might allow BSir Peter to put into practice some of his "good intentions".

webTitle: A new vision for mental health care

fields.headline: A new vision for mental health care
fields.standfirst: On the day that the Sainsbury Centre unveils a new community and citizenship programme for people with a mental illness, director Matt Muijen explains how it aims to promote inclusion and acceptance
fields.trailText: Matt Muijen: Years of prejudice have dominated the debate on mental health care. But a new programme being launched today aims to focus on promoting inclusion and acceptance.
fields.body:
Rather naively, in retrospect, it was hoped that the introduction of community care, and the closure of the mental hospitals, would deliver full lives for people with a mental illness - the kind of existence most people take for granted.

Employment, leisure, a family and friends, and opportunities for involvement in the wider community on the basis of respect and equal opportunities: that is probably what is meant by the term "social inclusion".

We are chastened now by years of obsessive concerns and prejudice that have dominated the debate on mental health care. Ask any cab driver, listen to the radio or talk to friends at a party, and you will hear both about the rise of violence in society, as a consequence of community care, and the poor lot of those sad, neglected people out on the streets. People are concerned about risk in society and exclusion from society, but neglect is perceived as the cause of the violence.

The reality is, of course, very different. There may indeed be an increase of violence but it is not because of community care. And homelessness is only very indirectly connected to the closure of the institutions. Nevertheless, suffering from mental illness is associated with the stigma of danger and leads to social exclusion.

The problem is not just a prejudicial, societal attitude. Integration is complicated by the reality that many people with mental health problems have periods, sometimes long periods, of poor functioning, and may need intensive treatment and care. Some are excluded because they choose to reject the mental health system, partly because of the stigmatisation of mental illness and partly because of the inability of services to engage them.

Uniquely difficult for mental health services is the need to work simultaneously at so many levels: the illness, the person's unique expectations and own resources (as members of communities that may already be discriminated against), their culture and environment, and the stigma of mental illness and the service itself.

These complex obstacles mean that no single intervention will magically lead to inclusion and acceptance on equal terms. We need to produce services acceptable to people suffering from mental health problems, sensitive to their fears of the consequences of being diagnosed and discriminated against. The community needs to provide opportunities, such as accessible educational courses, supported employment and decent housing. Neighbourhood renewal schemes and the new deals are promising.

Most important is the acceptance of people with mental health problems as citizens, who can contribute on their own terms, rather than being seen as liabilities who need to be tolerated. It should be a truism to say that most service users are no different from the rest of society, a few making unique contributions, others relying on support in one form or another, and most, probably like you and me, somewhere in between. Some, at times in their illness, are a risk to themselves or others and, at that point, require an intervention.

However, it is that rare and temporary single point in a few life stories which determines society's perception of a whole group. We would not stigmatise people with broken legs as lame invalids on the basis that very few will never walk again.

So, what to do? We need to prove our point, and change attitudes by showing that many people with mental health problems can function satisfactorily as partners, friends, employees and employers if we let them. We need to work together at all levels, developing better services and opening up communities, to create such opportunities.

Today the Sainsbury Centre for Mental Health launches its community and citizenship programme, jointly sponsored with the Department of Health. Working with many other organisations, we aim to focus on the way in which mental health design and organisation can more actively promote social inclusion at an individual and community level and fulfil a fresh vision of citizenship for people with mental health problems.

Individually, we may be perceived as marginal do-gooders but, together, we represent a powerful voice, able to persuade a society with entrenched views.

 Matt Muijen is director of the Sainsbury Centre for Mental Health

webTitle: The easy way to easy money

fields.headline: The easy way to easy money
fields.standfirst: Tips on the best way of meeting the new grant criteria of the national lottery's community fund
fields.trailText: With a 35-40% success rate, a grant from the national lottery's newly named community fund is relatively easy money, according to Luke Fitzherbert of the Directory of Social Change.
fields.body:
With a 35-40% success rate, a grant from the national lottery's newly named community fund is relatively easy money, according to Luke Fitzherbert of the Directory of Social Change.

Last week the national lottery charities board renamed itself the community fund and issued new application forms and criteria.

Mr Fitzherbert advised delegates at Charityfair yesterday how to increase their chances of success in bids to receive funding for up to £300,000 over three years.

The first step is to enlarge the list of criteria to A3 size and scribble under each one how the bid meets the requirement. "Then make sure these are incorporated somewhere in the application form," said Mr Fitzherbert.

A new dimension to the criteria is the publication of priorities for each region. These are quite specific and range from former coalfield areas to young offenders, depending on the needs of the region.

Mr Fitzherbert recommended increasing chances of success by splitting national projects into regional bids and even further subdividing the projects themselves into different bids.

He also gave the following tips to tackle some of the criteria:

 To prove the organisation is well managed and financially sound, describe the role of trustees within the organisation, how often the management committee meets and have a minute book at the ready for proof.

 Make sure figures add up and match any supplementary material being supplied, for example, the annual report.

 Don't underestimate costs in your budget, make sure it is reasonable and compares with local authority scales, if relevant.

 Your application will be marked down if you do not show knowledge of the local authority's strategy for the area or any relevant national strategies, for example, drugs or homelessness. Your application doesn't have to fit in with the strategy but you need to be aware of it.

 Nominate someone to answer questions who understands the finances of the organisation.

 Spell out why the money is needed and emphasise how it will help those at the greatest disadvantage. Remember that the grant officers have access to the social deprivation indices published by the Office of National Statistics.

 Show how you have addressed equal opportunity issues.

 To illustrate the involvement of service users, you can point to carers and parents as well as the end users.
