fields.headline: BT's poisoned chalice awaits Bland
fields.standfirst: Sir Christopher Bland faces a mammoth task in turning around BT. And already the high priests of the City are saying his appointment won't be enough to put the company back on an even keel
fields.trailText: Comment: Sir Christopher Bland faces a mammoth task in turning around BT. And already the high priests of the City are saying his appointment won't be enough to put the company back on an even keel, writes Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Sir Christopher Bland may have thought long and hard about his decision to take the reins at BT, but there will be no quick-fix solutions to help the beleaguered former state telecoms firm out of its current crisis.

If anything, the top job at BT is just another poisoned chalice. One City analyst said this morning that Sir Christopher was jumping from the frying pan into the fire.

While Sir Christopher is a perfect choice for the job on paper, given his experience of dealing with regulators, red tape and bureaucracy at the BBC and the trucking company, NFC, the City was hoping for fresh blood - someone to drive things forward rather than get bogged down in stonewalling.

A massive task awaits Sir Christopher. The telecoms company has a £30bn debt mountain - equal to almost all of its £35bn stock market valuation - and had hoped to repay some of its loans by selling off parts of its business and demerging others as separate listed companies.

Last night it finally managed to divest its stake in internet access provider LineOne, but for all its years of funding only received £6.2m in cash and £24.9m in Tiscali shares from the sale of the business.

This morning it emerged that BT was close to issuing a record-breaking £5bn rights issues to shore up its finances. Shareholders would be offered the opportunity to buy new shares at a big discount.

The rights issue was first mooted in March and BT has since been talking to fund managers to gauge City reaction. The feeling is that the City would support a cash call, but only if Sir Iain Vallance and Sir Peter Bonfield left the company.

Gone are the days when BT was the stock market darling. Its value has tumbled by 61% in the past year, from £15 a year ago to £5.40 today.

And, although hard to imagine, some commentators believe the company, which was once a utility just like water and gas companies, could disappear altogether unless radical steps are taken.

Sir Iain, who is also chairman of the Confederation of British Industry, and Sir Peter are viewed as jointly responsible for the company's predicament, and today cries of scapegoat accompanied news of Sir Iain's departure.

BT is no longer the global telecoms giant it once was. It is now regarded as little more than a bit part player on the world stage, and has been condemned from all quarters of industry for being a lumbering, archaic organisation.

Rather than rapidly expanding into new markets and rolling out new technologies, BT has dragged its heels on key issues such as ADSL and is now dwarfed by European rivals it once considered its equals.

While Vodafone has defiantly marched through world markets to become a genuine global force, BT has failed to create a global company - aborting mergers with the likes of Cable & Wireless and the US company MCI.

BT has also failed to fully exploit the internet and found itself sneered over by companies such as Freeserve, which have moved quicker and proved more imaginative with new services and pricing.

The City fell out with BT last year, saying its management was spending too much time and energy trying to hold on to its old monopolies and fighting the telecoms regulator. The icing on the cake was when BT paid £10bn more than it should have done to secure a 3G mobile telephone licence.

Since then, the City has been baying for blood and demanding the resignations of both Sir Iain and Sir Peter. The latter is said to be clinging on with his teeth, awaiting reaction to Sir Iain's departure before making a decision on his own future with BT.

What is certain today is that Sir Christopher won't have much of a honeymoon period when he arrives at BT next week.

webTitle: Foot and mouth in the media

fields.headline: Day 66: foot and mouth in the media
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk keeps you informed with a daily briefing on the press coverage of foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText:
Day 66: The papers rejoice in the news Phoenix the calf has been given a reprieve.
Special report: foot and mouth in the media
fields.body:
The Mirror
The paper splashes with an "exclusive" on Phoenix, the cute calf. The Mirror calls the tiny cow a "symbol of hope for everyone who has suffered in this crisis". The "voice of the Mirror" says Tony Blair did the right thing in sparing her: "if Phoenix had been killed, her death would have haunted the prime minister". Beneath a number of readers' faxes calling for Phoenix to be saved, the Mirror asks for an end to the killing. The paper also runs a piece in which a man who fears he has caught the disease claims his life is in ruins.

The Sun
The Sun reveals Phoenix's reprieve on page 17. Paul Stamper, the first of three men suspected of contracting the disease, is reported as saying people might be put off employing him in the future.

The Independent
Let the nation rejoice for Phoenix, cries the Independent on page one, because the little heifer is a symbol of hope. On page six, the paper reports on Downing Street's call for calm as hundreds of people besiege medical experts with concerns they may have contracted foot and mouth.

Daily Mail
The paper gives front page coverage to the story of Mr Stamper and claims an exclusive tag for the interview, despite his story being all over the paper yesterday. The Mail's Farm Aid appeal is going from strength to strength after three major donations - totalling £435,000 - take the overall total to £5m.

The Times
The paper runs a lead story about the government abandoning the policy of killing all livestock on farms next to those infected.

fields.headline: Outspoken ministers vie for attention
fields.standfirst:
After the election Cabinet members with time on their hands are worrying about their post-poll futures

Special report: Labour party
fields.trailText: Tony Blair is cross with some of his colleagues, though he is too busy running the country to have told them yet. Instead of concentrating on the job in hand, they are publicly worrying about what they might be doing after the coming election.
fields.body:
Tony Blair is cross with some of his colleagues, though he is too busy running the country to have told them yet. Instead of concentrating on the job in hand, they are publicly worrying about what they might be doing after the coming election.

Jack Straw, Gordon Brown, John Prescott, Robin Cook, Alan Milburn, Nick Brown and David Blunkett - all have either given media interviews in recent days, made speeches or had their future prospects predicted in large headlines by their friends - or their enemies.

It is not hard to guess why. With the most likely polling day postponed until June 7 - six weeks from today - it is not just the Whitehall decision making machinery that is largely on hold.

With the conspicuous exception of the agriculture minister, grappling daily with the foot and mouth outbreak, and his Treasury namesake, departmental ministers have unexpected time on their hands.

So do backbenchers. They all read the opinion polls and, even though they don't believe the result can possibly be as good as the polls suggest, they expect to win Labour's historic second term. They wonder if they are in line for a job - and what it might be.

But the scheming of the parliamentary pondlife, in Westminster's offices, cafeterias and watering holes, matters less than the public musings of the cabinet's big beasts who - doubtless with pure motives - seek to give the impression that they are still bursting with restless, creative energy that Mr Blair cannot possibly do without.

Last night Robin Cook used his Mansion House speech to restate the "ethical dimension" of his foreign policy. Today David Blunkett, who has cheekily told the teachers' unions he will miss them, gives a thoughtful, wide-ranging interview to the Guardian, which yesterday revealed Mr Milburn's latest NHS shake-up. Mr Prescott's views on future regional aid have also been aired.

In yesterday's Times the home secretary was reported to be considering adopting American mafia busting legislation, the so-called "Rico" law, to bring elusive criminals to justice.

Mr Straw also stressed that he really is not the Judge Dredd scourge of Guardian reading liberals he used to relish being.

On the same page Nick Brown was marked for culling in a shake-up that would replace his ministry (Maff) with a department of rural affairs. Mr Blair called that "nonesense" at question time yesterday. Aides say he will not break up Maff in mid-crisis.

The previous day the same newspaper had been the vehicle for the chancellor's insistence that the UK economy will weather the coming economic storm. He and Mr Blunkett, potential leadership rivals when Mr Blair stands down, are poised to produce books of their "personal manifestos".

Will the prime minister be impressed by any of this? Almost certainly not, it may even be counter-productive.

But everyone knows Mr Blunkett expects to become home secretary. So will Mr Straw go to the Foreign Office? Some MPs think not because Mr Blair needs a pro-European to balance Gordon Brown's wariness. The next Robin Cook will be Robin Cook, they predict, much praised by Mr Blair in recent months and clever enough to keep the left in line - unlike some Labour foreign secretaries.

"But Robin's credibility is damaged on the backbenches, he could be dumped with no fuss. Tony may calculate that Jack would go native [ie pro-European] at the Foreign Office," comes the counter-argument in the Commons tearoom.

Mr Straw could honourably be asked to take over John Prescott's mega-department, provided it is not broken up, as some predict.

Mr Prescott expects to keep his title as deputy PM, but take a quieter job as cabinet office enforcer. He wants to take regional policy with him.

Status has much to do with it. British cabinets are listed in pecking order with the top three departments - Treasury, Home Office and Foreign Office, all unchanged since 1997 - far more important than they are in France or Germany. "If education is so important why not make Gordon education secretary?" one MP dares to ask.

webTitle: Barry Norman 'wallowing in nostalgia', claims Winner

fields.headline: Barry Norman 'wallowing in nostalgia', claims Winner
fields.trailText: Michael Winner has attacked departing film critic Barry Norman, who condemned the standard of modern Hollywood films when he announced his retirement this week.
fields.body:
Michael Winner has attacked departing film critic Barry Norman, who condemned the standard of modern Hollywood films when he announced his retirement this week.

Writing in The Mirror, Winner - who directed the Death Wish trilogy - said the film industry is currently enjoying a golden age and he accused Norman of wallowing in hazy nostalgia.

Outspoken Winner said actors like Russell Crowe could benefit and hone their talent by studying the work of Marlon Brando and Robert De Niro. Citing Brando as the best, he said the heavyweight star helped change on screen performance from formal, visible acting to charismatic characterisation.

And he said the advances in the technical craft of film-making and in special effects are what helped make Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon "so wondrous".

"If films aren't as much fun, why are people going to them in ever increasing numbers?" he said. "Doubtless Mr Norman would retort that it's because we are of lower intellect and exhibit lesser expectations This is rubbish!"

Winner cited Bambi, Erin Brockovich, The Third Man, Gladiator and Lawrence of Arabia as his five film gems.

webTitle: Sven may play Owen on England's left

fields.headline: Sven may play Owen on England's left
fields.trailText: England manager Sven-Goran Eriksson has hinted that he may play Michael Owen on the left wing in future internationals.
fields.body:
England manager Sven-Goran Eriksson has hinted that he may play Michael Owen on the left wing in future internationals.

Owen has scored twice in Eriksson's first three games in charge, but that apparently will not stop the Swedish coach sticking the Liverpool man out wide.

"Michael can play as a first or second striker or from behind, as he has during the three games he has played for me," Eriksson told the Daily Mail today. "He was excellent in all three games in that position but I'm also convinced he can play as a winger on the left.

"I noticed that he often tries to find space on the left flank. From there he can go inside and shoot with his right foot."

But although this suggests Owen may often be popping up in surprise positions under Eriksson's tutelage, the England manager was at pains to point out that he still sees the 21-year-old first and foremost as a front man.

"I'm not saying he is the best striker in the world right now," Eriksson opined. "But he can definitely become the best."

fields.headline: Thursday's rumours
fields.standfirst: All today's rumours are aghast that the Mirror has put a picture of a baby calf named Pheonix on their front page, claiming it's a "symbol of hope for everyone who has suffered in the foot and mouth crisis". No it isn't. Look, she's still going to get slaughtered at some point
fields.trailText: Tottenham have beaten off interest from Chelsea, Liverpool, Newcastle and Parma to sign Barcelona captain Pep Guardiola, reports the Mirror. The paper claims that Guardiola will join Spurs on July 1 on a free transfer when his contract with Barcelona expires. He will immediately become the highest earner at White Hart Lane by signing a four-year contract worth a cool £2.5m a season.
fields.body:
Tottenham have beaten off interest from Chelsea, Liverpool, Newcastle and Parma to sign Barcelona captain Pep Guardiola, reports the Mirror. The paper claims that Guardiola will join Spurs on July 1 on a free transfer when his contract with Barcelona expires. He will immediately become the highest earner at White Hart Lane by signing a four-year contract worth a cool £2.5m a season.

However, the Sun has a different take on the story. The paper claims that Newcastle manager Bobby Robson remains "confident" he can persuade Guardiola to move to Tyneside - providing the board gives the Barca captain the £3m-a-season he is demanding.

Meanwhile, the Mail reckons that Tottenham's target isn't Guardiola but Emmanuel Petit. They report that Barca were last night expecting a formal £7m bid from Spurs after representatives of the two clubs agreed a fee for the player during a meeting in Barcelona yesterday.

But yet again there's dispute among the tabloids. The Sun reckons that Fulham are "desperate" to sign Petit - and are prepared to meet his £50,000-a-week wage demands in order to get him.

Manchester United will face competition for Kieron Dyer from Leeds. According to the Star, David O'Leary will move for the £20m-rated Newcastle midfielder if his side qualifies for the Champions League. And the Mirror reckons O'Leary is prepared to offer Newcastle Michael Bridges as "bait" for Dyer.

Another Manchester United rumour. According to the Sun, Alex Ferguson is willing to spend £4m on Derby's Mart Poom, even though he would only be the side's reserve keeper behind Fabian Barthez.

Aston Villa have renewed their interest in Benni McCarthy. John Gregory was in Perugia last night to watch the South Africa striker turn out against Italy and - according to the Sun - is hoping he can land the striker for a cut-price £6.5m. The striker has been in the cold at Celta Vigo after saying he wanted to leave the club, and is coming to the end of his contract.

Jim Jefferies has dismissed reports he will leave Bradford to return to the Scottish Premier League. "I couldn't believe what I read. I want people to know that I'm happy and have settled well in England," he said. "There's a big job to do at Bradford, and there's no doubt about my desire to stay and put things right."

fields.body:
Terry Manners, the Press Association executive and former editor-in-chief of Express Newspapers in Scotland, is to be the new editor of Northcliffe's Western Daily Press in Bristol.

The shake-up announced this week by Carlton and Granada Media has been described as the "strongest signal yet" that ownership rules will be changed to allow a single ITV after the General Election.

Newly appointed Sunday Mirror editor Tina Weaver was firmly in control this week after the dramatic departure of Colin Myler.

The BBC has stood by its decision not to broadcast an apology to Peter Mandelson for wrongly alleging in a Panorama programme that he had lied over his involvement in the Hindujas affair.

Channel 5 is to bring on ITN reporter John Gilbert as "the Man in the White Suit" to expose the spin of the General Election campaign.

fields.headline: Race inquiry blasts housing sector
fields.trailText: Housing associations and their regulator, the Housing Corporation, were characterised as being white dominated and hypocritical on race, at the first day of an inquiry into race and housing.
fields.body:
Housing associations and their regulator, the Housing Corporation, were characterised as being white dominated and hypocritical on race, at the first day of an inquiry into race and housing.

The inquiry was set up in the wake of the Macpherson report into the murder of Stephen Lawrence after it highlighted institutional racism in the housing sector as well as the police force.

Tony Soares, representing Arhag housing association, suggested to the inquiry that housing was run by few groups of white people, and that efforts to appoint black people to top jobs were "token gestures".

Mr Soares, a former director of Positive Action Training in Housing (Path), said: "There is an unmistakable glass ceiling which only a few people have penetrated. It is always the usual suspects who get the top jobs."

Mr Soares claimed the problem stemmed from the high proportion of white housing professionals who sit on the boards of other housing associations.

He said: "It comes down to who controls [registered social landlords]. Basically RSLs are controlled by housing professionals who sit on each others boards."

The inquiry panel later quizzed one of the country's largest housing associations - Notting Hill housing trust - on why none of its five senior directors was black, despite its area of operation.

Inquiry member Victor Adebowale, chief executive of Centrepoint, said: "Notting Hill has been operating in a black community for some time. It has not had any black people running it. Why has it taken so long?"

Roz Spencer, the trust's director of neighbourhoods, conceded that the problem needed to be addressed urgently, but claimed that a glass ceiling in the trust was slowly rising.

However, she added that if the trust rushed through the appointment black directors there would be "a significant risk of making bad decisions that could reinforce prejudices."

Mr Soares acknowledged the introduction of the housing corporation's black and minority ethnic strategy which helped fund the establishment of black-led housing associations.

But he said: "What one hand of the housing corporation tends to promote the other hand tends to demote."

He complained of excessive supervision of black-led housing associations and accused the corporation, the National Housing Federation - the trade body of housing associations and local authorities of "playing into the hands of the government's racist attitude to asylum."

Mr Soares pointed out that many white led housing associations had doubled and even tripled in size in recent years, while most black led housing associations had remained small.

He acknowledge that black-led housing associations tend to charge higher rents than average, but pointed out that this was because they have developed in the last 12 years when government has forced associations to borrow private money to build homes forcing up rents.

Mr Soares claimed that some leading housing associations should transfer debt-free homes to black-led associations to help them cut rents and increase their financial strength.

Clare Winstanely, chief executive of Innisfree housing association, expressed regret that no senior figures from the government, councils or the housing corporation had attended the inquiry.

She said: "If we are to see real race equality we need proper leadership."

Should Carlton and Granada be allowed to combine their sales houses as part of an ITV merger?

TalkSport has snatched the rights to broadcast live commentary of half of London's Premiership football teams, smashing Capital Radio's 10-year monopoly.

The popularity of reality TV shows such as Big Brother and Popstars has pushed the price of sponsorship packages through the roof.

fields.headline: Mirrorman goes to Express
fields.trailText:
10.45am: The Mirror's foreign editor, David Leigh, is to join the Daily Express, writes Jessica Hodgson .
Special report: Express takeover
fields.body:
The Mirror's foreign editor, David Leigh, has confirmed he is to join the Daily Express as assistant editor, news.

Mr Leigh, who has been at the paper for 12 years, said he had been given an offer he couldn't refuse.

His decision to leaves comes months after a reshuffle at the Mirror, which saw him moved from the newsdesk to the foreign desk.

"I've been here for a long time in a lot of different roles. I went to see Piers yesterday and he was brilliant and said he totally understood," said Mr Leigh.

In addition to his current role as foreign editor, Mr Leigh has also worked as night news editor and news editor.

He will effectively replace outgoing head of news Sean Rayment, who is taking voluntary redundancy from the paper and will leave after the election.

Related stories

webTitle: EU strikes new deal on freedom of information

fields.headline: EU strikes new deal on freedom of information
fields.standfirst: Special report: freedom of information
fields.trailText: Ordinary citizens stand to win unprecedented transparency from European Union institutions, it was claimed last night, after a landmark vote in the European parliament breached the defences of governments and bureaucrats.
fields.body:
Ordinary citizens stand to win unprecedented transparency from European Union institutions, it was claimed last night, after a landmark vote in the European parliament breached the defences of governments and bureaucrats.

"For the first time, citizens have a right to access official documents by virtue of EU law," declared Sweden, the current holder of the union's rotating presidency.

But the triumph of a bitterly-fought campaign galvanised by a celebrated Guardian court case was marred by angry criticism from freedom of information lobbyists that the deal left crucial loopholes and ambiguities.

The British MEP Michael Cashman, who drafted the agreement, hailed a "mature compromise" between EU institutions for a code of public access to documents, including having 90% available via the internet, a public register and an annual openness report. The arrangement is to be reviewed in three years time.

"It's the beginning of a process, not the end," he said after the 29-6 vote in the parliament's citizens' rights committee. "Considering that we had powerful governments against it, it is a considerable achievement."

Yesterday's decision - expected to be confirmed in plenary session next week - means that the 626-seat parliament, the European commission and the council of ministers have reached a historic agreement. In future, official papers on issues such as BSE, radiation from mobile phones or genetically modified organisms should be routinely available to citizens, as will information about border controls the European Police Office, Europol, and all but most sensitive papers on EU defence and foreign policy.

Sweden, with its own traditions of transparency, had worked hard to bridge gaps but critics complained that definitions of what can be labelled secret, top secret and restricted remained worryingly unclear.

"It's a stitch-up," protested Tony Bunyan of Statewatch, the London-based civil liberties group. "The parliament has rolled over and given in to the council. Its been a wholly undemocratic process."

MEPs had fallen victim to the "Stockholm syndrome" in which hostages identify with their captors, said the Greens, who voted against the agreement. The European Federation of Journalists said it undermined existing rights.

Backers of the code conceded that there were drawbacks but insisted it was a case of the best being the enemy of the good. Graham Watson, the Liberal Democrat chairman of the European parliament's citizens rights committee, called the vote a "roaring rip in the veil of secrecy".

Calls for more freedom of information in Europe increased after the Danish rejection of the Maastricht treaty, itself seen as a peak of bureaucratic and diplomatic opacity.

In 1995 John Carvel, then a Guardian correspondent in Brussels, backed by Denmark and the Netherlands, took the council of ministers to court for refusing access to documents that should have been available under its own rules, and won a knockout victory.

Two years later the treaty of Amsterdam, signed by Tony Blair just weeks after taking office, called for the creation of a code of access to documents by this month - which yesterday's vote now makes possible.

Freedom of information is a highly sensitive issue. The previous European commission, under Jacques Santer of Luxembourg, was discredited and forced to resign partly over issues of a lack of transparency.

Romano Prodi, his Italian successor, has published a list of his correspondence on his website, though not the documents themselves.

Britain has been praised for taking an open approach to the code, with diplomats arguing that transparency should increase the EU's popularity.

This agreement overturns a controversial decision by Javier Solana, the council's foreign policy chief, to exclude whole categories of documents from public access. Mr Solana argued that Nato would be less willing to share its secrets with fledgling EU defence bodies if freedom of information procedures were too relaxed.

Under the code, if a request for information is denied, the applicant may appeal to the ombudsman or the court of justice in Luxembourg.

EU institutions can refuse to provide information but must be able to prove that release would be harmful. But, following British practice, documents can only be kept secret for a maximum of 30 years.

Mr Solana argued that Nato would be less willing to share its secrets with fledgling EU defence bodies if freedom of information procedures were too relaxed. Under the code, if a request for information is denied, the applicant may appeal to the ombudsman or the court of justice in Luxembourg. fields.headline: 'Selfless' Arnie abandons politics dreams
fields.trailText: Arnold Schwarzenegger has put his political ambitions on hold in order to devote time to his film career and his young family
fields.body:
Arnie fans who were losing sleep following February's news that the muscle-bound star was looking to move into the world of politics can sleep easy again.

Arnold Schwarzenegger has announced that he is opting out of the race to become a Republican governor of California in 2002, saying his film career and family have taken precedence. With two film projects in the works, Schwarzenegger fears he does not have the time to pursue a political career at the moment. He will focus instead on finishing a sequel to True Lies, and production will begin later this year on Terminator III.

"I have to be selfless at this point ... and take care of those things," the 53-year-old actor told the Los Angeles Times. "The movie projects came together... I have to keep up my end of the deal." But he is not abandoning the idea of running for office as a Republican, only postponing his plunge into politics until his four children, ages 3 to 11, are older, he told the Times yesterday.

The Austrian-born former bodybuilder, whose film credits include Pumping Iron and Total Recall as well as the hugely successful Terminator duo, was rumoured to be running for governor back in March after he criticised the current governor for California's handling of the electricity crisis. Shortly afterwards, allegations of sexual harassment were levelled at Schwarzenegger, which prompted Sharon Stone, Jamie Lee Curtis and several other of his co-stars to rally to the actor's defence.

Schwarzenegger has long been a Republican activist despite his marriage to Maria Shriver, a niece of former Democratic president John F. Kennedy. A move into politics would echo that of another actor-turned politician, ex-president Ronald Reagan.

fields.headline: WPP results spark slowdown fears
fields.trailText: 10.30am: Ad giant WPP's first-quarter results have prompted renewed fears about the effects of the US economic slowdown, reports Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
WPP today reported a lower-than-expected rise in first-quarter revenues, prompting renewed fears about the effect of the US economic slowdown on the British advertising and marketing giant.

WPP, which now derives around half its revenue from the US, said like-for-like revenues excluding acquisitions and currency fluctuations rose 6% in the first three months of the year.

The figure fell short of even WPP's own estimations of 7% growth, which the company had described as "conservative".

But the headline figure in today's trading statement showed a 73% rise in revenue for the three months to March 31.

This reflected first-time contributions from the US advertising giant, Young & Rubicam, which WPP acquired last year, and the strength of the dollar and European currencies against the pound.

WPP said it was on track to lift its operating margin by one percentage point to 15% in 2001.

In a statement, the company said the economic slowdown had "impacted public relations and public affairs, and branding and identity, healthcare and specialist communications the most, advertising and media investment management less so, and information and consultancy the least".

webTitle: Hardline France tries to weed out cannabis lobby

fields.headline: Hardline France tries to weed out cannabis lobby
fields.standfirst: A ridiculous legal demand has sparked public outrage about France's draconian cannabis laws, reports Jon Henley
fields.trailText: A ridiculous legal demand has sparked public outrage about France's draconian cannabis laws, reports Jon Henley in Paris.
fields.body:
In what would be one of the more aberrant recent decisions of the French justice system, two pro-pot activists risk spending a year in jail for wearing T-shirts emblazoned with a picture of a cannabis leaf.

A zealous public prosecutor this week demanded 12-month prison terms for Jean-Pierre Galland, president of the Cannabis Information and Research Collective, and Laurence Duffy, head of the campaign group's Lyon branch, for contravening article 630 of the French public health regulations.

The law bans French citizens from "portraying in a favourable light and promoting or inciting the consumption of any product classed as a banned substance". The pair are also accused of selling CDs bearing the deeply suspect title of "A little piece of hemp music".

This is, of course, an absurdity, something that was pointed out by some 40 people, including philosophers, Green MPs, actors, film-makers and representatives of human rights and Aids groups, who signed an open letter to the prime minister, Lionel Jospin, saying as much.

Nor is it the first time that the collective, a nationwide association of committed weed smokers, has run into trouble. The brave Mr Galland has so far incurred fines totalling £10,000 for his activities, the most memorable of which was probably to mail all 577 members of the French parliament a neatly rolled joint along with a letter demanding the relaxation of France's drugs laws, among the harshest in Europe.

"Nurtured and cosseted by enthusiasts, this cannabis, raised under the sweet skies of France, has been generously donated by growers to give to you," read the letter poetically. The MPs would now be in the same position as the many thousands of their fellow citizens who had illegally rolled and shared a joint, it continued: "A law that is broken daily by hundreds of thousands of people is a bad law. It is time for the state to stop treating cannabis enthusiasts like delinquents."

To be fair, over the past couple of years, Mr Jospin's Socialist-led government has begun edging round to the collective's point of view. Officially, the use, possession and sale of marijuana is still banned, despite estimates that some 7m of the country's 60m people have tried the drug at least once and about 2m are regular users.

But after a number of high-profile admissions by ministers, France's traditionally draconian approach - which theoretically makes the import of few grammes of Dutch weed punishable by up to 30 years in prison - could no longer sensibly be maintained.

The Green environment minister, Dominique Voynet, caused uproar among conservative MPs when she admitted having smoked cannabis and favouring decriminalisation. "I am more worried by the number of French people who need sleeping pills than by the number of people who confess to having smoked a joint," she said.

The Socialist employment (and formerly justice) minister, Elizabeth Guigou, has also expressed the opinion that smoking the occasional joint was "no tragedy" and the health minister Bernard Kouchner is known to support the medical use of cannabis on prescription. Even Mr Jospin, when pressed, will admit to having smoked some hashish in the past.

The conservative opposition, headed by the president, Jacques Chirac, has always been hostile to any relaxation. Mr Chirac has repeatedly accused the Netherlands in particular of encouraging trafficking by tolerating soft drugs consumption. "Consuming soft drugs inevitably leads to hard drugs," he said. "All serious people are aware of this."

Nonetheless, encouraged in part by similar moves in several other European countries, France's inter-ministerial drugs commission last year recommended a rather softer approach and the justice minister has written to all the country's judges urging them to avoid prison sentences for offences related to cannabis consumption.

All of which, as the collective's supporters point out in their letter, makes the demand of the Lyon public prosecutor even more absurd. "It means," they said in their letter to Mr Jospin, "that in France, the birthplace of human rights, in the year 2001, you can no longer be jailed for consuming cannabis but you can be for 'portraying its consumption in a favourable light'."

The PM has yet to reply, but the case poses a difficult problem for him: one of the main aims of recent judicial reforms in France was to remove any possibility of government interference with cases coming before the courts.

Sadly, Mr Galland's fate is likely to hinge on whether or not the presiding magistrate ever rolled a spliff in his youth.

webTitle: Emap's Looks jumps on celebrity bandwagon

fields.headline: Emap's Looks jumps on celebrity bandwagon
fields.trailText:
9.30: Emap Elan's Looks magazine is rebranding itself as Celebrity Looks, reports Jessica Hodgson.
19.04.2001: Britain covets Celebrity Bodies
fields.body:
Emap Elan's Looks magazine is the latest magazine to rush into the celebrity marketplace, rebranding itself as Celebrity Looks.

The magazine's new name and logo will be unveiled for the June issue.

Looks magazine, which provides fashion and beauty advice for 16 to 25-year-olds, has increasingly focused on celebrity over the past two years.

Its editor, Margi Conklin, claims the change simply brings the magazine's name and logo up to date with its philosophy.

"When I joined the magazine a year ago we had a vision to make it 100% celebrity focused," Ms Conklin told MediaGuardian.co.uk. "This is simply the completion of that process."

"We are just in the business of clarifying where we are to our readers and advertisers."

Celebrity has become paramount in the increasingly competitive battle for circulation among magazine publishers.

The last ABC circulation figures showed that magazines with a celebrity focus saw their sales rise at the expense of the more traditional women's glossy magazines.

Looks, which was launched in 1986, has a circulation of 130,000.

webTitle: 'I had to fight for her, she couldn't fight for herself'

fields.headline: 'I had to fight for her, she couldn't fight for herself'
fields.standfirst: Last year, a woman was raped in a nursing home. Last week, thanks to her husband's refusal to give up the case, her attacker was jailed.  Diane Taylor reports
fields.trailText: Last year, a woman was raped in a nursing home. Last week, thanks to her husband's refusal to give up the case, her attacker was jailed. Diane Taylor reports.
fields.body:
Clara Parker (not her real name) is horribly traumatised by a rape carried out last year by John Archibald at the Buckinghamshire nursing home where she is looked after. She is in the advanced stages of Huntington's disease, a condition that impairs mental and physical ability. Her husband Michael (not his real name), a BBC presenter, had to fight to persuade the crown prosecution service to take on the case but at Reading crown court on Friday, when Archibald was jailed for three years for the rape, Michael had little time to feel vindicated nor Clara to feel safe. Moments after the sentence was passed, Archibald's brother Mark turned to Michael, tried to hit him and said: "I'll get you for this. I'll have you."

The next day, a minibus was burnt out in an arson attack outside the home. There is no evidence that it's connected but police are investigating.

Bringing to court any sort of rape case is fraught with difficulties and only around one in 10 of the rapes reported to police results in a prosecution. When the victim is especially vulnerable because of a mental or physical illness or a learning disability, the chances of getting a case to court slump even further. The Youth Justice and Criminal Evidence Act 1999 contains new provisions to help vulnerable adults give evidence in court, such as judges removing wigs, the erection of screens between witnesses and defendants and video recordings used as evidence. These provisions were supposed to be in place by the end of last year but a Home Office spokesman admits implementation of most could be another year away.

Progress has also been slow in the proposed reform of the Sex Offences Act which recommends strengthening the law in cases where a person in a position of trust or responsibility carries out abuse. The Department of Health has guidelines for local authorities to protect vulnerable adults who are abused, but there is no legal requirement to implement them.

Tamsin Cottis of Respond, which provides counselling for people with learning difficulties who have been abused, says: "Decisions can be taken very early on that women like Clara wouldn't make good witnesses. People like her are more vulnerable than others to abuse, yet when they are victims of sex crimes, it is much harder for them to get justice."

The assumption that Clara would not be a good witness dogged Michael when he tried to get her rape brought to court. Though the crime was witnessed by a wheelchair-bound patient and there was DNA evidence, the CPS said Clara's evidence might not be "reliable" because she is a nursing home patient.

Michael and Clara met in the early 60s when both worked as journalists on a local paper. They married in 1962 but problems began when Clara developed severe mood swings and obsessional behaviour in her late 40s. The couple separated in the late 80s and it wasn't until 1995 that Clara was diagnosed with Huntington's disease. Michael returned, saying he felt responsible for looking after her, and in January last year she moved into the Buckinghamshire nursing home.

The rape took place when another resident invited Clara, a compulsive smoker, into his room for a cigarette. John Archibald, who was visiting a relative, and his brother Mark came too. Mark handed Clara two cannabis cigarettes. She had never tried the drug before and did not know it was in the cigarettes. After smoking them, she tried to return to her room but John Archibald forced her on to the bed and raped her twice.

Clara says the attack is the worst thing that has ever happened to her. "I felt so unclean and they hurt me so badly. My body took weeks to recover."

The next morning staff told Michael what had happened and Clara was taken to a local rape centre where she was examined by a police doctor and video evidence was taken. However, the CPS decided not to prosecute and it took Michael four months to persuade them to change their minds. "I believe she was singled out because she was vulnerable. I had to fight for her, she couldn't fight for herself. I kept insisting that it was their duty to pursue the case, that they had DNA evidence, a witness and my wife's testimony."

The case finally came to court last November and the jury convicted John Archibald of the rape. Clara did not give evidence in court.

Often the only course open to a victim if the CPS decides not to pursue the case is to take out a civil action, not against the perpetrator but, in a case like Clara's, against the nursing home for allowing visitors to be left alone with her without supervision. And victims are sometimes unable to communicate what has happened to them or are too terrified to talk.

Christiana Horrocks, director of Voice, which provides support for adults and children with learning disabilities who have been abused, says: "Sometimes the reasons given to victims to stop them talking are even more evil than the abuse. One young woman was raped by a man who knew her mother was in remission from cancer. He told her if she said anything about the attack, her mother would die from the cancer."

Harriet Wistrich, a solicitor who advises women making complaints about the way their rape investigations have been handled, says women need to be "perfect victims" to avoid running into difficulties if the case goes to court. "Saying a woman consented is often used by the defence," she points out. "Even if there is evidence of serious bruises and other injuries, the defence may say: 'She just liked it rough.' There are so many rapes in children's and residential homes, and psychiatric institutions, because rapists know they can get away with it there."

Janine (not her real name), a 26-year-old who had been receiving treatment for severe anorexia and a personality disorder, was at a low ebb when she met a man who was kind to her. She had walked out of a hospital psychiatric ward and had nowhere to go. He offered her a bed for the night at the hostel he was staying at. Once there, he trapped her in his bedroom and force-fed her cannabis and crack before raping her four times. The drug cocktail paralysed her for several hours and it was only when her attacker finally fell asleep that she managed to half walk, half fall out of his bedroom, collapsing in the hostel office. Her heart stopped but she was resuscitated and taken to hospital.

"I told the staff what had happened and they reported it to the police. But the officer who came to see me was so hard. He tried to get me to sign a form withdrawing the rape allegations but I refused. He said if I didn't sign, I would put my family through hell and that I already had a history of that because of my anorexia. He said if the CPS threw the case out, they could get me for wasting police time."

Last December, two measures were introduced to protect alleged rape victims in court: restriction of admissible evidence about their sexual history and an end to cross-examination by the alleged rapist. But there is still a long way to go before all women, and particularly those who are most vulnerable, can get a fair hearing. As Janine says: "People are hit at their lowest ebb and it's when you get to that point that you are least likely to get support from the criminal justice system."

webTitle: Census scanners just raring to read

fields.headline: Census scanners just raring to read
fields.trailText: Census forms returned covered in tea stains or smeared with bacon and egg will present no problems for the electronic scanning systems that will process the results, officials of the office of national statistics promised yesterday.
fields.body:
Census forms returned covered in tea stains or smeared with bacon and egg will present no problems for the electronic scanning systems that will process the results, officials of the office of national statistics promised yesterday.

Even doctors' handwriting will be readable by computerised recognition systems programmed to decipher all sorts of UK styles, even those in capitals.

Forms that have been chewed by the dog or otherwise mutilated will be referred to one of the 1,200 people recruited to process census information at a huge centre in Widnes, Cheshire. They will judge whether the information can be deciphered.

The assurances came as the ONS tried to recover from an overload of calls from the public to its helpline. About 240,000 calls were received on Monday, and many callers found the number unobtainable or constantly engaged.

The ONS has increased phone lines from 400 to 870 and is drafting in extra operators to respond to callers whose questions are not answered from a menu of recorded messages covering the most common queries.

Graham Jones, the census director, said there should be no such hitches when it came to processing the returns. Advanced computer software has been installed to read the forms that are due to be completed by 33m households on Sunday.

"We have been planning this for eight years," he said. "We have done dress rehearsals to fine tune the computing systems, and we have completed the training of an excellent cadre of census workers."

About 300,000 boxes of completed forms will be delivered to the centre by the middle of May and will be scanned by computerised optical recognition systems at a rate of 88 forms a minute over the following 10 months.

Officials expect the system to handle 85% of forms automatically and without error. The rest will be referred to operators. Approximately 28 terabytes of images and data will be captured from the forms - enough to fill 20m disks.

The census, every 10 years, is the UK's largest survey. The confidential form contains 41 questions, on details including health, ethnic status and employment.

fields.headline: PR Week
fields.standfirst: Publication date: April 27
fields.trailText: April 27: The Railtrack and Scottish Power accounts are up for grabs and a host of agencies are set to scramble for the business.
fields.body:
Railtrack and Scottish Power, two of the most prestigious UK public affairs accounts, are up for grabs, with a host of agencies set to scramble for the business.

Fee income surged through the £0.5bn mark in 2000, according to the PR Week Top 150 league table of the UK's top PR agencies.

Buckingham Palace has appointed Samantha Cohen to handle Prince Andrew's high-profile transformation into a trade ambassador.

Oxfam is looking to appoint its first communications and campaigns director following a shake-up of its PR and campaigning work.

BSkyB has handed its public affairs, corporate and financial PR accounts to a start-up consultancy headed by the former BSkyB communications chief, Tim Allan.

Liberal Democrat lobbyists are lining up to help the party during the general election campaign. The latest to be recruited is Jeremy Browne Edelman, PR Worldwide account director.

The Association of Professional Political Consultants is to hire lawyers to advise on hidden dangers in the Political Parties, Elections and Referendums Act.

The two main PR industry bodies moved a step closer together last week with the launch of a joint committee to explore ways of working as one.

fields.headline: Scholes to sign £13m United deal
fields.trailText: Paul Scholes is set to sign a new £13m contract with Manchester United in the summer.
fields.body:
Paul Scholes is set to sign a new £13m contract with Manchester United in the summer.

Although nothing has been finalised, it is understood that United have agreed the broad outline of a five-year, £50,000-a-week deal which will double the England midfielder's current salary at Old Trafford.

United's director of communications Paddy Harverson said: "We are still in negotiations with Paul and are confident of concluding a new deal soon."

Scholes, 26, will be the latest in a line of high-profile players to commit their long-term futures to United.

The club are working their way through a group of key players and Andy Cole, Jaap Stam and Ryan Giggs have already agreed new terms.

Salford-born Scholes looks likely to be next and after him United will step up talks with David Beckham, Gary and Phil Neville, Wes Brown and Ole Gunnar Solskjaer.

United, who also broke the British transfer record with the £19m signing of Holland striker Ruud van Nistelrooy this week, hope to have all of these players tied down with lucrative long-term contracts well before manager Sir Alex Ferguson retires at the end of next season.

Agreeing a new deal with Beckham could prove the most difficult set of negotiations for United. Talks have started and United know there could be problems over Beckham's terms.

Beckham and his advisors are well aware of his value to United, both on and off the pitch, and he is determined not to sell himself short.

United appreciate this, but chief executive Peter Kenyon has already stated that the club will not break the bank for the England captain.

fields.headline: Should he stay or should he go?
fields.standfirst: Sir Christopher Bland's decision not to leave the BBC before a successor is found goes beyond his usual cavalier arrogance and borders on serious misjudgment
fields.trailText:
Sir Christopher Bland's decision not to leave the BBC before a successor is found goes beyond his usual cavalier arrogance and borders on serious misjudgment, writes Emily Bell.
Talk about it
26.04.2001: Bland 'must step down'
26.04.2001: Sir Christopher quits to join BT
Special report: the BBC
fields.body:
Sir Christopher Bland has, to his credit, never been a man who cared much about appearances - in a corporate sense at least.

He did not mind berating the plundering hordes of Granada executives during his feisty defence of the hostile bid for LWT, he did not mind holding onto the chairmanship of National Freight while he was chairman of the BBC, and he completely ignored the pressure to not appoint his right hand man, Greg Dyke, to the DG-ship of the corporation. He did not even mind the rather spurious rumour that to secure Dyke's appointment he had shut the governors in a room until they agreed with him.

And it was clear from his attitude on the Today Programme this morning that he won't bend to pressure to give up the chairmanship of the BBC before a successor is found, even though he is taking up the reins at BT immediately. This is clearly a nonsense. While he is perfectly entitled to hold both posts - the chairman of the Beeb is entitled to one other directorship - it is clear that neither of the jobs is particularly part-time.

His salary from the BBC may be a negligible seventy-something thousand, but it is still the public purse paying for it. And goodness knows the shareholders of BT can hardly afford to have a part-timer turning round their leaky tanker of a company - particularly on £350k. To insist there is nothing inappropriate about holding down two jobs of this size goes beyond Sir Christopher's normal charming cavalier arrogance and strays into the dangerous territory of serious misjudgment.

It is particularly baffling that Sir Christopher would want to carry on doing both jobs whilst he has the utterly able Goldman Sachs economist Gavyn Davies sitting at his elbow as deputy chairman. There would be no fewer conflicts of interest here, and Gavyn's day job as a partner at Goldman Sachs makes him both fully employed elsewhere and fabulously rich, but the profile and demands of his non-BBC commitments is significantly lower than the challenge Bland is about to take. Of course, the secret, which only Bland and a couple of others are privy to, is that being chairman of the BBC might not actually be the most taxing job on earth.

Of course, being a man of honour, Sir Christopher would at the very least take a pro-rata pay cut while the search for a new Beeb chairman commences. But one can't help thinking that one reason for Bland's reluctance to let go is because he would like rather more than a spectator's seat at the appointment of his successor.

But who should be appointed to follow Bland? Lord Denis Stevenson, chairman of Pearson, former head of the Tate Trustees and general polymath, is ideal, but his legion of other directorships would rule him out. Gavyn Davies himself prepared the report on the future funding of the BBC, and a stint as chairman of the BBC would add a further public service dimension to his CV should he ever want to think about the governorship of the Bank of England. A woman would make a refreshing change - Deanne Julius, who has recently stepped down from the monetary policy committee, would fit the bill, so would Baroness Jay.

The chairmanship of the BBC is in the gift of the government - and post election there will be at least two very able men with less to do than they would like available for service. Both have shown an extremely close interest in the inner workings of the BBC in the past, both have an intimate knowledge of government and media. Who could possible be more suitable than Alastair Campbell or Peter Mandelson? It is, as they say, a compelling thought.

 Emily Bell is editor-in-chief of Guardian Unlimited

webTitle: UK economy vulnerable to recession says Hague

fields.headline: UK economy vulnerable to recession says Hague
fields.standfirst: Special report: global recession
fields.trailText: William Hague will today issue a stark warning that Britain will suffer more than its competitors in a global recession because of the alleged failure of Gordon Brown to prepare the economy for a possible downturn.
fields.body:
William Hague will today issue a stark warning that Britain will suffer more than its competitors in a global recession because of the alleged failure of Gordon Brown to prepare the economy for a possible downturn.

In an intensification of his assault on the government's handling of the economy, the Tory leader will lambaste Mr Brown for raising taxes and increasing burdens on business, adding: "We're in bad shape to hold our own in an economic downturn."

Mr Hague will be careful not to predict a recession - the Tories have painful memories of their 1998 attack on the "downturn made in Downing Street" which backfired when the economy performed well. Amid growing fears, however, that Britain could be hit by the American downturn, he will say that Mr Brown has left the economy vulnerable by failing to cut taxes and reduce regulatory burdens on business.

In a speech at the Institute of Directors in London, Mr Hague will say that four conditions need to be met if Britain is to survive a global recession unscathed:

 Falling taxes;

 A cut in the burden on businesses to ensure they remain competitive;

 A reformed welfare system to keep people off benefits and in work;

 Interest rates set in Britain.

Mr Hague will claim that on all but one count - the setting of interest rates by the Bank of England - the government has failed. "The government is failing to cut taxes, failing to reduce regulations, failing to reform welfare," he will say in his speech which is being organised by the rightwing Centre for Policy Studies.

Drawing a line between the Tories, who have pledged tax cuts of £8bn in the next parliament, and Labour, which he claimed would continue to raise taxes by stealth, Mr Hague said that Mr Brown was the "opposite of a prudent" chancellor.

"Relentlessly raising taxes is the opposite of prudent preparation for economic difficulties," Mr Hague will say. The Tory leader will claim that real prudence requires careful preparation for the unexpected.

"The time to fix your roof is when the sun is shining," Mr Hague will say, quoting the chancellor's favourite US president.

Mr Hague's speech will be dismissed by Labour as an irresponsible attempt to talk down the economy, which is facing testing times. The chancellor gave his strongest hint of the challenge ahead earlier this week when he spoke of "the current instability in the financial and commodity markets".

However, Labour, which is likely to pledge that income tax will not be raised in the next parliament, is confident that the Conservatives are still seen as the party of "boom and bust".

fields.headline: NBC orders more Weakest Link
fields.trailText:
10.15am: The Weakest Link has been so popular with American audiences that NBC has commissioned another series, reports Ashley Davies.

20.04.2001: America warms to Weakest Link

17.04.2001: Weakest Link storms US
fields.body:
American audiences have warmed so much to the coldness of Anne Robinson that NBC has asked for twice as many episodes of The Weakest Link as originally planned.

The US TV network had only asked for 13 shows at first but has now asked the BBC to co-produce another 13.

More than 50m viewers tuned into the first three episodes of the gameshow.

American critics were less generous, but perhaps this had the effect of churning up more interest in the format.

"We are delighted the show has been such a hit for NBC and has become an important part of their summer schedule," said Colin Jarvis, director of programmes and operations for BBC Worldwide.

"It's great to see Anne's unique style and wit has travelled so well across the Atlantic."

webTitle: A day in the lives of family doctors

fields.headline: A day in the lives of family doctors
fields.trailText: Dr Nigel Watson New Forest
fields.body:
Dr Nigel Watson New Forest

7.10am Arrived at surgery. Dictated referral letters, signed prescriptions. Dealt with post - letters from hospitals relating to patients seen in out-patient departments, test results and x-ray results. Ran reports through computer to find patients who needed to be called for monitoring for various treatments, eg patients on certain drugs who have not turned up for blood tests.

8.30-11.30am Surgery. Overbooked again by three patients. Saw 17 patients.

11.30am-1pm. Three home visits.

1-2pm Meeting of three partners and practice manager, discussing how to fit in more patients and give each more time.

2-4.15pm Surgery. Saw 18 patients.

4.15-6pm Went with consultant psychiatrist, police and social services to section somebody under Mental Health Act, followed by another home visit.

6pm-8.30am On call for the night.

Dr Anna Livingstone Docklands, London

8.30am Arrived at practice. Did paperwork, prescriptions, answered phones, met nurses.

9am-2.15pm Surgery.

2.15-2.35pm Went through trainee's work with her.

2.35-3.05pm Computer work - looking at blood test results and answering urgent emails. Discussion with practice computer manager. Letters.

3.05-3.45pm Home visit. Back 20 mins late because of parking problems.

3.50-6.50pm Surgery.

6.50-7.15pm Supervised trainee.

7.15-11pm Returned patients' phone calls, did paperwork, wrote letters, discussed recruitment issues with partners, dealt with test results, wrote reports, summarised notes for patients moving away, looked at issues to do with PCT (primary care trust).

After 11pm Went home.

Dr Chris Taggart Coventry

8.15am Arrived at practice. Chatted with partners.

8.30-10.15am Surgery. Saw 16 patients.

10.45am Baby clinic. In between patients dealt with paperwork re meningitis in pilgrims to Mecca, diabetes targets, insurance reports, checking appropriateness of repeat prescriptions.

Lunchtime Interviewed a GP trainee who may want experience at the practice.

2-3pm Surgery. Saw 11 patients. Couple of difficult problems so took until 3.30

4-5.30pm Surgery. Saw 16 patients. On call for home visits, but those who rang were able to attend surgery.

6pm Opened post - letters from hospital consultants, blood tests. Wrote repeat prescriptions.

7pm Went home.

webTitle: Bamber Forsyth wins Radio First account

fields.headline: Bamber Forsyth wins Radio First account
fields.trailText:
10am: The digital football radio company, Radio First, has appointed Bamber Forsyth to give it a new corporate image, reports Julia Day.
13.03.2001: BSkyB takes option on football radio
fields.body:
Radio First, the company launching digital radio stations for football clubs including Chelsea and Aston Villa, has appointed the branding consultancy that created Kiss 100's image.

Bamber Forsyth will create a new corporate identity for First Radio and will design the identities of each of the eight football club stations within the group, which will be called the Fan Radio Network

The agency will also help position the network as a new national advertising medium

Each club station will have its own name - Chelsea's will be the Big Blue, Aston Villa's will be the Villan and Southampton's will be called the Saint.

fields.headline: New family drama for ITV
fields.trailText: 9.45am: ITV has teamed up with Peak Practice creator Lucy Gannon for an eight-part drama series, reports Jason Deans.
fields.body:
ITV has teamed up with Peak Practice creator Lucy Gannon again to create Blue Dove, a drama likened to soapy 1970s family saga the Brothers.

Blue Dove refers to a fictional pottery owned by the family at the centre of the series.

The drama is set in the Potteries region around Stoke on Trent.

"Blue Dove is a contemporary family saga, relating to a pottery family in the Potteries," said Nick Elliott, the ITV controller of drama.

"It's a big dynastic struggle with love affairs, business and back-stabbing, in the same genre as the Brothers.

"When the family patriarch hands over the pottery an internecine struggle breaks out between the siblings and others."

The eight-part series has been written by Ms Gannon and is currently in production.

The cast includes former EastEnders star Paul Nicholls and Ruth Gemmell, who played Colin Firth's long-suffering girlfriend in the film adaptation of Nick Hornby's book, Fever Pitch.

Blue Dove is being made by Carlton Productions, with the controller of drama, Jonathan Powell, executive producing.

fields.headline: Security alert for independence day
fields.standfirst:
Traditionally one of the liveliest days in the Israeli calendar, this year it will be a subdued affair, reports former Guardian Israel correspondent Derek Brown

Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Traditionally one of the liveliest days in the Israeli calendar, this year it will be a subdued affair, reports Derek Brown
fields.body:
This week has seen two of the most significant events in the Israeli calendar.

Yesterday was Memorial Day, the annual national tribute to the some 20,000 servicemen and women killed in defence of the state since it declared itself independent on May 14, 1948.

By the Jewish lunar calendar, that anniversary fell due this week, and Independence Day followed immediately after - and will end at dusk today. (All days in the Jewish year run from sundown to sundown.) After the solemnity of Memorial Day, the independence celebrations are generally light spirited, with fireworks and family outings. This year, they are subdued.

As usual, Arab homes within Israel and throughout the occupied territories will be decked in black flags, the traditional symbol of mourning and protest. And in Jewish homes too there is likely to be some sombre reflection on recent events.

The intifada or uprising which erupted at the end of last September has now killed nearly 500 people - 410 Palestinians and 70 Israelis. Even after the bloodshed started there was a slender hope that the two sides could be jolted into a permanent peace settlement. Now that hope is utterly dead.

Nobody is talking about peace now. The best they can do is to talk about limiting the bloodshed and calming the tension. To that end Israel has promised to ease its blockade of the territories controlled by Palestinian president Yasser Arafat, in exchange for greater Palestinian efforts to prevent violence.

The blockade is likely to remain absolute until Independence Day ends at dusk tomorrow. Islamist and other guerrilla groups have vowed to attack Israeli targets whenever they can, and to do so on a key national date would have high symbolic value.

But even after independence day, ending the conflict is going to involve more than gestures and tokens.

Most Israelis believe passionately that Arafat started the violence, and that he could stop it if he wanted. But if the Palestinian leadership ordered its ramshackle security apparatus to counter the militants, it would risk adding civil war to the misery of the territories, and do nothing to assuage the bitter anger which is fuelling the unrest.

Palestinians of every political and religious hue have simply had enough of Israeli bullying. They are sick of the blockade which has all but destroyed their fragile economy, of the casual use of live ammunition against rioters, and the mindset which dictates that any attack on Israeli territory should be answered with a barrage of rocket, artillery and tank fire.

There are two rays of watery light in the gloom. One is the growing involvement of the Bush administration in efforts to patch up relations.

The latest tentative agreement on measures to improve security and ease the blockade were negotiated at the home of the US ambassador in Tel Aviv, Martin Indyk.

The other small glimmer of hope is the imminently expected report of a five-member international inquiry into the intifada, headed by US senator George Mitchell. The report is widely expected, in Israel at least, to recommend the deployment of international observers in the occupied territory - an idea that has been ardently demanded by the Palestinians, and rejected out of hand by Israel.

An international presence will not, of course, solve either the present conflict or the ancient emnity which underlies it. But it could do much to cool the ardour of the hawks and hotheads on both sides, while giving the innocent an outlet for their fears and grievances.

fields.headline: NTL and Telewest to run video-on-demand
fields.trailText:
8.30am: NTL and Telewest have signed up On Demand Group to develop a video-on-demand service, writes Jason Deans.
12.04.2001: Gladiator to make TV premiere on pay per view
fields.body:
The cable TV operators, NTL and Telewest, have signed up the pay-per-view specialist, On Demand Group, to develop a video-on-demand service.

The three companies are already joint venture partners in Front Row, the pay-per-view film and near video-on-demand service.

This was developed by On Demand and has been managed by the outfit since it launched on NTL's and Telewest's cable networks in 1998.

The video-on-demand service will be developed under the Front Row brand.

Front Row offers customers six films a day on four TV channels and the near video-on-demand service provides 20 films a day on 50 channels.

u-direct and Front Row recently acquired the UK TV premiere of Oscar-winning movie Gladiator.

webTitle: C4 and ITN to pay libel damages

fields.headline: C4 and ITN to pay libel damages
fields.trailText: 9.15am: Channel 4, ITN and investigative journalist Duncan Campbell have agreed to pay a surgeon more than £900,000 in libel damages and costs.
fields.body:
Channel 4, ITN and investigative journalist Duncan Campbell have agreed to pay a surgeon more than £900,000 in libel damages and legal costs.

Mr Campbell and Channel 4 have agreed to pay consultant thoracic surgeon Joe Rahamim damages of £100,000 and ITN has agreed to pay him £75,000 in damages.

Legal costs of more than £750,000 incurred by Mr Rahamim, based at Derriford hospital in Plymouth, were also being paid by the defendants, according to the surgeon's solicitors, Peter Carter-Ruck and Partners.

The surgeon's counsel told the court that in July 1998, Channel 4 broadcast a report, produced by Mr Campbell, on its 7pm news, which "amounted to an unwarranted attack on Mr Rahamim".

Channel 4 had "viciously denigrated" Mr Rahamim who, since his arrival in Plymouth in 1979, had carried out well over 10,000 operations.

The broadcaster and Mr Campbell agreed to broadcast a retraction and apology on its 7pm news and undertook to the court not to repeat the allegations.

In a separate action, ITN also apologised for suggesting on its website Mr Rahamim was a "bogus doctor" and also regretted that the allegations had resurfaced in a programme, video and DVD entitled Great Frauds.

fields.headline: Tiscali clinches LineOne purchase
fields.trailText: LineOne, one of Britain's best known internet service providers, succumbed yesterday to a long-expected takeover, but at a fraction of its previous value.
fields.body:
LineOne, one of Britain's best known internet service providers, succumbed yesterday to a long-expected takeover, but at a fraction of its previous value.

Italian internet service provider Tiscali said it would pay €100m (£62.5m) in cash and shares for a business once tipped for a £1bn flotation.

LineOne, with 1.85m registered members, was jointly owned by British Telecommunications and United Business Media, and becomes the latest British dot.com to fall into foreign hands.

Last year Wanadoo, the France Télécom-backed internet firm, agreed to buy Freeserve, Britain's leading internet service provider.

Analysts have long predicted consolidation among the ISPs, arguing that while they struggle to make money only the best funded will survive.

Tiscali has said it will invest heavily in Britain and aims to turn LineOne into one of the three biggest domestic portals.

The British company has been on the block since the then United News & Media signalled its intention to quit the consumer arena and focus on business publications and media. BT is likely to use its share of the proceeds to pay off a fraction of its £30bn debts.

About €80m of the payment will be made up of Tiscali shares with the balance in cash.

 The US federal telecommunications commission yesterday agreed Deutsche Telekom's $26bn takeover of loss-making mobile operator Voicestream Wireless.

webTitle: Straw asks Europe to back asylum strategy

fields.headline: Straw asks Europe to back asylum strategy
fields.trailText: A push for a common European definition of who qualifies as a refugee was yesterday unveiled by the home secretary, raising fears that those under threat of rape or marital killings, those pursued by criminal gangs and other victims of "non-state persecution" will in future not be allowed asylum in Britain.
fields.body:
A push for a common European definition of who qualifies as a refugee was yesterday unveiled by the home secretary, raising fears that those under threat of rape or marital killings, those pursued by criminal gangs and other victims of "non-state persecution" will in future not be allowed asylum in Britain.

Jack Straw said yesterday the "mutual recognition" by European countries of the criteria of who qualified as a refugee, to be set out in an EU directive, was needed to tackle the problem of "asylum shopping" under which migrants tried one European country after another until their claim was recognised. The EU directive, backed by changes in UK law, would overturn rulings by British judges, who Mr Straw has attacked in the past for taking "an overliberal approach" to asylum cases.

The home secretary has also promised to set up more immigration arrest squads employing mobile electronic finger printing facilities and to increase the use of charter flights to step up the number of failed asylum seekers being deported from Britain.

The monthly asylum figures for March published yesterday showed applications, at 5,815, were 13% lower than 12 months ago, with most new claimants coming from Afghanistan, Somalia and Iraq. Home Office figures also showed the backlog of cases waiting for a decision had fallen to 36,390 - down from more than 101,000 in February last year. The proportion of claimants recognised as refugees or given special leave to stay in Britain last month was 25%, with a further 16% refused on technical "non-compliance" grounds.

Mr Straw said that 9,000 failed asylum seekers were deported in the past 12 months and others left voluntarily. He hoped the target of 30,000 removals over the next year would be met. Immigration officials admitted yesterday it was difficult to send failed asylum seekers back to countries such as Iraq as direct flights were not possible from British airports.

Three new immigration arrest teams are to be set up by this autumn in London to track down those who have failed to leave the country. The teams, which have the power to arrest failed asylum seekers without police officers present, will also have access to 150 new mobile fingerprint scanners. Five new x-ray scanners are to be installed in Calais to detect people hiding in lorries.

But it is the changes at a European level which are likely to have the greatest impact on the asylum system. Mr Straw acknowledged yesterday that some European countries operated narrower definitions of who qualified as a refugee than Britain.

He said: "There should be a level picture so we have similar definitions which apply across Europe. What I suspect is that under the EU directive we will have common standards. But I can't say whether ours will go up or down."

Refugee groups and immigration lawyers fear Mr Straw will use the directive to exclude people the courts in Britain have ruled should be given asylum. Jack Straw said yesterday the "mutual recognition" by European countries of the criteria of who qualified as a refugee, to be set out in an EU directive, was needed to tackle the problem of "asylum shopping" under which migrants tried one European country after another until their claim was recognised. The EU directive, backed by changes in UK law, would overturn rulings by British judges, who Mr Straw has attacked in the past for taking "an overliberal approach" to asylum cases. The home secretary has also promised to set up more immigration arrest squads employing mobile electronic finger printing facilities and to increase the use of charter flights to step up the number of failed asylum seekers being deported from Britain. fields.headline: Slaughter 'higher than Maff figures'
fields.standfirst: Special report: foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: The number of animals which may have to be slaughtered because of foot and mouth is far higher than ministers are saying, with the total approaching 3.7m, making it one of the world's worst epidemics numerically.
fields.body:
The number of animals which may have to be slaughtered because of foot and mouth is far higher than ministers are saying, with the total approaching 3.7m, making it one of the world's worst epidemics numerically.

Official Maff figures suggest 2.06m animals have been killed, with 178,000 awaiting slaughter, and the numbers falling every day. But this disguises the fact that more than 450,000 animals have already been slaughtered and 790,000 animals are still waiting to be killed under the intervention board's welfare scheme.

The figures do not take into account 250,000 animals which have been killed under a separate voluntary scheme but are not included in the main statistics.

Meanwhile, a group of more than 40 vets has written to the prime minister questioning the government's policy to cull all uninfected animals on contiguous farms.

David King, the government's chief scientific adviser, and Roy Anderson, from Imperial College, are both criticised for their lack of veterinary expertise. The letter states: "Neither of these men have any veterinary training... we are seeing a savage attack on what livestock remains in the north of England and south-west Scotland."

The number of animals due to be killed, according to Maff, is already more than five times greater than in 1967 when 433,987 animals were slaughtered. The ministry has also admitted that 5,725 farms have been or are due to be affected, more than twice the number in 1967.

The only other foot and mouth epidemic which has reached these proportions is believed to be the 1997-2000 outbreak in Taiwan when up to 4m pigs were killed or died.

New figures released by Maff also suggest that the daily average of animals disposed of in pits, rendered or burnt on pyres is actually declining despite a backlog of disposal cases.

Provisional figures for the week ending April 22 state that 32,000 animals were killed and 37,000 disposed of, compared with 61,000 and 56,000 respectively for the previous week.

A further crisis was developing yesterday in the Lake District where the national park has now had more than 24 outbreaks confirmed within its boundaries and 95 within two miles of it. Paul Tiplady, chief executive of the park said: "If we don't vaccinate in the next week it will be too late because the cattle are about to be brought out and once sheep and cattle mix, then vaccination will be impossible."
