webTitle: Surfing to victory on a wave of greasy blather

fields.headline: Surfing to victory on a wave of greasy blather
fields.trailText: I cannot remember seeing the prime minister so relaxed. He's like a marathon runner who, on entering the stadium after the first 26 miles, looks behind to see his nearest opponent not only falling down a manhole, but having his shoes catch fire.
fields.body:
I cannot remember seeing the prime minister so relaxed. He's like a marathon runner who, on entering the stadium after the first 26 miles, looks behind to see his nearest opponent not only falling down a manhole, but having his shoes catch fire, and a flock of angry crows tearing off his shorts and starting in on his generative organs. At this stage a certain complacency is bound to set in.

Take the moment when Julie Morgan, (Lickspittle, Cardiff N) asked: "What measures has my rt. hon. friend got in mind for continuing the drop in unemployment, which has already resulted in the lowest unemployment in Wales for 25 years?"

Her question tailed off with more stunning statistics, such as 70%, and at another point, even 90%, though by this time I was barely capable of staying awake long enough to write down either the figures or the reason why each one should make us rejoice on behalf of the people of Wales. (Now and again my job makes me feel like Bob Cratchit doing the accounts on Christmas Day, before Scrooge's change of heart.)

As it happened, throughout this slathering spume of sycophancy, Nicholas Soames kept up a running commentary. "Go on, try and answer that one, I'd like to see you try, come on, let's hear your answer..." He was being sarcastic, of course.

Normally Mr Blair would respond with some earnest line about how Tories jeer while the people of Britain are being ushered into a new Labour Elysium. Instead - and this is the mark of the high jumper who has just seen his chief rival's legs run over by a steamroller - he took time out to pause and to favour Mr Soames with a great big grin.

It was a significant moment. It implied a certain comity of interest, a coincidence of knowingness. That pause and that grin said, in effect: "Look, you and I are aware of what is going on. We know that I have to listen to that greasy blather, indeed I insist the whips demand it, rather in the way that King Canute wanted his courtiers to tell him the tide would not dare wet his feet, even though he and they knew perfectly well that it would.

"People like Julie Morgan," (the grin went on to imply) "will never amount to anything. William Hague will never amount to anything. They are spear-carriers, mere walk-ons in the great stage play of history. But I am prime minister and you are the Hon. Nicholas Soames, an office in itself far greater than those held by most of my cabinet." Or something along those lines.

Indeed, like so many men whose grip on power cannot be pried free, he is beginning to evince a certain contempt for the toadies and hangers-on who festoon his court. Mr Hague had spent a long time pointing out, reasonably enough, that the government has spent far more on advertising than on rescuing the tourism industry from foot and mouth. Mr Blair flipped him to one side by pointing out that his own tourism spokesman, Peter Ainsworth, had called the case of the slaughterman who may have caught the human version of the illness, "a massive setback to tourism".

"What we need is a little less of that and a little more helpful talk from you," he said.

Mr Hague had run out of time, and offered no response. At which point a man called Jeff Ennis from Barnsley, who is new to me, and who may only come into the House to keep warm, launched into an oleaginous spiel about how, thanks to Mr Blair's genius, the waiting list for hernia operations in Mexborough is now only three to four weeks. Tories groaned, but more importantly, the prime minister looked as if the "question" was scarcely worthy of his consideration.

fields.headline: Second-term Labour must be dull but worthy of voters
fields.standfirst:
There will be few whiffs of danger in the latest election manifesto

Special report: Labour party
fields.trailText: There will be few whiffs of danger in the latest election manifesto.
fields.body:
It is easy, I believe, to describe what the huge majority of people want from government. It's what they will be voting for at the election. They want to believe that ministers will deliver public services better in future than they have done hitherto. They want more and better schools, more and better hospitals, more and better policemen, more and better trains that can be better relied on to arrive on time. How ministers set about this is, for many people, a matter of indifference. What they want are results. Quite obviously they have decided that Labour will get closer to achieving some results in the next four years than the Tories have any chance of doing.

There's only one disadvantage to this programme. It sounds exceedingly boring. There's not a trace of glamour about it. The speeches it generates are of paralysing tedium. No whiff of danger disturbs the air, as the lists of claims and promises are trotted out. If there's a big idea here, perhaps still called the third way, it's so spacious that nobody can disagree with it. The politics of better public services creates few enemies. Even the Tory party, in this respect, is an inadequate enemy. It has chosen to mimic most Labour pledges, from more spending on health to increasing the minimum wage. So, on the issues people really care about, Mr Blair cannot rely on his opponents to generate the sparks that are absent from his own agenda.

This is at odds, however, with Blairism's image. The style isn't right. It's the politics of the roundhead not the cavalier. Blairite propaganda has always placed wearisome emphasis on novelty and excitement. All that terrible garbage, in the early years, about this young country of ours. All the deforming drama of the spin. All the double-claiming for single achievements, clothing repetition in bogus originality. Deep in the character of Mr Blair is an aversion to the political sobriety which is now, in fact, by far the most convincing message he could communicate to the country.

Thus, as the Labour election manifesto is poised before the presses, there's a fear that it lacks enough novelty. Policy wonks cast about for wheezes that will please the master's appetite for something different. Whatever they do or don't come up with, we can be sure the manifesto will be described as radical. "Radical", unlike "liberal", is a word that has retained its proximity to motherhood in new Labour's first term. It's the formulaic label every lefty, in fact just about every politician, wants to appropriate and define to suit himself. But it has been neutered. In the sense of meaning something alarmingly new, "radical", in the field of domestic social policy, is the last thing Labour needs to pretend it will be.

In the services that matter, people have had enough of novelty. The time has come to make old novelty work, at last. This is the theme running through The Blair Effect, edited by Anthony Seldon and published by Little Brown (£14.99), the indispensable new guide to what has happened so far, which shows what a long way there is to go before Britain becomes a much better country than it was four years ago. A thousand earnest quangos, ten thousand beavering committees, a million personal acts of service testify to Labour people's zealous reformist instincts. But many schools still turn out illiterates, and many hospitals continue to struggle against the tide of demand.

The manifesto therefore doesn't need to include any great surprises. For the most part, it just needs to make the right pledges to do better, and see to some kind of completion what Labour began to do already. In this sense, it needs more of the roundhead instincts of Gordon Brown than the cavalier febrility of Tony Blair, whose own long-termism is too often overlaid by the passion for short-term effect that has been the most disappointing weakness of his first four years. Nobody understands better than Brown that if a political thing is worth saying once, it must axiomatically be said 20 times. That would never do for an artist, and is a habit even a political commentator must try to avoid. For a politician, on the other hand, unembarrassed repetition often seems the only effective way to din his message into the public mind.

But the case against sudden originality, at this point in the Labour cycle, has another justification. It accords, I think, with the scepticism fair-minded voters retain about the possibilities of government and politics. The overriding demand is for mere competence, getting on and doing the intractable business that service delivery requires. Dull though they sound, therefore, some of the priorities flagged up for 2001-5 seem relevant to the moment. Reform of local government is one, the reshaping of Whitehall another. Not far behind is the sense that higher education is in urgent need of the reformer's hand. The fact that much of this is about structure and system, reliably the stuff of public narcolepsy, is a good sign not a bad one.

The next term won't send everyone to sleep. There will be important zones of passion where my apologia for dullness will not apply. They will enliven the election campaign. The argument about ethnic, and historical, and geographical, and psychological Britishness looks set to have a long and rancid life, though one which the manifestos, as distinct from some of the people, will handle circumspectly. Europe will dominate our politics for the next four years, whatever happens to and in the referendum, and nobody can pre tend that's an arid argument.

For the rest, though, I look to a considerable change of tone. Having crossed the river into a safe second term, Mr Blair should no longer feel so beholden to the demand for excitement. It's important not to lose momentum, but just as crucial to find a rhetoric that doesn't depend on reinventing bogus initiatives and claiming successes before they can be proved. The media, which have a large part in inventing a public thirst for novelty, will doubtless be the first to chide Blair for not supplying enough of it. I hope, in these engine rooms of state provision, that except for making good the multiple promises to spend a lot more money, he loftily ignores them. Going back to ground-zero for yet another rethink of primary healthcare is not the way to build credibility as a long-term reformer.

Some people say the test of Labour's manifesto is whether it outlines a less "cautious" second term than the first. Others note that it's rare for second terms to be more truly radical than first terms, though, as Seldon notes in his conclusion, Margaret Thatcher and Franklin Roosevelt offer counter-cases. Except for Europe, it seems to me, caution is not the issue. The vision of 1997 was already incautious, nothing less than the transformation of public service. It hasn't happened. What's now required is fulfilment. A plodding, worthy task, with barely a possibility of glitz.

webTitle: Blunkett keen to cast off 'hard' image

fields.headline: Blunkett keen to cast off 'hard' image
fields.standfirst:
Special report: Labour party
Guardian Unlimited Education
fields.trailText: David Blunkett, the education and employment secretary, is not normally a man for nostalgia, but on the eve of a widely expected promotion to the home secretaryship in a post-election reshuffle he is anxious to revisit his last four years.
fields.body:
David Blunkett, the education and employment secretary, is not normally a man for nostalgia, but on the eve of a widely expected promotion to the home secretaryship in a post-election reshuffle he is anxious to revisit his last four years to dispel the suggestion that he is an illiberal statist dragooning people into work.

It is a reputation he feels he does not deserve, and he denies outright that he had ever confided that if given the home secretaryship, he would make Jack Straw look like a liberal.

"I have never said that and I do not believe it.

"I am a rational balanced politician who in practice as leader of Sheffield council for seven years, and then in government has always balanced the freedom and liberty of the individual against social good of a rational, balanced social policy.

"My work on sex guidance in schools was highly liberal and highly socially responsible. There is now no one I know from either the libertarian or conservative wing of the party which is opposed to the sex and relationship guidance within schools."

Asked why he was seen by some as an authoritarian, he replies: "I don't go along with trends, I don't believe in gesture politics and my roots are in a working class community, and I hope will stay there."

In an indication that he is not quite the social conservative people claim, he says his concerns over an equal age of consent for gays have been largely set aside by amendments to legislation protecting those who are in a vulnerable position from people in a position of trust, such as residential care. He also insists he is not opposed to a debate on migration pointing out that he has done much to modernise the work permit system to encourage legitimate immigration.

Mr Blunkett is keen to ward off those who want to break up the Department of Education and Employment.

"The prime mInister will have to weigh up the pluses and minuses, but I hope in whatever he does he does not break the link between education, skills and employability."

Despite the achievements of the New Deal, including 1m extra jobs and 74.7% of working age in work, he admits there are still huge challenges ahead.

A hard core of unemployed - many of them on drugs, illiterate, on on incapacity benefit or lone parents - remain untouched by the New Deal.

He accepts there are still serious pockets of skill shortages especially for graduates in the public sector.

"We are now in a very buoyant labour market and our biggest challenge is to end the inequality in employment based on ethnicity, geography and class background. It is holding us back. We have to get into work people who historically have multiple social problems."

He cites as an example of new thinking a £40m programme aimed at hard core drug takers on the dole. Benefit will be withdrawn if the invidual refuses to go on a drug treatment programme.

"We will find someone a treatment clinic in one month instead of 12 months, and we will help that person stick with it, that is an enabling state."

He also praises the year-old employment action zones already securing twice as many job placements for the long term unemployed as trasitional schemes.

"Benefit is absolutely conditional and everyone is given a personal job account to help them with transport, a suit or training to get a job."

But he admits the raw figures - 280,000 young people off the dole, 60,000 long term unemployed through the new deal and into a job and 100,000 lone parents into a job - disguise a big problem of hidden unemployment.

fields.headline: Scotland's unfair share
fields.standfirst: Special report: Scottish parliament
fields.trailText: English regional devolution, which has suddenly gone to the top of Labour's agenda for the second term, is being powered by the perception that Scotland is a land of milk and honey awash with public subsidy. This idea needs qualification.
fields.body:
English regional devolution, which has suddenly gone to the top of Labour's agenda for the second term, is being powered by the perception that Scotland is a land of milk and honey awash with public subsidy. This idea needs qualification.

Scotland's population is falling, with net migration to England - hardly evidence of an economic hotspot. All its cities, except Edinburgh, are in decline. There is a chronic shortage of teachers, and parts of its health service are in crisis. Industrial unrest is disrupting its prisons.

Parts of modern Scotland are wealthy - particularly Edinburgh and Grampian. In Glasgow's West End, Edinburgh's New Town and the affluent dormitories the bourgeoisie sups its claret and plans its next foreign holiday. But take a walk in Glasgow, east of the High Street that some call the Berlin Wall, and you will see the pinched faces of poverty and endemic ill-health.

The Treasury's figures of per capita regional public expenditure also have to be qualified. Scotland's population of 5m is skewed in a large land mass, with many points of delivery for public services. These, inevitably, carry a higher unit cost. A mile of motorway thus costs much the same to build in England as in Scotland but its per capita cost will be much lower.

Even after such adjustments, most economists concede that Scotland does enjoy a historic advantage in public spending across a range which excludes defence. It was mostly entrenched during the Harold Wilson administrations when his secretary of state for Scotland, Willie Ross, shrewdly used the rising threat of nationalism to exact concessions from the Treasury.

Since then the Barnett formula, which shares out new public spending, has been adjusted to reduce Scotland's share as its population falls, both absolutely and as a proportion of the whole. Some economists, like David Bell at Stirling University, believe that a "Barnett squeeze" is beginning to bite on the Scottish grant. Others, like Arthur Midwinter at Strathclyde, argue that since Barnett affects only 6% of the total, Barnett is having hardly any effect at all.

But the growing campaign in the English regions has one very positive consequence. It is opening English minds to thoughts of federalism. Except in the north-east, regional awareness has been a feeble plant: English people tend to identify with their town, their village or their county. Once, during the 80s, a colleague and I from the Glasgow Herald interviewed Margaret Thatcher in Downing Street: as we did so that arch Yorkshire nationalist Bernard Ingham, her press secretary, prowled about at the back of the room muttering about "whingeing Scots".

The West Lothian question is now a reality. As Peter Preston wrote hyperbolically on Monday, there are 72 Scottish MPs at Westminster with nothing to do, marginalised at home by press and public alike. Yet the obvious solution - federalism - is still largely resisted. For a start, it would mean having a written constitution. And then we would be forced formally to consider the position of the monarchy.

But there is an even greater emotional difficulty. English politicians and theorists have always taken the view that Westminster is the English parliament continuing, that it absorbed the Scottish Parliament in 1707. The Scots view, expressedin Lord Cooper's judgment of 1952, is that the Treaty of Union is an inalienable constitutional document in which Scottish sovereignty is vested; certain parts, he held, could not be altered by Westminster.

The English view has mostly prevailed. This has made it difficult for the English to consider the possibility that there should be a UK legislature with a subordinate chamber for England to sit alongside the Scottish parliament and the assemblies in Wales and Northern Ireland. The convention proposed by Tam Dalyell and others - that Scots MPs should withdraw from English business - is no answer since English decisions, under the formula, would have an impact on the Scottish grant.

The resentments have to be addressed sooner or later. But swingeing cuts in Scottish and Welsh public expenditures should be resisted. If the aim is simple equity, then that could be achieved by rounding up as well as down. The devolution settlement requires that any change should be by negotiation. With mutual goodwill an adjustment could be managed without too much disruption.

But if the changes were punitive and led to a decline in the quality of Scottish or Welsh public services, then there could be only one outcome. Scotland would be pushed into the hands of the nationalists and British statecraft would have failed. Perhaps, now that we are all in Europe, it has had its day anyway.

 Arnold Kemp is a former editor of the Glasgow Herald

fields.headline: Diary
fields.trailText: Six weeks before the election, current Turncoat of Turncoats excitement concerns a sudden surge in votes for Home Office dandy Paul Boateng, whose odds Diary pundit Steptoe has slashed after sustained support (we are of course analysing the voting patterns for evidence of inside knowledge)
fields.body:
 Six weeks before the election, current Turncoat of Turncoats excitement concerns a sudden surge in votes for Home Office dandy Paul Boateng, whose odds Diary pundit Steptoe has slashed after sustained support (we are of course analysing the voting patterns for evidence of inside knowledge).

Steptoe now has Paul and Peter Hain as 7-2 joint third favourites behind market leaders Robin Cook at 5-2 and Bomber Short at 11-4. Gus Macdonald has drifted to 10-1. Voting will close at noon 10 days before polling day. This will give our seamstress time to customise all three coats - full size for the champ, miniatures for runners-up - and to find volunteers to present them to the lucky trio as they arrive to vote on June 7.

We offer £100 each to these volunteers, who must work in pairs - one to present the coat, the other to take the pictures. Medical expenses and legal costs will not be reimbursed.

 Anyone tempted by Paul but shy of taking the plunge may find the picture below useful. It was taken at a Christmas party in 1987 and printed originally in the News of the World. Paul is dressed as a lewd law lord at a time soon after he came to prominence as a Livingstone loyalist at the GLC. Happy days. If you wish to vote for Paul or anyone else, make your selection by email to Oofy Wegg-Prosser's politics web site, at theguardian.com/turncoats.

 Alan Greenspan has a British rival. Erstwhile Kelvin MacKenzie sidekick, Nick Ferrari, introduced a Rich List debate on Radio 5 Live on Sunday night thus: "There are more millionaires and billionaires in Britain than ever... but does this mean there is no such thing as poverty any more?" My colleague Marina Hyde rings for a chat. "Where is this going?" asks Nick. Well, would you see the US as a society that has wiped out poverty by having loads of millionaires? "Er, no, it hasn't. But some people would say..." Let's cut to the chase. Would you consider becoming Diary economist, so we can consult you about macro-economic trends when important indicators are published? "Right," says Nick. "OK." Good show.

 Nick joins a team of experts including the Rev Steve Chalke, who found a moment away from tending his flock on Tuesday to engage in yet another profound Radio 5 debate about "yob culture". The Diary vicar insisted we must rebuild society as a whole - but it wasn't all about avoiding meaningless generality. Peter Hitchens was there too. Is there no one out there who can offer this man some help?

 Ferocious PR Valerie Leon calls with news that on Sunday at Pinewood Studios the British Comedy Society will unveil plaques to Carry On actors Peter Butterworth, Terry Scott, Bernard Bresslaw and Kenneth Connor. Indeed, Val, who also faxes about a series of opera lectures in May at a restaurant called Putney Bridge, will be unveiling Terry herself (oooh err). Although best known to readers for her sure-fingered erection of Charles Hawtrey's tent in Carry On Camping, she appeared with Scott in Up The Jungle. We wish her well with that and with the lectures (020-8994 6197 for details), and trust this will guarantee the usual four to six weeks of relative peace.

 A commuter shopping at WH Smith's in Marylebone station reports that staff are stacking the new National Rail Timetable on the shelves for popular fiction. It is currently being displayed alongside Danielle Steel's The Wedding.

fields.headline: Rebuff to MPs on weapons
fields.trailText: Stephen Byers, the trade and industry secretary, last night refused to accept parliament's right to scrutinise major arms exports before they are agreed - a key demand of four Commons committees.
fields.body:
Stephen Byers, the trade and industry secretary, last night refused to accept parliament's right to scrutinise major arms exports before they are agreed - a key demand of four Commons committees.

He refused to do so during evidence on the government's draft export control and non-proliferation bill.

Pressed to say whether ministers at least had an open mind on the issue of prior scrutiny, Mr Byers said only that they had not reached a decision. "Many issues" were involved, he said. Ministers in the past have argued that prior scrutiny by MPs would lead to damaging delays and breach necessary confidentiality.

The UK Working Group on Arms pointed to other gaps in the bill in evidence to the Commons defence, foreign affairs, trade and industry, and international development committees. Export controls should cover all British passport holders even if they were engaged in arms brokering and trafficking wholly on foreign soil, they told the MPs.

webTitle: Cautious Canada underwhelmed by Charles's visit

fields.headline: Cautious Canada underwhelmed by Charles's visit
fields.standfirst:
Royal feet doused in disinfectant at airport but prince spared farm and sandwich questions

Special report: foot and mouth
fields.trailText: The Prince of Wales arrived in Canada yesterday to the traditional greeting his mother's largest dominion reserves for all visitors arriving from unclean lands such as Europe. Before he was even allowed to step on to the red carpet at Ottawa airport he had to place his well-shod feet on a mat in a tray of detergent to ensure no trace of foot and mouth disease came with him.
fields.body:
The Prince of Wales arrived in Canada yesterday to the traditional greeting his mother's largest dominion reserves for all visitors arriving from unclean lands such as Europe. Before he was even allowed to step on to the red carpet at Ottawa airport he had to place his well-shod feet on a mat in a tray of detergent to ensure no trace of foot and mouth disease came with him.

The prince was spared the routine questioning at immigration control about whether he had been on a farm in the past fortnight or was carrying any sandwiches.

Buckingham Palace had given prior assurances to authorities that the prince had not stepped off the Balmoral estate for the past two weeks and that it is remote from the nearest outbreak of the disease.

A spokeswoman for St James's Palace assured the Canadian media: "The prince accepts that the precautions are of the utmost importance and the clothes of all his party have been properly laundered, shoes disinfected and meat products have not been carried on board his aircraft. There have been no farm visits."

Members of the royal entourage including valet, equerry, press officer and security staff were similarly disinfected on arrival.

Canada, like the United States, has been shown a raft of pictures of burning cows in Britain in recent weeks, though the country's leading newspaper, the Globe and Mail, carried a reassuring headline in its sports section yesterday: "Golfers shouldn't forgo trips to Britain."

Its golf correspondent has apparently played all the top courses in the past 10 days without seeing a single charred corpse.

The prince went on a walkabout in central Ottawa and laid a wreath at the tomb of the unknown Canadian soldier, accompanied by Canada's prime minister, Jean Chrétien.

He had been due to meet one of the last Canadian survivors of the battle of Vimy Ridge in the first world war but Paul Metivier, now well over 100 years old, was too frail to attend and a second world war D-Day veteran Ernest-Adolphe Cote, a mere 87, stood in for him.

The prince, who also has Canadian citizenship, is the guest of the federal and regional governments, though his exact status is open to question. "I didn't realise we had a throne," said one of the Canadian journalists covering the trip.

The visit, expected to cost about £125,000, is being paid for by the Canadians. While on Canadian soil, the prince, like his mother, acts "on advice" from Canadian ministers.

Over the next five days, Prince Charles will visit the open prairies of Saskatchewan and meet farmers - though not on their farms - to discuss their opposition to genetically modified crops. He will also be heading north to the Yukon territory, an area which has rarely seen a royal.

It is no coincidence that the two regions are among the most pro-monarchist in Canada. No member of the royal family has set foot in separatist French Quebec for many years.

The prince has had some of his arrangements altered. Hotel staff are on strike for better pay in Saskatchewan and his entourage are having to change their accommodation so that he is not too inconvenienced.

The visit has received down-played coverage so far. The Globe and Mail has noticed that what it calls the royal rat pack of correspondents from Britain is smaller than usual and only the local Ottawa Citizen has welcomed him in a downpage editorial saying: "Prince Charles gets little respect or attention because he is not sexy or scandalous and, with a few lamentable exceptions, he does not make a fool of himself. Who among us can say more?"

Otherwise the Canadian press is full of reports about the leader of the country's Conservative opposition, Stockwell Day.

Mr Day is under fire from his own party and being pressured to step down for providing weak leadership, making a fool of himself with ill-judged comments and failing to make electoral headway. The prince must feel almost as if he is at home.

fields.headline: GPs to shut surgeries in row over conditions
fields.standfirst:
General practitioners say increased paperwork, more patients and new tasks are making their lives intolerable

Related story: a day in the lives of family doctors
fields.trailText: On May 1, many GP practices across the country will close their doors to all but emergency cases in a display of anger unprecedented in recent years. In a few weeks' time, their union, the British Medical Association, will ballot all GPs on a mass resignation from the NHS.
fields.body:
On May 1, many GP practices across the country will close their doors to all but emergency cases in a display of anger unprecedented in recent years. In a few weeks' time, their union, the British Medical Association, will ballot all GPs on a mass resignation from the NHS.

This is not a dispute about pay. General practitioners, who have been heaped with praise by Tony Blair and described as the vanguard of the government's NHS revolution, say they are working under intolerable conditions. They do not reject Mr Blair's grand ideas for the NHS - many of the reforms now taking place are good for patients and have been welcomed. But they say that they are being loaded down with new tasks, more patients and vast amounts of paperwork - and that shortages of GPs and nurses in the UK are making things much worse.

"Patient interests are being jeopardised," said Michael Pimm, a GP in Weston-super-Mare, "because you can't get a quart into a pint pot. I had surgery this afternoon. I have five minute appointments because there simply isn't the time for more. I'd love to appoint another doctor... Patients are better informed. "You can't just pat them on the head and say take the green medicine, you'll be fine," said Gareth Richardson, a Suffolk GP. "They want explanations. But the money that was earmarked for fighting coronary heart disease is going into coronary bypass grafts and chest pain clinics run by hospitals and not the extra nurses and drugs that GPs feel they need to carry out their part of the plan.

People are being discharged from hospital earlier than they used to be, which is good, say GPs, but they need a higher level of care once they get home. GPs are supposed to be developing services for post-natal depression and protocols for the care of the elderly. There are audits to be done and the training of GP recruits. And now all patients are supposed to be seen by their GP within 48 hours, according to the National Plan.

Some GP practices have closed their lists, but they cannot refuse to take more patients if the health authority instructs them to.

"I enjoy being a GP and my patients are always very grateful," said Dr Taggart. "I just feel I could do a better job for them if I had more resources and more time to do it."

The BMA is negotiating a new contract for GPs with the government, but it is taking a long time. The threat of mass resignations by April next year if the deal is not done is designed to concentrate minds.

The government is attempting to streamline GP practices, cutting out bureaucracy and spreading the load to nurses and ancillary workers. Much of their work is too complex to devolve, he says, and telephone consultations do not go down well with patients who are being told they should be able to walk in and see their GP within 48 hours.

webTitle: Mayor backs IT drive for schools

fields.headline: Mayor turns up bearing PCs
fields.standfirst:
Special report: Livingstone's London
Guardian Unlimited Education
fields.trailText: The mayor of London, Ken Livingstone, is donating his lucky campaign computer, together with thousands of PCs from businesses, to help schoolchildren learn information technology and address skills shortages in the capital.
fields.body:
The mayor of London, Ken Livingstone, is donating his lucky campaign computer, together with thousands of PCs from businesses, to help schoolchildren learn information technology and address skills shortages in the capital.

Mr Livingstone launched the Access IT! project yesterday at Friars primary school in Southwark, south London, with the three year aim of recycling 100,000 PCs from companies that are upgrading their equipment, and placing them in London schools at a 10th of a new computer's cost.

"Giving children the chance they need to develop computer skills will... benefit London as a whole," he said

Organising the campaign is Tools for Schools, supported by the Guardian, which hopes to provide a PC for every classroom desk. It has already supplied 500 schools nationally with 10,000 PCs at £95 each.

It has teamed up with London First, a consortium of 300 businesses, to encourage donations and drop costs to £75 a computer for London schools.

Gerry Acher, a partner at the consultancy firm KPMG in London and a member of London First, wants businesses around the country to follow suit. "It costs £800 for a computer, and they are worth £50 after three years," he said. "A lot of people just scrap them.

To help Access IT! on its way, Mr Livingstone helped to unload 11 refurbished Pentium computers at Friars, an £825 giveaway that has more than tripled its IT resources.

Its IT teacher, Martin Latimer, said: "You don't have to enthuse children about a subject if it's on a computer."

Pupils were opening the boxes as if they were Christmas presents. Dolapo Bamigbade, 10, said: "Mostly there's squabbles about who is going to log on. Now there won't be."

The headteacher, Janet Summers, said: "This frees most of our IT budget for spending on other items, such as educational software."

webTitle: Leader: Mr Milburn must prove his conversion

fields.headline: NHS abandons Stalinism
fields.standfirst: Mr Milburn must prove his conversion
fields.trailText: Many people within the health service would have been unimpressed by our front-page splash yesterday on the radical restructuring of the NHS planned by Labour in a second term. For good reason.
fields.body:
Many people within the health service would have been unimpressed by our front-page splash yesterday on the radical restructuring of the NHS planned by Labour in a second term. For good reason. Management layers have been added to and withdrawn from the health service at regular intervals over its 50 years. It starts with three layers, invents a fourth, then squeezes out one of the middle tiers. "Tears over tiers" is nothing new in the NHS. Virginia Bottomley abolished regional health authorities and then had to reinvent them. Keith Joseph introduced four tiers, which were later reduced to three by abolishing district management teams. Now Labour is to restore the district with its 400 primary care trusts, but reduce health authorities from 99 to 30. One is tempted to remind Labour of one its 1997 mantras: standards not structures.

But something much more important happened yesterday. No, not the well-leaked and almost obligatory cull of bureaucrats. This was quite specious. The managers released by the cull will be needed to run the new primary care trusts. The idea that these will be run by GPs and nurses is a nonsense. What was important at the launch of the government's modernisation agency was the unequivocal message from the health secretary that the time had now come to end the centralised control of the NHS. This was no throwaway line. He returned to it time after time. The cries for help from medics and managers - noted in these columns earlier this week - have not just been taken seriously but addressed. The health secretary set out cogent reasons why Labour had had to be centralist in its first term. He acknowledged the fatigue and cynicism that two decades of chop and change generated. He sensibly expressed sympathy for the pressure under which staff were currently operating. But then he showed them the sunny uplands. Reform was as much in the interests of NHS staff as patients. Work would become more rewarding. Money and decision-taking would be devolved to the front line. It would not be Labour's 10-year plan but the 1m NHS employees'. They would be the people who decided how the reforms would be delivered locally.

Of course there are caveats. What happens to public health? Officials reply that many new primary care trusts will be coterminous with unitary authorities, allowing a coordinated approach. What happens to social service departments under the new regional directors for health and social care? Officials say these posts are purely concerned with joining up the department's internal, not external, divisions. Most important of all, will Alan Milburn change his behaviour? Is it a true conversion? No health boss has been more Stalinist. Yet he has stripped himself of power: withdrawing from appointing 3,000 NHS chairs and non-executive directors; setting up an independent panel to resolve local disputes over service changes; abolishing regional offices. This last was the most important - plus yesterday's unequivocal speech.

Dr Livingstone says a national shortage means it is no easier to recruit nurses than GPs, and many who might have been interested have taken jobs instead with the nurse-led telephone helpline NHS Direct or the government's walk-in clinics. These are two of the high-profile initiatives that the government has said will relieve GPs' pressures. That is not what GPs say is happening. "We haven't noticed a lot of difference," said Nigel Watson, a GP in New Milton in the New Forest, "because a lot of people are being told to go and see a GP." GPs say that more people than ever are coming to see them, encouraged by the pronouncements of government that the NHS must be more consumerist. "There is increasing pressure from patients," said Chris Taggart, a GP in Coventry. "Quite reasonably they want to see their doctor and perhaps quicker than they did before." Patients are better informed. "You can't just pat them on the head and say take the green medicine, you'll be fine," said Gareth Richardson, a Suffolk GP. "They want explanations. They want longer with their doctor. That's all to the good, but I book to spend 10 minutes with each patient and it often over-runs." Not only are more people turning up, but GPs are now being asked to go out and find them. One of the big shifts in healthcare policy taking place is towards prevention. Frameworks for the treatment of diseases such as diabetes, coronary heart disease and mental health require GPs to call in patients for checks and run special clinics, some of which used to be done by hospitals in the past. But the money that was earmarked for fighting coronary heart disease is going into coronary bypass grafts and chest pain clinics run by hospitals and not the extra nurses and drugs that GPs feel they need to carry out their part of the plan. People are being discharged from hospital earlier than they used to be, which is good, say GPs, but they need a higher level of care once they get home. GPs are supposed to be developing services for post-natal depression and protocols for the care of the elderly. There are audits to be done and the training of GP recruits. And now all patients are supposed to be seen by their GP within 48 hours, according to the National Plan. "Not everybody who says they want to see a doctor needs to see a doctor," says Bob Button, a GP representative of the BMA in Wessex. "If you have a wart on your toe, it doesn't matter when you see the doctor." He says the increasing workload, the paperwork and the lack of help has drastically eroded the morale of GPs. "When I first qualified 40 years ago, I was resentful of the fact I had to retire at 70. Now doctors are saying quite frankly as soon as I get to 50, I'm out. We can't afford to have people who are so expensive to train leaving the NHS." Suicide The government has offered an extra £10,000 to GPs who will stay on until they are 65. But Dr Button said: "If they are willing to forgo their salary, they won't change their minds for an extra £10,000 over five years. The average doctor is looking to get out as soon as he can. I have one who is retiring at 42 and another who is being medically retired. He has gone for the alcohol because it was the only thing that gave him any peace at night. "In the past 18 months, two GPs in the area have committed suicide. There are doctors who are so desperate they cannot face going to surgery any more because it gives them the shakes." The BMA says the country is short of 10,000 GPs. The government has promised 2,000 more by 2004, but only 900 of those, the BMA argues, are additional to those already in training. Some GP practices have closed their lists, but they cannot refuse to take more patients if the health authority instructs them to. Most GPs talk of frustration and exhaustion rather than any opposition to what the modernisation plans are trying to achieve. "I enjoy being a GP and my patients are always very grateful," said Dr Taggart. "I just feel I could do a better job for them if I had more resources and more time to do it." The BMA is negotiating a new contract for GPs with the government, but it is taking a long time. The threat of mass resignations by April next year if the deal is not done is designed to concentrate minds. A Department of Health spokeswoman said: "Money is flowing in. There are projects to reduce bureaucracy going on. We are aware of the stresses, however we do have complete faith in primary care. It was never set out in the National Plan that we expect GPs to do all this just by working harder. We were disappointed that the BMA wants to ballot GPs." The government is attempting to streamline GP practices, cutting out bureaucracy and spreading the load to nurses and ancillary workers. But Hamish Meldrum, joint deputy chairman of the BMA's GPs committee, says: "Most of the initiatives that are supposed to make our lives easier have added to our work." Much of their work is too complex to devolve, he says, and telephone consultations do not go down well with patients who are being told they should be able to walk in and see their GP within 48 hours. At the heart of some GPs' discontent is their sense of being diverted from their primary interest of treating the sick. Lester Russell, the 42 year-old Portsmouth GP who resigned, says he went because it has become "sweatshop medicine for the doctor and production line medicine for the patient". There are no easy answers, and certainly no quick ones - a GP takes nine years to train.  NHS doctors yesterday welcomed government plans to slice out layers of bu reaucracy from the health service and shift power and cash to frontline staff but doubted whether the decentralisation scheme would release the promised extra £100m for patient care. Ian Bogle, chairman of the British Medical Association, said frontline staff knew where the money should best be spent, but warned that anything that took doctors away from patient care would increase their already heavy workload.

webTitle: Email is double Dutch to UK firms

fields.headline: Email is double Dutch to UK firms
fields.standfirst: More internet news
fields.trailText: Only 8% of British companies are able to respond correctly to foreign language emails according to a new survey. By Julia Snoddy.
fields.body:
Only 8% of British companies are able to respond correctly to foreign language emails, and significant business is being lost as a result, according to a new survey.

British companies performed much worse than French or German firms but better than American ones when 247 test emails were sent in different languages. Australian companies came bottom of the league with a zero score.

More than 90% of the world's largest companies were unable to respond correctly to foreign language emails, according to the report published yesterday by Worldlingo, an online translation company.

Companies fared particularly badly with Japanese, probably because their computer systems could not recognise Japanese characters.

Many companies did not even realise they were receiving a foreign message and responded in English that the email was corrupted. Others asked for the email to be sent again in English and nearly 69% did not respond at all.

Companies surveyed included Disney, which would answer only in English, AstraZeneca, Preussag Group and Kmart.

The survey was used to publicise Worldlingo's new software system designed to translate emails into 10 languages.

Worldlingo, which aims to be profitable by the end of 2001, boasts that it blends machine translation with human input.

fields.headline: Sir Christopher quits for BT
fields.trailText: 8.30am: Sir Christopher Bland is quitting as chairman of the BBC after five years to become chairman of British Telecom, writes Lisa O'Carroll
fields.body:
The BBC chairman, Sir Christopher Bland, is quitting the corporation after five years to become chairman of beleaguered British Telecom.

He succeeds Sir Iain Vallance, who is succumbing to mounting shareholder pressure and quitting after a 35-year-career at the company.

It is hoped that Sir Christopher, who once headed up the National Freight Corporation, now known as Exel, will turn the company's fortunes around.

Sir Christopher will replace Sir Iain on May 1, although the latter is to stay on as "president emeritus" until July 2002. The outgoing chairman will not take a seat on BT's board.

Sir Iain, who has been chairman of BT for 12 years, has been criticised in recent months as the company's debt mounted and its stock price plummeted.

But today he denied he was leaving under pressure.

"For some time now I have felt it right that I should stand down once we could find an able successor," he said.

"BT is an excellent company operating in a highly competitive sector," said Sir Christopher.

"I look forward to chairing the board through the next challenging and exciting period."

Sir Christopher planned to remain in his BBC job until the broadcasting company found a new chairman, the BBC reported.

His departure will be a blow to the BBC director-general, Greg Dyke. The pair had a close working relationship originally forged at London Weekend Television during the 1980s when Sir Christopher was chairman of the ITV company and Mr Dyke was managing director.

Today Sir Christopher denied there would be any conflict of interest in continuing to be chairman of the BBC and BT.

"The independence of the BBC, its editorial independence, is sacrosanct," he said on Radio 4's Today programme.

He told the BBC interviewer: "If I have as little influence on stories about BT as I have had about the BBC I am very happy about that."

Downing Street paid tribute to Sir Christopher's achievements as BBC chairman.

A spokeswoman for No 10 said: "Sir Christopher Bland has been a very fine chairman of the BBC and will no doubt make a huge contribution to BT when he takes over as chairman.

"The government was informed in advance and was pleased to hear he had agreed to stay on at the BBC until a successor has been found."

webTitle: ITV's digital rebranding is a switch-off

fields.headline: ITV's digital rebranding is a switch-off
fields.trailText: Carlton and Granada have failed to convince the City that their overhaul of ONdigital would let it compete with BSkyB. By David Teather.
fields.body:
Carlton Communications and Granada yesterday failed to convince the City that their overhaul of the pay-television business, ONdigital, would give it sufficient muscle to compete with the digital offering from BSkyB.

The two companies, which dominate the ITV network, confirmed plans to rename the struggling ONdigital operation ITV Digital in the hope of exploiting the brand strength of Britain's most popular television channel.

They also confirmed that ONdigital boss Stuart Prebble would take the job of ITV chief executive and announced the planned launch of premium sports channel ITV Sport and website operation ITV.com.

Conscious of shareholders' growing concerns over the level of investment in ONdigital, Carlton and Granada said they would cap the funding to break even at £1.1bn, slightly lower than previous estimates of £1.2bn. They have so far spent £700m between them.

Growth targets have fallen, however. ONdigital is now forecast to reach just 1.7m subscribers by 2003-4 against previous targets of 2m by the end of next year. But they said break even would now come at 1.7m instead of the earlier target. "Strategically it's the right thing to do - to bring the three main businesses under one brand. But that has done nothing to calm our fears for the long-term future of ONdigital," said Kingsley Wilson at Investec Henderson Crosthwaite. "This feels like the last throw of the die."

Shares in Carlton fell 16.5p to 379.5p while Granada closed 8p lower at 178p.

Mr Wilson said he was concerned about hidden, continuing costs such as sports right acquisitions and "churn" levels, which have now reached 22%. ONdigital added 75,000 homes in the first three months of the year, taking its subscriber base to 1.09m subscribers. There are no plans to end set-top box subsidies, Mr Prebble said.

The companies expect to make savings of £20m a year from aligning joint assets under a single management. Mr Prebble will retain control of ITV Digital as well as the free-to-air channels and ITV.com.

The closer integration of Carlton and Granada has already been given approval by regulators. Gerry Murphy, Carlton's chief executive, said: "Only six months ago Carlton and Granada working together would have been considered a contradiction. But we have proven the cynics wrong."

fields.headline: Children to share £1bn Labour giveaway
fields.trailText: Labour will today unveil its "big idea" for the second term when it publishes a £1bn plan to set up trust funds for every child, which could grow to between £5,000 and £7,000 by the time the individual reaches 18 years old.
fields.body:
Labour will today unveil its "big idea" for the second term when it publishes a £1bn plan to set up trust funds for every child, which could grow to between £5,000 and £7,000 by the time the individual reaches 18 years old.

The initial state dowry will be worth between £300 and £500 depending on the family income. It will be topped up by sums of £50-£100 three times as the child grows up.

The move is billed as a drive to fight child poverty and provide incentives to save. The shift will also signal that the government is no longer simply concerned with addressing income inequality, but also the distribution of assets.

David Blunkett, the education and employment secretary, in an interview with the Guardian yesterday, said: "Kids who grow up in a household where no one is working or has any savings end up with very dangerous role models. It has knock-on effect for their own performance in schools and in work, so we are trying to break that cycle. It is about self-help."

At the launch of the scheme today, the Chancellor Gordon Brown will say: "To ensure that every child has the best possible start in life, we plan not only to improve the weekly incomes on which a child is reared but to make it possible for them to own and value wealth."

The aim, he will add, is "to open up assets to all" and remove a further 1m children from poverty by 2004.

"A nation at work should also be a nation with wealth and, having created the opportunity for work and for incomes, now we must ensure that people have the security of a base of wealth behind them."

The initial cash dowry - placed in individual child trust funds - will be topped up by government as the child starts school at five, changes to secondary school at 11, and then for a third time at 16.

Each government top-up will be worth between £50 and £100 depending on the income of the parents. No tax will be imposed on the savings and no benefit entitlements withdrawn. Parents, grandparents and family will be encouraged to contribute to the tax-free trust fund.

Ministers also plan to set up a new "savings gateway" for low earning adults in which the government will match the cashed saved by each individual pound for pound up to a maximum of £1,800 saved.

The money will have to be invested for a minimum of three years and then can either be cashed, placed in a child trust fund, a pension fund or reinvested in an Isa.

The consultation paper to be issued at today's press conference is not expected to limit how the income from the child trust fund is eventually spent. Ministers would like the cash to be spent solely on individual development - for example, training, buying a home, setting up a business and helping to fund further education.

In practice ministers fear it would be impossible to police such limits effectively. How ever, they still believe the proposals will encourage self-reliance, forward planning and a habit of saving.

Supporters of the proposals - bound to be dismissed by the Tories as a gimmick - claim it fills a gaping hole in Labour thinking since it addresses the root causes of poverty, rather than the consequences.

The child trust funds would not just be set up for those children born after the measure comes into law, but also for those reaching the ages at which subsequent contributions are triggered. Currently 750,000 babies are born a year.

The two-pronged proposals drawon two years of analysis inside the Treasury, the Department for Education and Employment and the leftwing think-tank, the IPPR.

Using the National Child Development Study, Mr Blunkett's department found a clear link between family asset holding and the child's subsequent life chances.

Polling carried out for the IPPR found some distrust of the idea of capital endowment and matched savings. Some saw it "as too good to be true and that somewhere along the line individuals would pay, probably through future restrictions of government provision".

But government research shows that seven out of ten lone parents have no savings while half of all families on low or middle incomes with three children have no savings. The proportion of people without any financial assets has also doubled between 1979 and 1997 from 5% to 10 %.

In Mr Blunkett's view this in part reflects the collapse of traditional working class savings vehicles such as mutual societies, christmas clubs or post office savings accounts.

In his interview Mr Blunkett also admitted the government had to do more to bring the hardcore unemployed into work and said that among the challenges ahead were narrowing the employment gap in run-down areas and preventing any further rise in the number of people claiming incapacity benefit.

What you could get

Child trust funds

At birth: £300-500 (depending on family income)

At age 5: £50-100

At age 11: £50-100

At age 16: £50-100

Maximum total: £800*

*Could be worth £5,000-£7,000 by age 18

Savings gateway for low earning adults

Government will match pound for pound up to £1,800 saved. Money must be invested for three years, then placed in child trust fund, pension fund or an individual savings account.

webTitle: Lowe Lintas swoops for Henley Centre boss

fields.headline: Lowe Lintas swoops for Henley Centre boss
fields.trailText: 8.30am: Lowe Lintas has poached the head of the influential marketing consultancy to be its new UK chief executive, writes Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
Lowe Lintas has poached the head of the influential marketing consultancy The Henley Centre to be its new UK chief executive.

Paul Edwards, chairman and chief executive of the Henley Centre, replaces Paul Hammersley who is leaving to head up the agency's New York office.

The move marks a return to advertising for Mr Edwards, who was head of planning at the agency in a previous incarnation, Still Price Lintas, in the early 1990s. He has also worked for Bartle Bogle Hegarty and Young & Rubicam.

"Paul is a friend and ex-colleague and I can say with absolute certainty that his unique combnation of skills and experience will be of immense benefit to us," said Tim Lindsay, president of Lowe Lintas Europe.

Mr Edwards added: "The opportunity of working with such quality people across such a wide range of disciplines was too good to resist."

fields.headline: Branson to sponsor Sun's soccer heroes
fields.trailText: 8.30am: Richard Branson is sponsor the Sun's cartoon strip football team, Warbury Town, reports Julia Day.
fields.body:
Richard Branson is just about to sign one of the most enterprising deals of his career - sponsorship of the Sun's cartoon strip football team, Warbury Town.

The Virgin Mobile brand name is to be emblazoned on the shirts of the Warbury Town players in the newspaper's daily cartoon, Striker.

The mobile phone network will sponsor the cartoon for a year beginning on Monday April 30.

The sponsorship is being written in to the Striker storyline.

Mr Branson had a cameo role in the cartoon himself this week, meeting Warbury's Town's chairman, Fat Eric, to talk about sponsoring the club.

The deal will be signed in Saturday's edition and Mr Branson will continue to make occasional appearances in the cartoon.

Virgin Mobile and the Sun are to promote the sponsorship by selling Warbury Town football kits, merchandise and Striker-branded mobile phones to the paper's readers.

Text messaging competitions, such as "Guess the football result", will run later in the year.

The deal is being approached like a real football club sponsorship, but as a spokesman for Virgin Mobile said, it is costing significantly less than Vodafone's £30m sponsorship of Manchester United.

He added that Striker attracts 3.9m readers.

Striker is also being relaunched on Monday with new 3D-like illustrations and will take up three quarters of the page rather than the one third of a pages space it currently covers.

fields.headline: Buckley joins Sunday Mirror
fields.trailText:
8.30am: The paper has lured Nick Buckley from the Mail on Sunday to be its assistant editor, news, writes Jessica Hodgson.
25.04.2001: PCC backs complaint against Sunday Mirror
18.04.2001: Kelly expected to replace Weaver
12.04.2001: Tina weaves her way to the top
12.04.2001: Myler quits as Sunday Mirror editor
fields.body:
Nick Buckley has been appointed assistant editor, news, of the Sunday Mirror, prompting further speculation of a reshuffle under the paper's new editor, Tina Weaver.

Mr Buckley joins from the Mail on Sunday, where he was deputy news editor.

His appointment, the first under Ms Weaver, will raise a question mark over the future of John McShane, the Sunday Mirror's head of news.

webTitle: Women: Celebrity mags and American women

fields.headline: Stars in their eyes
fields.standfirst:
What do the new celebrity mags say about American women? Sharon Krum reports

MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: What do the new celebrity mags say about American women? Sharon Krum reports.
fields.body:
Orgasms. That single word was once the answer to the following question. What does the modern American woman want to read about in her magazines? But that was then, in the glory days of the 80s and 90s, when feminism stormed the workplace barricades and women demanded their piece of the action, bedroom included. Naturally, women's magazines, long a mirror to women's lives and a window to their aspirations, followed suit.

"When I first began editing women's magazines, there was an assumption that all women's lives were alike and you could appeal to them in a very general way, " says Anne Smith, who edited the media monsters Redbook, Glamour and McCall's before moving to Working Woman, the bible for the Wall Street female. "But today, women's lives have changed so much and their magazines are reflecting that shift. Couple that with the cult of celebrity that has taken hold here and what is happening makes complete sense."

What is happening is nothing short of an earthquake tearing up the landscape of women's magazine publishing, another clear sign that the post-feminist woman, circa 2001, identifies little with her older, you-go-girl sister. Today it is talk show host Oprah (O magazine), decorator and caterer Martha Stewart, (Martha Stewart Living) and TV personality and gun control advocate Rosie O'Donnell (Rosie magazine) who rule the newsstands, and there isn't an orgasm between them.

What their magazines do offer are healthy lashings of spiritual uplift, celebrity interviews, cookie recipes, politics, parenting tips and carpe diem exhortations. Oprah, whose magazine features an interview with Nelson Mandela sandwiched between articles about self-esteem and spirituality, is selling at a rate of three million copies per month.

"We are telling women what they need to know about themselves, not what they need to fix about themselves," O editor Amy Gross said recently, explaining that their calculated refusal to fuel women's insecurities, usually the mainstay of women's magazines, was the key to their success.

Rosie, launched across the US two weeks ago, is already a sellout on the newsstands. Unlike Oprah, whose feel-good TV show makes few enemies, O'Donnell, 39, a former stand-up comedian turned actor turned daytime host, is a lightning rod. She is a fierce liberal Democrat who makes no secret of her distaste for George Bush and his administration. She is the mother of three adopted children and an advocate of gun control. Her agenda is staunchly feminist left and she deftly mixes her acerbic humour and strong opinions with a parade of celebrities to garner four million TV viewers every day.

What Rosie is selling in her magazine is herself - her views on politics, community, guns and kids - with no apologies. No question her celebrity appeal seals the deal. Without her imprimatur, many of the stories would not see the light of day in a glossy monthly. Indeed Madison Avenue was sceptical about whether the mix of hardline politics and feel-good stories would sell, but they were wrong.

"What Rosie and Oprah showed publishers was that the old formula wasn't working," says MediaWeek reporter Lisa Granatstein. "Women today have different lives, it is no longer about just the home, or just getting ahead at work." Today, she says, women want to read about pro-choice celebrities and foster parenting - an interesting departure from 10 years ago, when sexual harassment at the office was the topic du jour.

"Oprah stands for self-development and personal growth, and that is where women are today," Smith says. "Rosie speaks to the woman who is opinionated, committed to her family and her community. Martha Stewart speaks to working mothers who don't know how to cook and clean. Feminism dumped on all those old-fashioned domestic arts, but Martha has made it OK for women to rediscover them."

Yet women are buying Oprah, Rosie and Martha not just because these publications mirror their lives but because of the seductive power of the celebrities marketing them.

"Celebrity is the unifying force in America today," says Mandi Norwood, the former editor of British Cosmo who moved to New York a year ago to edit Mademoiselle, a top-seller among women aged 18-30. "The power of a celebrity to sell magazines cannot be underestimated."

But what is an editor to do when her magazine is named Mademoiselle and not Oprah? Norwood says brand name magazines are not out of the game by a long shot. But unless editors get a perfect "read" on their "woman" - and in 2001 she is a hybrid, neither a feminist like her mother used to be or a home-maker like her grandmother - they may not survive the competition.

"It has taken me a good year to understand what young American women want," Norwood says. She revamped Mademoiselle to include more frank talk about sex - only to find that American women wanted her to take a softer line. "What I learned on Cosmo was that British women are not afraid of sex. American women like their sex coverage to be gentler, so you have to talk about sex in terms of intimacy and relationships. I have also discovered that while American women are very gutsy and confident, they do like to get married."

Veteran editor Smith adds: "What this revolution brought about by Oprah and Rosie is showing us is how much American women have changed in the past 10 years."

Power women, it seems, in print and in life, are a dying breed. Earth mothers who attend protest marches, raise children, do yoga, love Meg Ryan movies and run their own businesses are, apparently, the defining traits of Miss and Mrs America. "And never forget that women read for self-validation the way men do not. They seek affirmation of their life choices in magazines, and this is what they are getting."

webTitle: Agencies urged to improve radio ads

fields.headline: Agencies urged to improve radio adverts
fields.trailText: 8.30am: Poor quality radio adverts are a turn-off for listeners, a top agency chief has warned the industry, writes Maggie Brown.
fields.body:
Radio adverts are a turn-off for listeners and advertisers must insist on higher creative standards.

This was the message delivered at a packed, high-powered conference for the industry, hosted in central London's Royal Lancaster Hotel by the Radio Advertising Bureau.

MT Rainey, the co-chief executive of advertising agency Rainey Kelly Cambell Roalfe, told the 500 delegates from brands such as Sainsbury's and Colgate-Palmolive it was time the advertising medium "tried harder, and more often, to create great advertising" properly suited to radio.

Ms Rainey said while Britain had excelled at television advertising: "I don't think we have ever really consistently cracked it in radio advertising."

She added that, while the Americans were worse at all other types of advertising: "They are so much better at radio than we are."

She said neither advertisers nor agencies viewed radio in the correct strategic light.

During the conference, Ms Rainey noted the uniquely intimate characteristics of radio were not respected by the endless repetition of "come and get it in your local high street while stocks last" messages.

Even major advertisers often commissioned only one or two versions of their radio adverts - despite the fact they would be repeated frequently - to the annoyance of listeners.

Ms Rainey urged advertisers to try for six ot seven versions and to pride themselves on "beautifully scripted" work.

Too much radio had been shaped by the music culture, she added.

Katrina Lowes, head of broadcast communications for BT, described how BT had commissioned 42 versions of its advert promoting cheap local call zones.

It had paid attention to the voiceovers to ensure the wrong regional accents did not alienate listeners.

Ms Lowes also asked why radio adverts were not talked about in the pub the way television commercials were.

She urged advertisers to insist on pre-planning meetings and to hire specialist radio producers and good actors to ensure the finished product was listened to with enjoyment.

David Lethbridge, the co-founder of confetti.co.uk, the wedding website, said that by using Graham Norton - a well known but suprising choice - for its voiceovers, the site had received a massive boost in awareness and hits.

Ms Rainey concluded by warning advertisers not to buy radio airtime for the frequency of slots: "The biggest source fo annoyance among consumers in radio advertising is repetition.

"If the best TV and print campaigns have about two or three executions, a good radio campaign should have about five or six," she concluded.

webTitle: New BT chief raises bandwidth hopes

fields.headline: New BT chief raises bandwidth hopes
fields.standfirst: The shake-up at British Telecom has boosted the calls for an increase in Britain's limited broadband options, writes Sarah Left
fields.trailText: The shake-up at British Telecom has boosted the calls for an increase in Britain's limited broadband options, writes Sarah Left.
fields.body:
As a new chairman prepares to take over at BT, the online community is hoping that the change at the top will result in improvements to internet infrastructure in the UK.

Sir Christopher Bland, currently chairman of the BBC, is to replace embattled BT chairman Sir Iain Vallance. With share prices in a downward spiral and debts mounting, shareholders and competitors had been calling for change for some time.

And so have internet users. BT has been accused of standing in the way of internet development in the UK by failing to roll out high-speed ADSL technology quickly enough. It is a charge it denies, pointing to its steady moves to roll out its high-speed Openworld service.

Yet while millions of British internet users continue to dredge the net with clunky modems, surfers in France, Germany and Spain have seen broadband options coming onto the market more quickly.

Accusations have been levelled straight at the top of BT for a failure to move faster on ADSL. Rival telecoms firms rely on BT to allow them to install broadband equipment in the BT's local exchanges, and by and large these competitors feel BT has dragged its enormous feet.

AOL UK pointed to a recent survey that scored Britain second from bottom place in a worldwide survey of broadband internet access. The only country to do worse was China.

A spokesman for AOL UK said: "That is a source of national embarrassment and it is utterly the fault of BT."

A potentially lucrative business is at stake. As Sir Christopher will understand, media companies need broadband in place before they can offer bandwidth-hungry services like video on a large scale.

Internet service providers AOL and Freeserve have accused the company of restricting their ability to sell broadband services in favour of improving BT's Openworld ADSL offering. The problem for BT's management has been that opening up to competition is directly in conflict with its shareholders interests.

Robin Duke-Woolley, a senior telecoms consultant with Schema, defended BT's record. The technology has not been as simple to implement as the company's competitors suggest, he said, and the new chairman will have to create a better political climate for BT's internet interests.

"Companies that have rolled out ADSL faster - like Deutsche Telekom and Telefonica - have been expanding their own services at the expense of opening up to competitors. BT has been more susceptible to political pressure," he said.

To some extent, said Mr Duke-Woolley, BT should be less concerned about its competitors obtaining ADSL access and more concerned about getting the technology to end users, who after all do not care which company provides the service as long as they have a good service at a good price.

The ADSL Forum, a industry body, said that BT like many other telecoms firms has found itself with less money to invest in broadband infrastructure after incurring severe debt by investing in third generation mobile technology.

A spokeswoman for the forum said, "It's impossible to say what sort of difference this will make. BT has other issues to address." Internet users will want to see Sir Christopher deliver on broadband. His rivals want a complete change of heart from BT. And for a man with no telecoms experience behind him, it is going to be a tough job to satisfy everyone.
