fields.headline: At this price?
fields.trailText: Things are looking brighter for computer games retailer Electronics Boutique.
fields.body:
Things are looking brighter for computer games retailer Electronics Boutique.

The shares have bobbed between 60p and 70p for the past six months - about half their highest - amid concerns about the health of the market sector. But a recent rally causing a rise to about 80p and a confident forecast from the company suggest some signs of life in the games market.

Games sales have fallen sharply during the past six months because consumers were waiting for the next generation of consoles. PlayStation 2 was the first to come out, and is starting to rekindle demand.

Figures published yesterday show like for like sales for the first 12 weeks of the year rose 18%; since the third week of March they have risen by 31%.

Pretax profits for the year ending January were ahead of expectations, doubling to £13m. Sales rose from £251m to £307m, and the shares ticked up 10% to 76.75p.

Almost 400,000 PlayStation 2 consoles have been sold in Britain and 100 new games are due out before Christmas. PlayStation 1 has sold more than 6m units and the upgraded version is expected to do even better, suggesting Electronics Boutique should benefit from continued strong sales.

The next games gadget, Gameboy Advance, is due out on June 22, and should offer a further sales spur. Microsoft's Xbox, too, should be out by next spring.

Electronics Boutique is well positioned to deal with the sales. Online rivals such as Gameplay, which hoped to "squirt" games programs down phone lines rather than sell them in boxes in retail outlets, have fallen on hard times. Slow internet speeds and low adoption rates have led to lower sales than expected.

The games sector has not yet climbed from its trough, but Electronics Boutique shares present a better bet than most in the market.

Buy on weakness, then hold for the long term.

fields.headline: Dixons grows gloomier
fields.trailText: Executives at Dixons , the electrical retailer, would probably agree that April is the cruellest month. First its joint house broker lowered earnings forecasts, then the company was forced to admit its chairman, Sir Stanley Kalms, is retiring next year, now another leading broker has turned bearish.
fields.body:
Executives at Dixons , the electrical retailer, would probably agree that April is the cruellest month. First its joint house broker lowered earnings forecasts, then the company was forced to admit its chairman, Sir Stanley Kalms, is retiring next year, now another leading broker has turned bearish.

After a year-end meeting with the group's finance director, Ian Livingston, Dresdner Kleinwort Wasserstein has "significantly downgraded" its earnings forecasts. That news sent the stock spinning. Shares closed 19.5p lower at 245p, the worst FTSE 100 performer.

In a note to clients, Dresdner said it had cut its current year pretax profits forecast by 3.5% to £275m and its 2002 forecast by 8.0% to £298m.

"This essentially means that we have lost one year's growth and that the earnings per share growth rate for this year and next is coming down to nearer 7% from the double-digit rate previously expected," the note said.

Dresdner said the downgrades reflected lower demand for mobile phones and desktop PCs. Ominously for shareholders, the slowing rates of demand are more down to product cycles than the macroeconomic picture. A consumer downturn in Britain, Dresdner warns, would hit profits further.

In the wider market, it was a repeat performance of Tuesday's session with falling telecom shares offset by surging banking stocks and leading shares going nowhere as a consequence.

At the close, the FTSE 100 showed a loss of 12.8 points to 5,827.5, with Vodafone , off 4.75p to 210p, and BT , down 15p to 580p, responsible for pulling the index lower. BT was again hit by rumours of a deeply discounted rights issue, Vodafone was undermined by an earnings downgrade from Merril Lynch.

Equity traders were far from busy with just 1.8m shares changing hands.

There was no doubting the story of the day: merger talks between Halifax and Bank of Scotland . Both stocks ended sharply higher, Bank of Scotland up 61p to 803p and Halifax adding 30p to 768p, and pulled the rest of the sector with them as traders tried to predict which banks would be involved in the next round of consolidation.

Alliance & Leicester was a favourite, rising 23.5p to 804p, Bradford & Bingley rose 4.25p to 287.25p. Abbey National got in on the act, advancing 43p to £12.25, but Barclays fell 10p to £22.05 on fears it might break up the merger talks by bidding for Bank of Scotland.

The risers were not restricted to the banking sector. BAT was lifted by talk that the US justice department might not have enough cash to proceed with its action against the tobacco industry.

According to the chatter, President Bush's proposed budget does not provide enough funds to keep the government's lawsuit alive. BAT's American subsidiary, Brown & Williamson, is one of the companies targeted by the action. BAT shares ended 15p better at 538p.

Music group EMI was among the biggest blue-chip fallers, slipping 28p to 442p on concerns that anti-competition issues will force it to end merger discussions with Germany's Bertelsmann.

Satellite broadcaster BSkyB was marked 36.5p lower at 845p after joint house broker Goldman Sachs lowered its target price to £10.25, citing unspecified "technical fears".

Lower down the market, investors were exiting Cookson , the electronics and precious metals, ahead of today's annual meeting, which market professionals expect to be accompanied by a gloomy update on current trading. According to traders, the performance of Cookson's electronics division, which supplies equipment for printed circuit board makers mainly in the US, has been dire. Cookson fell 5p to 152.5p

Online directory services group Scoot.com nudged up 0.5p to 9p as a large stock overhang was finally cleared.

fields.headline: ICI under microscope
fields.trailText: With a week to go before first-quarter figures, traders are keeping a close eye on ICI, the speciality chemicals organisation.
fields.body:
With a week to go before first-quarter figures, traders are keeping a close eye on ICI, the speciality chemicals organisation.

The company's share price has been under pressure recently as a result of February's poor fourth-quarter figures and its exposure to the slowing US economy (30% of group turnover).

According to Deutsche Bank, the market is starting to lose its belief in ICI's premium growth rating, especially after the poor performance of its US-focused National Starch unit last year. Should this weakness continue, Deutsche Bank thinks the market will want some corrective action from ICI's management to support earnings.

Although the shares no longer trade at a premium to the sector, Deutsche Bank reckons there is better value and growth to be found elsewhere in the chemicals world.

ICI shares closed 5p lower at 404p yesterday.

fields.headline: City diary
fields.trailText: • Avoiding all reference to rumours that he is secretly betrothed to pop chart star Billy Piper, Sir Chris Evans, chairman of both Merlin Biosciences and car stereo alarm group Toad, delivered a robust reproach to the City at an Institute of Directors conference yesterday. Talking about a young broker who would not back one of his biotech ventures - preferring instead a dot.com shell that had already raised £40m but had no business to speak of, Sir Chris mused: "That young broker did not know his arse from his elbow." Adding, to peels of laughter: "And I hope he is in the audience." A typical display of the brashness, which has made him Britain's most loved late night chat show host.

 Avoiding all reference to rumours that he is secretly betrothed to pop chart star Billy Piper, Sir Chris Evans, chairman of both Merlin Biosciences and car stereo alarm group Toad, delivered a robust reproach to the City at an Institute of Directors conference yesterday. Talking about a young broker who would not back one of his biotech ventures - preferring instead a dot.com shell that had already raised £40m but had no business to speak of, Sir Chris mused: "That young broker did not know his arse from his elbow." Adding, to peels of laughter: "And I hope he is in the audience." A typical display of the brashness, which has made him Britain's most loved late night chat show host.

 It is always a delight to note the ridiculous titles awarded to people retained by their employer to do unspeakably dreadful tasks. One Chris Sweeney has been appointed to head Barclaycard's call centres in Teesside and Manchester under the extraordinary title Customer Experience Management Director - that's Head of Complaints to you and me. If you know someone with a ludicrous job title, share it with us.

 Few among the dispossessed of the dot.com world can forget the glorious devil-be-damned atmosphere in the local boozer on the night of the collapse of boo.com (first incarnation) last year. A reunion bash to mark the anniversary is planned, we learn, at the Midas Touch bar in Golden Square in London's Soho on May 18. Organisers, who claim to have found a sponsor for the event, promise the party will be followed by a lavish night bus trip during which cider will be decadently guzzled from champagne flutes and tuna meat will be troughed fresh from the tin.

 We are disappointed to learn of an unseemly spat involving our old friend, the mysterious Norwegian business magnate Fred Olsen. The head of Norway's richest family - whose resemblance to Springfield nuclear plant boss C Montgomery Burns is uncanny - is perhaps best known in Britain for his ruthless control of Timex during the closure of its Dundee wrist watch factory in 1993, and for his controlling stake in Belfast's Harland & Wolff shipyard. In his native Norway, Fred has hit the headlines because of a squabble with his brother Petter over the family art collection. Petter, who has always played second fiddle to Fred, is being sued by his elder brother after the former seemed about to inherit most of the 34 paintings, which include one of four original Screams by Edvard Munch. After 53 years of letting his brother get his way, Petter is fighting back. "I don't have to watch Big Brother," Petter was heard to say during one day of proceedings. "I've got one."

 An email arrives from Broomfield Estate, Devonshire retreat of the erstwhile titan of light entertainment, Noel Edmonds (co-incidentally a backer of Chris Evans' Toad). webTitle: Washington can't keep its hands off the ECB

fields.headline: Washington can't keep its hands off the ECB
fields.standfirst: Interest rate cut not required
fields.trailText: Today's European Central Bank meeting should not be a difficult one. Never mind what is happening to business confidence in Germany; inflation is ticking up both there and in Italy. For the ECB to cut interest rates would damage its credibility.
fields.body:
Today's European Central Bank meeting should not be a difficult one. Never mind what is happening to business confidence in Germany; inflation is ticking up both there and in Italy. For the ECB to cut interest rates would damage its credibility.

The difficulties will start if, as expected, the ECB keeps rates on hold. Most - though not all - of Europe's finance ministers appear to have grasped the idea that trying to push the bank into cutting rates can only lead to a perception of divided councils which in turn unsettles the euro. They have settled for saying as little as possible.

Not so outside euroland. The US, in the person of Treasury secretary Paul O'Neill, and the International Monetary Fund's Horst Köhler are pressing for an ECB cut. Even Gordon Brown, the chancellor, has added his mite.

The Bush administration's desire to see someone else take on a share of the burden of keeping global growth going is understandable but its approach smacks of the heavy handed. Worryingly, there appears within Washington (at the IMF as well as in the White House) to be a lack of understanding about the ECB's mandate. Its job is to maintain price stability. Growth - even within euroland, let alone the rest of the world - comes a distant second.

There are two points for concern. First, that a row over European rates disrupt this weekend's Group of Seven deliberations. That could rattle shell shocked equity markets. Second, a longer term anxiety. The US and euroland are enormous economic power blocs - yet their export sectors are relatively small, which means events elsewhere in the world have less of an impact than on more open economies. It would be unfortunate if policy misunderstandings were gradually to persuade each to turn more towards preoccupations closer to home; the expansions of the North American Free Trade Area and the European Union, for example.

The perils of polarisation could be greater than the grind towards globalisation.

Bank on speed

The Bank of Scotland initiated one round of consolidation within Britain's banking sector in 1999 when it bid for NatWest - only to be edged out by its rival, Royal Bank of Scotland. Now, in company with the Halifax, it has set a further round in train. In between, of course, it emerged as a possible merger partner for Abbey National.

Will it be more successful in the alliance stakes this time round? It is clear that the delicate details of the "merger" - read BoS takeover by Halifax - are yet to be agreed. The issue of sorting out who gets the top jobs, all too often one of the most vexed questions in a merger, is one issue that needs to addressed.

The even more difficult question of where to place the head office, given BoS' Edinburgh identity, will trouble the most diplomatic negotiators. But, while Halifax and BoS beaver away, the untimely leak of their talks raises even more tantalising questions.

Most pertinent, perhaps, is what Denise Kingsmill at the competition commission will make of the possibility of a creation of combined Halifax-BoS. Such a combination could be exactly the new "fifth force" to take on the big four which Abbey had reckoned it could create with BoS. Ironically, if that is right, then many in the City reckon she might be inclined to give Lloyds TSB - one of the big four - the green light to proceed with its takeover plans for Abbey. But, might this also mean that other members of the big four - Barclays, HSBC and Royal Bank of Scotland - would be enticed to take the plunge and spoil BoS's deal-making attempts yet again by bidding for it or Halifax?

It is a fluid situation but for staff and customers of those institutions involved a potentially uncomfortable one. The sooner the Halifax and BoS reach agreement and the competition commission the judgments it will be required to make the better.

Reverse charge

Trade and industry secretary Stephen Byers yesterday insisted that the £22bn-plus cost of acquiring third generation mobile phone licences in Britain had had nothing to do with Motorola's closing its plant at Bathgate.

The issue had not even been mentioned, he told MPs. Fair enough. It was not Motorola which shelled out the cash but the telecoms operators. The plant is a victim of what has been happening to the market for handsets for this generation of mobile phones, not the next.

Despite that, the suggestion that the government should help out the industry by giving the money back refuses to go away. The idea is nonsense. The bidders were making a commercial decision on how much they paid. Altering the terms now wouldhave those who missed out reaching for their lawyers.

fields.headline: Stake sale values Cazenove at £1.2bn
fields.trailText: Cazenove, the blue-blooded stockbroker which is ending 177 years as a secretive partnership, yesterday gave details of its finances for the first time as it confirmed the sale of am equity stake to leading City institutions.
fields.body:
Cazenove, the blue-blooded stockbroker which is ending 177 years as a secretive partnership, yesterday gave details of its finances for the first time as it confirmed the sale of am equity stake to leading City institutions.

The sale - valuing the Queen's broker at £1.2bn - is a precursor to a stockmarket flotation in two years.

The placing values the stakes of its 80 senior partners - including City grandee David Mayhew - at around £10.5m.

All 1,100 employees in the Square Mile will be given a stake in the company. In addition each member of staff has been guaranteed half what they were paid last year, including bonuses.

As part of the capital raising, Cazenove announced a pretax profit of £86m on revenues of £297m in the nine months to the end of January despite the tough market conditions.

"Our global equity business has held up very well. In corporate finance, clearly M and A [mergers and acquisitions] activity has declined but we are still very busy," said Nigel Rowe, the joint managing director.

Mr Rowe confirmed that Cazenove would start life as a corporate entity on Monday after successfully completing the £200m fundraising exercise.

Robert Pickering, Cazenove's other managing director, played down suggestions that the valuation implied by the equity placing was disappointing. When Cazenove announced plans to incorporate six months ago, a valuation of £1.5bn on flotation was suggested by the company.

"You have to compare the £1.2bn valuation from the private funding round with what we said it would be worth on float," he said. "An unquoted business will always be valued at a discount to a quoted business."

Cazenove, which acts as broker to half of the 100 biggest companies in the country, saw its unusual status in the City called into question by the wave of mergers and acquisitions among investment banks.

It raised £100m by placing shares with 16 City institutions, including Axa, Legal & General, M&G, Standard Life, CGNU and 3i. The other £100m was raised via a 24-year subordinated bond, subscribed to by some of the eq uity investors. On incorporation, the equity investors will own 9.2% of Cazenove Group and the staff a further 14%. The rest will be spread among the group's 122 senior partners. Eighty original partners will share 71.8% of the equity, with the final 5% spread among the firm's 42 new partners.

Cazenove also announced the appointment of Sir Roger Hurn, the chairman of Marconi, and Sir Steve Robson, a former Treasury mandarin, as its first two non-executive directors. Sir Steve's appointment came 24 hours after he became a non-executive director at Royal Bank of Scotland.

webTitle: After the champagne has gone flat

fields.headline: After the champagne has gone flat
fields.trailText: Dianne Thompson should remember that the Veuve Clicquot Businesswoman of the Year award has not always proved a spur to greater success.
fields.body:
Dianne Thompson should remember that the Veuve Clicquot Businesswoman of the Year award has not always proved a spur to greater success.

Last year's winner, Nikki Beckett, chief executive of NSB Retail, was showered with praise for building her retailing software design firm to a stock market value of £955m just six years after she founded the company.

Last month Ms Beckett hit the headlines again following disappointing results from NSB. The market halved the company's share price in a day.

Ms Beckett, Britain's second-richest woman last year behind Harry Potter author JK Rowling, is thought to have seen her fortune shrink by £24.3m.

Yesterday, NSB issued a statement saying it remained cautious about the north American economy, but "the widely publicised concerns over a slowdown have not impacted the business to date".

Marjorie Scardino, chief executive of the Pearson media group, won the Veuve Clicquot award in 1997 and was praised for more than doubling Pearson's market value in five years. Since then, some acquisition and restructuring decisions have failed to impress the market - Pearson's share price has been in slow decline over the past 12 months.

There have been rumours that she is considering quitting and returning to her native America.

Businesswoman of the Year 1996, Nicola Foulston, one-time head of Brands Hatch motor racing circuit, bowed out of business circles after negotiating its £120m sale to a US advertising group, Interpublic, in 1999. The sale followed an abortive bid for rival circuit Silverstone, home of the British Grand Prix.

After reportedly making £50m from the sale herself, Ms Foulston went to live in Switzerland with Richard Green, the Brands Hatch operations manager.

Another winner to have faded from prominence is Anne Wood CBE, whose Ragdoll Productions makes the Teletubbies programme for pre-school children.

Despite boasting that "the Teletubbies will go on for ever" after winning a Bafta for the programme last November, the BBC has said it has no plans to recommission the series after the contract runs out in October.

webTitle: CBI warns of US effect on industry

fields.headline: CBI warns of US effect on industry
fields.standfirst: Manufacturing hit by falling American orders
fields.trailText: Prospects for a sustained recovery in Britain's embattled manufacturing sector have been blighted by the slowdown in the United States.
fields.body:
Prospects for a sustained recovery in Britain's embattled manufacturing sector have been blighted by the slowdown in the United States.

Orders and business confidence among manufacturing firms have fallen, according to the latest quarterly survey from the CBI, while output growth have ground to a halt.

The CBI is ruling out a recession, and its latest forecast shows the overall economy growing by about 2.5% this year. But it is calling for a further 0.25 percentage-point cut in interest rates to help stem the slide.

"We do not wish to over-state the likely scale of the eco nomic slowdown. We are not in the same position as the US, and the UK economy remains fundamentally strong.

But we do need a quarter-point rate cut to limit the downturn," said Nick Reilly, chairman of the CBI's economic affairs committee.

Yesterday's data from the CBI is a particular disappointment because it reverses tentative evidence of an upturn in the previous quarterly survey.

"Manufacturers are clearly facing difficult times. The last survey suggested a small step forward, but now we seem to have taken two steps backwards. The next few months will be crucial," said Mr Reilly.

Although the CBI's stance does not contradict recent comments from the chancellor about the strength of the UK economy, the latest evidence of the difficulties facing manufacturing will serve as a reminder to election planners that the economic news over the next few months is likely to get worse, rather than better.

Yesterday the governor of the Bank of England, Sir Eddie George, emphasised that the bank had the scope to cut interest rates further if necessary, but he stopped short of promising a further reduction.

Sir Eddie told the Institute of Directors that, with inflation comfortably below the government's 2.5% target, there was no obstacle to the Bank reducing interest rates again following the two quarter-point cuts this year. "That is not a promise of further interest rate reductions, but it is a promise that we are prepared to move further if we have evidence that those [downside] risks are increasing."

The CBI said its survey showed business confidence had fallen for the fifth consecutive survey and the drop was the largest for more than two years, though it cautioned against reading too much into the extent of the decline.

But there was better news for Gordon Brown from the European commission. It predicted UK economic growth would hit 2.7% this year and 3% next, and said the outlook was for "good growth with inflation remaining subdued".

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: New hope for Cammel Laird | Chevron shows higher profits | L&G sees rise in UK business | Mobile users spend less | Chrysler upbeat on earnings
fields.body:
New hope for Cammel Laird

PricewaterhouseCoopers, acting as receiver for shipbuilder Cammell Laird, yesterday told union leaders they had received as many as 30 expressions of interest in the business.

The GMB union said workers had also been promised no further job losses after the 320 redundancies announced last week. PwC had said it hoped to be able to announce potential new buyers within two or three weeks, officials confirmed.

John Edmonds, GMB leader, said: "This is obviously good news potentially for the workforce. We believe the operations at Cammell Laird remain fundamentally sound and this view has been endorsed by the massive interest that's been shown in taking over the company."

Chevron shows higher profits

Chevron, the second largest US oil company, said first-quarter earnings rose a better than expected 53% on strong oil and natural gas prices, and better profits on gasoline and other fuels.

The company, which is acquiring rival Texaco, said net income rose to $1.6bn (£1.1bn), or $2.49 a share, from $1.04bn, or $1.59 a share a year ago.

L&G sees rise in UK business

Legal & General, Britain's third largest life and pensions company, said yesterday that the year had opened well for it with a 13% rise in global new business sales during the first quarter to £143m.

The figures showed new life and pension sales in Britain rose 18% to £119m, with growth coming mainly from group pension sales.

Mobile users spend less

Vodafone, the world's largest mobile phone operator, said yesterday that customers in its three main markets were spending less on calls, and that one in 10 had ceased using their mobile phones.

The figures, contained in a new quarterly performance report, were distorted by rapid growth in lower spending pay-as-you-go customers and masked encouraging underlying trends.

Chrysler upbeat on earnings

German-US motor group DaimlerChrysler said yesterday its earnings could return to 1999 levels of €9.75bn ($8.76bn) within two years, despite first-quarter losses of €3.75bn.

The group said a sustained improvement in earnings over the next year would be the likely outcome of its restructuring of Chrysler and Mitsubishi, its Japanese partner. The group has already announced 26,000 job losses and plant closures at Chrysler, along with 9,500 job losses at Mitsubishi, in which it holds a 37.3% stake.

fields.headline: Arthur Smith
fields.trailText: Last weekend in Paris I considered breasts. Women's, of course; men's are of no interest to anyone, with their feeble contours and pointless nipples.
fields.body:
Last weekend in Paris I considered breasts. Women's, of course; men's are of no interest to anyone, with their feeble contours and pointless nipples. I was telling a friend that the French used to feature breasts on 100-franc banknotes when suddenly some appeared on the French TV news (German breasts displayed in the name of art) and I knew a motif had emerged for my brief stay.

The next day, in an interview on Loose Ends, Jane Birkin told me Serge Gainsbourg was afraid of bosoms and that, since she had none to speak of, their liaison was assured. By now I was actively seeking out my theme, so I went to an exhibition at the Jeu de Paume called Picasso Erotique.

Here, of course, there were jugs in spades. The early ones were beautifully drawn, adorning dark-eyed models. Later, they became more experimental: frisbees, fried eggs, big eyes. And they proliferated - after all, why have two when you can have three? In sculptures they became steep, black hills with a cairn on top - guaranteed to intimidate Serge. In some works you can see connections between breasts, penises, hands, noses and feet, all possessing equal sensual weight, all comically mashed up together and ludicrous, like sex itself.

By now I was seeing them everywhere. Not that I was staring at women's fronts, more that images of them confronted me at every turn. French advertising abounds with bosoms. And, having experienced Picasso's various versions, everything took on mammiferous qualities: the Arc de Triomphe was a monumental cubist cleavage; my oeufs durs mayonnaise were four saucy boobs on a plate.

Oddly, I got some respite at the Années Pop exhibition at the Beaubourg. Lots of garish colours, plastic and Coca-Cola. Collage but no decolletage. Thank goodness. I had gone a little crazy but then, in a toilet at the Gare du Nord, I finally found the biggest tit in Paris, merely by glancing in the mirror.

fields.headline: 'My God, what the hell have we lost in the west?'
fields.standfirst: Nitin Sawhney has recorded street sellers in Bombay, Aborigines in Australia and taxi drivers in Chicago.  Eddi Fiegel  joins him in South Africa on the last leg of his musical odyssey
fields.trailText: Nitin Sawhney has recorded street sellers in Bombay, Aborigines in Australia and taxi drivers in Chicago. Eddi Fiegel joins him in South Africa on the last leg of his musical odyssey.
fields.body:
Nelson Mandela has a twinkle in his eye. He is clearly used to people being nervous in his presence, and while he exudes a statesmanlike dignity he also has a magisterial ability to put us at ease. "The young lady is reluctant to shake my hand," he teases gently when my turn comes to say goodbye.

We are on the steps of Mandela's Johannesburg residence with Nitin Sawhney, who has just recorded an interview with Mandela for use on his forthcoming album, Prophesy. It is the culmination of an extraordinary week in South Africa in which we have been welcomed by a children's choir, come within inches of being shot in downtown Soweto, seen the sun rise across the plains of Africa - and now met Nelson Mandela.

As the title of Sawhney's album suggests, Prophesy is about visions of the future. And although Mandela has in the past been wary of taking on the prophet's mantle - "I stand before you not as a prophet but as a humble servant of you, the people," he said on his release from prison in 1990 - Sawhney is here to ask him what he foresees not only for South Africa but for the world. Mandela tells Sawhney: "There are talented and good people, men and women throughout the world with vision and compassion, who realise that without lasting peace there can be no development. And therefore I am optimistic."

The idea of development is one that is also central to Prophesy. With the album Sawhney wants to challenge the west's definition of the developing world and highlight the contrast between the spiritual impoverishment of the materially rich west and the comparative spiritual wealth of the supposedly undeveloped world.

The first stop on our Johannesburg trip is the Rishile School in Soweto's Zone Four. Rishile is known for its school choir and Sawhney has written a song for the children to sing. As we wander across the school's leafy courtyard, past rooms full of small children smiling and waving excitedly at us, we begin to hear the soaring voices of the Rishile choir singing to us in Zulu. By the time we reach their classroom, their animated sound has filled the room and it is impossible not to be moved by the joy on the children's faces. As they sing, lining two sides of the room in their immaculate school uniforms, Sawhney sits down and starts to play along on his guitar.

"The feeling of hope is really strong in South Africa and that's something I noticed last time I was here," Sawhney tells me later. "I was really taken by the amazing optimism that came from the children in the face of oppression and poverty. You see it in the incredible yelps of delight when they see their faces in the camera. It made me think, 'My God, what the hell have we lost in the west?' So I felt that was really appropriate to put on the album."

For Sawhney, the trip to South Africa is the final lap of a global journey in which he has recorded with Aborigines in Australia, street sellers and tabla players in Bombay, and philosophising taxi drivers and blues singers in Chicago. There have also been Native American Indians on US reservations, Algerian rai singers in Paris and street children in Brazil - not to mention the English Chamber Orchestra and the London Community Gospel Choir in Britain.

The link between them can be found in Sawhney's ideas of the future and his musical vision. Each country he visited has had some influence on him musically and each one also provided another outlook on the future. Yet, in contrast to so much that has come out of the vogue for the appropriation of eastern musical styles, Sawhney means it. As a result, he is almost bemused by the celebrity glamour he has recently gained. His 1999 album, Beyond Skin, was nominated for last year's Mer cury prize, and since then Sawhney has been name-checked by Madonna: apparently she does yoga to the album. Before that he had collaborated with Paul McCartney, Sinead O'Connor, Sting and Jeff Beck, and even before that he was part of the original team behind the hit BBC TV comedy Goodness Gracious Me.

From the outset, Sawhney's work has centred on issues of cultural and racial identity and explored his own musical heritage as a British Asian. It is an approach that can easily be traced back to his childhood. As one of the few non-white pupils at his Kent grammar school in the 1970s, he was attacked frequently and violently by the then burgeoning National Front. His reaction was to go home and improvise on the piano. By the age of 11 he had reached grade eight, and although he excelled academically, everything else he did was merely a way of passing the time between playing the piano or picking up a guitar. Now, at 36, he says he has come to terms with many of the issues surrounding his identity and recognises that the injustices of the world go further than the facts of his own life.

Sawhney's global journey has been filmed for a forthcoming DVD in which the album's title track, Prophesy, is played at different locations at sunrise. Pilanesberg National Park in South Africa is 140,000 acres of open plains, wooded valleys and dense bush, complete with roaming lions, giraffes, elephants, zebras and rhinos, and is therefore the perfect choice. So at 3.30am we drive through the night to a mountain-top viewpoint. The valleys and plains below us seem inexpressibly infinite and you can almost smell the stillness in the air. But, as Sawhney begins to play his guitar, instead of being invasive, the sound seems eerily in harmony with the transformation happening around us. As his music gains pace the sun's orange glow gradually begins to warm the earth and somehow it feels like a genuine awakening.

Back in Johannesburg, our final stop is a return to Rishile to present the school with a synthesiser keyboard and CD sound system. Sawhney is aware that by recording the children he is laying himself open to accusations of exploitation, so in each country he has visited he has made a point of giving something back to the people he has recorded, either by means of a financial donation or an appropriate gift. "It's a very viable accusation and it's something I think about a lot. But I can't see any other way of trying to depict the imbalances of the world from a personal viewpoint unless you do actually go to places and do something like recording a choir in a school in Soweto."

As we arrive we are amazed to find the entire school waiting for us, seated assembly-style in the school courtyard. Once again, they begin to sing and, once again, it is breathtaking. After welcoming us, they unwrap their gifts. The children shriek with delight and the teachers dance around in a joyous circle of celebration. Later, when their head teacher thanks us in private, her voice shakes with emotion as she tells us that most of these teachers grew up without shoes and that for a black school in Soweto to have a piano of this kind is beyond anything they could ever have dreamed of. "It's a miracle," says teacher Jane Kubayi. "Our prayers have been answered and our dreams have been met."

With Prophesy, Sawhney is giving his audience the chance to become passengers on his voyage of discovery. It is a journey that raises as many questions as it answers, through a combination of lush Brazilian strings juxtaposed with, yearning laments, Indian flutes with drum and bass, speech, news and hard rap with rousing blues, and aching ballads with barbed lyrics.

But, I wonder, how much of Sawhney's intrinsic message will be fully digested? Does he really believe music can make a difference? "Music is a universal language," he says, "so it has no barriers. It's also an abstract form of expression that taps into people's subconscious, and that means it affects them much more deeply. So yes, I believe it can."

 Prophesy is out on V2 Music on June 4. The South Africa Freedom Day concert in aid of Nelson Mandela's Children's Fund takes place in Trafalgar Square, London on Monday.

fields.headline: Aussie strippers seek union cover
fields.trailText: Australian lapdancers, strippers and topless waitresses are forming a trade union to fight for better pay, related to the amount of flesh put on display and the length of the performance they give.
fields.body:
Australian lapdancers, strippers and topless waitresses are forming a trade union to fight for better pay, related to the amount of flesh put on display and the length of the performance they give.

Mystical Melody, spokeswoman for Striptease Artists Australia said she and other erotic dancers decided to set up their own union because "so far no other organisation wishes to associate with the nature of the striptease industry".

Once it was registered with and recognised by the Industrial Relations Commission, she said, she hoped the union would help provide better professional development for the thousands of erotic performers who work in bars, clubs and pubs throughout Australia.

Prostitution and "adult entertainment" - unknown to the Aboriginals - arrived in Australia with the first convict ships from England in 1788.

The shortage of women -a ratio of one to six men until the 1820s - helped stimulate an industry which has continued to flourish despite draconian laws in some states.

In Western Australia, prostitution remains illegal.

The state authorities also outlaw the practice of throwing money at barmaids to encourage them to strip, a tradition which developed in pubs in the Kalgoorlie goldfields.

fields.headline: Geisha wants cut of Golden's goose
fields.trailText: Arthur Golden was as grateful as one might expect to the woman who gave him access to a closed world and supplied the authenticity that helped his first novel - Memoirs of a Geisha - to sell at least 4m copies.
fields.byline: Michael Ellison in New York and Jonathan Watts in Tokyo
fields.body:
Arthur Golden was as grateful as one might expect to the woman who gave him access to a closed world and supplied the authenticity that helped his first novel - Memoirs of a Geisha - to sell at least 4m copies.

"I am indebted to one individual above all others ... Mineko Iwasaki," he wrote in his long list of acknowledgments. "She became, and remains, a good friend. To Mineko, thank you for everything."

That was three and a half years ago. Now Ms Iwasaki, 50, is suing him, claiming that he "tarnished her reputation, breached an unwritten contract not to reveal her identity and unjustly enriched himself through the novel".

She wants an "appropriate percentage" of the $10m (£7m) which she estimates the book has earned.

The case entered in the Manhattan federal court says that Golden's book "repeatedly stated that Ms Iwasaki was sold into the geisha world as a child by her parents and that her virginity was auctioned to the highest bidder when she came out as a geisha".

"Both stories are patently untrue and Golden has falsely represented them as fact."

Her lawyer, Dorothy Weber, said: "The selling of her virginity, that rite of passage did not happen. She feels terrible that he said that. He has said in public the story is based on her and that has affected her life negatively, since a lot of the stories he's portrayed were not accurate."

The story is set in Kyoto before and during the second world war, the last years of the old-style geisha houses, whose traditions ranged from classical dance to practices tantamount to bonded labour.

Ms Iwasaki is not named in the book but her case centres not only on the help she gave Golden but also on her assertion that the main character is entirely her, not a composite.

Golden, who has an MA in Japanese history from Columbia University and has worked in Tokyo, found the voice for his novel, that of an elderly geisha living in Manhattan, after interviewing Ms Iwasaki nine years ago.

He was not available for comment yesterday, but he has said: "Mineko feels that I violated her anonymity. But I have a fax from her in which she really was requesting more publicity. The Japanese phrase she used translates roughly to 'Put my face out there a little more, please'."

There are an estimated 15,000 geisha in Japan, although the number is falling. The book has ruffled feathers in the high-class tea houses of Kyoto and Tokyo, where they insist that the practice of auctioning virginity has long since died out.

Golden is reported to have said at a reading two years ago that Ms Iwasaki was proud hers sold for a record $850,000.

webTitle: Police brave Manila mob to nab Estrada

fields.headline: Police brave Manila mob to nab Estrada
fields.standfirst: Former Philippine president faces the death penalty after he and his son are charged with economic plunder
fields.trailText: The disgraced former Philippine president Joseph Estrada suffered the ignominy yesterday of being arrested for corruption and refused bail, despite thousands of diehard supporters who fought running battles with the police to prevent them taking away their idol.
fields.body:
The disgraced former Philippine president Joseph Estrada suffered the ignominy yesterday of being arrested for corruption and refused bail, despite thousands of diehard supporters who fought running battles with the police to prevent them taking away their idol.

Three months after being forced out of the opulent presidential palace, the one-time action-movie star cut a sorry figure as he had his fingerprints, mugshots and blood pressure taken at Manila's sprawling police headquarters.

He was escorted to a spartan 3.5-metre by 5.5-metre cell with airconditioning but no telephone or television. The only concession he was given as a former head of state was a private cell - not even sharing it with his son Jinggoy, who was also arrested yesterday.

Mr Estrada, 64, insisted that he was the victim of a political plot. "This is all part of the new mob rule," he said in his cell.

"I was denied the due process of law and I vehemently denounce this violation of my basic human rights. This makes a mockery of the bill of rights and the constitution."

Prosecutors charged Mr Estrada and Jinggoy, the mayor of San Juan, a Manila suburb, with economic plunder - an offence for which there is no bail and which carries the death penalty.

Few people, however, believe he will suffer that fate, particularly as his successor, Gloria Arroyo Macapagal, opposes capital punishment.

She was adamant, though, that Mr Estrada should remain in detention and not be allowed house arrest.

"The Sandiganbayan [anti-graft court] has spoken. And the message is clear ... this is as it should be," she said in a statement.

"The Filipino people were victimised when government funds were used for private purposes. They deserve justice."

The charge stems from allegations that Mr Estrada illegally amassed more than 4bn pesos (£55m) during his 31 months in office.

His grip on power was ended by a popular uprising and a political coup after his impeachment trial for corruption collapsed.

Initially he was charged with perjury and corruption, charges on which he was allowed bail. But the prosecutors persevered with their investigations, eventually gathering enough evidence to bring the charge of economic plunder.

The police took no chances when they went to serve the arrest warrant at his luxurious Manila mansion. Thousands of officers, including sharpshooters and several helicopters, were deployed to move the masses of Estrada followers who had blocked the approach roads. Several people were injured when the police used water cannon and teargas to clear stone-throwing protesters. Most dispersed after members of the Estrada family appealed for calm.

Family friends said Mr Estrada had been very depressed for the past few days, crying often and rarely eating. He looked a shadow of his former jocular self as he was led out wearing the same jacket as when he left the presidential palace for the final time.

"Please take care of him. Don't hurt him," a weeping relative told the national police chief, General Leandro Mendoza, as he served the warrant.

He was whisked away under extremely heavy guard in a dark police van, still maintaining his innocence.

"This government is illegitimate," he said, with his wife, Luisa, by his side. "This government is unconstitutional. It's conspiring against me. As far as I'm concerned, I'm still the duly elected president under our constitution."

He is expected in court on May 17 on the perjury and corruption charges. No hearing has been set for the more serious charge.

The police took no chances when they went to serve the arrest warrant at his luxurious Manila mansion. Thousands of officers, including sharpshooters and several helicopters, were deployed to move the masses of Estrada followers who had blocked the approach roads. Several people were injured when the police used water cannon and teargas to clear stone-throwing protesters. Most dispersed after members of the Estrada family appealed for calm. Family friends said Mr Estrada had been very depressed for the past few days, crying often and rarely eating. He looked a shadow of his former jocular self as he was led out wearing the same jacket as when he left the presidential palace for the final time. "Please take care of him. Don't hurt him," a weeping relative told the national police chief, General Leandro Mendoza, as he served the warrant. He was whisked away under extremely heavy guard in a dark police van, still maintaining his innocence. "This government is illegitimate," he said, with his wife, Luisa, by his side. "This government is unconstitutional. It's conspiring against me. As far as I'm concerned, I'm still the duly elected president under our constitution." He is expected in court on May 17 on the perjury and corruption charges. No hearing has been set for the more serious charge.

webTitle: Israelis tense on eve of independence day

fields.headline: Israelis tense on eve of independence day
fields.standfirst:
Bombed four times, the town of Kfar Saba will find it hard to relax today

Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Many Israelis shared their unease yesterday as they mourned their war dead before giving themselves up at sunset to the outdoor concerts, barbecues and maddening traffic queues that distinguish the national holiday.
fields.body:
Ori Wald is 15, his girlfriend Natalie Warshafksy 14, and they share a teenage certainty about what they will and will not do. They will not ride on buses, they will not tarry in public places and they will be safely tucked up at home when the rest of Israel celebrates independence day today.

Many Israelis shared their unease yesterday as they mourned their war dead before giving themselves up at sunset to the outdoor concerts, barbecues and maddening traffic queues that distinguish the national holiday.

None more so, perhaps, than the 80,000 people of Kfar Saba, a town of wide avenues and shopping malls north of Tel Aviv which has been bombed four times by Palestinian militants since the uprising began.

The last suicide bomber, from Hamas, struck near the main square on Sunday, sidling up to a bus before killing himself and a middle-aged doctor and injuring dozens of others.

By yesterday afternoon the soundmen were at work in the square, setting up the stage for the public party.

People drifted by to watch; some told stories of their escapes: the missed bus, the sudden change of routine, the pipe bomb that was so close that the smoke curled in through the living room window. Several said they would miss the party for fear of another attack.

"I am afraid to go out," Ori Wald said. "We are going to stay at home and watch TV this year because, if I was the one doing the killing and the bombings, I would do it right here."

After Sunday's bombing of route 29, he and Natalie feel too jittery to take the bus. Yesterday they walked through the fields into town, a 25-minute journey.

"It's kind of funny. It is our independence day but we don't feel independent in our own country because if we go out we could die," he said.

In Kfar Saba, as elsewhere, the anxiety has been stoked by official warnings that Palestinian militants may try to wreck the festivities.

To Palestinians today commemorates a calamity - the event that robbed them of their homes, making them refugees for the last 53 years. They mark Israel's creation on May 15 as Nakba Day, the day of the catastrophe.

Yesterday, with Israelis caught up in their own fears, the army tightened its siege of Palestinian towns in the West Bank and the teeming territory of Gaza. At Jericho and other West Bank towns, long queues of seething Palestinian motorists formed at military checkpoints.

Such hardships barely registered in Kfar Saba, even though the town lies only a few minutes drive from the West Bank city of Qalqilya.

Even people who identify with the Israeli leftwing say it is too soon to think of resuming peace talks with the Palestinians. Some who say they are on the centre, such as Rina Ferdinaro, a bookkeeper lugging two bags of groceries across the square, say it would be better to focus on war.

"We have to give them a huge blow - we have not been strong enough so far - we have to be decisive. It's clear we can not live in peace. At least let us live in quiet."

But less than two months after Ariel Sharon was installed as prime minister, there are doubts whether he can deliver his promise to crush the uprising.

The doubt increased when US pressure forced Mr Sharon to abandon his plan to reoccupy a square mile of Gaza last week.

"I think the Palestinians only understand the language of force," Ina Finker, a native of St Petersburg who has lived in Israel for 10 years, said. "But we as a nation lack the independence to use force because of pressure from the United States. Our hands are tied."

Despite the anger, Kfar Saba is no bastion of the Israeli right. The town bucked the national trend that swept Mr Sharon to power and remained loyal by a tiny margin to the loser, Ehud Barak.

Like most other Israelis, the Labour party mayor, Yitzhak Wald, feels betrayed by the past seven months.

But he believes that eventually Israelis and the Palestinians will have to talk peace again.

"Look, I created strong and close ties with Qalqilya, because I believe that you have to push for peace from below," he said.

"I must say though that I am very frustrated with what has happened in the last few months. This is a knock - but not a knock-out - to our will for peace."

webTitle: ANC accused of plot against Mbeki

fields.headline: ANC veterans accused of plot to harm Mbeki
fields.trailText: The  South African government has ordered the investigation of three leading anti-apartheid politicians for allegedly plotting to physically harm and oust President Thabo Mbeki.
fields.body:
The South African government has ordered the investigation of three leading anti-apartheid politicians, including the former secretary general of the African National Congress Cyril Ramaphosa, who is a now a monitor of the IRA's weapons dumps, for allegedly plotting to physically harm and oust President Thabo Mbeki.

The investigation was immediately denounced as an attempt to use the police to suppress legitimate political challenges to Mr Mbeki's leadership of the ANC.

The president added to speculation about a conspiracy by issuing a call for those with information about the alleged plot to come forward.

The surprise announcement came from the security minister, Steve Tshwete. He said that, among other things, Mr Ramaphosa and two former provincial premiers, Tokyo Sexwale and Mathews Phosa, were being investigated for spreading "disinformation" that could endanger Mr Mbeki's safety.

He implied that the men were responsible for rumours circulating in the ANC that Mr Mbeki had a hand in the murder of the highly popular Communist party leader Chris Hani in 1993.

"This rumour can set the president up to be harmed, because Hani was loved by the people," he said.

"It can put the president in danger, not only as the president of the ANC but as the head of state. We need to investigate, because when something happens, people will say 'We told them about this'."

Hani was a young charismatic politician and leader of the ANC's armed wing who was widely tipped as an alternative successor to Nelson Mandela. He was murdered by an anti-communist Polish emigrant who was in league with a leading member of the racist Conservative party.

Mr Tshwete said some of the allegations had been made by a former ANC youth leader, James Nkambule. They were being taken seriously because Mr Nkambule "was pretty close" to some of the people allegedly behind the plot.

Mr Tshwete's announcement in Xhosa on South African television followed an interview he gave to a Johannesburg Sunday newspaper in which he alleged that there was a threat to Mr Mbeki's safety from inside the ANC.

Mr Ramaphosa, who led his party's negotiations to end white rule and lost to Mr Mbeki in the contest to become Nelson Mandela's deputy president, is now a wealthy busi nessman and chairman of a publishing group. But he remains a hugely popular member of the ANC's national executive, and is widely touted as an alternative to Mr Mbeki.

Mr Phosa, who was the ANC's constitutional law expert, and Mr Sexwale are also in business.

All three men, who had ambitions to lead their party and South Africa in the past, denied the accusations.

"It is rubbish. What are they talking about? It is really crazy," Mr Phosa said. "They accuse us of horrendous things and that is a provocation. I am not going to jump around as if I am guilty."

Mr Sexwale said the allegations were "complete hogwash". Mr Ramaphosa did not comment in public but told other ANC leaders that the charges were nonsense.

But Mr Mbeki increased speculation about the alleged plot by calling, in a television interview, for anyone with information to come forward.

"Some people want to be president of South Africa. That's fine. The matter that's arising is the manner in which people pursue their ambitions," he said.

"If there is any talk of plotting, those who have information must come out openly and say this is what they know about the plotting, who is involved and so on."

He added that there was a campaign by key businessmen to fund a challenge to his leadership of the ANC at its December 2002 congress. The party leader is automatically the ANC's candidate for president of the country.

"It's a conspiratorial thing. I know you have business people who say we will set up a fund to promote our particular candidate and we will then try to influence particular journalists," he said.

But his statement raised questions about the motive for the investigation. There is nothing in South African law to prevent business people funding or otherwise backing a candidate for leadership of the ANC or the country, or trying to win the support of journalists.

The police commissioner, Jackie Selebi, said that an inquiry had begun after a "senior ANC member" said that the party's national congress next year was likely to result in a "bloodbath".

The official opposition said the investigation was "an abuse of office by the minister and an outrage in a parliamentary democracy".

"Minister Tshwete and President Mbeki, who has presumably given his approval to this abuse, would do well to remember Nixon. Watergate was a scandal where the power of the state was misused to fight political opponents," the Democratic Alliance's chief whip, Douglas Gibson, said.

The ANC said that as a result of the accusations it was concerned about the safety of Mr Mbeki and the three men accused of plotting against him. But in a confused statement, it tried to blame the allegations of dissent in the party on the press, even though the investigation was ordered by one of the ANC's cabinet ministers.

Mr Mbeki has been the target of conspiratorial investigations over the years. In the late 70s he was accused by ANC intelligence of being a CIA agent. He quit the movement for a short time because he believed the charges were part of a plot to get rid of him, or even to justify killing him.

In the 80s, when he was the ANC's principal negotiator in early talks with representatives of the apartheid regime, other leading activists - including Hani - accused him of selling out the movement.

Facing inquiry Liberation leaders deny claims

Tokyo Sexwale

Sexwale, 47, was the first person on the scene after the murder of the popular Communist leader Chris Hani in 1993, and played an important role in calming the anger felt by many black people at the killing. But later he pushed it too far trying to claim Hani's mantle.

He became premier of Gauteng province, which includes Johannesburg and Pretoria, in 1994, but fell from grace with the party hierarchy

Mathews Phosa

The former premier of Mpumalanga province was never a favourite of Mbeki. After law, business is Phosa's main interest and as premier he promoted investment, including a misplaced faith in gambling as a rich source of tax revenue.

In 1997 Phosa, 48, ran for deputy president of the ANC under Mbeki but withdrew in favour of Jacob Zuma. He was removed as premier by the ANC not long after Mbeki came to power

Cyril Ramaphosa

The 48-year-old former miners' union leader was central to the negotiations between the ANC and white government a decade ago to establish democratic government in South Africa.

He was secretary general of the ANC, but after he lost to Thabo Mbeki in the contest to become deputy president he turned down a cabinet post in Nelson Mandela's government. Although he played a leading role in writing the country's new constitution, he was kept from real power and went into business.

But he remains one of the most popular leaders with the rank and file. Although he retired as secretary general, he topped the voting by ordinary members to the ANC's national executive.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Meningitis kills 3,500 in Africa
fields.body:
Meningitis kills 3,500 in Africa

Meningitis sweeping across Africa has killed at least 3,500 people and caused a serious shortage of vaccine worldwide, the International Federation of Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies said yesterday.

"From the Red Sea to the Atlantic , 38,000 cases have been documented, but many more are likely," it said. AP, Geneva

David doffs a loin cloth

A replica of Michelangelo's David now wears a white loincloth after complaints by residents of Luke Alfred, Florida, when it was placed outside a local business. AP, Luke Alfred

US hostages freed in Kenya

The Kenyan police have rescued three Americans chained up for weeks by thugs who lured them to Africa with fake internet offers of business opportunities.

The police ambushed one of the kidnappers, who led them to a small house where the men were held. Reuters, Nairobi

webTitle: Saddam inquiry sparks debate on immunity

fields.headline: Saddam inquiry sparks debate on immunity
fields.standfirst: Special report: Iraq
fields.trailText: The disclosure that Scotland Yard is investigating President, Saddam Hussein and his deputy, Tariq Aziz, prompted a row yesterday about the immunity enjoyed by heads of state.
fields.body:
The disclosure that Scotland Yard is investigating President, Saddam Hussein and his deputy, Tariq Aziz, prompted a row yesterday about the immunity enjoyed by heads of state.

It also brought the allegation that it amounted to wasting police time. The Metropolitan Police Federation, which represents 26,000 officers in London, said the inquiry was "posture politics of the worst kind".

The police are investigating the possibility of bringing charges against President Saddam and Mr Aziz for alleged war crimes in connection with the taking of hostages, including Britons, in the run-up to the Gulf war.

Human rights campaigners and lawyers protested yesterday against a ruling by the attorney general, Lord Williams of Mostyn, that offers the Iraqi president virtual immunity. They said his view that heads of state were immune from prosecution was outdated.

Geoffrey Bindman, the human rights lawyer who represented Amnesty International in the Pinochet case, said the world had changed and such immunity no longer applied in cases of torture and other crimes against humanity.

Indict, a London organisation set up to try to bring Iraqi leaders to trial for war crimes, which has received $1.5m from the US Congress, passed a dossier to Lord Williams in September urging prosecution of President Saddam and Mr Aziz.

Lord Williams passed it on to Scotland Yard at the end of March. When they have read it they will have to decide, in consultation with Lord Williams and the crown prosecution service, whether to investigate further.

A Met spokeswoman said: "The attorney-general thinks it is worth pursuing: we are." She added: "There is still a long way to go."

But the chairman of the Metropolitan Police Federation, Glen Smyth, said: "The man is a dictator and until he is toppled nothing will happen - when he is toppled his own people will take such retribution that will render anything we do in this country as useless."

A police source, asked whether the investigation was just a paper exercise unlikely to lead to an indictment, was non-committal. But the source pointed to a statement from Lord Williams's office saying that there was no realistic prospect of convicting President Saddam, because he was "entitled to assert immunity from criminal prosecution".

Human rights campaigners said that Lord Williams ducked the issue of immunity because it is a can of worms.

The worry is that other leaders could face indictment: Vladimir Putin for Russian action in Chechnya, Jiang Zemin for China's in Tibet, Ariel Sharon for the West Bank and Gaza, and Tony Blair for Serbia and Iraq.

But Indict has received legal advice that heads of state no longer enjoy immunity for crimes against humanity. "We have to grasp the nettle," one of its legal team said.

Mr Bindman said: "The traditional view is that the current heads of state are immune from policies in any circumstances in English courts.

"But there are indications from some of the opinions of the Lords in the Pinochet case that this may not apply to proceedings from torture. Other trends in international human rights law show the position may have changed in relation to torture and other crimes against humanity."

The international criminal court, in the process of being set up, will not recognise the immunity of heads of state.

Ann Clwyd, the Labour MP who heads Indict and was seared by her travels among the Kurdish victims of the Iraqi government, said that yesterday's publicity had prompted more hostages to contact Indict.

She said: "It is pretty obvious that Saddam can claim immunity, but I do not believe British courts would uphold such a claim. After Pinochet, there is an international consensus that heads of state can be prosecuted. That is clear from the case against [the former Serbian leader Slobodan] Milosevic.

"There is some debate, but there is no reason why our country should not prosecute perpetrators of crimes against British citizens." She said the fear that leaders such as Mr Blair would be open to prosecution was an "enormous red herring".

fields.headline: To my darling grandchildren ...
fields.standfirst: Once a fortnight, Sir Henry Thornhill sent illustrated letters to his beloved grandchildren in India. Eighty years later, they paint an intimate picture of a Victorian gentleman's love for his family.  John Crace reports
fields.trailText: Once a fortnight, Sir Henry Thornhill sent illustrated letters to his beloved grandchildren in India. Eighty years later, they paint an intimate picture of a Victorian gentleman's love for his family. John Crace reports.
fields.body:
In any list of the Victorians' many achievements - the industrial revolution and colonising other people's countries, to name but two - bringing up children would feature somewhere near the bottom. At worst children were still seen as an exploitable commodity and at best as tabulae rasae to be shaped and bullied into the formality of their parents. And if affection and tenderness were thin on the ground in child/parent relation ships, then the atmosphere turned positively glacial where grandparents were concerned.

At least that's the archetypal image. But there were exceptions, and a notable one, that of Sir Henry Thornhill, has been given a new lease of life by his great-grandson and great-great grandsons on a website, Ultimate Grandparent, which they hope will both entertain and encourage other grandparents to re-evaluate the way they relate to their grandchildren.

Sir Henry Thornhill was the quintessential upperclass Victorian colonialist to the last inch of his 6ft 8ins physique. He was born in Agra, India in 1854, but was sent back to England to be educated at Eton. Later he joined the Indian army, where he collected various medals and rose to the rank of lieutenant-colonel, before retiring from active service and becoming a military magistrate for the Anderman Is lands and the North West Provinces of India. Having turned down a knighthood some years earlier on the grounds that "it would do little more than add 10% to my bills", he relented in 1911 and became a Knight Commander of the Indian Empire.

Sir Henry had three children, Cudbert, Charles and Madge. In 1912 his first grandchild, Teddy, was born. The nearest that Teddy could get to the word grandpa when he was little was "kaka"; and so Kaka was born. Although Kaka had moved back to England, his grandchild was still in India, and he took to sending Teddy a fortnightly postcard which included a story and carefully drawn illustrations. Over the next nine years, Teddy acquired three sisters, Margaret, Elizabeth and Anne, and they too joined Kaka's fortnightly mailing list.

Some 60 years later, in the mid-1980s, Charles Grimaldi was helping his father move house when he came across a collection of letters and cards gathering dust in a linen-bound album in the attic. "I realised they must have belonged to my mother, Margaret, who had died in 1972," he says, "but I had no idea whom they were from. My father thought they might be from my mother's grandfather and suggested I check with uncle Teddy. He produced two albums of his own, and calls to my cousins rounded up four further albums from my aunts, Elizabeth and Anne. Within a matter of weeks I had what is now believed to be the world's largest collection of illustrated correspondence."

A small book featuring a few of the stories was produced a short while later, but it wasn't until a family Sunday lunch last year that the Grimaldis decided to give their forebear a virtual existence. "Kaka was fascinated by technology," Charles says. "His letters often featured new inventions, such as Marconi's wireless, and he would have enjoyed using the internet and email as a way of keeping in touch. We now post a new original letter on the site each week, as well as writing new ones in his style, and people can also email us to have a notebook letter dedicated to their own grandchildren."

Keeping in touch is a phrase that Grimaldi uses frequently. "Even though Kaka was thousands of miles away from his grandchildren he made the effort to keep in touch," he says. "Quite apart from the fortnightly letters, he never missed a birthday or Christmas and would make sure that his cards and presents arrived on time. Moreover, he went out of his way to communicate in a way that the children could relate to, often by incorporating them both into the stories and the illustrations.

"He instinctively realised that it was up to him to make the relationship work, and that his grandchildren had no obligations to him. And it clearly paid off; later in life Teddy, then a grandfather himself, described Kaka as 'the best friend I ever had'."

Curiously, it seems that Thornhill was never as close to his own children as he was to his grandchildren. His children were sent to England to be educated, but there is no evidence to suggest that he carried on a similar intimate correspondence with them. Whether this was because he didn't have the time, or because he later regretted not knowing his children better and was determined not to make the same mistake with his grandchildren, is unclear. Maybe he just found the grandparent/grandchild relationship less complicated than that between parent and child, and felt freer to indulge a more childlike self.

Whatever the reason, Thornhill's legacy has had a profound impact on Grimaldi. "I enjoyed seeing both my grandmothers from time to time," he says, "but there was nothing special about our relationship. After finding the letters, my wife and I felt we should work harder at creating the time and space for our sons to form deeper relationships with their grandparents, and I think it has paid off as they are now good mates. I'm not a grandparent yet, but if and when I become one, I hope a little of Kaka's spirit will rub off."

But how will Thornhill's Beatrix Potter-meets-Rudyard Kipling short stories go down with a modern audience? "I think they still stand the test of time," says David McKee, the children's book author and illustrator best known for his Elmer the Elephant series. "They're clearly of the Indian Empire era, and some of the inventions might seem dated now, but they have a very natural feel to them and he's gone out of his way to find interesting things to write about. The illustrations are lively, fun and have been done with a nice light touch and I like the fact they aren't too slick."

webTitle: Hunter Davies on the family's pet tortoise

fields.headline: Out of my shell
fields.standfirst: Hunter Davies on how a tortoise bridged the generation gap
fields.trailText: Hunter Davies on how a tortoise bridged the generation gap.
fields.body:
I'm surprised our three children have turned out as well-adjusted and normal as they are, considering I was so horrible to them in their childhood. The times they moaned and groaned, accused me of unspeakable cruelty, depriving them of vital championships, the chance to establish meaningful relationships. All because I wouldn't let them have any pets.

Lots of reasons, really. Firstly, what I like doing best with animals is eating them. Secondly, I felt that bringing up children was hard enough without having to worry about any other creatures. It's true that animals don't play music, don't demand their own bike, computer, mobile phone, don't need driven anywhere, don't have awful friends or come home very late and very noisily, but even so, I didn't want to be responsible for them. Or the expense. Have you seen the price of cat food and dog food?

Caitlin, our eldest, really did cry herself to sleep when I refused her a puppy. Everyone else had one. It wasn't fair. Of course she would look after it herself, so she said. You'll hardly have any time I replied. You've got your little brother Jake to look after. When he in turn started begging for a pet, we then had Flora.

Towards the end of Flora's growing up days, when she was twittering on about a pet, I did something out of character. I got one. Not exactly a cuddly pet, the sort you can take to bed. We got her a tortoise.

One day, while feeding the tortoise, she got bitten by it. That was a surprise, as they don't have teeth. What they have it incredibly strong gums which, when clamped suddenly together, can easily draw blood out of little fingers. We then put a notice up on the front gate saying "Beware of Tortoise". I wanted to put it in Latin, like Cave Cane, but I only just got Latin O-level.

I can definitely recommend a tortoise, though it's a pointless recommendation. You can't buy them now: it's illegal for pet shops to import or sell tortoises. It means there are now tortoise burglars, who go round the gardens, nicking them in the night.

We called her Tortee, a very unimaginative name, but that's what Flora called her. We decided she was female because we got this book out of the library which told you how to sex tortoises. A jolly useful skill, never know when you might need it. It's to do with whether the underneath bit is concave of convex. Can't now remember which was which.

We put her to sleep in the autumn in the garage in a straw box, as directed, safe from marauders like rats. She woke up again in the spring, as nature redirected. Then in the third year, when it was time to put her down, we couldn't find her. She'd disappeared, done a runner or died. All winter we fretted, convinced she'd been eaten, then one day in late April, out she staggered, alive and well.

She's now 20 years old and every winter, we just let her put herself to sleep. We don't feed or water her. In fact she needs no care or attention. Ah, if only children were like that - we might have gone on to have had dozens.

She woke up yesterday, bang on time as ever, but this spring she got a bit of a surprise. There to greet her with me was Amelia - my granddaughter, now nearly two, daughter of Jake.

Amelia was a bit too young last year to enjoy the full pleasure of Tortee, but now she loves her. Together, we cleaned her up and oiled her shell. Yes, I know I said she needs no caring for, but this time is for pure cosmetic purposes. So she looks good on the camcorder.

Naturally I recorded the whole touching scene. It's what grandparents do. First time round, it was boring old silent Super Eight, using three minute films which I always seemed to burn holes in when I showed them. Now it's full frontal, digital Hollywood-quality movies, coming to a multiplex near your shortly, or after next Sunday's family supper, whichever comes first.

Amelia and I also gave Tortee some squashy strawberries. This again was for our pleasure, not Tortee's. She can survive perfectly well on, er I dunno, what do tortoises eat? Whatever, she's a good example of sustainability, keeping herself alive all these years on stuff in our garden.

Amelia loved feeding Tortee the strawberries and, of course feeding herself, and the colour does look awfully good on film.

So, what fun we had together, me and my granddaughter, playing with the tortoise. Good for companionship and relationships. After all these decades, perhaps I could become a pet person, in moderation ...

fields.headline: Storm in a teacup
fields.standfirst: Weardale
fields.trailText: Weardale.
fields.body:
We knew we were in for a painful few minutes when the black, ragged-edged clouds drifted towards us. Soon the first hailstones began to bounce off the road, so we took what shelter we could find in the lee of a leafless ash and braced ourselves for a bombardment.

For five minutes a torrent of hail hid the dale behind a curtain of grey, as the balls of ice piled up at our feet. The storm ended as abruptly as it had begun and within a few minutes coltsfoot flowers on the roadside verges opened again.

A fortnight of days like this has meant a slow start for the spring flora but at last cowslips, primroses, gorse, drifts of celandines and even daffodils are beginning to make an impact on road verges - our main walking routes while footpaths are closed. The daffodils are all introductions to the dale's native flora, mostly arriving via fly-tipping of garden waste, judging by their frequent appearance around farm gateways and under hedges. Many are vaguely familiar modern cultivars, but sometimes there are less perfect blooms with narrow twisted perianths.

They're almost certainly descendants of bulbs bred by William Backhouse, a wealthy Darlington banker and noted mid-19th century daffodil breeder. Backhouse lived at St John's Hall, on the moorland edge near Wolsingham and his passion for daffodil hybridisation generated over 200 named hybrids. Some of the long-trumpeted, double- flowered varieties that turn up in sites of long-abandoned dales gardens are incapable of producing seeds and might well be 150-year-old clones of forgotten cultivars that Backhouse would recognise as his own creations.

fields.headline: No 1,867
fields.standfirst: Miss France
fields.trailText: Miss France.
fields.body:
Psst! What?

The er, blonde, over there, is she er, y'know ... What? Giving you the eye?

No is she erm, yunno? Nudge, nudge, wink, wink? Oh, right. Yes. Yes. She's Miss France, 19-year-old Elodie Gossuin from Picardy.

Really? I thought it was Nicolas Lavannar, the 27 year-old transvestite cabaret dancer from Paris. Easy mistake to make.

Who told you that? I cannot reveal my sources.

Please. Oh, all right. Some bird in a bikini hobbled up to me in a pair of stilettos and whispered it in my ear.

Pah! Mere tittle-tattle! Are you sure? She's a pretty lass, but that's what they said about Liberace.

Did they? Maybe I mean Boy George.

But what I'm saying is you can't be sure in this day and age, can you? Men with long hair, girls with moustaches. I mean, that bloke from the Kinks, he was fooled easily enough. Yes, but Elodie is a bona fide lady. She has simply been the victim of a vicious slur campaign.

Zut alors! I know, I know. An article on the French internet newspaper L'Examineur, claimed that la belle Elodie was, in truth, un homme.

What sort of rotter would do that? Well, Mlle Gossuin has many rivals. And all of them have very long nails. She is battling it out for the crown of Miss Universe in Puerto Rico as we speak.

Shocking! Do you think it will come to blows? I'm sure it would boost the ratings figures if it did.

And how have the judges decreed that Elodie is, erm, of the fairer sex? She has been forced to sign a declaration, denying that she is anything other than a snake-hipped mademoiselle with a gruff voice.

And presumably her curly, girly handwriting swung it? No, no. I'm sure the fittings for the swimwear round allowed the judges the sort of verification they needed.

Do say: "I want to work with children."

Don't say: "I want to work with powerful cars."
