webTitle: G2: A rescue operation in Antarctic

fields.headline: On a wing and a prayer
fields.standfirst: In howling winds, pitch-black skies and temperatures approaching  -60C, the crew of a Twin Otter landed at the south pole yesterday to save a sick American. It was the first time a plane had touched down there in winter.  Oliver Burkeman  reports on one of the most dramatic rescue missions in the history of the Antarctic
fields.trailText: In howling winds, pitch-black skies and temperatures approaching -60C, the crew of a Twin Otter landed at the south pole yesterday to save a sick American. It was the first time a plane had touched down there in winter. Oliver Burkeman reports on one of the most dramatic rescue missions in the history of the Antarctic.
fields.body:
It takes an uncommon kind of personality to spend the winter at the Amundsen-Scott research station at the geographic south pole, a blue dome and a scattering of warehouses huddled around a runway scooped out of the ice, dwarfed amid the 5.4 million square miles of Antarctica. In March, when the days draw in and the 200-strong summer teams of US Navy scientists head home, the station is left to a tiny community of 40 or 50 support staff to endure six months of unbroken darkness and some of the most hostile weather on earth. Their navy colleagues call them the Winteroverers.

Captain Scott's diary entry on reaching the pole in 1912 - "Great God, this is an awful place!" - holds true today, and never more so than in winter, when summer highs of -18C plummet to -62C and below. The Winteroverers are trapped: even if the driving snow and rain were to relent enough to let an aeroplane land, the bitter cold would thicken its fuel to a useless sludge; wingflaps and propellors would cease to operate.

Routine struggles to assert itself against remoteness - there is a gym and a snooker hall, a TV room with a stack of films on video - but it is a superficial normality, easily pierced. Winterover Syndrome sets in - a clinically recognised cocktail of depression, irritability, insomnia and the Long-Eye, an amnesiac, dreamlike "fugue state". Station folklore abounds with stories of the time a Soviet scientist killed a colleague with an axe over a game of chess, or when a fight broke out 1,350km away, in the base at McMurdo Sound, and two navy cooks were attacked with hammers.

So when 59-year-old Ronald Shemenski passed a gallstone earlier this month, and the pains he had thought might be pancreatitis continued, his options were limited. He phoned his employers at Raytheon Polar Services in Colorado, which operates the facility for the navy, but the call came several weeks too late to catch a plane home for treatment. Shemenski took a course of antibiotics, but consultation with doctors in the US via telephone and the internet concluded that a life-threatening relapse could not be ruled out: surgery to remove his gall bladder would be needed.

Shemenski did not have the option of receiving surgery from the station's only medical doctor: he was the station's only medical doctor. At 10.34am local time on Tuesday - not that the word has much meaning there at the moment - a window in the weather was deemed suitable, and one of the Otters - carrying the two pilots, an engineer, replacement doctor Betty Carlisle and several containers of fuel - took off into the blackness. At Rothera and Amundsen-Scott, there was nothing to do but wait.

"Even in summer, landing is an in credibly tense business," says Sara Wheeler, who spent seven months in the Antarctic, and Amundsen-Scott, for her book Terra Incognito. "The pilots rarely switch off their engines, because if you turned the engine off you'd never get it on again." In winter, though, you just can't get out. "There aren't many places that is true of. And you've got to remember that you're at two-thirds the height of Mount Everest. Nothing works at that temperature: living takes longer, never mind landing aeroplanes."

Despite the tensions of coming and going, though, Wheeler remembers her time in the frozen south with deep affection. "To look at the southern lights there in the winter is an experience given to the few," she says. Winteroverers are usually only required to serve a single winter, but many end up returning.

At Amundsen-Scott, workers prepared for the Otter's landing by lighting debris and pots of fuel along a 600m strip of ice, and Penikett crossed his fingers.

Then, finally, shortly after 8pm local time, news crackled through from Amundsen-Scott to Christchurch and Calgary that the Otter was safely down - the first plane to land at the south pole during the polar winter. Heaters were fixed to the engines to prevent them freezing up.

In retrospect, the pilots were nonchalant. Asked to describe the flight, Penikett recalls: "One of them told me he lost several dollars playing crib. It was uneventful. The weather was pretty good, actually."

It was a day for dramatic landings: hours earlier, at the McMurdo Station on Ross Island, 800 miles away, a New Zealand Air Force aeroplane had evacuated four sick Americans in another operation that was highly unsual for the time of year.

The Amundsen-Scott crew rested for 10 hours yesterday, and Dr Carlisle began her six months of isolation. At 5.47pm, after a spot of fog and a small technical difficulty, the Otter took off for Rothera. All being well, they will be back there early today.

The disparate countries that share in the administration of the Antarctic under a 1959 treaty do not always get along perfectly ("Some say America behaves as if it owns the continent," says Wheeler). But the rescue missions seem, temporarily at least, to have united them. "When you're flying into darkness, at the limit of your range, you are utterly reliant on good-quality meteorological information, and what has come out of it so strongly is how the different agencies have networked, mostly using email, to provide accurate information," says John Hall, director of operations at the British Antarctic Survey. "I've just received a message saying this would make a terrific article for an American meteorological journal," he adds, voice cracking. "I'm sorry, I'm getting excited."

Shemenski's family have kept their counsel for most of the operation but last week Ronald's brother Robert, also a doctor, was persuaded to break his silence and issued a statement in which he expressed his concern for the safety of those taking part. "We are aware of the dangerous conditions under which they will be flying," he wrote. "Therefore, we hope they have a very safe round-trip journey."

And in conveying his family's encouragement to Shemenski's replacement at the research station, the statement ended with the warmest expression of support one can bestow on a Winteroverer at Amundsen-Scott.

"We wish Dr Betty Carlisle a very uneventful six months," it said.

webTitle: Alix Sharkey of The Wag club

fields.headline: The last dance
fields.standfirst: The Wag in London is closing down, to be turned into an Irish theme pub.  Alix Sharkey has fond memories of the club that epitomised the best - and worst - of the 80s
fields.trailText: The Wag in London is closing down, to be turned into an Irish theme pub. Alix Sharkey has fond memories of the club that epitomised the best - and worst - of the 80s.
fields.body:
The news that the Wag lease has been sold, and that this legendary Soho club will soon become an Irish theme pub, marks the end of an era in British nightlife. Since it opened in April 1981, it has been a focus for clubland innovation, a catalyst for racial integration, and a temple to unremitting hedonism. But more than this, this tiny nightclub also symbolised how profoundly our culture has changed over the past two decades.

Soho during the mid-70s was a very different country. Anyone frequenting the area was, by definition, of a dubious character. The area was known for brothels, strip-clubs, gambling and drinking dens, and nasty-looking blokes with big fists hanging around in shop doorways. There were no gay pubs, no fast food restaurants, no 24-hour espresso bars, no trendy members' clubs or all-night supermarkets. Neon signs were confined to Piccadilly Circus. Restaurants were few, snotty and expensive. Pubs were approached with caution if you weren't a local. As per the rest of the country, everything was shut by 11 pm.

Except nightclubs. Which is why, aged 17 and yearning for life beyond closing time, I set out from Essex for the West End. My mates reckoned the return ticket was a waste of money. "You'll get cut," they warned, as I boarded the train to Fenchurch Street.

In 1974 the Wag was still called the Whiskey-A-Go-Go. A huge black man who looked like an extra from Shaft stood outside in black leather jacket and a black fedora with a white silk band, hissing the words "coke, mary-jane" at passers-by. Very few, I think, got his drift.

Inside, up a steep flight of stairs, one wall was entirely covered in mirror tiles. The ceiling had been plastered crudely and painted silver-grey to resemble a lunar surface, while the supporting pillars were rough approximations of stalactites. On the dancefloor, a skinny bloke with a patchwork leather trenchcoat and flared jeans strutted his syncopated footwork, while gazing at the reflection of his own hennaed perm. A few girls in clogs and minidresses shuffled around him.

Soft drinks only, no licence, they said at the bar. A weasly-looking geezer at the next table put me straight. "Ask for a can from under the counter," he grinned. This advice earned me a light ale. Illegal drinking in a black dance club where people wore patchwork leather coats. Could it get any better?

It did. After I had sidled onto the dancefloor and spent an hour copying the bloke with the perm, there was a ruccus at the top of the stairs, followed by shouting and a mad scramble as everyone in the club seemd to dash into the men's toilets. By the time the police had actually gained admission, there were discarded joints all over the floor, and the sound of cisterns being flushed could be heard above the music. Two uniformed coppers half-heartedly frisked a couple of punters, while a detective in a mac disappeared into a back room (presumably to get his "drink"). They left as quickly as they had arrived. Fantastic. My first night in Soho, and I had witnessed a police raid.

Best of all, the Whiskey lasted till 1 am - desperately late, in those sad, forgotten grey days before punk, New Romantic and acid house. It seemed impossibly exotic, this former Soho R&B club which had been popular with Mods, fallen on tough times, and was now the home of an underground scene where young urban blacks and whites mixed together, rubbing elbows with drug dealers and pimps, dancing to records that were never played on radio, a new kind of brassy, sweaty dance music by people such as James Brown, Fatback Band, Ohio Players, and Kool & The Gang.

And when you got talking to doormen, they'd tell you how The Who and Jimi Hendrix would drink here, sometimes even jump on stage and jam, if they were in the mood and there was a decent act playing. But in truth, the Whiskey had never been as glamorous or as popular the Flamingo, the jazz and R&B club which occupied the ground floor premises beneath it. And toward the late 70s it seemed a mere shadow of itself, haunted by memories of better times.

In 1981 the Whiskey-A-Go-Go became the Wag club, when musician-turned-club-promoter Chris Sullivan and two business partners bought the lease. Sullivan, bored with the relentless monotony of the electronic music favoured by the New Romantic scene which had sprung up in The Blitz and St Moritz clubs, felt it was time to revive the music of his youth.

"At the time, all the West End clubs were playing shit pop music, so I wanted to open somewhere for me and people like me, a cool club with a great mix of music, whether it be jazz or funk or disco or reggae, a different vibe every night," he says. Sullivan's idea of a club that changed atmosphere, music and clientele every night was a fresh and radical departure, and soon there were queues down Wardour Street as a hip young crowd of art students, musicians, designers and shop assistants.

And so it was that hip-hop legends Grandmaster Flash and Afrika Bambaataa played their first UK gigs here, while Shane McGowan was clobbered onstage with a guitar by his co-singer Caitlin. Some of the most popular acts of the 80s graced the venue's tiny stage, including Fine Young Cannibals, Tom-Tom Club, and Bananarama. Sade played one of her earliest gigs at the Wag, and the Beastie Boys hammed it up here, too.

On the dancefloor, regulars included Boy George, John Galliano, Jean-Paul Gaultier, Neneh Cherry, Michael Clark and Leigh Bowery, as well as any number of models, stylists, photographers, style journalists and "fabulous nobodies". The trendy crowd led to accusations of snobbery and elitism, but Sullivan says it was simply a matter of looking after your own. "It was a tiny place, so of course we had always had people on the door picking out the regulars from the queue. That's why it was so successful, because we would never let any of the nights get swamped with newcomers. It's the people who make a club, and if you can keep your regulars the club will thrive."

During the mid-80s, the regular Friday night slot, Black Market, spawned the rare groove scene which did so much to fuel the growth of hip-hop and rap in the UK. It also disproved the "elitism" tag, says Sulllivan. "All the other West End clubs at that time turned young black kids away, the Wag was the only place that wanted them."

The club will close on May 5, but Sullivan will wrap up his fond memories with a final bash on May Day. "I'm going through my address book right now, sending invites out to all the old faces. But I don't regret it ending, no. Twenty years is a pretty good run, isn't it? You can't ask for better than that."

Guest list: memories of the Wag

Mike Pickering, DJ

It was a great club, really the best place to go in London at the time, if you were interested in music. I was living in Manchester and I still came down to London to go. You never had a bad night at the Wag, one of the best nights I remember was when I DJd there with Todd Terry in 1987, it was great night.

The worst thing about the Wag was if you were playing there you had to drag all the equipment two floors up a narrow staircase, which wasn't much fun.

Dylan Jones, editor of GQ

It was one of the most debauched places I've ever been, I think. I once saw a couple having sex on the dancefloor. It was one of the places to go to be seen when it opened in the early 80s. It was one of the last elitist clubs in London before the bigger places started opening up.

The last time I was there was about 10 years ago for a wake for Vaughn Toulouse who was in a band called Department S.

Robert Elms, DJ and writer

I went there quite a lot for the first three or four years. It very quickly became the centre of a very small world, it contrived to make you feel special for being in there and it was always nicely grotty. It was never some super slick place. I even DJd there a couple of times. I was one of the world's worst nightclub DJs. There were always great bands there. I saw Sade and the Pogues play in the very early days. It was the sort of club where the sweat stains would run down the walls and it had the atmosphere of a slightly shabby house party.

Charles Shaar Murray, music journalist

I always associated it with that very Thatcherite London club culture and despised it. I remember going there with a friend once, and after about an hour, we turned to each other and said: "We're standing here drinking over-priced beer, surrounded by fools, listening to records we've got at home." I'm always sorry to see a venue close down, but the Wag club was so associated with everything I hated about the 80s, so I have to say in this case I'd make an exception.

Kathryn Flett, writer

I remember once drunkenly wandering over to George Michael and saying in a rather sentimentally drunk way: "Thank you for writing Everything She Wants," and he looked utterly horrified at this weaving woman. I think it was the last time I was there. Aside from the Camden Palace, there wasn't a designated place of cool. There weren't members clubs then, but the Wag was a sort of unofficial members club with a horribly strict door policy, so when you went there you made a bit of an effort.

Jah Wobble, musician

I used to do a residency in the Wag. It was a very busy club with a charged-up sort of atmosphere. The door policy there was pretty good because there were still lots of pretty girls down there. The 80s were a horrible time, but of that period it was the only club that still seemed to have a slightly bohemian edge. I was a punk so I hated the whole new romantic scene, and the Wag became a bit of a home for me.

Dylan Jones, editor of GQ It was one of the most debauched places I've ever been, I think. I once saw a couple having sex on the dancefloor. It was one of the places to go to be seen when it opened in the early 80s. It was one of the last elitist clubs in London before the bigger places started opening up. The last time I was there was about 10 years ago for a wake for Vaughn Toulouse who was in a band called Department S. Robert Elms, DJ and writer I went there quite a lot for the first three or four years. It very quickly became the centre of a very small world, it contrived to make you feel special for being in there and it was always nicely grotty. It was never some super slick place. I even DJd there a couple of times. I was one of the world's worst nightclub DJs. There were always great bands there. I saw Sade and the Pogues play in the very early days. It was the sort of club where the sweat stains would run down the walls and it had the atmosphere of a slightly shabby house party. Charles Shaar Murray, music journalist I always associated it with that very Thatcherite London club culture and despised it. I remember going there with a friend once, and after about an hour, we turned to each other and said: "We're standing here drinking over-priced beer, surrounded by fools, listening to records we've got at home." I'm always sorry to see a venue close down, but the Wag club was so associated with everything I hated about the 80s, so I have to say in this case I'd make an exception. Kathryn Flett, writer I remember once drunkenly wandering over to George Michael and saying in a rather sentimentally drunk way: "Thank you for writing Everything She Wants," and he looked utterly horrified at this weaving woman. I think it was the last time I was there. Aside from the Camden Palace, there wasn't a designated place of cool. There weren't members clubs then, but the Wag was a sort of unofficial members club with a horribly strict door policy, so when you went there you made a bit of an effort. Jah Wobble, musician I used to do a residency in the Wag. It was a very busy club with a charged-up sort of atmosphere. The door policy there was pretty good because there were still lots of pretty girls down there. The 80s were a horrible time, but of that period it was the only club that still seemed to have a slightly bohemian edge. I was a punk so I hated the whole new romantic scene, and the Wag became a bit of a home for me.

fields.headline: No time for remorse
fields.trailText: Kavanagh QC | Your Money Or Your Life
fields.body:
John Mortimer said that he would not like to be a judge as it involved saying "Take Him Down!" to another human being. (This is what the judge says with some relish when you fail to persuade the jury that your wife committed suicide by hitting herself over the head with your niblick.) On the other hand, it is possible he was never asked, being notoriously given to levity. As a judge once said, summing up after what Mortimer had described as the most boring case of the year, "The sole purpose of the criminal law is not to amuse Mr Mortimer."

In Kavanagh QC (ITV), a one-off special, John Thaw is agonising over whether to become a judge. Levity is not the problem as Thaw's forte is irritability rising to rage. So what makes him hesitate?

He suspects that greatness is being thrust upon him to stop him appearing in an appeal against a murder conviction. It is a very minor murder. As his old acquaintance Laurence (now in government and answering to the more media-friendly Laurie) says, it is only about a drunk topping a tart. Until, that is, a private detective Mark Yelland (Tim Piggott-Smith) is let loose on it.

I have not seen much of Tim Piggott-Smith on TV recently and the resemblance to a ginger ferret was downright disturbing. Lean and lethal, he shot off down various dark and devious burrows and emerged licking his thin lips. He was very good indeed. This is, perhaps, not unrelated to the fact that I haven't seem much of him on TV recently. He fell on this role ravenously. It was a pleasure to see a lad with such a good appetite.

The whole setup was strangely similar to Perry Mason: Thaw as Perry Mason, the lawyer who never lost; Piggott-Smith as Paul Drake, the energetic private eye; and Samantha Bond as the devoted Della. Updated, of course, with a story about computers and spooks and spies and dirty tricks. I always have to watch anything about spies slowly (and anything with double agents twice) to grasp what is going on. It never seems to make much sense even when the detective, thank God, explains everything at the end, as he does here.

A beautiful Hungarian spy (oh, shut up) is murdered by her lover while trying to steal his data encryption system for British Intelligence. They, the intelligent British, have the hotel room under surveillance and see it all. So, naturally, they put the girl's body in the room of a wholly innocent man, who is found guilty of murder, and blackmail the real murderer into giving them access to his clients' coded business secrets. Stand up the boy who said "Oh, for crying out loud!"

(I still can't understand how the innocent man managed to get drunk on two cans and a miniature vodka or why Kavanagh and Yelland were prepared to work for nothing. But I'd really like to know where I can find two cans of beer, a miniature vodka, a QC and a detective like that.)

Directed by Jack Gold, the whole thing looked decorative and distinguished, if rather old-fashioned. I'd particularly like to mention Susannah Wise and Woytek Pszoniak, who gave their cameo roles more disturbing passion than they strictly deserved.

And so Kavanagh QC never got to be a judge. Never mind, old son, the wig would never have suited. You'd have looked like a basset hound.

Alwyn Hall would, you feel, be a trying house guest. In Your Money Or Your Life (BBC 2) he settled himself on the sofa and said "This is really nice. How much did it cost?" (James Barrie, who wrote Peter Pan, would not have been at a loss here. When he was paid for an article, he bought a piece of furniture and stuck a label underneath saying how much it cost and how he had earned it.) Sam and Alison were the proud, if insolvent, parents of triplets. Hall discovered that they had only kept their heads above water because - and it came as a revelation to them - their fond relations regularly baled them out.

Alwyn Hall is so cool, cats could take his correspondence course. I have only seen him at a loss once. He was standing in an ostrich farm, deprecating this as a sound investment. The ostriches gathered round batting their lashes at the camera. They nibbled his ear lobes and flirtatiously untied his bow tie. Ostriches have little grasp of book-keeping but they do have devastating eyelashes and excellent digestive systems. Which, on balance, is better.

fields.headline: Pick of the day
fields.trailText: Voices From Chernobyl | Why Did We Do That? | Costing The Earth
fields.body:
The 15th anniversary of the world's worst nuclear accident is marked by a sobering docu-drama, Voices From Chernobyl (2.15pm, Radio 4). Lucy Baldwyn has adapted the play from accounts given to the dissident Belarussian journalist Svetlana Alexievich. The central character is Ludmilla, the wife of a fireman sent to fight the blaze at the decrepit nuclear reactor. Lorraine Ashbourne brings enormous power and compassion to her portrayal of a woman whose personal tragedy is compounded by mindless official cruelty.

The precipitate abolition of urban tramways is Chris Bowlby's opening topic for the new series of Why Did We Do That? (8.0pm, Radio 4). Well may he ask. Since few car owners ever felt brave enough to challenge the trams' right of way, they could offer really rapid transit around London and other cities. The Europeans wisely hung on to theirs.

Alex Kirby travelled to Southern Mexico to conclude his inquiry into private companies that try to patent exotic plants used in traditional medicine. The Welsh firm bio-prospecting in Chiapas province is Molecular Nature Ltd. Its research director Robert Nash assures Costing The Earth (9.0pm, Radio 4) that the company's activities are altruistic. The Mayan Indians in the region don't believe him. They are convinced that patenting plants is a way to make them pay for what Nature provides for nothing.

fields.headline: Ulster fuel racket costs UK £300m
fields.standfirst: Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: Racketeers, some of them members of the Provisional IRA or the dissident Real IRA, are raking in millions of pounds from smuggling fuel across the Irish Republic's border with Northern Ireland.
fields.body:
Racketeers, some of them members of the Provisional IRA or the dissident Real IRA, are raking in millions of pounds from smuggling fuel across the Irish Republic's border with Northern Ireland.

The fraudsters make their profits from the huge difference in taxes and duties - about 35p a litre on diesel and 26p on unleaded petrol - between the two parts of the island, and the disparity between sterling and the punt. They also sell laundered agricultural diesel.

But their activities are costing the UK Treasury as much as £300m a year in unpaid taxes, drastically cutting oil companies' sales to Ulster and driving legitimate petrol retailers to the wall.

Overall oil imports have halved from 940,000 litres in 1994 to 440,000 last year, and BP now has just 51 outlets in the province, compared with 98 three years ago.

"Fuel smuggling is a major problem," said a police source. "It has its roots in republican areas, and Pira members and dissidents are involved, although it is not clear to what extent some are making money for their organisations or themselves. But by no means is the entire business run by paramilitaries."

Fuel smugglers are particularly active in the south Armagh and Derry areas, and industry insiders claimed a growing number of petrol sites were leased to paramilitaries.

Customs and excise seized 800,000 litres of illegal fuel (smuggled and laundered) in 1998-99 and 1.5m litres in 1999-2000.

Last year, customs officers raided 13 laundering plants, capable of producing a total of 40m litres.

Tom Nelis, of the customs press office in Belfast, said: "The fuel comes over the border in all sorts of vehicles, from curtain-sided lorries to specially concealed compartments. We even intercepted a truck with a skip welded on the back.

"They also buy diesel for use in agricultural vehicles, which is dyed red in the north and green in the south, with very cheap duty at about 2p a litre.

"They pass it through acid to bleach out the dye in specially constructed tanks, and then sell it on as normal diesel."

Mr Nelis also warned motorists that the chemicals used to launder diesel can wreck car engines. Noel Smyth, regional manager for the Petrol Retail Association, said that about 80 petrol stations in Northern Ireland had closed due to economic pressure in the past five or six years. There are now just over 700 stations.

He said smuggling was hurting legitimate retailers but they were also feeling the squeeze from the duty and currency differences, particularly in border areas, and increased competition from cut price supermarket petrol chains.

"The profit margin on legitimate fuel is very, very slim, an average of only 2p a litre on petrol and diesel," he said. "Many lorry fleet owners as well as ordinary motorists are filling up in the south as they are legally entitled to do.

"There is also growing competition from the likes of Sainsbury's and Safeway, where even lower profit margins are subsidised by grocery sales. But yes, smuggling is also a problem. There has been a 50% drop in fuel imports to Northern Ireland in the past six years and the take-up is coming from somewhere."

He said his members had long lobbied for a lowering of fuel duties in Northern Ireland to try to ease the situation, but the government had consistently rejected this as outside EU rules.

"The Stormont assembly is sympathetic to our plight but the power on this matter lies with the Treasury," he said.

fields.headline: Pick of the day
fields.trailText: The Blair Witch Project | Payback | The Shining
fields.body:
Films

The Blair Witch Project
(Daniel Myrick, Eduardo Sanchez, 1998)
8pm, Sky MovieMax

The celebrated micro-budget horror movie that reinvented the genre. It's the story of three film-makers - Heather Donahue, Michael Williams, Joshua Leonard - shooting a documentary in a remote Maryland wood, site of a gruesome legend. When night falls, things start to go bump, and a nameless horror closes in. Shot on jittery video, it's extremely creepy; the actors look terrified, and probably were - Myrick and Sanchez dumped them in the wood and started playing tricks on them.

Payback
(Brian Helgeland,1998)
10pm, Sky Premier

Mel Gibson had a serious falling out with director Helgeland, replacing him to reshoot and add new scenes to a thriller that isn't as hardboiled as it would like to be. It's a rerun of Point Blank, John Boorman's version of Richard Stark's novel The Hunter, with Gibson gamely filling the considerable Lee Marvin role as Porter, a hard-as-coffin-nails hood double-crossed and left for dead, and now returning to get even with the Outfit: "I just want my money back". Punchy entertainment, with veterans James Coburn and Kris Kristofferson among the heavies.

The Shining
(Stanley Kubrick, 1980)
10pm, Sky Cinema

Jack Nicholson is the writer-turned-caretaker going crazy in a sepulchral, snowbound, close-season hotel in Kubrick's superbly crafted ghost story, a highly expensive contrast to the cheapskate Blair Witch (above). For a while the heavy, brooding atmosphere is almost tangible, but Kubrick's elegant, disturbing images give way to a welter of blood, while Nicholson becomes laughably loopy. The final chase through the hotel's frozen maze is some compensation. Shelley Duvall is the terrorised wife, Danny Lloyd the son; Scatman Crothers a shiver-inducing clairvoyant.

Practical Magic
(Griffin Dunne, 1998)
11.45pm, Sky Premier

Yet more horrors for this evening, though this is soft stuff compared to what's gone before. Nicole Kidman and Sandra Bullock are sisters and descendants of witches; there's an ancient curse that kills off any men unfortunate enough to fall for female members of the family, so Aidan Quinn's lovelorn detective is in deep hubble-bubble trouble. This is plotting of abracadabra simplicity, and the two leads are upstaged by old hands Stockard Channing Dianne Wiest as their spinster aunts.

Sports

Live little football
6.30pm, British Eurosport

It's not often you get to see the cream of European talent playing on British shores but the Uefa Under-16 Championship is allowing us to do just that. And what a tiny treat it's turning into. England's group is on a knife-edge, with every team on three points after two games, and will be decided tonight when the home side take on Hungary in Huddersfield. The Hungarians have already beaten Italy; the Italians beat England 3-1.

fields.headline: Feedback
fields.standfirst:
Send letters to online.feedback@guardian.co.uk
Please include a full postal address and telephone number. Short letters stand a better chance of being published. No attachments, please.
fields.trailText: Your mail
fields.body:
Mum's word
As a stay-at-home mother and freelance journalist who regularly uses the web, I was appalled at Deborah Bee's patronising piece on mothers and the internet (Online April 19). All the examples she gives of why mothers don't use it - such as out-of-date websites and the difficulty in finding information - apply to everyone, not just mothers. The idea that mothers are a special case - "unadventurous" in the words of one of her interviewees - is outrageous.

To make matters worse, she says that mothers will soon be able to compare notes with other mothers on the web about how to "get a baby to sleep" or "give up chocolate". How insulting can you get? I've got better things to use the web for - and if I want to talk about babies, I'll go down to the local mother-and-baby group, thank you.
Dr Kim Thomas
kim@concat.demon.co.uk

I disagree with Deborah Bee; the net fits in very well with working mothers' time-saving strategies. Women multitask better than Windows and it is perfectly possible to order groceries from Tesco, breastfeed the baby and help the 11 year old with his homework at the same time. The problem comes when you try to get the five year old's supper as well.
Sue Jackson
(a working mother, online since 1996)
s.jackson@dial.pipex.com

Pogo head
Pogo's Tim Critchley wonders why "no other phone company or network has thought of using compression to offer faster mobile internet access before?" (Online April 19). Of course they have.

Wap already uses a binary tokenisation to keep the size of headers and tags down. The Wap forum has developed a special image format (WBMP) optimised for effi cient transmission over low bandwidth networks.

And this points us at Pogo's Achilles heel - images. Pogo will have transmit jpegs to give a coherent full access to HTML pages, but jpegs are already efficiently compressed so there's not much mileage they can give to the largest component of web pages. Of course, they could process the web pages into slimmed down versions, but AvantGo and others already deal with this.

So what is Pogo? A mobile phone that is mostly taken up with a high-definition screen that provides HTML viewing rather than WML (Wap) viewing. At £100 or £150 a pop it could definitely become the handset of choice compared to Wap over GSM, if only for the better screen quality and much larger range of web pages - just don't let them think no one else uses compression and don't believe it'll be like your 56k modem.
Bill Rivers
powerexe@btinternet.com

Text only
I think Douglas Rushkoff (Online April 19) is perhaps missing the point of the internet. While it's great to have web pages appear instantly, they do not necessarily offer good value for content. Adverts aren't the only thing you lose out on - pictures convey the news sometimes just as well as words.

Complexity isn't derived by imagery, rather by bad imagery. Wireless devices don't rely on Unix commands - they use graphical menus. Graphics are generally better suited for the masses - hence the success of Windows.

If you need any further proof of this look to Wap, a text-only service and all but dead - and it's not because of lack of support - it's simply not what the public wants. If all we had on TV was Teletext/Ceefax, TV too would have faced a premature death. It's the richness of multimedia that the public wants - no matter what the cost. There's a place for plain data, maybe even for the mass market - but news isn't it.
Chris Hudson
chrishudson3@cwcom.net

Douglas Rushkoff wrote last week: "This simple, open and accessible information architecture is the closest you can get today to the internet that those of us who were online in the early 90s keep talking about." I still use Lynx (on Linux and Windows) quite a lot and that's pretty close as far as I'm concerned. This is quite apart from the fact that the machine is a lot more useable than most of the Wap-enabled hardware out there now. Lots of us still use text mode browsing when we want something quickly.

That aside, the tone of the article is exactly right. Good sites realise the "graphics problem" and provide alternative versions of content (BBC News Lo-Graphics for instance).

I just wish more knew about good web design and development so they could do the same.
Darren Stephens
d.stephens@dcs.hull.ac.uk

Douglas Rushkoff made some good points about the usefulness of the simple New York Times and Wall Street Journal news sites. So - when will the Guardian be providing a site like that?
Eric Thompson
ej.thompson@btinternet.com

Online replies : try www.theguardian.com/pda/avantgo/.

Movie mystery
I read with interest your article E-movie (Online, April 19). Can I tell you that for some time now I have been happily copying my DV movies from camera to PC (out) and from edited Adobe Premiere timeline back to (in) DV tape in my Sony camera. The new Sony DCR-TRV30E is thus not the first Sony camera with DV "in" and "out". How is this possible? I own a Sony DCR-TRV20E and have done for some time.
Tony Hill
tonyhill@brit.croydon.sch.uk

To make matters worse, she says that mothers will soon be able to compare notes with other mothers on the web about how to "get a baby to sleep" or "give up chocolate". How insulting can you get? I've got better things to use the web for - and if I want to talk about babies, I'll go down to the local mother-and-baby group, thank you. Dr Kim Thomas kim@concat.demon.co.uk I disagree with Deborah Bee; the net fits in very well with working mothers' time-saving strategies. Women multitask better than Windows and it is perfectly possible to order groceries from Tesco, breastfeed the baby and help the 11 year old with his homework at the same time. The problem comes when you try to get the five year old's supper as well. Sue Jackson (a working mother, online since 1996) s.jackson@dial.pipex.com Pogo head Pogo's Tim Critchley wonders why "no other phone company or network has thought of using compression to offer faster mobile internet access before?" (Online April 19). Of course they have. Wap already uses a binary tokenisation to keep the size of headers and tags down. The Wap forum has developed a special image format (WBMP) optimised for effi cient transmission over low bandwidth networks. And this points us at Pogo's Achilles heel - images. Pogo will have transmit jpegs to give a coherent full access to HTML pages, but jpegs are already efficiently compressed so there's not much mileage they can give to the largest component of web pages. Of course, they could process the web pages into slimmed down versions, but AvantGo and others already deal with this. So what is Pogo? A mobile phone that is mostly taken up with a high-definition screen that provides HTML viewing rather than WML (Wap) viewing. At £100 or £150 a pop it could definitely become the handset of choice compared to Wap over GSM, if only for the better screen quality and much larger range of web pages - just don't let them think no one else uses compression and don't believe it'll be like your 56k modem. Bill Rivers powerexe@btinternet.com Text only I think Douglas Rushkoff (Online April 19) is perhaps missing the point of the internet. While it's great to have web pages appear instantly, they do not necessarily offer good value for content. Adverts aren't the only thing you lose out on - pictures convey the news sometimes just as well as words. Complexity isn't derived by imagery, rather by bad imagery. Wireless devices don't rely on Unix commands - they use graphical menus. Graphics are generally better suited for the masses - hence the success of Windows. If you need any further proof of this look to Wap, a text-only service and all but dead - and it's not because of lack of support - it's simply not what the public wants. If all we had on TV was Teletext/Ceefax, TV too would have faced a premature death. It's the richness of multimedia that the public wants - no matter what the cost. There's a place for plain data, maybe even for the mass market - but news isn't it. Chris Hudson chrishudson3@cwcom.net Douglas Rushkoff wrote last week: "This simple, open and accessible information architecture is the closest you can get today to the internet that those of us who were online in the early 90s keep talking about." I still use Lynx (on Linux and Windows) quite a lot and that's pretty close as far as I'm concerned. This is quite apart from the fact that the machine is a lot more useable than most of the Wap-enabled hardware out there now. Lots of us still use text mode browsing when we want something quickly. That aside, the tone of the article is exactly right. Good sites realise the "graphics problem" and provide alternative versions of content (BBC News Lo-Graphics for instance). I just wish more knew about good web design and development so they could do the same. Darren Stephens d.stephens@dcs.hull.ac.uk Douglas Rushkoff made some good points about the usefulness of the simple New York Times and Wall Street Journal news sites. So - when will the Guardian be providing a site like that? Eric Thompson ej.thompson@btinternet.com Online replies : try www.theguardian.com/pda/avantgo/. Movie mystery I read with interest your article E-movie (Online, April 19). Can I tell you that for some time now I have been happily copying my DV movies from camera to PC (out) and from edited Adobe Premiere timeline back to (in) DV tape in my Sony camera. The new Sony DCR-TRV30E is thus not the first Sony camera with DV "in" and "out". How is this possible? I own a Sony DCR-TRV20E and have done for some time. Tony Hill tonyhill@brit.croydon.sch.uk

fields.headline: Eastern learning
fields.standfirst: Ken McNaught is sales director for NIIT's UK knowledge solutions business. NIIT is India's top offshore IT developer
fields.trailText: Ken McNaught is sales director for NIIT's UK knowledge solutions business. NIIT is India's top offshore IT developer
fields.body:
Who has adapted best to the vagaries of e-commerce? The bubble's certainly burst a bit but the reason even Yahoo didn't turn a profit is that it is trying to "buy clients" and increase its customer base. There's no doubt it could change to make a profit in the short-term but it would mean losing market share in the long-term. In the same way that AOL probably isn't making much money from its £15 a month unlimited internet offer, but it is going to get people for life. In my field of online learning there are companies trying to sell to individuals, expecting them to spend hundreds of pounds on online courses. That's not going to happen because we expect to get it for nothing. The winning model is companies that are selling online learning to other companies or to universities and schools. The money transaction is B2B which then happens to be passed on to the end user for "nothing".

Does the UK lag behind the rest of the world in IT terms? We have some of the best IT people in the world. That's why companies such as Hewlett-Packard and Psion have their research facilities here. Where we do lag behind is in the number of people with IT skills. There ought to be some qualification in the UK for people without degrees but who are good IT programmers. In India we run the GNIIT programme which is recognised as the No1 IT qualification and we get more than 400,000 students a year. Of course theirs is a very process-driven culture but maybe here we could be more flexible in our approach to finding people with IT skills.

Was the failure of Wap to capture the public imagination a surprise? I'm sure there are some people for whom it works very well but, at the moment, it's more of a gimmick. Prior to NIIT I worked for an organisation that was rolling out the earliest examples of Wap content and it was a railway timetable! The emerging Bluetooth and 3G technologies look set to deliver more of the "look and feel" to which Wap aspired.

How did you become involved with computers? I had a Sinclair ZX81 so early that when I phoned Sinclair to ask for a 16k RAM pack they wanted to know how I'd got my hands on one. I was using Husky handheld computers in the mid-80s then progressed to a Sun Spark Station 2. I'm currently using a Toshiba Satellite Pro 4300, which is a lovely bit of kit. I also use a Pentium III Packard Bell system at home with the whole electronic office and ISDN link.

Any favourite websites? I like the e-learning guru Eliot Masie's site. There's also www.people performancemagazine.com and I like to check on Mr Coulthard's progress at www.itv-f1.com.

Visit: www.niit.com

fields.headline: Netiquette for email and news
fields.trailText: Start here...
fields.body:
Everyone who joins a new group or society knows there are certain conventions that must be observed, and the internet is no exception.

One difference in the virtual world is that there are no unwritten rules. In fact, the rules are written all over the place, as guides to "netiquette". It is a good idea to learn them, even if you plan to break them.

The problem with netiquette is that it is based mainly on the internet that existed 10 years ago. In those days, many people had slow connections, and computers had very little memory.

Resources were scarce, so there was peer pressure not to waste or misuse them. Brief notes were good; long formal letters were bad. Long "sigs" were bad. Chain letters and "spam" (unsolicited commercial email) were very bad - and they still are, especially if you are paying by the minute to download them.

There is a curmudgeonly tendency that still wants to be economical with the content of emails and newsgroup postings. In this view, everything should be sent as plain text. However, many people now have powerful computers and fast internet connections, both at home and in the office. They don't want to be limited to a few lines of plain text. Instead, they want to use different typefaces and coloured backgrounds - "rich text" - and attach pictures or even video clips to their messages.

The sparks fly, of course, when "rich texters" send their bloated encoded email and graphics to people who are diehard plain text users. Me, for example.

Most email software lets you choose whether to send messages as plain or rich text - usually HTML, the markup language used to create web pages. In Outlook Express, you can set this globally. Go to Tools, select Options, and click the tab marked Send. This shows a properties sheer with radio buttons for Mail Sending Format and News Sending Format.

You should select Plain Text for both options. With mail, you cannot assume that a recipient's mail software will be able to understand HTML. Almost all mailing lists and Usenet newsgroups also run on plain text.

However, you will still be able to use rich text whenever you like. When you start a new letter, simply select the Format menu, and choose the format you want.

Before closing the dialogue box, click the button marked Plain Text Settings. This lets you set a line width. Most software can handle lines at least 80 characters long, but it is better to choose a shorter number, such as 72. Long lines tend to get broken in transmission, especially when they are subsequently quoted and have angle brackets (>) added to the front.

While netiquette still insists on using plain text unless it is mutually agreed otherwise, it makes sense to reply to letters using the format in which they were sent.

Outlook Express 5 provides exactly this option as a tick-box item on the Send sheet. America Online's latest software stupidly sends both: AOL users should read the Unofficial AOL Email FAQ (file of Frequently Asked Questions) at http://members.aol.com/adamkb/aol/mailfaq.

The other thing that causes friction is the use of "sigs" or signature files. A sig is - or was - a piece of text that could be added automatically by the software to the end of every email message you sent.

Netizens typically used a sig to save retyping contact details: name and address, job title, phone numbers and so on. Many sigs also include a brief, sometimes witty, quotation, such as: "Money is the root of all evil. Send $9.95 for more info"; or "Any really good job is one you can do in your pyjamas" (Scott Adams of Dilbert fame).

Almost all email software lets you add a sig, and some programs let you have different sigs for different purposes.

To add a sig in Outlook Express 5, go back to Tools|Options and click the Signatures tab. Click the button marked New, and type or copy your sig into the lower box, marked Edit Signature.

It is also possible to use a file as a sig, by clicking the lowest radio button and browsing to the file you want to add.

This is useful for sending vCards or "virtual business cards", which enable recipients to load your contact details straight into an addressbook without retyping anything. The facility can be, and is, misused to send multimedia sigs that lookmuch like advertising banners.

Sigs are great for people you only write to occasionally, but if you see the same sig many times a day, it becomes more than a little tedious.

Large sigs can also be a waste of resources: it is not unusual for sigs to be much bigger than the messages they are attached to.

As with the use of plain text and rich text, using sigs is now less a matter of netiquette than of common sense.

It is a pity there is not more of it about.

fields.headline: Hiroshi Teshigahara
fields.standfirst: Japanese director whose erotic masterpiece won an Oscar nomination
fields.trailText: Japanese director whose erotic masterpiece won an Oscar nomination.
fields.body:
Great surprise was expressed in some quarters when Ang Lee was nominated for Best Director for Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon at this year's Academy Awards, because of the extreme rarity of a foreign director of a non- English-language film being considered for an Oscar. Yet, in 1966, along with David Lean, William Wyler, John Schlesinger and Robert Wise (the eventual winner for The Sound of Music), there was an obscure Japanese director, Hiroshi Teshigahara, who has died of leukaemia aged 74.

The film for which Teshigahara was nominated, and which remains his masterpiece, was Woman In The Dunes (Suna No Onna, 1964), only his second feature, made independently for $100,000. This poetic, erotic allegory told of an entomologist (Eiji Okada) from Tokyo, who finds an attractive young widow (Kyoto Koshoda) living at the bottom of an enormous sandpit on a deserted beach. He becomes her prisoner and has to carry out the Sisyphean task of endlessly shovelling sand to avoid being engulfed, wondering whether he is "living to shovel or shovelling to live". Eventually, he becomes like one of the insects he has been studying. Teshigahara and his cinematographer, Hiroshi Segawa, effectively used extreme close-ups until the characters almost become part of the landscape.

Adapted by Kobo Abe from his celebrated novel of the same name, the film deals with one of the recurrent themes in modern Japanese literature: the conflict between eastern and western traditions. The westernised scientist gradually gives up material things, and finally accepts his position in the true order of the universe. Both Kobo and Teshigahara had moved away from Marxist ideology (they had been members of the Japanese Communist party in the 1950s) towards a more Taoist philosophy.

The formal beauty of the film reflected the director's artistic background. His father was Sofu Teshigahara, a grand master of the Sogetsu school of ikebana (the art of flower arranging), transforming it into a highly expressive art form. Hiroshi studied painting at the Tokyo Art Institute, where he became interested in surrealism and the avant-garde.

After a stint as a film critic, he studied cinema technique, making his debut as director of a short documentary on the painter Hokusai (1953). In direct contrast, he shot another short on the middle-weight boxer José Torres in New York in 1959.

Teshigahara described his first feature, The Pitfall (1961), made by his own production company for a meagre $50,000, as "a documentary fantasy". It was written, like most of his films in the 1960s, by Kobo Abe, and revealed a preoccupation with the bizarre. After Woman In The Dunes gained him his Oscar nomination and the Special Jury prize at Cannes, Teshigahara seemed destined to take his place among his contemporaries, Nagisa Oshima, Shohei Imamura and Yoshishige Yoshida, as a leading light of Japanese cinema. It didn't happen.

His following two films, both based on Kobo Abe novels, The Face Of Another (1966) and The Man Without A Map (1968), sombre meditations on alienation and the loss of identity, had only limited success. The former, the more interesting film, was about a scientist whose face was disfigured during an industrial explosion. Subsequently, he hides behind a handsome mask and, in this disguise, he seduces his wife and then accuses her of adultery.

Teshigahara's next film, Summer Soldiers (1972), which he also photographed, followed the path of an American GI (Keith Sykes) stationed in Japan, who deserts in order to avoid being sent to Vietnam. He and other Americans hide out with Japanese families, constantly moving from one household to the next to avoid arrest. Questions about the American action in Vietnam are raised that were ignored by American films of the time. Shot in a cinema verité style, the film's main weakness lies in the passive performance of the leading actor, a folk-rock singer from Kentucky.

After the film failed, Teshigahara decided to concentrate on the traditional arts, such as pottery. In 1980, after the death of his father and sister, Teshigahara became head of the Sogetsu school, which has 450,000 students. However, he didn't abandon film-making altogether, making a feature-length documentary on the Catalan architect Antonio Gaudi in 1984.

The film, full of mesmeric pans and lingering takes, ends with the words, "Everything comes out of the Great Book of Nature. Anything created by human beings is already in there."

His last two films were Rikyu (1989), about the conflict between a petty warlord and a distinguished master of the ancient art of the tea ceremony, and Basara: The Princess Goh (1992); in 1993, he directed a production of Turandot at the Lyons Opera.

Teshigahara is survived by his wife, Toshiko Kobayashi, a former actress, and two daughters.

Hiroshi Teshigahara, film director and artist, born January 28 1927; died April 14 2001

fields.headline: Regina v Saddam
fields.standfirst:
This case may be beyond Scotland Yard

Special report: Iraq
fields.trailText: Saddam Hussein and members of his Iraqi regime have few defenders in this country. Nobody seeks to justify the atrocities perpetrated by Saddam's forces in Kuwait in 1990-91 or, to give another egregious example, his use of chemical weapons to murder Kurdish civilians.
fields.body:
Saddam Hussein and members of his Iraqi regime have few defenders in this country. Nobody seeks to justify the atrocities perpetrated by Saddam's forces in Kuwait in 1990-91 or, to give another egregious example, his use of chemical weapons to murder Kurdish civilians. To suggest that Saddam is responsible for numerous crimes is hardly a controversial position. Thus the attorney general's decision, prompted by a US-funded lobbying group, to ask Scotland Yard to investigate the specific cases of British subjects taken hostage on Saddam's orders in Kuwait and Iraq in 1990 seems on the face of it justifiable.

Indeed, this argument can be logically extended much further. In ordering a massive allied air assault on Baghdad in January 1991, the then US president, George Bush Snr, knowingly endangered the lives of Iraqi civilians - and many died as a result. A similar investigation could be mounted against him. Likewise, Vladimir Putin's conduct in Chechnya, Jiang Zemin's policy in Tibet, and Tony Blair's actions in Serbia in 1999 all could be said to provide grounds for investigation of possible criminal wrongdoing or worse. Perhaps the Yard should haul in the Israeli ambassador for questioning; he is, prima facie , associated with an apparent policy of unlawful killing in the Occupied Territories. Such cases will not be brought, of course, because they involve the British government, Britain's friends or countries that Britain dares not offend. Saddam and his close associate, Tariq Aziz, in contrast, are politically defenceless targets in Britain (as, to a lesser extent, was Augusto Pinochet).

This is no basis on which to pursue global justice. A preferable, less selective course would be action via the UN's international criminal court which will have impartial, apolitical jurisdiction in all such cases, big and small. Nor does the court's statute allow heads of state to claim immunity from prosecution. The sooner the ICC starts work, the better.

fields.headline: Talking dirty
fields.trailText:
"The reason Bridget is such a sexy little minx is because she looks like a real woman"
Tony Parsons, Mirror
fields.body:
"The reason Bridget is such a sexy little minx is because she looks like a real woman ... Bridget Jones is not merely a fat cow. She cares about her weight, but not too much. We are so accustomed to seeing women who do not look very real - women who are starved to perfection for the cover of Vogue or worn to a frazzle in the gym - that we have almost forgotten what a real woman looks like. A real woman looks like Bridget Jones. And [Renée] Zellweger is far sexier with some meat on her full English breakfast, just as Geri Halliwell was more sexy as buxom Ginger Spice in a Union Jack mini dress than she is now. The model girls who grace the glossy magazines are undeniably beautiful. But it is a beauty that makes you feel like standing back and admiring it. Bridget Jones has the kind of beauty that makes you feel like getting stuck in"
Tony Parsons, Mirror

"I was very honest with him. He wanted to know why I hadn't sold my work to him and I said: 'Because you did marketing for Thatcher.' And he said: 'But I've also done marketing for other things, including Tampax.' And I said: 'Well, stick to Tampax! Tampax is more admirable' "
Tracey Emin on her first meeting with Charles Saatchi, W magazine

"Most women would find the prospect of dying wrinkled a lot worse than the prospect of dying of dementia"
A San Francisco dermatologist on why bovine collagen implants are still in demand, despite fears of mad cow disease, Daily Express

"Should we really go gooey over the fruits of these long-lived loins? Nature sensibly decreed a cut-off point for would-be mothers; the menopause is God's way of telling you you don't want to get up three times a night to apply teething gel. But men can go on siring into old age - and, being men, just because they can, they do"
Allison Pearson on Phil Collins, who has just become a father again at 50, Evening Standard

"I've been to three of these events. I can tell you, she's gorgeous. There's no doubt in my mind that she's a woman. You can tell by her frame, the way she walks and the Adam's apple"
A beauty pageant official lists the crucial criteria for identifying a real woman amid reports that the new Miss France is, in fact, a man, Daily Express

webTitle: Women: A husband's fight against  a rape case

fields.headline: 'I had to fight for her, she couldn't fight for herself'
fields.standfirst: Last year, a woman was raped in a nursing home. Last week, thanks to her husband's refusal to give up the case, her attacker was jailed.  Diane Taylor reports
fields.trailText: Last year, a woman was raped in a nursing home. Last week, thanks to her husband's refusal to give up the case, her attacker was jailed. Diane Taylor reports.
fields.body:
Clara Parker (not her real name) is horribly traumatised by a rape carried out last year by John Archibald at the Buckinghamshire nursing home where she is looked after. She is in the advanced stages of Huntington's disease, a condition that impairs mental and physical ability. Her husband Michael (not his real name), a BBC presenter, had to fight to persuade the crown prosecution service to take on the case but at Reading crown court on Friday, when Archibald was jailed for three years for the rape, Michael had little time to feel vindicated nor Clara to feel safe. Moments after the sentence was passed, Archibald's brother Mark turned to Michael, tried to hit him and said: "I'll get you for this. I'll have you."

The next day, a minibus was burnt out in an arson attack outside the home. There is no evidence that it's connected but police are investigating.

Bringing to court any sort of rape case is fraught with difficulties and only around one in 10 of the rapes reported to police results in a prosecution. When the victim is especially vulnerable because of a mental or physical illness or a learning disability, the chances of getting a case to court slump even further. The Youth Justice and Criminal Evidence Act 1999 contains new provisions to help vulnerable adults give evidence in court, such as judges removing wigs, the erection of screens between witnesses and defendants and video recordings used as evidence. These provisions were supposed to be in place by the end of last year but a Home Office spokesman admits implementation of most could be another year away.

Progress has also been slow in the proposed reform of the Sex Offences Act which recommends strengthening the law in cases where a person in a position of trust or responsibility carries out abuse. The Department of Health has guidelines for local authorities to protect vulnerable adults who are abused, but there is no legal requirement to implement them.

Tamsin Cottis of Respond, which provides counselling for people with learning difficulties who have been abused, says: "Decisions can be taken very early on that women like Clara wouldn't make good witnesses. People like her are more vulnerable than others to abuse, yet when they are victims of sex crimes, it is much harder for them to get justice."

The assumption that Clara would not be a good witness dogged Michael when he tried to get her rape brought to court. Though the crime was witnessed by a wheelchair-bound patient and there was DNA evidence, the CPS said Clara's evidence might not be "reliable" because she is a nursing home patient.

Michael and Clara met in the early 60s when both worked as journalists on a local paper. They married in 1962 but problems began when Clara developed severe mood swings and obsessional behaviour in her late 40s. The couple separated in the late 80s and it wasn't until 1995 that Clara was diagnosed with Huntington's disease. Michael returned, saying he felt responsible for looking after her, and in January last year she moved into the Buckinghamshire nursing home.

The rape took place when another resident invited Clara, a compulsive smoker, into his room for a cigarette. John Archibald, who was visiting a relative, and his brother Mark came too. Mark handed Clara two cannabis cigarettes. She had never tried the drug before and did not know it was in the cigarettes. After smoking them, she tried to return to her room but John Archibald forced her on to the bed and raped her twice.

Clara says the attack is the worst thing that has ever happened to her. "I felt so unclean and they hurt me so badly. My body took weeks to recover."

The next morning staff told Michael what had happened and Clara was taken to a local rape centre where she was examined by a police doctor and video evidence was taken. However, the CPS decided not to prosecute and it took Michael four months to persuade them to change their minds. "I believe she was singled out because she was vulnerable. I had to fight for her, she couldn't fight for herself. I kept insisting that it was their duty to pursue the case, that they had DNA evidence, a witness and my wife's testimony."

The case finally came to court last November and the jury convicted John Archibald of the rape. Clara did not give evidence in court.

Often the only course open to a victim if the CPS decides not to pursue the case is to take out a civil action, not against the perpetrator but, in a case like Clara's, against the nursing home for allowing visitors to be left alone with her without supervision. And victims are sometimes unable to communicate what has happened to them or are too terrified to talk.

Christiana Horrocks, director of Voice, which provides support for adults and children with learning disabilities who have been abused, says: "Sometimes the reasons given to victims to stop them talking are even more evil than the abuse. One young woman was raped by a man who knew her mother was in remission from cancer. He told her if she said anything about the attack, her mother would die from the cancer."

Harriet Wistrich, a solicitor who advises women making complaints about the way their rape investigations have been handled, says women need to be "perfect victims" to avoid running into difficulties if the case goes to court. "Saying a woman consented is often used by the defence," she points out. "Even if there is evidence of serious bruises and other injuries, the defence may say: 'She just liked it rough.' There are so many rapes in children's and residential homes, and psychiatric institutions, because rapists know they can get away with it there."

Janine (not her real name), a 26-year-old who had been receiving treatment for severe anorexia and a personality disorder, was at a low ebb when she met a man who was kind to her. She had walked out of a hospital psychiatric ward and had nowhere to go. He offered her a bed for the night at the hostel he was staying at. Once there, he trapped her in his bedroom and force-fed her cannabis and crack before raping her four times. The drug cocktail paralysed her for several hours and it was only when her attacker finally fell asleep that she managed to half walk, half fall out of his bedroom, collapsing in the hostel office. Her heart stopped but she was resuscitated and taken to hospital.

"I told the staff what had happened and they reported it to the police. But the officer who came to see me was so hard. He tried to get me to sign a form withdrawing the rape allegations but I refused. He said if I didn't sign, I would put my family through hell and that I already had a history of that because of my anorexia. He said if the CPS threw the case out, they could get me for wasting police time."

Last December, two measures were introduced to protect alleged rape victims in court: restriction of admissible evidence about their sexual history and an end to cross-examination by the alleged rapist. But there is still a long way to go before all women, and particularly those who are most vulnerable, can get a fair hearing. As Janine says: "People are hit at their lowest ebb and it's when you get to that point that you are least likely to get support from the criminal justice system."

fields.headline: Sacked father wins tribunal payout
fields.trailText: A father of two sacked by his employer for taking time off after the birth of his second child, yesterday won compensation at an industrial tribunal.
fields.body:
A father of two sacked by his employer for taking time off after the birth of his second child, yesterday won compensation at an industrial tribunal.

Backed by the GMB union, bus driver Dean Matthews claimed his dismissal was in breach of recent family-friendly legislation, even though he had been with Stagecoach North East for less than twelve months. Mr Matthews, 23, of Sunderland received a £2,000 payout.

A union statement said he had missed a shift when his partner, Karen Priest, was in labour in August last year.

It said he returned home after the birth to find a letter telling him a disciplinary hearing was to be held the following day at which he would be dismissed for his poor attendance record.

During the pregnancy, Mr Matthews had taken time off to care for his partner when she was ill, and to look after his one-year-old daughter.

He challenged the dismissal under section 57a of the Employment Rights Act 1999.

His solicitor, David Mole, said it was the first time the laws had been used successfully by a claimant.

A GMB union spokesman said: "This section allows time off to care for dependants such as partners and children from day one of employment rather than the normal 12 month qualifying period for unfair dismissal."

Mr Matthews said: "I am delighted to have stood up for the rights of dads and won."

Stagecoach North East said: "In the short period of time he worked for us, Mr Matthews had a very poor attendance record and had been through every stage of the formal disciplinary process.

"However, the timing of his dismissal was clearly unfortunate and Stagecoach accept this."

webTitle: Inquest on murdered family told of affair

fields.headline: Inquest on murdered family told of affair
fields.trailText: A man admitted at an inquest yesterday that he had had an affair with his boss's wife months before she was found bludgeoned to death at her home with her four children.
fields.body:
A man admitted at an inquest yesterday that he had had an affair with his boss's wife months before she was found bludgeoned to death at her home with her four children.

David Osborne said he had had a sexual relationship with Catherine Mochrie, 45, whose battered body was found at her home in Barry, south Wales, alongside the bodies of her children, James, 18, Sian, 16, Luke, 14, and Bethan, 10, last July. Her husband, Robert Mochrie, was discovered hanging from the loft space on the landing of the £250,000 house.

Mr Osborne, of Barry, was manager of the Pembroke Hotel in Haverfordwest, west Wales, owned by Robert Mochrie from 1997 until it closed down after a kitchen fire in January 1999.

He told the inquest in Cardiff that to his knowledge Mr Mochrie had not known about the affair, which ended in February 2000. "I saw her once after that, soon after her birthday," he said. "She seemed all right but we had a slight argument. He [Robert Mochrie] never indicated he knew about the relationship."

He added that insurers had launched an investigation into the fire, and the insurance payment was taking a long time.

The inquest also heard from Paul Wyatt, who had formed a close relationship with Mrs Mochrie. He had met her at a local cafe for a chat on Monday July 10, the day before she was last seen alive.

He said he received a "strange" text message from Mrs Mochrie, a university graduate in sociology and philosophy, just after midnight on July 12. It read: "Couldn't call. Battery dead. Call later."

Mr Wyatt told the court: "It seemed a bit strange at the time. I've got no doubt about it, it was actually from her."

Earlier Mrs Mochrie's best friend, Deborah Zeraschi, broke down in tears as she described how she raised the alarm after not having seen the family for 11 days.

Ms Zeraschi said she last saw Mrs Mochrie on the evening of July 11, when she dropped her off after their weekly salsa dancing class.

She arranged to pick her up the next evening for a PTA meeting, but late the following morning received a text message from her friend saying she could not go to the meeting as her mother was ill.

During the following week, Ms Zeraschi said, she made repeated telephone calls, sent text messages and visited the house, but heard nothing from her friend or the family.

By the evening of Sunday, July 23, Ms Zeraschi was "very concerned" and called the police after taking a ladder to look through Luke's bedroom window, where she said she saw a "shape" in the bed.

Describing Mr Mochrie, she said: "Rob was a good friend, a good man, a loving father and a very good friend."

Mrs Mochrie and her children died from several blunt force blows to the head. The bodies were found in bed wearing nightclothes. Pathologist Andrew Davison said it was unlikely they had been drugged, but he thought they were probably "unconscious or asleep when attacked".

The cause of Mr Mochrie's death was given as hanging. He had also taken a "life threatening" amount of paracetamol tablets. The inquest heard Mr Mochrie had cancelled the family's daily milk delivery and Bethan's bus lift to school on July 12.

Police took more than 60 statements during the investigation into the deaths.

The inquest resumes today.

fields.headline: A day in the lives of family doctors
fields.standfirst: Related story: GPs to shut surgeries in row over conditions
fields.trailText: Dr Nigel Watson New Forest
fields.body:
Dr Nigel Watson New Forest

7.10am Arrived at surgery. Dictated referral letters, signed prescriptions. Dealt with post - letters from hospitals relating to patients seen in out-patient departments, test results and x-ray results. Ran reports through computer to find patients who needed to be called for monitoring for various treatments, eg patients on certain drugs who have not turned up for blood tests.

8.30-11.30am Surgery. Overbooked again by three patients. Saw 17 patients.

11.30am-1pm. Three home visits.

1-2pm Meeting of three partners and practice manager, discussing how to fit in more patients and give each more time.

2-4.15pm Surgery. Saw 18 patients.

4.15-6pm Went with consultant psychiatrist, police and social services to section somebody under Mental Health Act, followed by another home visit.

6pm-8.30am On call for the night.

Dr Anna Livingstone Docklands, London

8.30am Arrived at practice. Did paperwork, prescriptions, answered phones, met nurses.

9am-2.15pm Surgery.

2.15-2.35pm Went through trainee's work with her.

2.35-3.05pm Computer work - looking at blood test results and answering urgent emails. Discussion with practice computer manager. Letters.

3.05-3.45pm Home visit. Back 20 mins late because of parking problems.

3.50-6.50pm Surgery.

6.50-7.15pm Supervised trainee.

7.15-11pm Returned patients' phone calls, did paperwork, wrote letters, discussed recruitment issues with partners, dealt with test results, wrote reports, summarised notes for patients moving away, looked at issues to do with PCT (primary care trust).

After 11pm Went home.

Dr Chris Taggart Coventry

8.15am Arrived at practice. Chatted with partners.

8.30-10.15am Surgery. Saw 16 patients.

10.45am Baby clinic. In between patients dealt with paperwork re meningitis in pilgrims to Mecca, diabetes targets, insurance reports, checking appropriateness of repeat prescriptions.

Lunchtime Interviewed a GP trainee who may want experience at the practice.

2-3pm Surgery. Saw 11 patients. Couple of difficult problems so took until 3.30

4-5.30pm Surgery. Saw 16 patients. On call for home visits, but those who rang were able to attend surgery.

6pm Opened post - letters from hospital consultants, blood tests. Wrote repeat prescriptions.

7pm Went home.

On call for home visits, but those who rang were able to attend surgery. 6pm Opened post - letters from hospital consultants, blood tests. Wrote repeat prescriptions. 7pm Went home.

fields.headline: Belgian verdict against England hooligan upheld
fields.trailText: The only England football fan convicted of hooliganism during Euro 2000 vowed to clear his name yesterday after a Belgian court rejected his appeal and reaffirmed he was guilty of sparking riots and assaulting armed police officers last June.
fields.body:
The only England football fan convicted of hooliganism during Euro 2000 vowed to clear his name yesterday after a Belgian court rejected his appeal and reaffirmed he was guilty of sparking riots and assaulting armed police officers last June.

In a judgment which surprised observers, a Brussels appeal court ruled that disputed eyewitness evidence against Mark Forrester, 34, of Birmingham, was objective and dismissed video footage showing the Aston Villa fan minding his own business as inconclusive.

Mr Forrester, a father of one, spent a month in custody in a Belgian jail before being given a one year suspended sentence. Yesterday that was cut to a £50 fine and a six-month suspended sentence.

His lawyers immediately indicated that they would take the case to the highest appeal court in Belgium - the equivalent of the House of Lords - and then on to the European court of human rights.

A visibly shaken Mr Forrester, who had expected to be acquitted because of a lack of evidence, claimed after the judgment that he had been used as a scapegoat for the 750 England fans arrested at the time and argued that the fast- track system under which he had been sentenced was deeply flawed.

"I'm shocked, I didn't think they'd stick with this verdict," he said as he left the courtroom.

"I can guarantee that I didn't lay a finger on any police officer. I'll prove my innocence without a shadow of a doubt."

Forrester, who lost his job as a plant hire manager as a result of the conviction, is said to have incited serious rioting in Brussels ahead of the England v Germany match. It is also alleged, by a police hooligan spotter, that the burly fan attacked five armed police officers.

In a dramatic new twist, Stephen Jakobi of campaign group Fair Trials Abroad, which backs Mr Forrester, claimed yesterday to have obtained fresh video footage taken by the British police which could prove decisive.

Jakobi alleged that the Belgian police knew of its existence but had refused to accept it from the UK authorities.

"This is a clear conspiracy to pervert the course of justice by concealing British evidence from the court. I am calling for a full judicial inquiry into the matter."

Forrester called the last minute evidence vital, although it is unlikely to be admitted as evidence during the appeal court hearing.

"This looks like the beginning of another battle," he said.

It had looked like Mr Forrester would be acquitted yesterday after a Belgian public prosecutor conceded last month that the original conviction was unsafe.

Tried and sentenced in just seven days, his defence argued that it did not have enough time to assemble the necessary evidence.

His Belgian lawyer, Jan Fermon, yesterday suggested that the court's decision to uphold the original conviction was a political one.

"If they said that Mark Forrester was not guilty the whole fast track system would fall apart. This was a test case for that system," he said.
