fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText:
Eighth officer faces action | Drink bet death misadventure |  Whiplash 'costs £2bn a year' |
Seahenge plan dropped |  London dearest for homes | Games condom sponsor sought | Whales blind to blue
fields.body:
Eighth officer faces action

An eighth Cleveland police officer is to face disciplinary charges as a result of an operation which investigated alleged wrongdoing in the force, the police complaints authority said yesterday.

Drink bet death misadventure

A verdict of misadventure was recorded at Westminster coroner's court in central London yesterday on guardsman Martin Rimmer, 22, of Clitheroe, Lancashire, who died after a drinking binge in which his friends bet him £50 to drink half a litre of vodka.

Whiplash 'costs £2bn a year'

A survey indicated car headrests at the wrong height were costing around £2bn a year in whiplash injuries, the RAC Foundation claimed yesterday.

Seahenge plan dropped

English Heritage last night bowed to academic outrage and abandoned the plan to rebury the 4,500-year-old timbers of Seahenge, in Norfolk.

London dearest for homes

A New York estate agents yesterday named London as the city with the most expensive housing in the world - ahead of New York, Tokyo and Hong Kong.

Games condom sponsor sought

Organisers of next year's Manchester Commonwealth Games are looking for sponsors to fund condoms for athletes and officials.

Whales blind to blue

Whales and seals are blind to the colour blue, the New Scientist reported.

webTitle: Scot held hostage in Colombia tells of will to survive

fields.headline: Scot held hostage in Colombia tells of will to survive
fields.trailText: For almost two years, Alistair Taylor has lived a forgotten existence as a hostage in the mountains of Colombia. The 47-year-old British oil worker was seized by leftwing guerillas in 1999 and has languished ever since in a succession of makeshift forest camps.
fields.body:
For almost two years, Alistair Taylor has lived a forgotten existence as a hostage in the mountains of Colombia. The 47-year-old British oil worker was seized by leftwing guerillas in 1999 and has languished ever since in a succession of makeshift forest camps.

This week he has been able to talk of his ordeal after a freelance journalist located him and negotiated an interview through his National Liberation Army captors.

Government ministers yesterday denied that he had been forgotten and said his case had been raised with the Colombian government by a number of high profile politicians.

In the video, filmed by reporter Karl Penhaul, Mr Taylor talked of his determination to survive his captivity. "I am not going to let this beat me. I am not going to crack," he said. "It is set in my mind that I will walk out of here some day to freedom."

Mr Taylor, originally from Inverurie in Aberdeenshire, was kidnapped in August 1999 in the town of Yopal, where he had been working for the US-based oil company Weatherford.

Initially the rebel group, the ELN, demanded a £3m ransom, which has been reduced to £2m. He has been held for more than 600 days, despite the efforts of his family in Scotland and his Colombian wife and son to have him released.

Looking thin but well, Mr Taylor is seen in the film surrounded by his armed and masked guards in a muddy mountain camp. His only luxuries are a small shortwave radio and cigarettes.

He said he had been cheered by some letters which took months to reach him from home and pictures of his wife and four-year-old son.

"I'm suffering but the guer rillas are not going out of their way to make it hard," he said, in an extract from the video serialised in the Daily Record.

"They are not torturing me physically, but at the same time I know I cannot leave here until they say so ... you just get up in the morning and tell yourself that it might be today. All it would take was for somebody to come up the hill and hand them a note and say it's over."

His brother, Charles Taylor, from Inverurie, said he hoped the publicity over the case might now mean that progress could be made in securing his release.

"If it can make people do a bit more then it will be well and good," he said. "He seems to be coping quite well and he seems quite relaxed around his captors as well," he said. "We can see from the video that in some stages he is struggling and he wants home - and everybody wants him home."

In the video, the rebels said they were annoyed at the failure of Texas-based Weatherford to send a senior representative to negotiate Mr Taylor's release.

The Foreign Office minister, Lady Scotland, said yesterday that Mr Taylor's employers were taking the lead and had appointed a liaison officer to work for his release.

"We have been working very hard from the moment that we knew he had been taken," she said. Cabinet Office minister Mo Mowlam and Foreign Office minister John Battle had raised Mr Taylor's case on a visit to Colombia.

The country is acknowledged as the kidnap capital of the world, with more than 2,500 people taken hostage each year. The Colombian army has estimated that rebel groups have grossed more than £600m in ransom payments over the past five years.

webTitle: Kenyans maimed by bombs get legal aid to explore suit against British army

fields.headline: Kenyans maimed by bombs get legal aid to explore suit against British army
fields.trailText: Dozens of Masai and Samburu tribal people, mutilated by blasts from bombs that had lain unexploded in Kenya, have been granted legal aid to   explore the possibility of taking legal action against the British army in UK courts.
fields.body:
Dozens of Masai and Samburu tribal people, mutilated by blasts from bombs that had lain unexploded in Kenya, have been granted legal aid to explore the possibility of taking legal action against the British army in UK courts.

The army has been carrying out manoeuvres in Kenya for 50 years, mainly at Archers Post and Dol Dol. Troops use heavy artillery at Archers Post, but live ammunition is no longer used at Dol Dol. Legal aid has been granted to explore action on behalf of 45 people, mainly children. One victim saw his friend - who was killed in the incident in which he was maimed - devoured by hyenas.

Martyn Day, a partner in the London law firm Leigh, Day & Co, who plans to fly to Kenya with an ordnance specialist on Sunday, said: "There has been an average of four deaths or mutilations a year of innocent citizens in these two areas. And yet the British army here is attempting to act as if this has nothing to do with them. We will be looking next week to establish whether the army's denials have any substance."

An army spokesman said: "We take a great deal of trouble to ensure ranges are clear of munitions or ordnance, so as far as humanly possible there is no danger to civilians. We will look at any evidence presented to us. If we are shown to be culpable, clearly we will have to respond to that."

fields.headline: It's the American way
fields.trailText: George W Bush may not have the intellectual and communication skills of his immediate predecessor, but his appeal to large swaths of rural voters in the west and south should not be underestimated (Presidency of dunces, April 25).
fields.body:
George W Bush may not have the intellectual and communication skills of his immediate predecessor, but his appeal to large swaths of rural voters in the west and south should not be underestimated (Presidency of dunces, April 25). Few care about his syntax or his ignorance of world affairs - they have little interest in matters far removed from their everyday concerns, but still regard a strong military as vital to their continuing economic security. Even if the majority do not benefit from the proposed tax cuts, it is a step in the right direction if it means Washington takes even less from big business. There is relatively little overt animosity towards corporations.

As for tactical voting - it serves only to dilute the will of the electorate which, both here and in the US, still generally prefers a clear winner to emerge from the ballot box (the more so in view of last November's shenanigans) with a mandate to govern subject only to the limitations imposed by constitutional and democratic principles.
Bill Jackson
Nottingham
bill.j@ntlworld.com

webTitle: Letters: Straw defends his race law

fields.headline: Straw defends his race law
fields.trailText: Hugo Young's dismissal (Ministerial double-talk simply masks a racist law, April 23) of the Race Relations (Amendment) Act 2000, the most radical change to race equality legislation in a generation, as "a law of national and ethnic and racial discrimination" is bizarre.
fields.body:
Hugo Young's dismissal (Ministerial double-talk simply masks a racist law, April 23) of the Race Relations (Amendment) Act 2000, the most radical change to race equality legislation in a generation, as "a law of national and ethnic and racial discrimination" is bizarre. The act outlaws race discrimination in public functions not covered by the original Race Relations Act 1976, and places a positive duty on listed public authorities to promote race equality actively.

We had a drafting problem with the act, however, in that immigration control by the United Kingdom (and every country in the world) does discriminate by nationality. Some foreign nationals do not even require a passport to travel to the United Kingdom (citizens of the Republic of Ireland); some do, but without a visa; while nationals of other countries require pre-entry visas.

Sometimes within a nationality group, we have to discriminate in favour of those of a particular ethnic group (eg ethnic Albanians in Kovoso); more often, we may need to scrutinise entrants of one ethnic group more than another within the same nationality. This has been long- standing good practice. The provisions in the act to which Hugo Young took exception simply ensure that this continues to be lawful and by clear and explicit ministerial authorisation.

The immigration service has a good record on racism. The complaints procedure is independently audited. Of millions of people who enter the UK lawfully each year, and of the thousands who seek to do so unlawfully, there was just one complaint alleging racism by staff substantiated of 47 made.
Jack Straw
Home secretary

 Vikram Dodd exposes the Home Office's "Secret u-turn to send Kurds back" (April 25) and the arrests in Southampton. Since then we hear that almost all those arrested on Tuesday are in fact victims of traffickers; and, far from being "encouraged" to return, as reported, they are all to be deported immediately. Furthermore, Hugo Young has rightly attacked the "reptilian disingenuousness" of the Home Office in amending the Race Relations Act to permit "authorised official prejudice against national groups", and in instructing officials to take account of ethnic origins when detaining people, instead of treating each asylum claim on its individual merits, as required by its own guidelines and by the UNHCR.
Helen Kimble
Asylum Welcome, Oxford

 Your report about the Home Office's "change of practice" leading to a rejection of 80-90% of Iraqi Kurd asylum claims bears out what I had been hearing from lawyers and Kurdish asylum seekers recently.

Considering that almost nine out of 10 similar claimants were being given refugee status or leave to remain on humanitarian grounds last year, suspicion must arise that this is a result of a deliberate policy to mas sage down the asylum figures in this pre-election period. If so, this would show utter cynicism by Jack Straw and Barbara Roche, sacrificing the lives of individuals to their nasty "race to the bottom" with the Tories on who can be harsher towards asylum seekers.

And why are we bombing Iraq in protection of the "no-fly zone" in Kurdish northern Iraq and enforcing sanctions against Saddam Hussein, who is indeed evil, if the inhabitants have nothing to fear?
Baroness Sarah Ludford
Coordinator, European parliament Kurdish Network

 How does the government's policy on Kurdish asylum seekers square with their foreign policy stance on Iraq? Could it be that the no-fly zone and intermittent bombing raids are intended to keep Iraqi Kurds in Iraq? If Saddam Hussein is seen as an important ally who needs our help, at least let the government admit it.
Barry LaceyOxford

webTitle: Letters: the power of the press

fields.headline: The power of the press
fields.trailText: On Tuesday, the Guardian accuses Alan Milburn of taking his eye off the ball and letting the health service reforms wither on the branches (NHS reform falters, April 24).
fields.body:
On Tuesday, the Guardian accuses Alan Milburn of taking his eye off the ball and letting the health service reforms wither on the branches (NHS reform falters, April 24). On Wednesday, Alan Milburn announces a wide-spread reorganisation across the NHS (Labour's NHS power shift, April 25).

You must be very pleased that the Guardian has such influence.
G H Legate
Alesey, Beds

 How refreshing to see that France is taking strong, fair and practical measures to crack down on "stock market" redundancies (April 25). Is there any chance of persuading Lionel Jospin to put up French Socialist party candidates at our election?
Nick Blackstock
Bradford

 Poor Ravel indeed (G2, April 25). To be remembered only for the bloody awful Bolero, when he wrote such a lot of good music, too.
Henry Wickens
Waldbillig, Luxembourg

 I am mystified by the references to vicars' wives (Letters, April 24). The only married vicars I know have husbands.
Kevin Stracey
Croydon

fields.headline: Martha the martyred
fields.trailText: The headline reads "Gunning for Martha - Audrey Gillan investigates" (April 24). Apparently that investigation did not include attempting to contact me, the author of Beautiful Exile: The Life of Martha Gellhorn.
fields.body:
The headline reads "Gunning for Martha - Audrey Gillan investigates" (April 24). Apparently that investigation did not include attempting to contact me, the author of Beautiful Exile: The Life of Martha Gellhorn. Gillan reports that Gellhorn wrote 25 pages of notes about my errors. I wrote to Victoria Glendinning, one of Martha's friends, and asked her to point out my mistakes. She replied that she did not believe there were mistakes but rather that Gellhorn was simply opposed to my doing the book.

Gellhorn's "friends" have had 10 years to seriously refute the first edition of my book and they have not done so. Nor did Gellhorn force any changes in the first edition. She only threatened a legal case. I don't believe, in fact, that these "friends" of Gellhorn's have even read my book. Certainly they have not read Francis King's review in The Literary Review. He calls my biography "perceptive, well researched and well written".
Carl Rollyson
New Jersey, United States

fields.headline: Who pays the piper...
fields.trailText: Andrew Clements (Sounding off, G2, April 21) proposes more Arts Council money for new composers and praises the South Bank-based London Sinfonietta for giving inexperienced composers an annual opportunity to get their works performed.
fields.body:
Andrew Clements (Sounding off, G2, April 21) proposes more Arts Council money for new composers and praises the South Bank-based London Sinfonietta for giving inexperienced composers an annual opportunity to get their works performed. He says this is a thoroughly "worthwhile" event. Is it?

Since when have any of the composers Mr Clements mentions written anything that contains a hint of a tune or perhaps a phrase or two that anyone can remember? Why is it that once played, these works are never heard of again?

Experimental pieces should be played at the composers' expense, not at the public's expense at publicly owned concert halls, where very few want to listen to overblown musical tinkering.

Who is deciding what is indeed "worthwhile" in new music? Why should we, via the Arts Council, fund mediocrity in contemporary arts?
Philip Mitchell
Herne Bay, Kent
fields.bodyText: Andrew Clements (Sounding off, G2, April 21) proposes more Arts Council money for new composers and praises the South Bank-based London Sinfonietta for giving inexperienced composers an annual opportunity to get their works performed. He says this is a thoroughly "worthwhile" event. Is it? Since when have any of the composers Mr Clements mentions written anything that contains a hint of a tune or perhaps a phrase or two that anyone can remember? Why is it that once played, these works are never heard of again? Experimental pieces should be played at the composers' expense, not at the public's expense at publicly owned concert halls, where very few want to listen to overblown musical tinkering. Who is deciding what is indeed "worthwhile" in new music? Why should we, via the Arts Council, fund mediocrity in contemporary arts? Philip Mitchell Herne Bay, Kent

webTitle: Letters: Counting the cost of devolution

fields.headline: Regionalism and counting the cost of devolution
fields.trailText: The remarks by John Prescott that additional funding to Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland (Scots and Welsh face subsidy axe, April 24) will be reviewed is just a bit of electioneering.
fields.body:
The remarks by John Prescott that additional funding to Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland (Scots and Welsh face subsidy axe, April 24) will be reviewed is just a bit of electioneering. He is certainly not reflecting the views of Gordon Brown, the chancellor and an important Scottish MP, or the fistful of other Scottish MPs in the government including Robin Cook, Helen Liddell, Lord Macdonald and, dare I say it, Tony Blair, who was born in Scotland and attended a posh school there.

In the white paper issued by the government in July 1997, it made it quite clear that "Scotland will continue to benefit from its appropriate share of UK public expenditure". To try to alter this arrangement will bring the 72 Scottish MPs to the throat of the government, never mind the 129 members of the Scottish parliament.

Certainly the one advantage Scotland has that should be brought to an end is the number of MPs they have in Westminster. At present they have 72; on the basis of population they should have only 57. This privilege should have ended when the Scottish parliament was set up.
Stan Smith
South Shields, Tyne & Wear

 So Scottish politicians argue that they have special needs which deserve higher than average spending (Scots defend extra spending, April 25). Quite right too - that's their job. But the English regions cannot be denied entry to the debate. I support your proposal for an independent board to come forward with a new and rational mechanism to distribute money on the basis of current need, not historical accident.

Abolition of the Barnett formula is supported by the Lib Dems, the Scottish National party and Plaid Cymru - and pressure for change in the northern regions is becoming intense. The government, and John Prescott, deserve praise for raising this issue. It has been fudged for far too long. The regions of England need a strong political voice to fight their corner when dealing with this new independent board. That strong voice can only come with directly elected regional assemblies.
John Adams
Campaign for the English Regions, Newcastle upon Tyne
london@cfer.org.uk

 Vernon Bogdanor was right to acknowledge that further devolution in the United Kingdom will have to be "piecemeal and asymmetrical" (England may get its turn, April 23).

However, try telling that to some of the anoraks who campaign for English regionalism. They assume that regional boundaries were pre-ordained by God rather than to satisfy the whim of bland administrative convenience.

Yes, we should devolve. But let's do it to places that exist. Otherwise voters will stay home in their droves.

After all, why destroy a region with a strong identity - such as Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly - merely to create a synthetic region without one?
Andrew George MP

fields.headline: International round-up
fields.trailText: San Marino scrape an unlikely point and France hammer Portugal, plus the rest of last night's European international action.
fields.body:
San Marino picked up their first World Cup point for more than eight years yesterday when Nicola Albani earned his country a 1-1 draw with Latvia in a Group Six qualifier.

The home side must have thought they were in for an easy win after Southampton's Marian Pahars put them ahead after 46 seconds but though they dominated the first half, with San Marino failing to have a single shot on goal, they were unable to add to it.

Then Albani struck just before the hour with a close-range header which left Latvia second from bottom of the group, seven points behind the leaders Scotland. The last time San Marino gained a World Cup point was in March 1993 when they drew 0-0 with Turkey.

France proved their Euro 2000 semi-final golden goal victory over Portugal was no fluke, with a resounding 4-0 win at the Stade de France. Sylvain Wiltord, Mickael Silvestre and Thierry Henry all got on the scoresheet from a starting line-up that featured seven Premiership players.

Denmark scored three second-half goals as they marked Peter Schmeichel's 129th and last cap with a 3-0 victory over Slovenia in a Copenhagen friendly. Chelsea's Jesper Groenkjaer opened the scoring with his first international goal.

Russia 's substitute Vladimir Beschastnykh struck with a 72nd-minute diving header to give his country a 1-0 win over Yugoslavia in Group One, a game which leaves Russia on top of the group with 13 points from five matches.

Yugoslavia pushed forward in the dying minutes but to no effect and were jeered off by a near-capacity crowd of 48,000. Their manager Milovan Djoric said: "Some of these players will not feature for Yugoslavia again as long as I am in charge. I won't resign or be toppled by the media as an uphill task of creating an entirely new team lies ahead."

Iceland's 4-1 win in Malta took them above Northern Ireland in Group Three.

England's recent tormentors Albania won 2-0 against Turkey in a friendly though the result flattered the visitors. "We had more and richer chances and positions but they scored from theirs," said Turkey's coach Senol Gunes after a match in which he saw Tayfun Havutcu hit a post with a penalty and Aston Villa's Ozalan Alpay missed from less than a yard.

England's next opponents, Greece , drew 2-2 in a friendly away to Croatia.

In Geneva two second-half goals from Anders Svensson gave Sweden a 2-0 victory against Switzerland in a friendly, only their second win in 13 attempts on Swiss soil and their first since 1976.
